description:
Seafood restaurant in the Bayshore district? Its good??


These were the thoughts in my mind after working up an appetite shopping at the Resturaunt Depot. 

The resturaunt has been around forever. The outside is covered in fishing nets and decorative giant clams. You walk in thinking you're at a seaside resturaunt.  

Our server greeted us quickly and served us clam shots and by far the BEST giant sourdough bread we'd ever had. This sucker was huge but it was so good that we had no leftovers! I ordered the cioppino which was packed with delicious seafood... clams, calamari, fish, crab legs, sweet potato, corn and red potato. My step father ordered the seafood linguine which had the same ingredients but a little more kick.


Unfortunately,  we inhaled it all before I could take photos. Oh well, I'll have to go back for photos soon!
author: Mitra K.

description:
It's been yeaaars since the last time I ate at The Old Clam House so was giving it a go for Mother's Day despite mixed reviews.

Surprisingly it wasn't busy on this Mother's Day (we made reservations), so I'm sure walk-ins would have been accommodated.

Food was as good as I remember. We love seafood so Mom was happy (and that's what counts).

Service was attentive and friendly.

May not wait so long to come back for another special occasion.
author: Carolyn J.

description:
I love cioppino, so when my friend told me about this spot that wasn't too far from where I live, I immediately bookmarked it.

I had made a reservation for 3 at12:30 on a Sunday but it wasn't necessary at all. When we arrived, it was mostly empty and they told us we could seat ourselves.

To start off, they give everyone a complimentary shot of clam broth. It's still hot, so you know it's fresh. My friends and I slowly sipped at it and enjoyed the delicious clam flavor.

We knew we wanted to share the cioppino, so the only decision for us whether to order a regular size for $29.99 or the large for $49.99 and what bread to order. Based on the server's recommendations, we went with a large as it seemed like it was a much better value, and also ordered the house-made kettle bread ($0.99) as well as the skillet roasted garlic bread ($5.99).

I'm really glad we went with the large cioppino, as the portion was maybe 3x as much as the regular size. It was a tiny bit spicy, so I had to take some breaks as I was eating to cool my mouth down, but overall the broth had great tomato and seafood flavor. My only complaint was that there was too much broth and not enough ingredients in the stew. If they're going to give us a huge pot of cioppino, there should be a corresponding amount of seafood in it, and there wasn't. Instead, they filled it with plenty of potatoes and olives, both of which seemed very out of place. Thank goodness we had a ton of bread or I would've left hungry!

Speaking of the bread, both types we ordered were AMAZING!! The kettle bread is really good value, as you get a huge round loaf of bread that you can easily tear off for only $1. The bread is very soft and soaks up the cioppino broth well, making it the perfect complement to the seafood stew. The garlic bread was amazing as well! We saw another table next to it order it and it looked so good we had to get it for ourselves. Highly recommend both!

Service was a little bit slow, but as my friends and I were in no hungry, it didn't bother us at all. 

I'm not sure if I'll be back again for the cioppino, but I wouldn't mind coming back to try something else.
author: Dianna H.

description: Amazing! Came around 3 pm and we were seated immediately. Complimentary hot clam broth. I thought it would be gross but it was amazing. Ordered two bread bowls and we shared a Cesar salad. Both INCREDIBLE. the Cesar has this amazing cheese on it and the bread bowl clam chowder was creamy and delicious. The oldest restaurant in San Francisco! Best possible way to end my trip. Thanks Clam House!
author: Emilie C.

description:
I'd say my actual rating is about a 3.5, same as the current overall rating for the restaurant.

This is a good place. You can get free clam broth, which tastes way more appetizing than it sounds. I've also never been to a restaurant where you can just have bottomless clam broth so I guess that's nice. The food is also pretty good! We got some crab cakes, clam escargot and some other stuff, all of which was tasty but kind of not memorable. The service was pretty good.

Fair warning: I'm a Maryland girl, so my judgment for seafood may be a little harsher than necessary--you may want to take my opinion with a grain of salt. But I didn't really think the food was worth the hype. It was about as good as mediocre crab cake you'd get anywhere. It wasn't bad, but it just wasn't something I'd come back for. I also was a little put off at how expensive it is. I'm completely willing to pay this much (more, even) for amazing food, but I didn't think it was that amazing. I get the feeling this place was once better than it is now, as I once saw it listed as California's 'iconic restaurant' in an article that listed every state's most iconic restaurant. I don't think this is even remotely close to being 'iconic' in any way, especially not to California as a state. 

The restaurant is also in a really 'meh' area of San Francisco. We used to live in Bayview and The Old Clam House was on the way home. It's not somewhere you want to go for fun.
author: Claire C.

description:
Okay!!  WE ARE BACK and TOCH didn't disappoint..  had a birthday-anniversary crab feast with some amazing and remarkable longtime friends.  Experience from last visit was like night and day.  Crab came seasoned, sizzling and cracked.  Service was exceptional and with one of our long-standing waiters.  I think the last visit the incorrect crab prep was ordered by the waitress and she didn't want to take responsibility for it.  Last nights meal was simply marvelous! Well.. nothing more to say but ..I'll
be Back!
author: Bre'a C.

description: Excellent service and food. There was 14 of us with 2 babies. Everyone had a great meal, really outstanding. I'm gluten free and they were very accommodating.  Great place to get that old SF feel. Parking is tough but not impossible.
author: Lisa A.

description:
Wow, before I came here, I had never heard of it.  My hubby wanted to take me to a historical place, that was Keto diet friendly, and he knows how much I love seafood.  

What a fan I am now.  They serve you a glass of clam juice for starters, and it was so good, I had to order a mug.  Had the fried calamari (large portion), crab cakes (no fillers), and shared the cioppino.  Yum, the food was fresh, and delicious.

Our waitress was one of the best ever.  So warm, receptive, and knew exactly how to please the customer.  

Will be coming back!
author: Meme E.

description:
This was my second visit here in less than a few months.  I brought my dad here for lunch.  My dad ordered the Seafood Platter and I ordered the Crab Alfredo.  We also ordered the garlic bread! It was a half loaf of bread served on a hot iron platter.  The best garlic bread ever! 

The servers were very friendly this time.  They actually took some time to talk with us this time.  I'm definitely going back again.
author: Raymond S.

description:
It's been ages since I've been here. Came during lunch and parking very difficult. Drove around a couple of times before finding a spot. Walked in and there is a sign that said "grab a menu and seat yourself ". That's exactly what we did, as soon as we sat down, 3 shot classes of of the clam broth was brought out to the table. It was nice and salty and very nice start to a cold and wet rainy morning. We had the iron skillet of shrimp, mussels, and crab. Along with the clam chowder, clam pasta and the kettle bread.  The bread came out first and was warm crispy on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside. The iron skillet of seafood trio came out next and it was sizzling! The clam chowder was yummy and I ate it with my bread. My 4 year old loved the broth and the clam
Pasta, the soup/ sauce went well with bread. We devoured everything and had no room for dessert. Must come back again.
author: Alicia A.

description:
I really wanted to love this place. Its been here longer than I've been and still looks about the same. Inside has a lot of nice decor and was well remodeled. Doesn't feel too cheesy like those chain restaurants that try to imitate this style. 

Went in on a Wednesday evening, only a few people inside.  My friend got the crab pasta and I ordered the cioppino. This is my first time getting Cioppino, came out hot in a big bowl. The sauce was very good, had lots of seafood in it and crab and flavor. The seafood was hit or miss, definitely ate a few questionable mussels. 

Then I realized the bread I ordered and vegetables never showed up. I had to flag the waitress and she said the kitchen missed those items on the order... 

My friend ate his pasta but it looked like he separated the crab and left about half the plate there.  

We overheard the other tables issues with their orders too. More missing food and poorly made drinks. The drink wasn't well so they added more liquor, way too much I guess because they gave them a side of mixer also after. Confusing. 

The next morning my friend calls me frantically because he woke up with violent food poising. I had an upset stomach as well. Then I remembered the questionable tasting seafood. This place needs better management and quality control. I hope they get it together.
author: Yosof R.

description: Nothing but amazing experience here!  If you love seafood and want to have an experience, this is the place for you when visiting or living in San Fran.  We has the double crab and shrimp and it was amazing.  The service is wonderful and the place is cool from the inside with many old pictures and memorabilia.  You will see me there when I come back!
author: Derrick F.

description:
What started as a great meal ended with it being just so so.  The clam juice was wonderful to start us off and mussels and chowder were definitely on point!  Even the mojito was probably one of the best I've had but then comes the entrees.  The fish fry was heavily breaded and not much flavor let alone dry and under whelming.  The crab enchiladas were not anything I imagined. Although plenty of crab meat the flavor was off and it needed more sauce:  the cheese was also over melted to the point of burnt.  Would not order these again.
The service was attentive and spot on so that would make us try it out again and order different entrees.
author: Shelton F.

description: Same family of restaurants as the Crab house and the Franciscan in the fisherman's shark, the stinking rise and the dead fish in Crockett. You will recognize the similarities. As then expected excellent meals and killer clam chowder and steamers. They claim to be the Oldest restaurant in the city and as the ancient pictures may arrest. Will. One again.
author: Geanr L.

description:
The 11 Of us celebrated hubby's birthday last night.  We had their chorizo bread, kettle bread, calamari, clams, kettle chicken, mussels and crab. The chorizo bread was
The same as Osso's steakhouse - make sure you eat it when it's hot. The calamari was good and crispy, the clams were perfect in the broth. They gave us lots of broth and even the sweet potatoes, corn on the cob, black olives and potatoes were good in the broth. Everyone enjoyed the kettle chicken with corn and potatoes. The
Chicken was very tender and tasty. The mussels and shrimp were
Okay. I think the shrimp could have been bigger. I wish there were more crab. What I had was delicious. They gave us a free cream brûlée cheesecake for the birthday boy. It was yummy. We finished all of it.
author: Donna L.

description: I have loved eating here for as far as I can remember. I love the host the waiters, some employees have been there for a while and are great people who have always offered me great customer service. I used to get the surf and turf with the filet mignon and crab but ever since it was taken off the menu a while back I came for their crab Alfredo except I would always modify it to shrimp Alfredo. I only eat Alfredo pasta from here The Old Clam House and the crab house at the pier they're the only places with the best Alfredo my mom is my only exception. I usually order to go. I recently went and I'm not sure if the bartender took the order wrong who by the way is always a pleasure to see I usually order from him or if it was the cook who got my order wrong. I have so much love for this place especially since its many of the few historic buildings that hasn't been gentrified that I was not at all mad for the wrong order but sad. I do not live in San Francisco so when I got home ready to eat my food I noticed my order was wrong which has never happened before so , I was really bummed because I go out my way to drive far and pay to eat what I'm in the mood for. So, I decided to call them and let them know hoping that they would offer some type of comfort reassurance that they care that my order was wrong basically some sympathy. Well I was wrong and beyond dumbfounded especially since I've always received great service from them. I'm not sure who answered. But, the guy who answered when I called and told him how far away I went to get my food to find my order wrong when I got home he said "oh ok is there anything you want me to do?" I was at such surprise I didn't know what to say and told him I'm just calling to let you know because I don't think it's fair and he ended the conversation with "ok thank you" the employees should be trained and have  protocols for such situation so that they can make their customers feel that their clientele is appreciated and not make them regret that they had such love for the place. I added a picture of my receipt I saved it because I'm super busy but didn't want to forget to write a review of my experience when I had time.
author: Brenda C.

description:
Like me, you may have driven past this place like a thousand times but never got a chance to go in. Granted, it's not in the most picturesque part of town, but if you want a classic San Francisco establishment with good hearty food, you've gotta come here! 

This place has been open since 1861, making it the oldest restaurant in the city! Perhaps some gold dust still lingering in the air makes its way into the food and gives it that extra flavor. 

When you first sit down, each person is given a shot of hot clam juice. It totally warms you up and gets you ready to eat! 

Start with the kettle bread. It's a huge loaf with the softest bread on the inside and a wonderful light, crispy crust on the outside. It's so perfect with butter that I could almost be happy with this as my meal. 

(You can also order the cheesy version of this- covered in melted cheese and chorizo bits. I just about died when I saw it!)

Next, I ordered the Salmon Fisherman's Catch. The salmon was cooked to perfection in a garlic lemon butter caper sauce and served with buttery soft pasta and yummy crunchy veggies. 

They have a full bar with yummy cocktails to compliment your meal. 
The decor is fun and kitschy, not stuffy or cold as some modern restaurants in the city. The whole place just feels warm and welcoming. 

I loved it and can't wait to come back!
author: Mitzi G.

description:
After a long day of endless drinking, I was starving. I've been on a seafood kick lately, so when looking up reservations on OpenTable, I decided to revisit The Old Clam House. I made a same day dinner reservation for four for Saturday, March 10th at 7:15pm. We arrived about 15 mins early (parking was super easy), but were seated right away.

*House-Made Crispy Kettle Bread ($0.99)
*Clam House Whole Clam Chowder: Bacon, Onions, Potatoes, Celery In A Cream Broth ($11.99)
*Caesar: Garlic Croutons, Shaved Spanish Manchego Cheese ($11.99)
*The "Original" Old Clam House Clam Bake Cioppino: Clams, Mussels, Crab, Shrimp, Calamari, Fish Fillet, Potatoes, Yams, Onions, Olives, Garlic, Corn ($29.99)
*Fish & Chips ($19.99)
*Garlic-Encrusted Baby Back Ribs ($19.99)
*French Fries ($8.99)
*Peroni ($6.99)
*Hess Select Cabernet, North Coast ($9.99) x2

They start you off with a complimentary small glass of what I believe was a seafood broth each. Nice way to warm up and start our meal. I really wanted soup and salad, so ordered the chowder and caesar. The soup was nice and creamy. I remember the celery flavor being very prominent, so if you don't like celery, maybe go for something else. The caesar was standard. Lots of croutons though which were left behind. I believe their cioppino is their signature dish, so I ordered that as well. Lots of seafood. I was craving crab, so this fulfilled that. The sauce was good for bread dipping. A friend ordered the ribs which I thought were okay. Not much smoky flavor, but very tender. I'm not eating deep fried foods at the moment, so I couldn't try the fish and chips. It was a huge piece and came with a bunch of fries. Not sure why we also ordered a side of fries, but I guess the more, the merrier?

I haven't been here in about a decade. Fun to revisit what I believe is the second oldest restaurant in SF? If you're looking for an old school restaurant, The Old Clam House will take you back to a simpler time.
author: Elena N.

description:
Service was ok, Seems like they don't really check to refill your water. But we were seated quickly!

Food was ok! I got the crab sandwich, which was a little too cheesy to the point where I couldn't really even taste the crab in the sandwich.

Only thing that sort of upset me was the misleading menu. It looks like you have a choice of a side with the sandwich but it's actually an additional charge and NOT included. I've attached an image to show that (at least for me) it LOOKS like you have a choice of the sides listed with the fries being an additional charge. But I was charged extra for the soup..

Anyways, the best part for me was probably our appetizer which were they oysters. I'd probably give them a try one more time and try their pasta in the future.
author: Chassidy T.

description: My first time here and I really love it! Really nice decorations inside and the food was super good! We had the clam chowder bread bowl and seafood linguine and the portion was really big and enough for 2 people. The service was also really nice. Highly recommended!
author: Bellebiez P.

description: Classic SF spot. Great fish sandwich!!! The place is an old classic, and it feels old and tired. But food is delicious and service is usually pretty good!
author: JonJon W.

description: OMG this was sooooooo Good !  It was out first time here on date night and we were not disappointed at all. We also order garlic bread. It was delicious, but the mussels and shrimp were the best.
author: Silvia R.

description:
Great service and some good food!  The cioppino was solid and the Mac looked pretty unique but neither knocked my socks off considering the price. Hence, 4 stars.

It's a fun historical kind of place that's family friendly as long as the family can deal with the prices.  Not too busy and the waiting staff is attentive and helpful!
author: Michael N.

description: My review is compiled of only 4 of their dishes that I personally tried myself. sea bass plate is delicious a solid 4 stars. Cooked to perfection and seasoned generously, but a tad too alty for my taste. The ambiance is amazing here. If u ever want a blast of nostalgia while u sit down and grub, the old clam house is perfect. Their food is a bit on the saltier side. The crab enchillada is a nogo. Generic mission trotillas and pasta sauce around the plate it's not worth the price tag. Their chicken was also delicious, but it was a bit dry. Their crab is cooked to perfection plump and juicy. I'm not too crazy about ciopinno, theirs was fine. Nothing memorable besides their couscous! Mmmm delicious! For the price tag it's decent, but for those of u who only come out once in a blue moon to celebrate i reccomend the sea bass plate paprika styled and their crab. Most bang for your buck!
author: Jared L.

description: They take their reputation seriously! This place is good. Service is friendly and attentive. Everything is beautiful and delicious. Good came out quickly, drinks are on point. Lots of options. Authentic, classic, entertaining. You'll be glad you did
author: Zeoy S.

description:
Where to even start?
- the Fish & Chips are the best in the Bay Area.
- the $1 bread made in house is great.
- Menu pricing is all over the map. Not consistent with similar restaurants.
- the Parking.ugg. Go mid day, otherwise risk your life for a good meal. Tiny lot & street parking is sketch AF.
- the Crab Sandwich was small. 
- Sides are extra.
- lobster bisque was solid.
- the grilled bread dipped in garlic & butter, then put in the oven, is destination drive worthy.
- Service mid day after the lunch crowd was nice. 
I would come back during daylight hours on a Weekend. It's really fun visiting establishments like this that have been around for decades. I could spend a day just looking at all the old photos of SF on the walls.
author: Patrick Z.

description: I went here with my mom and my girlfriend's family back in May. It was a good experience overall. The food wasn't too expensive and the portion was really good. I would go there again with my family and I would recommend to other people as well. I've also heard that this place is an old spot in the town. I hope they're around for much longer.
author: Daniel B.

description:
What a little gem! The Old Clam House was nearly empty when we walked in. It was late, and we were craving seafood. We were warmly greeted my a hostess and seated at a cozy table! 

The food was really good-- comforting, flavorful, and fresh! We tried a bit of everything:

Oysters: fresh and cold! $2.99 each! 
Clam chowder: had bacon, was really flavorful and light! A refreshing take on a usually heavy and hearty soup
Fish & chips: amazing batter and fry on the fish, and awesome fries! Like seriously, their fries are insanely good
Garlic noodles: just do it. Soooo good. 
Ribs: I didn't personally have any, but my family raves about how tender they were!

Bottom line, give this place a try. The staff is really friendly and fun, and the food is great. Thanks!
author: Dom B.

description:
You know what? Make a pilgrimage to The Old Clam House they are a historical place steadily vanishing old-school San Francisco restaurant vibe. Thoroughly enjoyed the vibe the staff the food and the soothed baby who had 3 generations of men attending to him making the rounds.

The food is standard fried seafood, very good, though.
author: San Francisco C.

description: I am surprised how low their overall rating is.  This is a very good restaurant that serves chippino, kettle bread and many other high quality food. We have had cippino, baked crab, kettle baked bread and they are all good.  I have been to this restaurant three times already and I will definitely go back.
author: Eri F.

description:
Oldest restaurant in San Francisco... the building that now houses the bar was built in 1861!

I've been going here for years... I've always thought of it as the working man's Tadich Grill.  Classic menu, excellently prepared, ample portions.  We had the garlic bread today for the first time, and man, is that a treat.  You should get that... half a loaf of sourdough with garlic and butter dripped all over it.

The sad thing is that they've had to bump their prices to keep pace with San Francisco.  Entrees are almost all in the mid or high 20s now.  Probably should be $$$ by the Yelp scale.
author: G M.

description: Great service good food love thee atmosphere second time there yesterday will be coming back soon love this place!!!!
author: CuzCuz 4.

description:
This is an oldie and goodie.

I used to come here all the time years ago 
Me and a friend decided to see if the food was still the same... it was even better than I remembered... we had sizzling crab shrimp and mussels ..., everything was delicious... we were so full we had to share dessert. The servers and staff were outstanding... I already want to go back ASAP ...the food was so good that I don't have any pictures to show... maybe next time.
author: Serenity A.

description: Y oh really good clam Chowder the garlic shrimp was great. A lot of great history on the walls. Kind of in the older part of town. Service is great. Class was about equal with any other Seafood House had a lot of other good things on the menu that I'd like to try some other time
author: Fran P.

description:
Have you had your clam juice today? If not, you should!

Overall, The Old Clam House is an SF institution but doesn't fall victim to gimmickry. Generous portions of high quality seafood, deliciously prepared make this old-school style restaurant well worth a trip to the Bayview. 

Food: I'm not sure why this place gets 3.5 stars. Maybe the prices? Or the location? But let's all remember, this is seafood restaurant, and no it's not waterfront, but then again, it probably tastes better for less :).

My friend and I shared the clams escargot, the crab cakes, a regular size cioppino, and one crispy kettle bread (we managed not to eat all of it and that was actually a good thing!). I was so stuffed at the end that my elastic-waist leggings felt tight!

The clams escargot is exactly what it sounds like - clams with garlic butter and bread crumbs in a little dish with divots for each clam. It's actually a very simple and rich dish. And it is good--let's be honest, how would it not be?

The crab cakes aren't huge, but as our waiter noted, other than the breading on the outside, it's straight up 3.75 oz of dungeness crab without any of that BS filler. So, the cakes themselves don't look huge, but you're getting your money's worth bc there isn't corn or bread crumbs or peppers or, well, any of that filler BS in there. 

The cioppino is theoretically for one person unless you order the large or the family size...and maybe that is true if you stop by here after your 18 mile marathon training run. Wha? I don't know what person could eat one cioppino by his or herself. Oh, maybe one of those carb-free people, but you HAVE to get the kettle bread to go with the cioppino! The sauce is the expected tomato variety but with a surprising and addictive kick of spice! You need the bread to sop up that sauce (sopping up that sauce...that's what did me in and why two hours later I'm still stuffed and wondering how I'm going to go to sleep).

The cioppino has generous portions of mussels, clams, fish, calamari, two crab legs, two pieces of corn, and olives and sweet potatoes. The only thing that didn't quite work were the sweet potatoes. I can't tell you why, since I generally love them. The flavor didn't work w the rest of the flavors.

And, the kettle bread - it didn't disappoint. Crusty on the outside, soft and perfect for sauce absorption on the inside :). It's only 99 cents and a huge portion, you really can't go wrong. 

Ambiance - old school in a really good way. A little more spacious than the typical SF restaurant. You can comfortably move between the tables without sticking your rear into someone's food. The vibe reminded me of the seafood places in Maine--casual, weathered wood, booths, bentwood chairs, checkered table cloths. 

Also, unlike 99% of the restaurants in SF, you can carry on a conversation without raising your voice. If you don't get down and dirty w a crab, it could be a great date spot. Or, maybe this is where you test out whether your boo is right for you--can they handle you getting down and dirty with a crab ;-)?

Service - attentive w a side of snark--and that's a good thing! Like I said, the waiter was the one who noted there wasn't any BS in their crab cakes. He walked us through his favorites on the menu and was quite friendly without being overbearing. Also, I asked for a taste of a wine I was considering ordering. He forgot it, so when he did bring it, I received a double shot to make up for it--lol. We never felt rushed, and given there were open tables, it isn't like so many other places where you feel like you're just a table to be turned.

Price/Value - this isn't a cheap place. But, the last time I made cioppino at home, it wasn't an inexpensive undertaking either, and frankly, the quality and freshness of the seafood is probably better at The Old Clam House than I can get at Whole Foods. And, I didn't have to cook it and don't have to do the dishes after. For the portions, quality, and flavor, The Old Clam House delivers value for your dollar. Also, the wine, when I got the glass, was like a 8 or 9 oz pour. If I hadn't been driving, I would have gone for one of their martinis. I hear they give you the shaker so it's like 2 for 1.

This place is worth trip and the indulgence!
author: Sara E.

description: Was disappointed. Went here a lot 30 years ago and I remember the food was much better. Went here again  for my birthday dinner and found the food to be just ok. The service a bit slow but nice. Was charged for bread and paid $4.00 for a coke and another $4.00 for lemonade. May not be back again.
author: Ben S.

description:
ORDER THE KETTLEBREAD!!! It's the best $1 you'll ever spend. They make it fresh in house and the portion is HUGE, good for 4 people It's a soft and fluffy, yet slightly dense. It's perfect for dipping in cioppino or even just by itself. My fiancé doesn't typically like bread but he couldn't stop eating this! 

The complimentary clam juice shot as you sit down (yum!) sets the tone for a delicious dinner.
The service was super friendly and quick. The ambiance is pretty casual (Bayview district) and the crowd is pretty diverse. Prices are pretty reasonable for seafood.

Cioppino - very solid, not too tomatoey, and comes with a TON of seafood. Everything tasted fresh.

We only shared the regular 29.99 size between two of us, but with how great the food and prices were, I will definitely be a return customer!
Would love to taste all the other things on the menu!
author: Emily C.

description:
Went here on a whim based on yelp reviews for quality and cost
Place is nice and quaint little seafood place 
Quality of food far exceeds the ratings 
Table had clam linguini pretty much a go to
Salmon plate with some glaze I can't recall but it was awesome and salmon was wild
Also two crabwhiches and stone bread

All above are "you can't go wrong"

Not that the following are bad but I would focus my cash elsewhere in the menu!
Shrimp plate appie
Clam chowder .... it's good but not for the money

Service and server Anna were great too
I would go back fore sure.
author: Craig P.

description: It was so good last night, we came back for early lunch today. Crab cakes, clam linguini with skillet shrimp for dinner, along with their skillet bread and soft butter... Yum. For lunch we shared sea bass and skillet bread. Dang that bread n butter is yum. My wife really liked the warm shot of clam juice as she drank 3 at lunch... With a little tabasco and salt n pepper... Really good!
author: Dennis H.

description: If you're headed north from the airport and looking for a convenient place to stop for dinner and wait out the traffic this is a great stop! The food, atmosphere, and price are all great! Fun old San Francisco vibe. A lot of history with this place!
author: Nicole J.

description:
I have nothing but love for this place. For years I drove by without paying attention until I found out how old and how long this place has been around!!! After trying it once, I am hooked on the old timey feel, the friendly service, the delicious food and the authentic old San Francisco nostalgia. 
I love this place and I hope they stay right where they are and never change. 
Ps. Best clam chowder ever!
Pss. Sand dabs are perfection.
author: Nilu r.

description: We have driven past this place so many times and always wanted to go in and today we finally went and were not disappointed. The food was amazing! The house bread with butter was baked to perfection and the mussels in sauce are probably the best I have ever tasted. My husband had the fish and chips which he said was delicious. Definitely worth visiting if you have visitors from out of town because this is a classic old building with a great atmosphere and service! I'll definitely become a regular here!
author: Kelly M.

description:
So impressed with this restaurant! We ordered house made bread, the combo platter, and finished with the salted caramel vanilla crunch cake. Dinner was delicious...dessert was to die for! I will probably dream about it tonight.
The main reason for my review though is for our amazing server for the night, Alexi. He provided us with amazing service and really made our first experience one to remember. Alexi was very attentive without being too pushy.
To top it off, the ambiance was perfect and made for such a comforting dining experience. Needless to say, we left happy :)
author: Ashley P.

description:
I ordered the Clam Linguini from here and from other people's photos via Yelp, it was served on a plate and looked pretty appetizing. My food was served in the iron skillet pots and my food itself was extremely hot for me to even eat. I would usually expect my food to be too cold for me to eat but I've never experienced an issue where my food was too hot. 

My clam linguini was basically an Italian version of ramen. It was just clam soup with butter, clams and pasta. Not worth $25 just saying. 

However the garlic bread and the crab bruschetta was pretty good. I was told the quality of this place was good in the past.
author: Payal R.

description:
A friend suggested this place a few weeks ago. I needed to kill some time before a Saturday appointment in Bayview, so dropping in The Old Clam House for lunch was perfect timing. The restaurant was very quiet, and seating was plentiful.

The decor pays a lot of homage to the history of the place. Interesting (to a history buff like me), but bordering on cluttered. I'm unsure if the decor of a historic place can be viewed as dated...

The hot clam juice sample brought when I sat down was served in a cracked glass. I enjoyed the taste, once an unbroken glass came out. 

The menu has lots of very pricey selections! Most of my seafood favorites were in the $$$ range - prices you would expect at Pier 39. I settled on the clam enchilada with two eggs. By the time the skillet got to me, the sunny-side eggs were hard. The enchilada name was a bit misused, as the sauce and flavor was definitely un-Mexican. The filling of the enchilada was just okay; I thought the amount of clam was a tad lacking, and the clam flavor was overwhelmed by the other filling ingredients. Next time, I will have two enchiladas and save the eggs for breakfast. Or, next time I will save up my milk money, so I can treat myself guilt-free to a different item altogether.

The 99-cent bread loaf was too much for one person, especially one who is not much of a bread person. I will avoid the loaf next time, and put that .99 towards a plate of food instead.

The waitress kinda forgot about me, and never checked on how I liked the meal. Getting the check took too long, and when it came, it was someone else's check.

Overall, a forgettable experience.
author: Tony B.

description:
Awesome seafood linguine !!! And the hook
Line drink !! Definitely coming back for more !!
author: Mary H.

description: Great service, great good.  Bread was served warm, fried calamari, crab Alfredo and crab sandwich. Will be back.
author: Araceli A.

description: The food is not great but it is good.  As a museum that serves good food it's a treasure.  It opened in 1868.  Clean up after your horse when your done!
author: Steve T.

description:
Although I've lived in SF for quite a long time, I always hesitated to go to the Old Clam House. It's out of the way, and the exterior looks a bit campy, with a giant clam shell on the roof. 

And I haven't had the best time at some other "classic" Bay Area restaurants. Tadich Grill (Est. 1849) was expensive and mediocre. Spenger's Fresh Fish Grotto (Est. 1890) served spoiled fish that got some people in our party sick (those who actually ate the stuff). 

Well I finally tried The Old Clam House (Est. 1861), and now I'm recommending that you try it too. 

The Old Clam House is both full of history and unassuming. People stop in after work for a beer and to watch a game, but they also have a TV-free dining room). The place is full of old photos and memorabilia, of the genuine kind, not the fake ones you'd find in a TGI Friday's. 

And the food is good, and reasonably priced (for seafood, that is). 

Everyone is started off with a shotglass full of salty warm clam broth, which has a nice flavor and no fishiness. They bake their own bread, and serve at least some of it hot, like the garlic bread in a skillet, which was as garlicky and oily as you'd want it (or at least as I wanted it). 

Classic clam chowder was thick and rich with a touch of herbaceousness: very far above average. They also have a more modern variety with small whole clams on the shell in it, which I'll try next time. 

Crab cakes were full of fresh crab meat and nicely crispy. This place actually does serve fresh fish, still, nearly 150 years after opening on what was then the waterfront. 

This review is getting long, but I want to address one thing that some people have complained about: the price. No, it's not a cheap restaurant. But let's compare it to other real seafood places like Woodhouse:At Woodhouse the crab sandwich is $35. At The Old Clam House it's $17. Is $17 cheap? Not at all. Is it reasonable compared to other similar food in SF? Yes it is. 

In retrospect, a restaurant that's been in business since 1861 must have something going for it, and The Old Clam House does. Put it on your list to visit soon!
author: Jacob L.

description: Love This Place! Sea Food LVER!  2nd time this week! Highly Recommend! Fantastic Service! Excellent Food!
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
First time here and received great customer service and food was delish. Only thing is I personally did not enjoy it I am not a seafood fan. I like seafood but very picky about it.

I got the crab enchiladas which was recommended by the waiter and my first but into the amazing looking dish was not so great. Not sure if it was because I don't like the fishy taste or because it did not taste what I had expected. After switching my option with my cousin I loved the crab lenguni. Not so fishy but still they taste if good crab doors in rich sauce.
author: Jaxy L.

description: Great find.  Historic restaurant off the tourist path but a short Lyft ride away from Fidi.  Seafood rules here.  Had the whole Dungeness Crab in garlic oil and drinks.  The porch seating is bright and filled with old photos.
author: Yachtmaster 7.

description:
Old Clam House has been open since Abe Lincoln was President and is one of the oldest restaurants in the city and definitely worth a try. 

My family was visiting from LA and wanted a "unique to SF" dinner but with parking. Luckily Old Clam House wasn't too far from me on Bayshore from Potrero Hill. Warning, it's rather sketchy outside at night. However, I was thoroughly impressed by the interior, nicely decorated and adorned with old SF memorabilia but still very classy.  My family got a huge kick out of the warm clam juice they serve you right when you sit down. We all thought it was a shot of vodka. It was a nice touch to the meal. 

We had:
Ciopinno(couple size): It was hugeeeee! My family of 5 could not finish it. It was filled with tasty meaty crab, mussels, shrimp and more. Not the best ciopinno you'll have in town, but it was a tasty version with briny olives, hearty potatoes and corn.  
Fried Calamari(family size) $15: Also giant but tasty
Kettle Bread: It was served lukewarm, they could've heated the bread to make it so much more appetizing, but nice and affordable at $1 per giant loaf for dipping
Crab Linguine: Tasty but rather plain 

Definitely would come back to try other seafood items on the menu or try and to have the tasty ciopinno again.
author: Linda H.

description: A great restaurant. The decoration is very very nice and authentic, and so are the waiters. The food is good and very fresh. I tried mussels and oysters and they were very fresh and tasty. I went there on a Tuesday evening and I found the restaurant was a little bit empty. It's a good place !
author: Romain N.

description:
Came here for business dinner. Thrilled that this 155 year old institution is near our neighborhood. Service was prompt and attentive, the dining room is cluttered with cool antiques, and yes, the guests are on the venerable side.

The draft Anchor Steam beer was great, the calamari with fried lemon slices, cocktail sauce and tartar sauce has savory crispy batter and tender squid within. The homemade sourdough with butter was outstanding--crusty with a dense crumb.

The skillet was huge with shrimp, mussels and crab. The shrimp were served shell-on and a bit on the bland side. Farm raised? 

The mussels were really good with the sauce doused tableside and then reduced and caramelized as the hot cast iron skillet sizzled and cooled.

But the crab... man, that crab stole the show. Plump, easy to shell. I only needed the cracker on the claw.

A chance to eat at a SF icon without braving city grind, parking or hipsters? Awesome!
author: Lu-Shien T.

description:
We were looking for a nice restaurant that has no corkage fee, and The Old Clam House exceeded our expectations. As soon as we were seated, we were served a complimentary shot of delicious hot clam broth, and our waiter brought out wine glasses after seeing that we had brought a few bottles. 

I started off with the clams escargot which are baked clams on the half shell, served on an escargot tray, covered with garlic, butter, and breadcrumbs.  We also ordered the skillet roasted garlic bread, and the cheesy chorizo spiced bread - both of which were outstanding and complimented our seafood well. We also had a small order of fried calamari, which was light (for fried food!) and crispy.

For my main entree, I ordered the Fisherman's Catch sand dabs, prepared sizzling on a cast iron pan with paprika, garlic, and butter. These were perhaps the best sand dabs I've ever had - they were super tender and buttery and practically melted in my mouth!

Although I didn't order it, I had a bite of my dining companion's garlic noodles, and they were incredible - extremely garlicky with a sharp bite - and much better than the garlic noodles at Crustacean or Thanh Long.

Very highly recommended, especially if you have lots of wine at home that you'd like to drink with seafood!
author: Allen T.

description:
The Old Clam House is the oldest restaurant in the city, and I now understand why they're still in business.  Classic, unpretentious, and family friendly, the atmosphere is very inviting with high quality seafood and comfortable seating.  The walls are lined with all kinds of knick knacks and signs, and while I was there to enjoy the food and my wonderful date, I also appreciated that the Warriors game was on in the background.

I will preface this review by saying that the service on the night I went was really scattered and left a lot to be desired.  After being seated and given our shot of clam juice (which was delicious and buttery) almost immediately, we were ignored for almost ten minutes before being greeted or offered any water.  I'm choosing to overlook this because the waitress acknowledged they were short staffed and seemed visibly flustered, even getting into decently heated arguments with the other server about who had which table.  While I don't think that staff should be at odds with each other in the front of house, I'm pretty sure this kind of stuff doesn't usually go on, and I understand things happen when people call out, get sick, etc.

Service qualms aside, the food here is fantastic.  Apparently their house made kettle bread used to be complimentary, but now it costs a whopping 99 cents and I cannot recommend it enough.  It was some of the BEST bread I have ever been served in a restaurant - warm, thick, and fluffy with a beautiful slightly yeasty flavor and crispy exterior that was hard to stop eating.  It is served with some wonderfully salted and lightly whipped butter that was downright fantastic.  The serving for less than a dollar was more than my date and I could finish, even after eating way more than I should have.

We ordered the calamari appetizer and "individual" size serving of cioppino to share, and along with the bread it was plenty of food.  While the calamari wasn't the most elegantly seasoned I've had, it was fried well, only slightly greasy, and came with a couple whole fried lemon slices, which I love, and some sweet cherry peppers, which I haven't had served with calamari before and it was a great pairing.  What really made the calamari a winning dish though, was the tartar and cocktail sauces that came with them.  Each sauce was executed perfectly and the cocktail had an excellent amount of horseradish zing and tomato acidity that cut through the crispy calamari flawlessly.

The real star of the evening, and one of the restaurants' star dishes, was the San Francisco staple cioppino.  This cioppino was a little different than ones I've had in the past with a thicker, more robust broth that had more of a saucy consistency and very pleasant spice kick.  It tasted deep and roasted like it had simmered for hours and was wonderful on its own or ladled atop of their amazing kettle bread.  The cioppino had corn, olives, and potatoes in it, which I thought was a little odd, but I actually enjoyed every component and there wasn't so much of them that they felt like filler.  The clams were abundant, shrimp cooked well, fish soft and flaky, calamari firm and tasty, but I wish there was just a touch more crab.  Other cioppino's I've had at places like Sotto Mare make the crab the total star of the show, integrating the flavor into the broth, and here the two seemed a bit more separated.  Still, I enjoyed every single bite, and the crab that I had was well cooked, sweet, and delicious.  

I will absolutely return to this old school SF establishment, and the only thing holding it back from 5 stars is the prices are a little high.  I'm never opposed to paying premiuum prices for seafood, and I don't feel like I got ripped off by any means, but considering the location and serving size I would have liked just a bit more bang for my buck.  Overall I am impressed and enthused to add this to my list of destination restaurants to experience some wonderful fishy fun in a relaxed room with a enough history to withstand earthquakes and fires galore.
author: Sean S.

description: Great atmosphere combined with excellent food and wine list. We sat out on the patio which I would suggest as it has great indoor outdoor lighting. Excellent seafood paired with pastas seems to be the theme of the menu. It has great history ties to the location and community where it's located.
author: Bob S.

description:
I made reservations based on all the wonderful yelp reviews and ratings and just before my reservation one of my coworkers mentioned that the food was not good but I still decided to give it a try and my coworker was definitely right about the food not being good. 
The food was not tasty and it was definitely overpriced. $14.99 for a small bowl of garlic noodles? The crab didn't taste fresh.  
The only good thing is the ambiance and that this place is one the oldest restaurants in the city but there's definitely a lot of more restaurants where you can more for your money. 
We ended up going to get tacos after cuz we were still hungry after our $175 meal (3 people).
author: Betcy J.

description:
I really enjoyed the clam juice upon arrival. They even gave me seconds. I had the crab Louis which excellent the dressing was very tasty. 

They have outside dining which can be nice in a hot day. A must have is the garlic c bread it was absolutely delicious!

Staff was friendly and they have a full bar, my type of establishment!
author: Sexy S.

description:
The Old Clam House is supposedly the oldest restaurant in SF... and I feel like this is a restaurant everyone should try while in SF. The food is just okay, but the decoration inside is pretty cool. It's definitely retro and feels like you're on a ship!

So they charge for bread and apparently that used to be free. Bummer :( Not sure if you're really supposed to drink the clam juice or order the bread to dip it? 

All in all, so-so food but a cool little restaurant.
author: Janet H.

description: Delicious seafood Italian style...love it with big party....great service. ..Fresh seafood. Variety of dishes.
author: Supawat J.

description: We had the Cioppino, the crab cakes, the kettle bread. The Cioppino was thick, rich, and among the best I have had. Plus, it's the oldest restaurant in San Francisco. Good service too. Certainly worth a visit.
author: Gogo A.

description: Since the new owner took over I haven't had a bad meal at this place. It my go to for fish and chips but everything I've had is very good!!!
author: Troy H.

description: We went today to the clam house with a party of 12. The service has been hit-and-miss there ever since I've been going there. Service was slow nobody in the restaurant at 12 noon can't understand why it was so slow. Waitress was asked twice for items that she did not bring to the table. Orders were wrong and then had to wait for their correct orders to come. Food was not all that great. When I ask for clams and luini with white sauce, I don't expect to get Campbell soup broth and clams. Because that's exactly what it looked like campbell's chicken noodle soup minus the chicken with clams. For  Expensive lunch I wouldn't expect better.
author: Debbie A.

description:
I used to love coming here for lunch and dinner but they keep raising their prices and charging for bread. For bread!! Come on people this is not a time for crime. If you charge $30 for a seafood soup don't mug a customer $$ for bread. I have walked out the last three times I have been in and have to let the owners know they need to send a mystery shopper in and report about the poor food quality, service, and how the prices are bonkers. 

They don't have lunch specials and I went in with a large group and we demanded they create some for us. They could not so we went to the Yankee.
author: James T.

description: Yummmmmm! That is all. The crab is so amazing. Can't wait to go back. No wait on a Saturday - even though I made a reservation. Super service.
author: Breana L.

description:
Old Clam House is one of those restaurants in San Francisco that you just have to visit if you're a seafood lover. They're known for their crab ciopino, steamed mussels, and of course, their clam juice. Serving sizes are moderate and prices for seafood are pretty decent considering the relative price of a good meal in SF these days. Theirs and old school, family friendly feel here and the waiters and staff are all very accommodating and sweet. 

I saw lots of folk ordering their pasta dishes- personally, I'm not a pasta fan. The BF and I share a small ciopino and a hot plate of mixed seafood. The ciopino was good, but I would say that I prefer the base/broth at Sotto Mare much more. There's a sweetness there and the base here is more savory. Also, there's a lot of potatoes in this one which more than seafood.

Overall, I would still recommend coming here and checking the restaurant out. The atmosphere is fun and inviting. The parking was smooth.
author: Diane T.

description:
3 1/2 stars actually- A crowded neighborhood restaurant with great cioppino! The tomato sauce was thick and a little spicy. It is full of crab, fish, mussels, and clam, with carrots, potato, and corn, too! Yum! 

Make sure to ask for bread- it is a complimentary big warm loaf, but you need to ask for it- this bread is perfect to soak up the cioppino sauce! Every last drop- lol. 

Also, everyone gets a complimentary shot of warm clam juice at the beginning of the meal - the clam juice tastes better than it sounds! 

I docked the Old Clam House half a star because they used to serve a big piece of crispy garlic bread with the cioppino, but no more. Sigh.
author: Charissa N.

description: Awesome service and would definitely recommend this place! The food was extremely delicious and mouth watering!
author: Angelica V.

description:
We had dinner reservations on Christmas Day.   It was very busy and we expected a slight delay in service.   No a big deal 
We enjoyed our leisure dinner. 

Being locals for many years, we've passed this restaurant many times since we live in the Mission.

The food was excellent and we plan on going back.

The crab cakes and fish and chips amazing.  We'll try something else next time
author: Mark S.

description:
Omg ,, not only is this the spot from back in the day !! But now 30 years later I return with the Love of my Life,, this is one of our special spots close to home ,, the food is still so good. I must say I kind of miss all the License plates ( lol) but the new look is the bizness,, but most of all , our GIRL DEZ!! You are the BEST my dear,, Augustine and I now have you on the Fam list Lady!!   Your true regulars Always!
SFC ONE LOVE
author: Gina M.

description:
Sometimes you find something good from the oddest sources. I had a Groupon for an auto detailing, I was warned by the manager NOT to walk one direction, but to walk the other, to get lunch while they work on my car. So off I walked. He mentioned this place, but as I'm not a HUGE upscale-seafood guy, I didn't really think I'd end up here. But as I walked, I passed it, it looked interesting, so why not?

The clam juice that they serve as an appertif freaked me out at first. But I screwed my courage to the sticking place and took a sip. Turns out that it's the flavor of New England Clam Chowder with the consistency of chicken broth. Neither of which are scary thoughts... and it was pleasant enough. Unique for sure. Not certain I'd order it if it were on the menu, but I'll drink it again when I return.

The seafood sandwich I had was amazing. The bread was out of this world. Like, I'd eat every sandwich ever on this bread. Even better than Ike's Place Dutch Crunch, which is honestly the watermark for me.

A bit spendy... and the location is quirky, not a neighborhood I'd spend a lot of time in, to be honest. But it was a really friendly (and cute) server, delicious food, and a fun old-school historic vibe.

Definitely worth checking out. I'd file it under "hidden treasures" ironically, considering the nautical theme.
author: Sean B.

description:
The entrees & drinks are a little pricey, but the cioppino seems to be worth it.  Great flavor too!

Love the old style decor, & the food & bread is pretty good.  The Garlic Bread was out of this world.  

Would def come back once & a while when craving cioppino.  Not in the greatest neighborhood, but it is a landmark!
author: Eli G.

description: Went for dinner on wed night.. It was very good.  The restaurant is one of the oldest in San Francisco 156 years old!! We split a shrimp Louie and then between the four of us we had two salmon dishes and clam linguine everything was served in the cast-iron..... Very Delicious salted Carmel cake for dessert!
author: Anita V.

description: Great food and service! Had a great time just sitting with friends causal laid back atmosphere. It has a really interesting history!
author: John C.

description: Chipino was tiny and filled with potatoes and black olives . Absolutely terrible. Chicken dish was way overcooked .  Just not a good experience.  Will not be back
author: Tim C.

description:
This place was great! True to other reviews, the housemade kettle bread was pretty darn tasty-- warm and with the perfect mix of soft inside and crunchy outside. And their traditional clam juice sounds less appetizing than it actually tastes-- more like a broth to warm you up after a chilly winter's day.

We went on a quiet Sunday night and were seated quickly near the bar. I ordered the crabwich with the $3.99 clam chowder add-on and my partner ordered garlic noodles with crab. 

We were pleasantly surprised at the generous crab portions on both our meals, though the overall dish portions (amount of noodles, size of sandwich) were a little smaller than we expected for an old-timey place. Still, that plus the bread was the perfect amount of food for us to feel full.

Overall, the food was great but a little pricey for a regular night out (came to about $72 for two with tip, and only one of us had a drink). The server was quite friendly, but was either trained to or was independently trying to upsell wherever she could, so it could easily get even more expensive. That said, I did appreciate she was always upfront with how much the upsell would cost, so I only mention it if you're budget-conscious to keep an eye on. A solid date-night or special occasion spot.
author: Krista L.

description:
This place is amazing!!! Definitely a hidden gem!  The service is fast and friendly, the food is delicious and fresh! 

This isn't a commercial restaurant so paying $1 for freshly made bread isn't out of this world. If you want free bread go to outback lol

The clam chowder has whole clams in it! 
The crab cakes are all crab- no fillers here people!! 

I'll be back!
author: desiree c.

description:
A true SF tradition. It's worth putting up with the neighborhood. Sit at the bar! 

Adding more stuff because Yelp is stupid and thinks this is too short. 

More stuff. 

Even more. 

Is this enough now?
author: JC D.

description: My family and I have been going to this establishment for years. And each time it gets better. The place takes reservations which is awesome and the service is always consistent. This place has been around for over a hundred years so you can say it's a part of the history of San Francisco.
author: Paul C.

description:
Nothing special. Seafood broth shooters were good, and kettle bread ($1) was easily the best thing we had -- crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, huge and served warm with room temperature butter (THANK YOU, Clam House for that). I 100% recommend the kettle bread.
Service was pretty awful. We sat there for 20 minutes before getting any water, and I had to ask twice (this on a hot day!). Our server didn't touch the table at all until we had been there 15 minutes. This when the restaurant was quite dead and he didn't seem busy at all! He never came back to check how our food was.
I had steamed clams and my friend had the cioppino. My clams were cooked correctly and the broth was pretty tasty, but honestly it was just a one note wonder of garlic butter. I liked the sweet potatoes in there and the corn was ok (both were a bit overcooked), but since they were swimming in a bowl of what appeared to be 2-3 sticks of butter, it was too much. My side of veg, on the other hand (broccoli and squash, steamed) were literally unseasoned save a little butter, so I had to add a considerable amount of s&p. Cioppino was good, definitely big enough, but the sauce was a touch sweet (at least it had some heat to balance). 
Carafe of Hess cabernet was OK.
We didn't order dessert because I was guessing they would all be super sweet. That kind of place.
Parking was not difficult on a Thursday at 7:30. Not the best neighborhood.
Overall,  nice to have gone for the history/nostalgia factor, but neither of us will be back. Definitely not worth the 2 hours of driving roundtrip from Lafayette.
author: Janice T.

description:
Amazing! Fine dining? nope. overpriced? not even close. going home hungry? not a chance.
i was in love with this place at first visit. its hella old, but doesn't smell like old socks, like some other old eateries. karma must be in love with this place also. it never burned down, let alone several times. 
super friendly staff, food arrived rather quickly. normally id say thats a red flag, but with only 4-5 other tables, it just shows that the lunch shift kitchen has their stuff together. Ana, our server was great, very sweet and didn't push us to order anything. my wife and i are always on the lookout for "the bomb" fish and chips in this city. we found the best "fish" part of the fish and chips. so good in fact that i didn't even care that the fries weren't cut fresh, rather were frozen. so i'm not faulting them, for that. the huge piece of fish was so buttery, and the batter stayed stuck to the fish, kudos to your staff, chef. the portions were so big, that we have leftovers for dinner. 
if you like clam chowder, order it with the bread on the side. you'll appreciate the huge loaf of fresh baked bread to dip in the soup as you go. we ordered the original, not the one with whole clams. 
my wife and i shared the fried calamari, Tentacle pieces!!!!!? woo-freakin-hoo, my favorite part. perfectly cooked, not rubbery and so much of it. 
she had the classic caesar salad, and i could hear her crunching the crispy romaine, and it looked properly dressed. she crushed it, i didnt get to try that one. maybe next time.  plus they have liters of super cold draught beers served in glass "Strauss Farms" milk bottles. 
the food, drink, staff, history, will ensure my return. please don't ever change a thing. its my wife's and my new favourite place to bring our out of town family and friends for a real taste of san francisco history and food.
author: Rafael D.

description: Had a great Sunday meal. Delicious food, great service, reasonably priced and very accommodating with food substitutions. Server said they never charge a corkage fee or a cake cutting fee if you bring your own dessert. A very charming and historical dining experience.
author: Lissette I.

description:
Mom and I came here for lunch on Thanksgiving day; no wait since I made a reservation beforehand and the place wasn't busy at all. It has an old school, casual atmosphere. Very relaxing and different than most places in SF. 

At first, we didn't even know where to park (it took us like 10 min and finally parked behind the restaurant) and my mom was a little intimidated by the surrounding environment. She kept saying that the food here better be worth it. And let's just say it was!

We ordered the skillet bread, individual sized clam bake cioppino, and a sea bass (with the cherry tomatoes, olives, garlic and basil seasoning option). 

The bread came in a skillet but it wasn't warm, which was a bummer. It had a crackly crust and the inside was nice and soft though. It was pretty big for only $.95. I probably won't get it again unless it's warm as if it just came out of the oven.

The cioppino was delicious. They gave me a bib, towelettes, and tools needed to eat shelled fish. There were so much goodies and the seafood tasted fresh. The sauce was great for bread dipping! It wasn't too spicy or salty. The only thing to note is that there weren't any shrimp in mine... I didn't finish mine and I think it's big enough to share among two people.

The sea bass my mom ordered was really good too. The portion is pretty big-- she was stuffed afterwards! It comes with potatoes and veggies, and this pasta thing that looks like couscous.

They also gave us shots of clam juice and I had their chili Bloody Mary. The clam juice was too salty for my taste, but it was great to dip the bread into. The Bloody Mary was probably one of the best I've ever had; it had such a nice kick to it. 

Service was great. Our server was polite, welcoming, and checked up on us periodically.

Overall, we had a nice thanksgiving lunch at this place and my mom definitely changed her mood afterwards. We left happy and were fueled to spend the rest of the day in the city :)
author: Christina W.

description: It was our first time coming here and we had a delicious meal. Our server was really nice. We ordered a lot of food here like clam chowder, calamare, shrimp and mussels but the one that stand out the most was the the Crab Alfredo, Chorizo cheese bread, baby back ribs and sea bass  cooked in paprika garlic parsley butter. There was a lot of crab in the crab  alfredo. The sauce of the chorizo bread was so cheesy. The meat was falling off the bone in the baby back ribs. While the sea bass and couscous was buttery delicious. I will definitely come back here again.
author: Bernadette C.

description: Best clam chowder in town!  Looking for a very late afternoon lunch. Sat at the bar and had great service and delicious soup!  Fun spot with great San Francisco history!
author: Karen K.

description: Ana was a breath of fresh air after a hard day meeting with real estate clients. My wife and I got the food and service we have come to expect but is increasingly difficult to get these days! Ana was attentive to our needs for the whole visit. She accommodated our request to change tables, get more of the wonderful clam soup, and even turn up the heat on this cold night. WOW! The food was great and we thank you Ana for your first class service. We'll be back ourselves and with clients...as long as Ana is there. Keep caring!
author: Dwayne B.

description:
First of all, someone please confirm that the state maximum alcohol content is 3 ounces. I've looked at the Alcohol laws and found that that is not regulated. We were told by Anna, our server, and Dennis the manager that the maximum serving of alcohol per drink is 3 ounces. The drink we ordered was similar to a Long Island iced tea, but with pineapple juice instead of coke. We complained to Anna that the drink seemed like it didn't have enough alcohol but she said the max alcohol per serving was 3 ounces. We were surprised with her comment but decided to keep the drink anyways. Anna came back and said since we weren't satisfied they would comp the drink but had to take it back. Huh?! A compensated drink is on the house from what I remember in the business. Anyways, we never asked to return the drink and were fine with the drink, but didn't see it coming when she took the drink from our table.

We also had dinner at this restaurant . We had the clam chowder  and calamari. The chowder was gritty and overly thick , the calamari was salty and just okay. Based on other's suggestions those dishes are supposed to be top notch.  Needless to say, we will not be back at this establishment.
author: Regan O.

description:
This was our second time at the Old Clam House, and our group of four had a good time. Starting with the classic clam juice/broth shooter, and listening to classic rock n roll on the stereo. 
We were there for the crab of course, so we ordered the Too Two Crab for three of us ($74) and an order of fish and chips. 

We were a bit surprised that our waitress could not answer some basic questions about the order, like how many crabs exactly we were getting. "A lot of crab," what she basically told us. Turns out for $74 we got two medium sized crabs. You decide if that is good value for the money. When they came out, the presentation was about as bare bones as you can get: two crabs on a plate. Weirdly enough, the legs and body were not cracked, and the legs were still attached to the body. I'm pretty sure last time we came here, the crabs were ready to eat without having to wield a mallet, which we didn't have. 
When we asked the waitress, "How do we eat these?" she said, "I don't know, I don't eat crab." 
Finally I asked that the crabs be sent back to the kitchen to see if they could separate the legs from the body at least and maybe crack the claws. Away they went and back they came in five minutes nicely separated and ready to eat. Except we weren't supplied with crab forks or clarified butter to dip. When we asked for crab forks, we were supplied with what looked like salad forks...basically useless for dinning out those last delicious morsels hidden down deep inside the shells. 
But we made do, and the crabs were well spiced and cooked and we had a fun time trying to get the crab meat out. And the generous wine pours for our glasses made it all go down nicely. 

I like the atmosphere of the Old Clam House, and hope that next time I go back they have ironed out basics like info about the menu, presentation, cutlery, and clarified butter!
author: Phillip D.

description: The Old Clam House is truly a five star establishment.  From the moment we got there we felt at home!  Our group tried a variety of items on the menu and everything was delicious.  Loved looking at all the old pictures and couldn't help but notice how nice and clean the restaurant was.  Our servers were wonderful and we were happily surprised that our waitress gave each of us a free kettle bread with the clam chowders we ordered to go (four orders!!).  Can't wait to go back for the Caesar salad and crab sandwich.
author: Bambi W.

description: They started us off with clam juice with scallions.  We also ordered garlic bread. I had the sea bass with garlic sauce and capers with potatoes, small onions, carrots, and olives. My boyfriend had the fish and chips.  The food came out quickly.  The service was great.  I would like to try the crab and clam chowder next time.
author: Rose Marie J.

description: Parking is a massive headache coming here. The food was sufficiently tasty, if a tad seafood-heavy in taste. I know that sounds strange. But two of the three in our party felt that even though we expected seafood cause that's what we ordered, the flavor and quantity was a bit overmuch. The bread and butter was off the charts yummy though.
author: Jonathan G.

description: Worth the price. Historic venue as the water used to creep all the way up and boats would dock to eat at this great establishment. I had pretty much everything on their menu in five sittings. Everything is what you'd want and expect it to be. Portions were good.
author: Adidas W.

description: Came here with a friend. Service was good, meal portion size was good and so was the food. A little on the pricy side though.
author: Clark P.

description: Great food, great service, and the steamy clam juice shot that they give everyone on arrival is delicious! The garlic bread was also great. Clam chowder was good but nothing too special. The fish breath basil martini was so refreshing!
author: KC R.

description: Great clam chowder and clam juice! First time here and service is great. Very friendly and explained their special bread made in house. So yup I'm getting bread bowl clam chowder. Will definitely be back to try something different on the menu.
author: Mari S.

description: Went for lunch.  Waited for menus.  They finally arrived.  Then we waited for the waitress to come take our order, and waited and waited some more.  We got up and asked some employees who were chatting about personal matters to take our order.  They said they weren't handing our table and didn't help.  After waiting some more, we left.   Too bad the service has gone downhill because the food is good.
author: VM B.

description: I don't write too many reviews anymore, but this is the 3rd time I go to this restaurant since moving closer, and it's always been a pleasant experience.  Want compelled me to write today is Ana, the wonderful server we had tonight.  It's been a while since I've had such warm service at a restaurant.  She was just so attentive and atune to our needs.  We really enjoyed her.  Besides the excellent service, one dollar for the kettle bread is a steal, and one of the best deals in town.  I like the complimentary clam soup, and the,food is well made classics served in generous portions.  I much prefer to come here instead of dragging myself to Fisherman's Wharf, which I do not enjoy, but when you have visitors, sometime you just don't have a choice.  Glad this place is still around!
author: Vivian P.

description: Ordered the chick-wich today - I have NEVER seen a thinner slice of chicken breast in a sandwich ANYWHERE!  Left feeling like I had only eaten bread with grilled onions and sweet cherry peppers - completely unsatisfying.  My husband ordered linguini and clams which were served in a bowl of clam broth - more like a weak soup than a pasta dish.  Have dined here many, many times over the years with my family but today was the last time.
author: michael d.

description: I walked past this place for months and kept telling myself I was going here with my friends one weekend but we kept putting it off.So seeing that I simply love clam chowder I went inside the place had a very warm feeling you can tell they'd been around for awhile.A few regular customers,I quickly was seated where I could really check the place out.The clam chowder was nothing like the canned camble soup version.This was a whole different level of chowder to me.Delicious it was creamy,with potatoes and corn and of course clams. I needed a bigger spoon and more omg.So...good.Just sad I didn't look further into the menu.But if I'm ever in the area again because I am from Michigan. I will return and have a feast.And take full advantage of that wonderfully stocked bar that I say near.
author: Aubdul W.

description: Jonesing for one of those salty/brothy dining experience on the way back from the airport tonight and found The Old Clam House tucked beneath the freeway in Hunter's Point. I was really happy with our choice because our waitresses and staff made our visit that much more of an experience. Got to taste the clam juice/broth for the first time and also had a second round. I had no idea warm clam juice tasted so good. Our order included the linguine with clams, clam escargot and their world famous clam chowder. It wasn't very busy here tonight on  a Tuesday evening. Their menu doesn't include a brunch serving, but their everyday menu items would be well worth trying. Anyways, thanks to our waitresses for catering to us and giving us such a memorable time. Food was delicious and not over salty. Looking forward to our return.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I have dreams like this. I am so not kidding. 

I have dreams of an abundance of sizzling hot seafood glazed with garlicky butter, impossibly fresh cold oysters on the half shell nestled on shining trays of ice, steamy pots of clams, and hearty bowls of cioppino. 

My visit here can easily be summarized like this: I rolled my sleeves up and literally ate so much delicious seafood, I almost had to be rolled out of the restaurant. 

You think I am kidding. I am not. 

I liked sitting in a booth because everyone loves a booth (especially me)! I liked this booth in particular because it had actual chairs for 6 - which meant 4 could sit comfortably and our seafood feast would fit on the long table. 

If I were your friend (well, we kind of are already friends because...Yelp, but you know) I would tell you to order this: 

Clams Escargot 
Crab and Shrimp Skillet
Kettle Bread 

The Cioppino and steamed clams we ordered were just ok. I prefer the way I make both of those at home. The clam juice wasn't my thing either but I can see why people love it (you can have mine). 

The dishes I did like, I LOVED. I am still thinking about that dinner!

The service was professional. You will see the bussers more than your waiter but don't worry - there are so many of them, you will not feel neglected. Just ask for what you need and it will appear. I really appreciate that team effort. 

Make reservations on Open Table and you will have a fuss free dining experience. Well, that is my hope :) 

The Old Clam House is the pride of San Francisco as it has stood there since 1861. Sometimes when I walk along Van Ness Avenue I look at the houses that survived the fire and I marvel at them. The tin ceiling and walls at The Old Clam House have that same effect. Research the history of Tin walls and ceilings and you, too, will have a great appreciation for them at The Old Clam House. It is like being in a museum - looking at an artifact. 

Come. Wash your hands so you can eat with them. Use your bread to drench in the garlic butter that is on the sizzling iron skillet with your seafood. Eat until you cannot possibly eat another bite....then order dessert and coffee. 

Life is meant to be this good. 

Thank you to all of my Yelp friends who visited here before me and wrote such great reviews (even the low star ones) because that gave me a strong sense of what to expect, order, and be open to experiencing.
author: Jennifer C P.

description: Bruh... Hands down one of the best meals I've had. Brought my dad when he was visiting town - we shared the kettle bread (noms), I had the sand dabs and he had the linguine. Everything was perfect, cute and out of the way resturaunt. Totally a place to come and treat yo self!
author: Bethy B.

description:
I haven't been here in ages. The last time I was there had to have been at least 10 years and even then, the food was pretty good.  We had a birthday dinner for my brother the week before in anticipation that he would need to work late on his birthday, but he got done early and it was a last minute plan to head over to The Old Clam House for another dinner.  We showed up and it was a very quiet Monday evening. 

Our dinner started off with the Crispy Crab Cakes and they were tasty.  For my entree, I decided on the Garlic Noodles and added crab to it.  That thing was a bowl of heaven.  It was so good that I contemplated on ordering another one even though I was stuffed.  It was the right amount of garlic and they didn't skimp on the crab meat which was very fresh.  I've been dreaming about those noodles.  I don't want to return to this place.  I NEED to return. 

All in all, it was a great dining experience.  Great service.  Great food.  They're not the cheapest around though.  Just for my garlic noodles and crab ran $25.00.  The crab cakes were $17.00.   For 5 people, the bill came out to a tad over $180 and that was without wine and one beer.   I probably can't afford to frequent this place, but I can make it a regular destination whenever I want some delicious food.
author: Milton W.

description:
They don't make 'em like this anymore.  I want to call it Ye Olde Clam House, because it really is old enough to warrant some Olde English.  It was THE FIRST restaurant in SF in the 1860s... can you believe that? The waterfront used to be just outside, then SF's landscape changed and made the Clam House a land-locked roadhouse. Regardless, seafood is still their jam and that's what you should come for. 

Love the old-timey feel here. The original long wooden bar, the red checkered tablecloths, the martinis served in a shaker so you can refill on your own.  This reminds me of the down-home, family-friendly restaurants my parents would take us to as kids, like the Washoe House in Petaluma and Rancho Nicasio. Similar low-key vibe with tons of Americana character. 

Crab cakes are a must-try. They're almost 100% crab, with a crispy fried coating and lemon aioli. The clams escargot are another fun dish to share -- clams baked in butter & herbs (no snails involved). The cheesy bread was a glorious sight when it arrived at our table, but the bread was a bit overcooked & tough. Save stomach space for the real stars (seafood!) We saw some folks ordering whole crabs and platters of mussels... definitely tempting if you're willing to sport the bib and get your hands dirty.
