Bartenders & servers were all genuinely friendly, and John filled us in on the history  of The Old Clam House while we sipped blood orange bellinis and martinis from the "here fishy fishy fishy" menu. 

Such a fun little spot to escape to and experience a side of SF you've never seen!
author: Nique F.

description:
Love love love this new find. Not sure why it's taken me this long to find this neighborhood joint. It's so popular that reservations are recommended for large groups. 

There's a bar which seemed to be hosting a lot of regulars. It's a bit noisy as we were sat adjacent to it. But what the hay, we jumped in when the bar busy out a happy birthday tune for a birthday girl. 

There's another room with curtain lines booths and yet another room with detailed window decor on the glass. Wherever you look there's a cool collection of memorabilia and flat screens!

We were quickly seated and offered a shot of clam broth. It went down nicely as we just came in from the cold. The garlic bread was saturated with buttery garlic and so indulgent. We made sure to soak up any uncoated bread with the drippings in the pan. Woo hoo artery clogging goodness!

To continue our buttery expedition, we ordered the crab which came out  sizzling smelling like we
We're about to eat the most delicious crab! The  meat was so tender and flavorful that it didn't take long to clean that plate! They even used the brains in the butter dip making it rich but not overpowering for crab and bread. Can you feel the arteries getting tighter?? It didn't end there!

We also tried the oyster with mignonette, escargot clams and a caramel dessert. They were delish and we cleaned our plates clean! We had another clam broth shot and felt our choices left us content, happy and just right!

The staff are super friendly and it feels like that place you could visit weekly for dinner, where everyone knows your name. 

We definitely want to bring some friends and family here for the experience and to try some pan skillet shrimp and mussels or pasta.
author: Carlyn C.

description:
Clam juice! Get your hot clam juice! 

It sounds disgusting, but clam juice is the featured beverages at The Old Clam House. Famous for being one of the oldest establishments in the City of San Francisco, I guess it makes sense that diners are offered a shot of warm clam juice before the meal arrives. 

Why clam juice? Apparently there secret health benefits to drinking piping hot broth with a touch of clam. http://theoldclamhousesf.com/menu/och-menu.pdf

Other reasons why The Old Clam House is special:

+ Love the bar! It's the original wood framework from the 1860's. Order a dirty martini, you won't regret it.

+ Clams served a la escargot. Surprisingly delicious!

+ Crabby crab cakes. Tons of meat, not a lot of filling.

+ Clam chowder. Rich, buttery and perfect on a cold winter evening. 

Even with a "remote" location (P.S., Bayview isn't that far away!), this family-friendly restaurant was full on a Thursday evening by 6 pm. Put on a bib and order some seafood - and don't forget the clam juice!
author: Abby S.

description: Ate here tonight with family and friends. We were a party of four. The service was excellent, as were the food.  Portions were generous and tasty. We arrived just before the dinner rush and were seated immediately. I would recommend the clam chowder (obviously).  The parking was limited and a bit concerned about the area as it was surrounded by warehouses.  In the end, you'll be happy you decided to eat here.
author: Gregg L.

description:
Amazing place. I'm not sure how this place has only 440 reviews. I'm also not sure why this place only gets 3.5 stars. This place had been on my list for a long time. It just became my new old favorite place in the city.  

The seafood cioppino is delicious, it's base is thick and rich. There are huge chunks of tomatoes and carrots mixed with shrimp, white fish, clams, muscles, calamari and two huge crab legs. It's definitely one of the best seafood cioppinos I've had.

The clam chowder is thick and rich, really solid performance even without a bread bowl. The chowder has great flavor with large chunks of potatoes. 

The seafood linguini had calamari, muscles, clams and shrimp. The serving size is huge as far as I'm concerned,  more than enough for a reasonably hungry person. The crab and shrimp Louie salad was also fairly large as well,  it looked fresh and delicious.

The service is great, our friends we met there have been over 20 times. They said they'd had special events like birthday parties and large groups for dinner and the place had always been accommodating.

The atmosphere is totally old school. I really like the classic feel of the place. More importantly,  the food is great.
author: Ben M.

description: The cioppino wasn't ciopipino it was more like a big stew with a lot of big pieces of carrots and potatoes. Why would you put black olives in cioppino?? The prices were pretty high too. No good, I won't be going there to eat ever again.
author: Steph B.

description:
Starting off with a warm cup of clam juice is actually a nice way to kick off the dinner. It warms up your stomach and if you're celebrating an event, you can make a toast and kind of break the ice. I dunno, it's just an overlooked part of the dinner I liked. We had a large group with Aleski (Alexi? Alexy? idk) as our server. He was very attentive and patient while my uncles and mom shouted over each other because they're old, Chinese and overbearing. But i digress.. On to the food. 
We had ordered hella food but i'll stick to the things I ate personally. The kettle bread was interesting. Fresh, large, and initially it didn't seem so special. I was wrong. But i'll get to that later. I had their signature Cioppino which was pretty good, although nothing special. Same goes with the fried calamari. The dish that I had thoroughly enjoyed was the clams escargot. Theres something magical about the marriage of butter and garlic. Throw some hearty clams in there and you have one happy Joey. I'm salivating profusely just thinking about it. Now, the kicker with this dish was that after you've eaten all them clams, you have 2/3rds of the holy garlic butter mixture sitting all lonesome in that pan. Enter kettle bread. That bread is so spongey and absorbent, you just dip right into that pan and you've basically got yourself a whole nother dish. Just when I thought things couldnt have gone better, my mom blurts out to Alexi that it was me and my brother's birthday, and if there's anything complimentary he can give to us... Blunt, I know. Alexi didn't flinch as he turned to us and asked if we like tequila. We do. Comped us two shots on Don Julio while he served us the cake we brought in. As a guy who had to constantly apologize to servers for some of things my mom says, I give Alexi major props for taking everything with a smile. Owners, if you're reading this, give him a raise. Thanks!
author: Joey C.

description: I really wanted to love the clam house again but unfortunately I was disappointed with my meal i'm not a big fan of the new menu and I like oldies and goodies which they've taken out many of the classic dishes I may give them one last shot because I really love them so much before but honestly I'm not going to be surprised if it's not good. The prices for the amount t of food is sad too.
author: Natie R.

description:
The warm clam broth they serve upon entering this 'ol establishment has been served for years! I would come here after work about 30 years ago and was so happy to see it hasn't changed very much. The food is excellent; great choice of beers on tap; the kettle bread is out of this world. Kudos to the owners for keeping it as authentic, charming and scrumptious as I remember! The sand dabs with lemon, caper, butter were fabulous!
If you want to experience a great San Francisco seafood restaurant (the building dates back to 1861), without the over priced entrees you will love this original. CHARMING & AUTHENTIC!
author: Cindy S.

description: The worst place ever . I lived in sf all my life and my grandmother church was right next door to the old clam house . When I was a little girl I use to eat there stuffed mushrooms over rice and clam chowder w/ slice of bread . The best clam chowder ever ! I decided to make a visit yesterday and got their clam chowder which was $14.99 smh . It was was like water . I thought clam chowder was suppose to be thick . It also had clam shells and potatoes was not cook all the way . My bread was shape in a circle and cut in 4 smh . I'm do not recommend people to eat here . This restaurant was better when I was a little girl . I do not know what happen
author: Chuntel P.

description: Love this spot- classical old San Francisco restaurant. Rarely crowded. The menu has classic winning dishes - they really know what they are doing. Highly recommend the cheesy bread and the crab Loui salad. Neighborhood doesn't look super nice, but trust me, it's worth it to get a meal at this spot!
author: Lucy F.

description:
I've had this restaurant bookmarked for a long time, it's so close to my house but just never got around to trying it until today. I did not enjoy it at all and will definitely not be returning. 

First of all, they charge you for table bread, and the bread is not even good. Secondly, while their prices do not seem outrageous, the reason for that is because the portions are tiny. The crab sandwich was horrible. It was on the same soft doughie bread that they charge you for on the table and it wasn't toasted or anything so it was just really soft and chewy, like Wonder Bread, and then there was avocado and red onion slices; the avocado, soft bread and crab made the sandwich just a big soft mush ball. There was really no flavor at all to the sandwich except for the flavor of the onions and bread. I am pretty positive they are using canned crab. But there was honestly, on the tiny sandwich, only about 1 leveled tablespoon of crab and the rest of the sandwich was onions and a little bit of overripe avocado: it was not good at all, even my brother who has a hollow leg didn't like it and we ended up just eating a tiny bit of crab out of the center and leaving all the bread.  This tiny sandwich comes with nothing and it's $17.  You can add a cup of clam chowder to your sandwich for four dollars but the clam chowder is bland and seems to contain canned clams. 

They bring you a little shot of hot clam juice at the beginning of the meal, but it was totally flavorless, it could've been low-sodium chicken broth for all I know. 

The fish and chips looked pretty good, but I don't know if it was flavorful because I didn't try it.  

Kids sodas are $4 each so so for two kids meals, a crab sandwich, a fish sandwich and two bread bowls on clam chowder, our total for lunch was $160. 

The bussers were polite but our server was no good. She barely ever came to our table and was awkward and rude when she did. This place has been in business a long time but it seems that they changed ownership recently because one of my co-diners said that the place was totally different the last time she came which was a few years back, she said the service and food were way better back then.  It's obvious why this place is still in business after all these years: charging for table bread and putting a $17 price tag on a sandwich that contains a tablespoon of canned crab means that this place is making a huge profit on their crappy food.  Two stars for decent bussers and free refills on their $4 sodas - the rest is a total bust.
author: Emma H.

description: A great neighborhood gem! Great decor like you travelled back in time. Iron skillet is a must try!
author: J C.

description:
Pretty retro seafood house

Located just off the 101, I've drove by this place countless times but never went in. Well this time I've actually had a chance to visit! The vibe inside is actually much more chill than I thought, with most of the patrons sitting in the bar area. The vibe is ok, with not much background music, but a warm interior. Most of the customers looks like they are truckers from the area. From the posters on the wall, it looks like this place has existed for a long time--the menu also says this place has been established for decades, and is one of the oldest seafood joints in SF.

In terms of the food quality, the place actually exceeded my expectation--the food is a little on the expensive side ($25 for a seafood pot), but damn it's tasty! The cioppino had serious punch, with a lot of tomato sauce, and amazing seafood. The balance was just right--not too much sauce, but just enough so it gave a lot of flavor without overpowering the seafood. Nice

Overall, definitely recommend stopping by. This place is actually pretty chill, so it's suitable for both large and small groups.
author: Henry L.

description:
Well this was my favorite place to get clam chowder and it has been ruined. Walked in today to the end of the bar to place a to go order and the bartender (2014Griseld) tells me, "Go back by the front door and get a menu to place your order". I do as she says,  come back to her,  place my order, sit at tge bar, and wait for it. Another lady comes in (of a different ethnicity), goes over to the same bartender and request to place a to go order and the bartender says,  "Have a seat while I grab you a menu to place an order". 
My jaw dropped..... I waited until she finished and said,  "Excused me, what is the difference between me and the customer you just assisted?" She had a dumb-founded look on her face. I said, "When I came in you had me to retrieve a menu myself and when she came you went in and got one for her, why?"

SMDH.....WOW

Needless to say.... no longer my favorite place!
author: Doretta B.

description:
Cioppino!! SOOO good. By far my favorite place in the city to get it. Prices are super reasonable. It's a great place to take out-of-towners to show them what it's like. Especially if you get something besides the cioppino, the serving for two is MORE than enough for four people.

You can also bring your own wine! No corkage fee. There was a table next to us that was certainly taking advantage of this offer. If you don't come prepared, there's a certain place that offers "more beverages" within walking distance. 

The only thing I had here that I didn't like was the mussels. Took my folks who aren't really into that sort of thing either so it didn't help with my trying to win them over to the shellfish side. They tasted really "off" but I did eat some and didn't get sick...so...win?!

Other than that, servers have always been amazing, the rest of the seafood has been super fresh and definitely don't pass on that free shot they give you when you first sit down! (It's clam juice...and it's warm and it's amazing.) Plus the building itself is super old and has a giant and very photogenic clam out front.
author: Carol M.

description:
I've been coming here on and off for years as the ciopinno has always been solid. I came in today and sat down really looking forward to having a big bowl.

And then I look at the "original" ciopinno on the menu which is billed as "clam bake" style. Been eating this dish for 20 years all over the Bay Area and never heard of clam bake style anywhere much less at this restaurant. Once a look at the ingredients I'm more than a little dismayed. The ciopinno has potatoes, carrots and . . . Corn? 

I figure "well must be a seasonal special surely they have traditional ciopinno."  Nope. This it. 

Very disappointed I got up and headed over to anchor in the Castro which while farther I know to have the ciopinno I was looking for. 

I'm sympathetic to how hard it is to turn a profit at a restaurant in sf so I am guessing these non traditional ingredients are an attempt to control costs a bit on the dish. But perhaps it's just an attempt to differentiate a bit. But in either case I would implore the management to go back to a recipe that doesn't include these ingredients. Most of us who eat this dish and know find it off putting (as I can see in other comments here on yelp). 

I look forward to coming back when I can get the ciopinno traditional style!
author: Carlos C.

description: Very, very salty food from the clam juice through the steamed clams and even the bread was salty. My wife had a poorly done calamari steak which was horribly underdone and way over priced. We will go back one more time to use up our gift cards on sandwiches, and thats it.
author: David L.

description:
For my birthday dinner with family, I chose the Old Clam House. I made a reservation and we were seated in glass patio area at a nice big table. 

Although many things about this place have changed, several things remain the same, which makes me happy. I'm a San Francisco Native and grew up in the neighborhood, we celebrated many events here and we all love the quality of the seafood. 

Service was excellent! Our waitress Griselda gave us great recommendations and kept everyone happy with food, beverages and anything we needed. 

The unique tradition of the clam broth served with the fresh sourdough bread still holds up over all of these years. My nephew, who is 7 and super picky - loves it. It's a perfect broth that is soothing and great to dip your bread in. they will even bring you seconds and thirds, if you want. 

To start, I ordered a Blood Orange Margarita. It was my birthday, so of course I should celebrate. With that a few oysters which I enjoyed with some of the hotsauces that they have (if you haven't seen, they have quite the collection!). 

My boyfriend and I split the sizzling platter of crab, mussels and shrimp - which is just my style. All seafood, no sides. My mom, sister and brother in law all ordered the Crab Louie salad which was not only beautiful, but had a lot of fresh crab on top. 

My Dad ordered the calamari steak with couscous, which he loves. It's tender and delicious, so he orders it everytime without even looking at the menu. Family friends ordered the fish and chips and crab burger with fries. Everyone was very happy with thier selections and satisfied with the size of the meal. 

I had a wonderful meal with my family and that was by far the best present I received for my birthday this year. Thank you Clam House, I hope to spend many more family dinners here over the years.
author: Rebekah T.

description: I went here with my family like 2 weeks ago and it was good. Definitely I little pricey but definitely worth it. We sat in a middle both with two curtains and I quite enjoyed the old school feel of the place. Plus the food came out rather quickly! Will probably return here on date night!
author: Tha C.

description:
Location: there's limited parking in a dead end alley behind the restaurant. Otherwise, park in the streets at your own risk - it's a sketchy neighborhood.

Service: 4/5 we had to wait a while for the hostess to seat us, our dirty dishes were taking up a lot of space on our table for a while, and our cups of water sat empty after our appetizers. Our waiter was nice.

Food: we came here for restaurant week, and the fixed menu is definitely worth a try. 
Crab escargot: 12 clams in olive oil and bread crumbs - delicious.
Kettle bread: a big helping for the table, but ours was burnt on the bottom.
Clam chowder: delicious, full of flavor and lots of clams.
Fish fillet: nicely cooked and seasoned well.
Seafood linguini: the highlight of the dinner. It is linguini steeped in a healthy helping of layered sauce with clams, squid, crab legs and fish. The sauce was delicious, it reminded me of the sauce from Boiling Crab.
Tiramisu: light and fluffy, nothing too special.

Bonus: the complimentary clam juice is tasty and salty.
author: Ruby K.

description:
3.5 Stars

Came here with the fam bam for dinner once and then recently ordered take out as well. 

The night we went in we ordered 

Crab Louie Salad-very simple, clean, refreshing salad
Calamari-batter was fried well, properly seasoned and portion was good 
Cioppino (couple)-a good robust assortment of seafood swimming inside a mildly spicy tomato sauce that can easily feed 4 people 
Fish and Chips-fish was fried well, moist and seasoned beautifully 
Crab Alfredo-no highs or lows, a good dish for kids 

For take out, we decided to order just the Cioppino for two ($50), portion size appears more in the to go, seafood wise, but there is more broth when you dine in 

Overall Thoughts

Fish and chips + cioppino were solid and almost enough to bump it up to 4 stars, maybe third time will be the charm!
author: Eddie W.

description: Usually a great stand by place after a day in the city or after shopping. We have had the family meet there for good drinks and great food. Last night stopped by got a table right away!  Then the waitress came. The stars started falling off right away. At first we figured it was her first day and gave her a break, after we gave our drink order twice( she even asked one of our guests about his water twice). Never brought water for the table ever!  Got our appetizers then sat until our soup came before our drinks came (this is where we were sure she was new. Tip here, sell drinks, pretty sure that's what your boss wants you to do. Dinner came it was great, tip here, you need bread with linguine and clams. Had to ask twice!  While enjoying our dinners, she passes by and says did you guys need to look at the dessert menu?  Tip here, should have asked if we wanted another drink,  that's what your boss wants you to do. She dropped off the bill by picking up a bowl of clam shells and putting down the bill then the bowl of clams back on top. WHAT, REALLY!  Needles to say we waited forever for her to pick that up. When I went looking for her, found her back by the kitchen having a great time with the other staff. Oh well, we went Home had a dessert and drink still happy with our dinner.  Tip here, to the manager, she needs more training, lots more training! I'll be back to the Clam House but if she is our waitress we will ask for another table. (We sat in the outside area, about 8PM)
author: L O.

description:
The chiopino and seafood pasta dishes were served in cast iron pans which added a smokey taste and kept the food for hot.  The dishes were spiced which tended to mask the other flavors in the dishes.

We will definitely return but probably will opt for one of our old favorites, fish and chips or calamari.

Love the old SF ambience with the bar / restaurant and the locals catching up.
author: Karen Richard D.

description: Milwaukee steam beer! Tastes as good as it's name, and why it seems to only exist here is just one of the special treasures that awaits you at this remote outpost of culinary joy.  Solid fish, chowder, typical fare and a great unpretentious yet traditional atmosphere...  awesome
author: Nick A.

description: This was adorable and charming. My husband and I were looking for some good seafood outside of fisherman's wharf and this was recommended. Immediately upon sitting down we were met with glasses of water and hot clam juice (my husband was hoping it was tequila but was very pleasantly surprised when it almost tasted like a "good miso soup") Being from out of town and loving sea bass, I went for it. It was good, but I can get better at home (hence the 4 stars). My husband got the short ribs and said they were fantastic. I was concerned about being too "dressed down" for dinner after a day out, but this was more of a nice, laid back place. Homey, old school vibe. If you're looking for an out of the way place with a variety of food to make everyone happy, this is it.
author: Jen H.

description: I used to love and I mean LOVE coming here - I haven't been in over a year bc well, new baby = don't eat out much.  Apparently they've changed the menu and what feels like a crazy increase in their prices . . .some of the food is still decent (bread is killer) but other items have been changed so much that they aren't a favorite anymore.  Case in point, the fishwich, used to be this long, coleslaw filled piece of delicious heavenly fried fish, now, it's the same fried fish with a wee bit of LETTUCE slaw and bread, that's it.  There are other items gone from the menu that were favorites, I get it, rotate stuff but bummer, I miss them.  Lastly, who uses fine table salt for the rim of their margaritas!?!?  I used to think this bar had drinks that were yumm, now - I'll go somewhere else for the same price and better food.
author: Maria H.

description:
Ohhh The Old Clam House! My future husband brought me here on a date-day as a surprise. I was completely unaware of this amazing little gem and it's history. 

We sat on their little sun-porch and were greeted with a warm shot of "Clam Juice". Tentative, we picked up our glasses, gave a playful clink and down the hatch they went. To our delight, this clam juice was the most delightful BROTH I have ever tasted, briny, garlicy, oniony, clamy goodness! When our waiter came to take our order, we requested seconds!

My boyfriend and I decided to share the Mussel and Shrimp skillet (small). It was around $20. Also asked for bread (which you have to pay for as it is a large loaf made in house and SO WORTH IT) and of course we HAD to try their house-made clam chowder. 

Mussel and Shrimp Skillet: Packed full of mussels, drizzled with soy sauce right at the table and served with melted, garlic butter which I probably could have drank. Our seafood was cooked to perfection, fresh, tender, warm and salty. I would order this again in a heart beat.

Clam Chowder: Very chunky and packed full of clams. Flavorful. But did not "WOW" us. A very typical San Francisco clam chowder. 

This is one of the coolest spots J has taken me too in a long time. The history, the story, the food, the ambiance. A true San Francisco gem. I can't wait to share this place with my friends.
author: Meghan L.

description: Awesome and easy old-school spot. Good food, great service. Our new favorite seafood restaurant!
author: Catherine T.

description:
Restaurant is clean and inviting, wait service is fair.  
Food was really hit-or-miss.  Good: clam bisque, beet salad with crab.  Horiible: all the pasta dishes are soggy greasy messes.  Kitchen staff completly random - half our orders only showed up after repeatedly telling the waiter what was missing. Overall, I would not go back.
author: Jeffrey O.

description: Oldest restaurant in San Francisco and still going! The Cioppino is really good and the in-house beer served in a milk bottle is the best! Oh and the garlic bread... oh.. so... good.
author: Stella D.

description: I came here with my son for the first time last night at his recommendation (he's been here 5 times) and had a wonderful meal start to finish. Thumbs up to the kettle bread, stella on tap, crab cakes, mussel and shrimp sautee, cioppino, and tiramisu (yes, we ate all this!) The seafood was exceptionally fresh and perfectly seasoned. The crabcakes and tirimisu stand out as possibly the best I've ever had. Additionally, the wait service was professional and attentive. All in all a great evening, I can't wait to go back.
author: nanci c.

description: Seriously awesome food. My boyfriend and I had the garlic bread and the calamari to start. So good. My boyfriend was really pushing me to try the clam juice and I was so hesitant but I'm glad he did because I loved it! For our entrees we had the clams paella and the garlic noodles with shrimp. Everything was fresh and delicious. Both dishes were rich in flavor. I really recommend this place!! 10/10
author: Brenda R.

description: Best fish & chips I've ever had....light, tender...great presentation. I inhaled it. Even the tarter sauce was homemade and flavorful.... Decor beautifully retro. Crab cocktail was solid too. Dessert menu could have the volume turned up but I suppose it's not important given their focus.
author: J T.

description:
The Old Clam house is a historic restaurant located by the 101/280, exchange.  The restaurant has character, has lot of fishing tools on the walls to create an at-sea atmosphere.  As soon as you are seated they provide you with a shot glass of clam juice and bread with butter. 

The food is excellent, in the past I've ordered the crab enchiladas, and calamari.  This last visit we shared clams escargot, and I ordered sand dabs as an entree.  The clams had bread crumbs and garlic, and we ordered bread to sop up the flavored oil.  The sand dabs were cooked perfectly to go along with some Israeli couscous. 
The Old Clam house is a historic restaurant, and deserves the credit for being a great seafood place to enjoy a great meal.
author: Marlon T.

description: This spot is a favorite. A must try is the chorizo cheese bread and the pot of clams.  The portions are big so it's a great spot for sharing.  The chill bar area is great for casual dining and catching a game.  They also have a family style dinner area if you want the traditional restaurant experience.
author: Andrea S.

description:
So I use to love this place but recently I feel like the food isn't as good as it was the last time I visited (last year). I ordered an organic beet salad and it only came with 2 pieces of lettuce, cheese that didn't taste fresh, and a good amount of beets but it's not a "salad" as they claim. The clam chowder use to be so freaking good but the past 2 times I had it, I can feel the grit of the dirty clam pieces in my soup. The soup use to be very clean and had no nasty pieces of grit. I don't want to feel like I am breaking my teeth when I eat the little pieces. The only reason why I am giving a 2 star is because the bread bowl that came with my soup was delicious and fresh. I don't think I will be visiting this place anymore because of how much of a lack in quality there is. 
Also the last time I came, the server ignored my table and she didn't even check to see if we liked the food or needed an extra water jug. She was checking everyone's table but ours and I still have no idea why. The service has been sh*tty and it wasn't very busy where we were eating as well.
author: Star S.

description: Good atmosphere and service, but pretty overpriced.  I don't recommend ordering oysters at the Clam House, they're the size of clams and $3 EA.  That along with my cocktail and rock in my cioppino was all fairly disappointing.
author: Lysle T.

description: Mmm...dont do the thanksgiving dinner here. Did. We wont again.. 103 dollars for that cheap plate?   Live n learn..we used to go twice a month..then once every three months and then once a year...now thats out...oh well.
author: David W.

description:
I don't remember when I gave a one star review, maybe was a while. This place definitely did not meet those exaggerated expectations flamed by a thrilist article on the best clam chowder bowls in San Francisco, Google and yelp reviews. The chowder was:
1. Disgusting (tasted like it was microwaved and couple days old).
2. Their "fresh" sourdough bowl "baked daily" was not fresh, but dry and old. 
3. Overpriced and overhyped. Should have went to fisherman's wharf and fixed myself a $5-6 meaty, creamy and fresh clam chowder bowl.
What an unpleasant experience it was.
author: Vladimir G.

description: Eh... overpriced. Our server was nice and fast but tried to rush us out before we finished our drinks. Food is better at Red Lobster :( that pains me soooo much to say-- we live in the area and thought it would be a nice local cozy dinner out. My $10 Caesar salad was so pitiful. Only 2 croutons and no bread. My crab cakes for $17 were two tiny patties barely enough as an appetizer. Extra 5% added to the bill for "operating expenses"---OK... they said that on their website so we knew...  but plus extra charge for bread (the best part by far!) and then the tip... we left totally sad and underwhelmed. Really sorry to report.
author: Jennifer Z.

description: The food was amazing!!! We had the clam chowerd, crab enchiladas, fish and chips. The fish fry and a little over fried.  The service was pretty good, our waitress forgot a couple things but really was not a big deal.
author: Megan L.

description:
Old School San Francisco at its best! It's places like this that make me love this city even more than I thought possible.

I liked coming here on a slower weeknight, because I would imagine it can get pretty busy. After being surprised by the complimentary warm clam juice (trust me, it's the bomb! Just think soup. It's really more of a broth, but I digress) My friend and I decided to order the chorizo bread, ciopinno for 1, and the fish fry to split. When everything came out, I thought we might have overestimated our abilities! However, everything was so delicious, it ended up not even being an issue. Apparently, it's the oldest restaurant at the same location in SF (1851), and it has been lovingly maintained, making its charm-o-meter go though the roof. 

The fish is so fresh and delicious, even fried, it never felt too heavy. The Ciopinno was excellent as well....and the chorizo bread?! whoever invented that should be up for sainthood!

I can't wait to bring all my seafood-loving friends and family, because it really is the kind of place you want to share with people to make sure they experience. Also, I want to come back myself and try everything on the menu!
author: Caddy M.

description:
A classic establishment with super rich food. We tried the cioppino and the shrimp and mussel skillet. Both were great, especially on a chilly July evening.

The real charm of this place is that it's has been around for over 100 years and it looks the part. Parking in the back alley is a little sketch, but we made it out without any broken windows or slashed tires.
author: Colt S.

description:
I can't believe what a nosedive this place has taken.  Three of us for lunch mid-week, and we were given the worst service ever in spite of the fact that there were only 3 other tables taken when we arrived.
You are first "greeted" with a sign that says seat yourself.  Two sides to choose from for seating when it would be better if only one was open when there are so few people there.  The server, a woman, never welcomed us, never even smiled, and didn't seem to want to have us there.  She was very annoyed.
I wanted to get up and leave.  Because it was a chore to find parking, walk through a disgustingly smelly neighborhood, and go inside we continued on.
Asking questions about the menu annoyed the server.  She rushed us through our meal, which
was actually a Godsend since this was such a bad experience.  This woman is tired and
demonstrated over and over that she hated her job.  We shouldn't have left a tip, but there
was a busser who probably depends on her to split the tip., if she even does that.
The food has also taken a nosedive.  Crab sandwich came with absolutely no side - they are extra, and very little crab in the sando.  Fish & chips turned out to be one unidentifiable long piece of battered fish, fried to a chocolate brown color, and slapped on top of some fries that hardened into a big greasy mess.
The prices are outrageous for what you get.  They charge for some bread that everywhere else is complimentary, even if you're having a salad or other entrée.  
We did not have any drinks from the bar, only water which they did not charge for. 
The "atmosphere" is outdated, not on purpose I'm sure. 
 I'm sorry we went there. I'm hoping I can forget how awful this was.  Never again!  There are so many other better historical restaurants in San Francisco in decent neighborhoods.
Never Again!!!!!
author: Kathleen C.

description:
Had the Cioppino  for lunch and I was totally satisfied. I'd recommend that. The bread was really good as well. For dessert the rum cake was great. 

The atmosphere here is great. Tons of old pictures of when the restaurant was opened in the late 1800's and early 1900's. A lot of history on the walls. 

Really liked this place a lot.
author: Chris V.

description: The food was okay. The service was lacking. There wasn't enough wait staff. The food was overpriced especially considering what part of town it is located. We were literally robbed. Our car window was smashed and literally thousands of dollars worth of personal property was stolen.
author: Lisa B.

description: What ever happened to the Pasta Con Comarones (spell Check)?? (Huge breaded prawns on a bed of noodles covered in delicious creamy white sauce).... my wife and I use to love this place and their menu... things sure have changed... (for the worse)
author: Danny Q.

description: This is an amazing kitschy adorable delicious place. Free clam juice is awesome. The $1 bread is baked in an iron pan and is amazing. Garlic noodles are greasy AND delicious. Cioppino will warm your soul. Go here. You won't regret it.
author: Makiko H.

description:
I was so excited to try this place, reading about the chowder and steamed clams made me excited! I got a bowl of chowder, first bite, it was barely warm!! I asked doe my soup to be reheated...Bad sign when your chowder is cold. 15 minutes later I got it and I was disappointed. It was super grainy and thick like they pureed a bunch of potatoes into it. Ok flavors but it was more a potato soup than clam chowder. We got beet salad also, that was real good.

ONE HOUR LATER...after I purposely made a loud comment that they forgot about us the hostess came over and asked us if we wanted more clam juice...uh we never got any in the first place! We sat for an hour no food, no service. Our waiter offered us a free drink, which I took!

Food finally came the clam stew was good but the clam linguini, the noodles were cold and dry, it has obviously been sitting. It pretty much tasted the same as the clam stew but with noodles. We were so hungry, we ate it all then waited...waited...we started timing how long it woukd take for anyone to check up on us. We were the only people in a empty room for a good 15 minutes after we were done. We got a desert menu. I decided forget it, I didn't want to wait anymore. We had to walk to oir waiter to pay for the bill. 

Positives, there were a few good dishes, beet salad, clam juice, steamed clams ok. 

Fyi they charge for bread, no thanks.
author: Karen T.

description:
HOTDIGGITYCLAM... HOTDIGGITYDAMN...
(3.9 stars)

I came in hungry and healthy AND left feeling full, extremely bloated, with diabetes, gout, and high blood pressure. Just Kidding but not really!! Sodium overload, THEY AREN'T STINGY WITH THE SODIUM.

- FOOD, tasty
- PRICES, bit pricier then the average
- SERVICE, ok
- AMBIANCE, vintage


You go to a clam house FOR CLAMS!!! Coming from the Pacific Northwest, I'll be the judge if the clams were worth it. Seated immediately in a booth with curtains and was quickly served the complimentary claim juice shots with bread and butter. 

HEFER STATUS.

MAC MURRAY ($34/bottle) - Have to hit the red bottle of wine!! This Pinot Noir went down smooth and had some really light notes, bolder at the end. Wine and seafood goes hand and hand.

CLAM JUICE SHOTS (free) - It doesn't sound too good at all but it was very good. It was this warm clam broth in a shot glass. **WARNING** very salty. Dipping the buttered bread will help that. We had asked for seconds because it was good.

STEAMED CLAMS ($16.95) - Came out in this big pot, two toasted slices of bread, and alot of clams in a light green broth with some lemon wedges. The broth is with white wine and it was SO SALTY, good but salty. I had to dilute the broth with some  of my ice water and squirted the lemon wedge and throw the lemon wedges in the broth for the acidity to balance the saltiness out. After that, it was OMG GOOD. My manila clams were perfectly cooked. 

CLAM CHOWDER ($5.95) - Dipped into my company's clam chowder to just "try it". UHM, NOT THE BEST CLAM CHOWDER. The chowder had a dark color and it kind of tasted sweet?! I've had WAY BETTER chowder elsewhere. I don't recommend this.

HOUSE SALAD - Loved their salad because they had pumpkin seeds. I love pumpkin seeds, great taste and texture.

CHOCOLATE TRUFFLE MOUSSE CAKE - sweet and rich. I could only take a few bites and then got sick of it pretty fast. it was good with the whip cream, helped balance out the sweet tooth.

BLOOD ORANGE MARGARITA ($6.95) - Patron in my margarita was perfect. Love blood oranges and this was a very tasty and great margarita. It didn't look like the classic margarita with the salted rim, just looked like a "fruity" drink but definitely tasted like a margarita. 

Will I be back? Yes, I'd like to come back for more clams.

Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
just had dinner.  
First off we were served hot clam juice (soup like) then came hot bread with butter in a cast iron. we Ordered Seafood Linguine and Crab Enchilada, both delicious, cooked in cast iron.  
Generous portions prices are $24.99 and $19.99. 
We've plenty of left overs for work lunch. 
Ambience is antique with old SF pictures and memorabilia.
author: Jen O.

description:
The city's oldest restaurant, ey? Well that's a restaurant definitely worth visiting. The old photos on the restaurant walls depict the restaurant's long history. 

I came here with family and we enjoyed the fresh seafood we had. We ordered from the prix fixe menu which I thought was a pretty good deal. 

At the beginning of the meal, a lil' cup of clam juice comes out with the bread and butter. It's a nice, warm and salty teaser to wake up your taste buds, although I don't recall finding any clam bits in my juice. 

Our table did share an order of the calamari which was good but oddly, included battered and fried lemon slices. Something different I guess. 

I had a cup of clam chowder next which was tasty but surprisingly thick, as if the soup itself was thickened with mashed potatoes. 

For my entree, I had the cioppino which had an ample amount of mussels and clams with smaller amounts of shrimp and squid and lastly, one crab claw. The broth was flavorful and the stew was topped with two slices of crusty bread, perfect for dipping in the broth. 

My family shared dessert including the tiramisu and the lemon torta della nonna, both served with whipped cream. I was pleasantly surprised by the tiramisu which was delicious. Lemon lovers would definitely enjoy the torta della nonna.  

Service could have been warmer (the hostess wasn't very friendly and I said hi before she did, and our waiter did his job but nothing beyond that). 

We parked behind the restaurant in an alley but there is also street parking on Bayshore.
author: Maya S.

description:
The ambiance is great. Old location, matching vintage decor and uniforms, friendly staff (though not always attentive), decent food (one dimensioned, nothing really stood out).

The portions are out of this world, but with mediocre food, it doesnt seem to really go anywhere.

Get the crab enchiladas! The clam mac and cheese and cioppino were underwhelming.
author: Judy L.

description:
The allure of the oldest operating restaurant in the city is strong. Walking in the door, the historic photos coupled with the walls crooked from settling over the 150+ years of operation create the ambience you would expect from such an historic location.

Unfortunately, that allure quickly fades when you find yourself paying gourmet prices for average meals. In the few times I've been there I've never gotten anything I didn't like, but nor have I got anything that was exceptional. If you are just looking for great seafood, I'd recommend elsewhere where the quality is better. If you are just looking for good seafood, I'd go elsewhere where the prices were better.
author: Ross D.

description:
My original birthday dinner plans failed because we showed up to the place and they were closed for the evening. Thankfully, Yelp led me here- a place I've frequently passed, but never thought of visiting.
I always thought that this place would be dark/damp and have a lot of older clientele. But, much to my surprise, there were a range of clientele here, younger/older couples, families, etc. and the place was really bright! 
We were immediately seated in a "booth" (I think you could close the curtains to your table?) and within minutes, the hostess hands us clam juice shots! A great way to start the meal. It was hot, briny and salty, just flavorful.
Once we looked over the extensive menu (and because I'm a visual person, I had to check out Yelp user's photos) we finally decided on our order.
For appetizers, we got our usual calamari.
I opted for the steamed clams, hubby got the grill plate with crab and shrimps. The kids got shrimp and linguine and clams and of course pasta and cheese. Surprising, our waitress brought us samples of the clam chowder because we told her that it was first time there. My first thoughts were that it was creamy and had a lot of texture. There was definitely a great ratio of clams just in the small serving.
And of course we had to get the bread (for .95 cents extra. Our waitress made sure to let us know that it was an extra charge.) haha! We ordered 2 servings of it because we couldn't get enough of that crunchy, yeasty bread. 


Our food definitely came out quickly. A plus is that our food was piping hot!!! Like, super hot! Just picking it up with my fingers hurt. 
Although I'm somewhat allergic to crab, that didn't stop me from having a leg (or 2). What I loved was the butter!!!  It was rich, creamy and just delicious!!! I'd be able to pour/dip anything in it! The crab meat was sweet and delectable.
I enjoyed everything here. We even tried the chocolate mouse and strawberry cheesecake dessert. Nothing to rave about, but it helped my sweet tooth.

The only downside is that the food was a little pricey. All the waitstaff was prompt, and our waitress showed excellent service. Definitely a place to come and visit when you're looking to go somewhere special.
author: Mimie L.

description:
Very fresh whole clam chowder.
Love the bread.
Excellent service and nice old restaurant established for more than a century
author: Dustin T.

description:
4 Stars because it was the right place at the right time!

Went in on a weekday night, Oysters & Crab were great....,. throw in a glass of White Wine... Perfect!

Not a huge buzz there as far as peep's but the serive & the food was realy, really good.

Worth giving it a try!
author: Michael P.

description:
We recently went here to celebrate my husband's birthday.  We had a couple of cocktails, clam chowder, and cioppino for two with the pan roasted house bread.  The meal was great and we want to go back.  

The chowder was second to none.  The cioppino was tasty and filling.  The bread was rustic first class.  The cocktails were rather weak.  Next time we'll probably get a pitcher of draft beer instead.

The parking was rather difficult and the neighborhood is "industrial", but adequately lit at night.
author: Susan C.

description:
Very good seafood linguini and house bread ("kettle bread").

Average calamari.

Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Delicious!! Found this place on a list of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco. Decided to try it for dinner and it was fabulous. First off, the wait staff were super attentive and so kind. I order a glass of wine, cup of clam chowder, some bread, and 1/2 crab and tiramisu to go for desert. 

Every item was impeccably prepared and absolutely delicious!! The chowder was some of the best I have ever had and the butter on the crab was sensational. 

Would highly recommend going to this place as it has history, great customer service, and delicious food!!
author: Katie T.

description:
The Old Clam House is definitely an SF institution. A great place to come to experience some old SF nostalgia! I've been coming here since the late 80's. Over the years, I've had breakfast, lunch & dinner. Menu selection is good and the food is generally good. My usual has always been the steamed clams...but I guess like a lot of other things over the years it seems like the clams & portions have gotten smaller. But at least the taste is still the same...(after all it is Steamed Clams). 

On a recent visit for dinner (it had been a few years since my last visit) I was surprised to find that they charge xtra for bread...not thrilled about that...even though it's "homemade." I would recommend sitting in the bar area for the decor...it's really cool & you really feel like your back in the "good old days" of San Francisco. Parking is not easy and the farther you park away just be aware of your surroundings especially at night. Overall just a fun & great SF experience.
author: Rich H.

description:
My father was visiting from out of state and we decided go here because my boyfriend had been here during lunch and thought it was a unique spot claiming to be SFs oldest restaurant. Initially entering the restaurant I liked the ambiance. Its walls are full of history and victorian character.

So after ordering we get a small shooter of clam juice. I asked our server about it because my family was unsure of it and the server was curt and answered me as if I was stupid for not knowing the tradition of it or what to do.  I tried to brush it off but throughout the evening she seemed bothered and at one point decided to not come by after the food was served and finally came by when we had to call her from across the room to get the check. My family was extremely disappointed. For service I give a 0!

The food on the otherhand was very tasty. My father got the individual cioppino which could have been split between two people. It was his first time ever having the dish and enjoyed it a lot. The tomato broth was rich and the seafood fixings on point. I glanced at another table and saw a sizzling plate of mussels, defintiely intrigued me enough to want to come back despite the service. For the food I give a 4. 

Too bad my customer experience with the server was terrible otherwise my review would of been higher. If i come back i'll update and hopefully have a better time overall.
author: Cindy M.

description:
First time back since the Stinking Rose folks took over.

I did the $15 Prix Fixe. You choose cup of clam chowder or salad and choice of Single Crab Enchilada, Shrimp Scampi, Chicken Milanese or Calamari Steak Dore. There is a $25 option with a more extensive choices like Sand Dabs, Sizzling Crab legs, Cioppino, and Filet Mignon. I chose Shrimp Scampi.

First out was bread with clam broth (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-old-clam-house-san-francisco?select=UlPrZuzdX1kiosDWuVuJvg#UlPrZuzdX1kiosDWuVuJvg). They might put crack in this as this stuff is addictive.

Cup of clam chowder is nice and thick with plenty of tender clams (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-old-clam-house-san-francisco?select=qpxOUo0yunZvjmiwbcag9w#qpxOUo0yunZvjmiwbcag9w).

The scampi comes with couscous mixed with sun-dried tomatoes and green beans (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-old-clam-house-san-francisco?select=qpxOUo0yunZvjmiwbcag9w#74hZ1SdwHTzM2Yq7ptsdqA). I liked it. Maybe a dozen smallish shrimp which were nice and tender and some crispiness from, I'm guessing, being lightly floured and pan seared before adding the garlicky butter sauce. The crispiness was different, but maybe I don't eat enough scampi.

The g/f got the Shrimp Louie ($17 tomatoes, beets, onions, olives & egg, also available with crab or chicken http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-old-clam-house-san-francisco?select=w1iNAj3QBE_G-3wyYlv2Tw#w1iNAj3QBE_G-3wyYlv2Tw). Egg was over-boiled and a little chalky. Other than that, it was a good rendition. Beets & olives veered from tradition, but added good flavor to the dish.
author: Andrew C.

description:
GF and I split a couples cioppino $50, the portion is enough for three. Unfortunately we weren't impressed with the sauce (lacking anything except a generic marinara flavor) and the temperature which was a few degrees under boiling. The potatoes, carrots,and corn are an unwelcome addition also. I'd have been happier with a smaller portion of delicious cioppino over the giant seafood stew they currently serve.

If we came back it wouldn't be for the cioppino! Don't trust the good reviews about it.

The bread was delicious and the .95 price tag did not bother me. 

Also the lack of a corkage fee is awesome.
author: Jim W.

description: Loved this place! Quaint, funky, been there forever. Menu is huge and a food lovers paradise. Everything we ordered, fish and chips, mussels, clams, cioppino, all yum. The chorizo cheese bread was weird but I warned my friend not to order meat at a seafood restaurant. All in all a really fun, delicious slice of history.
author: stephanie c.

description: We were lucky and got a last minute reservation for 8pm on Mother's Day. The place was very packed at 7:50 but we were promptly seated in the side room that is brightly lit by the windows on Bayshore and Oakdale Blvd. Our poor server, John, was sweating so much because he had 8 tables to himself and some were large parties. Most were waiting to pay and he just couldn't get to them fast enough. We ordered and then they brought out the Kettle Bread. Our food quickly rolled out one at a time. We shared a Chop Chop Salad which wasn't very good followed by a delicious bread bowl of Clam Chowder. We had just wanted a bowl without the bread but oh wells. The chowder was great with chucks of clams and potatoes and it was served piping hot, just the way I like soup. We didn't get our drinks until after the soup and we had to ask the bus boy who then brought us our beer and wine. Once we saw the table next to us have the Combo Iron Skillet of Mussels, Shrimp and Crab, we had to have the same thing. It was so so finger licking good...very nicely prepared, hot, fresh and flavorful. And like that table, we had to also ask for crab crackers while another table asked for silverware after they got their salad. The service was not that attentive  because John was simply swamped but the kitchen had it going on. We were done eating within 50 minutes of us sitting our butts in our seats. And another plus was the friendliness and efficiency of the bussers.
author: Jen L.

description:
We only had the cioppino for 2, which came in a GIANT kettle pot.  I am sworn to Sotto Mare's but this is probably one of the better one's that I've had in a while.  The broth is rich and thicker than what I'm used to and there is no pasta.  We had so much left over, we decided we could've had the single serving. The bread was good but it would've been better warm.  

The cheesecake dessert was literally like a cake with cheesecake in it, fluffier than a traditional cheesecake.  Tiramisu was not bad. 

The building itself is really interesting and the old details are well-maintained.  I didn't get to sit in one of the cool booths, but probably next time. The service was great - friendly and attentive.  

I minus a star because of the location in an industrial area. Our guests from out-of-town showed up and were disappointed that there wasn't too much to see in the area.
author: Trish P.

description:
Don't order da turf when you in da surf, man. Know what I'm sayin'? I made a big mistake the first time Jamie W. and I visited exactly a year ago. Big. Huge. I ordered the Prime Rib, and it was lousy. What was I thinking? It was such a devastating experience that we didn't return for nearly a year when I was browsing for places that were offering a Thanksgiving dinner. Sure enough, the Old Clam House offered a three-course dinner for the bargain-basement price of $29.95. Jamie and I tried it and thought it was pretty good even though it wasn't exactly "surf". We received a double header of a Dinner Salad and a cup of their Clam Chowder.

The chowder was still thick and still full of fresh clams (see photo). Delicious and never in need of the oyster crackers. The Turkey breast slices were good, not great, with a generous ladle of gravy, a side of moist Stuffing, a small cup of Cranberry Relish, and a half-dozen of their famous Smushed Dutch Creamer Potatoes (see photo). A slice of Pumpkin Pie finished the meal in a pleasing manner, but I still felt my original three-star rating stood. Flash forward to New Year's Day 2013, exactly one year after the prime rib debacle. But Jamie loved his Fish and Chips the first time out, so we're back and me with a bit of trepidation.

This time we both went all-clam with our meals. Jamie went for the $14.95 combination of the Clam Chowder and the Clam Po'boy Sandwich (see photos). what was funny was that the waitress came out with the Clam Chowder first, and another server came out with another bowl of it with the sandwich on the same plate. But in an ironic twist of fate, Jamie doused the first bowl with more hot sauce than he anticipated and basically made that one inedible. The Lord giveth and the Lord taketh away. While the sandwich was chock full of fried clams, it was too much for Jamie who thought it a bit too chewy compared to crab.

Nonetheless, he devoured it. I decided to go full gonzo on one of their $24.95 Prix Fixe Dinners since it appeared to be quite a good deal. First came the Clam Chowder, and then my entree, which was literally a large cast-iron saucepan filled with a house specialty, the Clams Paella Acini. Finally we have a winner. Bathing luxuriantly in a thick, hearty cioppino sauce, the plentiful clams were mixed with bites of Italian sausage, black olives and melted cheese atop the acini, tiny beads of pasta softened nicely in the sauce (see photo). Crusty sourdough bread that came out throughout the meal was the perfect absorption vehicle. I get it now. You order clams for the main, too.

That was plenty enough food, certainly plenty enough clams. But I get a dessert with my meal. Oh darn. Despite the lure of tiramisu and chocolate truffle mousse cake, I thought Jamie and I could share a slice of Italian Wild Strawberry Cheesecake. Ooops, I forgot that we weren't at the Cheesecake Factory. It was a big enough slice, but it definitely came out of the icebox with a congealed strawberry preserve on top and strawberry slices suspended inside. It was drizzled with more strawberry jam and came with a dollop of whipped cream that tasted like Reddi Wip (not that it was a bad thing - see photo). Clearly cafeteria fare, but we still wiped it up in minutes. Auld lang syne, Old Clam House.

FOOD - 4 stars...that tasty clams paella could serve a little league team all of whom must be residing in my stomach
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...still a Barbary Coast saloon, probably a C-ticket if it was in Disneyland
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...two bowls of clam chowder for one...I'm down with that
TOTAL - 4 stars...oh I get it now...you eat clams at the Old Clam House...another star for you
author: Ed U.

description: The shot of clam juice is 5 stars all the way. The fish and chips could feed an army. Portions are huge! Garlic noodles and spaghetti are delicious. Solid quirk spot off the beaten path. I'll be back!
author: Justin Y.

description: I've been coming to the Old Clam House for more than 30+ years, watched it go from one owner to another. They rebuild it, but I can say the food has always been to my liking. Im yelping tonight because of an unexpected experience. Due to the cold weather, my husband and I stopped in for a clam chowder. The waiter was courteous as always. When the chowders were served, I added 4 drops of the hot sauce which is a habit to me. I must say it was a mistake. It burned my lips and when I read the label it stated it was called "Liquid Stoopid". The waiter offered to call the Manager and I agreed. I discussed the matter with Dennis, and he thought I was just asking for it to be taken off the bill. I suggested to him that it was not the point of the bill,  but that the establishment should remove this hot sauce from tables and offer mild, medium and hot sauce. This is a dangerous substance especially for kids. Please consider my advice.
author: maxine m.

description: The service was great, The amuse voucher of clam broth was a nice surprise. I was excited about the cioppino, while seafood was plentiful the seasoning was lacking.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Some folks are unhappy, but their problem is the wholesale cost of seafood these days, and the requirements to provide family leave and paid sick leave to employees.  The place is FABULOUS as to its history and tradition, the bar is cool.  I've loved the food I've had here, but yes its pricey.
author: David H.

description:
Sadly, I no longer like the Old Clam House.  I've gone here a few times a year for about 15 years and always loved it.  I went for the clams.  Big, delicious, steamed clams.

It's been about a year since I stopped in and I was dismayed to find that the steamed clams they serve are now the tiny manila clams as opposed to the larger clams they used to serve.  Very disappointing to find this out.  This was one of the few places in town where you could get large steamed clams.

On the plus side I loved the roasted Dungeness crab and the bloody mary's are great but for me it's all about the clams.  The Old Clam House is off my list.  :(
author: Bob S.

description: Fun, relaxed, cheerfully old-school and gimmicky little food spot with friendly and relaxed guests, good homey food, and fun decor. The giant clam on top of the roof of the restaurant is matched with sea-themed interiors and wooden booths in one room or you can eat in the bar area and watch the sports screens in the other room. They have a full bar, decent house wine, reasonable prices, delicious apps (the chorizo bread is amazing!), and easy main courses ranging from fried fish (average) to crab sandwiches (yum!). Don't expect anything fancy, come here when you're in a relaxed, social mood and fancy some good old fishy cooking!
author: Nik Y.

description:
The Old Clam House.. .been going there for years. It was one of my folks favorite San Francisco restaurants back in the day!  They've gone through a couple of ownerships but I still see they are still cranking out great service and food.

On a Sunday 12:00 afternoon, my family decided to have lunch here. Table for 11.
We ordered a pitcher of Bellini's for adults, Pellegrino water for the kids.  We started with the kettle bread. Of course immediately came out, each a piping cup of New England Clam Chowder, chunks of potatoes & clams, SOOO GOOD!!  I ordered for lunch a Shrimp Louis. It was humungeous!  Usually, places give you too much lettuce, the Clam House seemed like it didn't give enough. Too much tomatoes that I couldn't even finish. But it was Delicious, with a smooth, creamy and  not too dressed dressing.  Shrimp was plentiful & plump. My family had various different dishes, my sister had the Crab Louie, my brother shared this huge platter with my brother-in-law called Lotsa Crab, I think it was a pound of crab. The kids (I mean teens) had Fish & Chips, they sure do have hearty appetites, they eat as much as adults now!  And my cousin & her husband both had some kind of pasta seafood dish that looked fabulous!

Service was excellent. Food came out of the kitchen with perfect timing. Our server was polite and friendly.

I split a Tiramisu with my sister. The twins had a dessert called a Chocolate Bomb, which they loved!

Happy with our lunch here, as it's been a couple of years now.  So many restaurants...so little time (and $) LOL.
author: Janet T.

description: I love coming here. Double mussels double crab is the way to go. Service is always good too.
author: B-rad R.

description:
This place is more of a 3.5 star. 

Came here with the BF on Valentine's Day and had a reservation but still had to wait a little over 30 minutes to get seated so we went to the bar to grab a drink while we waited. We ordered the large skillet with mussels and shrimp, the lotsa crab and garlic noodles. We loved the mussels and will definitely order again but will pass on the shrimp. The shrimp was super small and not very tasty. But the lotsa crab was to die for... So fresh and tasty and the portion was huge and the crab was so meaty. Probably one of the best crabs I have ever had. The garlic noodles were mediocre and very greasy and just not what I would call garlic noodles. 

Will definitely come back for the mussels and crab. Service was great and they do give you a shot of clam juice to try which was actually pretty good.
author: Daisy W.

description: Love this place. The warm clam juice they give you is like a consommé. I came here two days in a row for lunch. The Louis Salad with Crab is fresh and delicious. The Fish and Chips are fried to perfection. The bread is has a crunchy crust and a wonderfully soft interior. Other reviewers who are not specific and use profanity are not to be listened to. Some other grudge I suppose. I dine all over the world. I will make it back here every time I come to SF. Its off the beaten path for tourists. Its old school and thats what I love about it.
author: Mark B.

description: We moved to the neighborhood recently and love this joint. Must sit at the bar with Judy!!! Who doesn't love a local. Clam chowder with clam broth is a must. Apparently it's a 100 year old tradition.
author: Gabriela H.

description: Very cool place in the heart of SF. Was here for the weekend taking my wife out for her birthday.  Pleasant staff nice menu. Delicious food. I'll try that place again!
author: Patrick R.

description:
3.5 stars 

Came here for dinner with the family. Made reservations in advance so we skipped the long wait time during dinner hour.  Dishes we ordered:

Double mussels and crab - pricy for what is is.. But roasted nicely and very tasty. Wish there was more in the offering!

Cioppino - thick fish stew with lots of veggies, calamari, clams, mussels and a few crab legs. Pretty delicious. The crab legs didn't taste very fresh, that was my only gripe. 

Seabass with lemon garlic sauce - husband liked this dish a lot. Fish was fresh and plump. The couscous on the side was okay. 

Garlic noodles with crab - great noodles done just right, slightly small portion. But very tasty. 

Ambiance was like the place next door and very cozy. Parking was easy outside. Place was packed for Saturday night dinner. Fun place for large groups. 

For 3 people and couple glasses of wine and $8 fries for the kid.. About $180. It was pricey for what it was, but I feel a lot of that pricing is for the namesake of the place and less of the food. 

They also own Dead Fish in Rodeo and that place was much better in terms of how the food was done - $180 there would have been worth it. The menu is near same.
author: Nancy H.

description: Food and. service was wonderful! Clam chowder & cioppino to die for! Zack our server was awesome!
author: Robin C.

description: Pretty nice decor and a lot of history on the walls.  Clam juice shot rocked and I had another one. Dang.  Ordered clam chowder and it's not like the typical all white you see everywhere else but it hit the spot and it ranks in my top three and it's loaded with clams.  Next up is the mussels and shrimp pot and it's awesome great garlic flavor   My friend got a crab sandwich it's a footling and loaded with crab. Great food 4 stars due to price but a 25 lunch is a rarity but you get what you pay for and service was excellent.
author: Tony B.

description:
Overpriced and horrible  food! !!!
The old clam house was fantastic.  The new ownership ruined it. In the words of Chef  Ramsey, "Fuck off this place!"
Save your money
author: Laurie W.

description:
Clam juice is pretty tasty with chopped green onions, just like Taiwanese traditional soup without ginger. 
We ordered sea bass and salmon which were all good. Colorful veggie were pretty fresh with higher quality than other restaurants'.
Parking was a problem. That area wasn't safe for me, either.
author: Trudy L.

description:
I don't know why this place has only 3.5 stars. the food was AMAZING!  The service was GREAT! And my friends' drinks were EXCELLENT!  

The four of us shared clam escargots, couples cioppino, fish and chips, and garlic bread. Everything was just beyond tasty. Our waiter was very nice and attentive. The decor was super charming. 

Everyone should come and try it!
author: William L.

description: My husband and I love the clam juice & bread here. It's very good. This place is a city Classic in our minds. Also, their cioppino is the best I have ever had! It's not too oily, not too thick, and not too thin. Not over spiced, not under spiced. It's just perfect. They also have such a hearty serving size and serve quality seafood within the dish. Always large pieces of shellfish and mollusks. Good cioppino is a hit and miss. I hardly order it at other places because most of the time it's a miss, unfortunately.
author: Krista B.

description: We had just flown into town and wanted to try something we never had before. I would say I'm extremely disappointed. Our server had about 10 tables to take care so even though she was nice she barely came to our table. We had to wait for a long time for refills, our food, for boxes (asked 2 different people for them), and a check (total of over an hour and a half). It wasn't even that busy. The food was bland. Overall not a great way to start our first day in San Francisco. Plus they had "Animal Kingdom" playing on the tvs... which had naked people on it about 3 times. I work in the industry and was looking forward to going here from other people referring it. I'm sad to say I will not return nor refer it to anyone. :(
author: Daphne S.

description:
Ye Old Clam House has been thru a lot of changes over the years, but you  are not going to do better in that neck of the woods for straight ahead authentic seafood- It's old world , a bit on the pricey side but ooo soo tasty. The interior is sectioned off into three areas I liked the bar dining room, but the one one the left side has those oh so cozy booths. And then there is the enclosed "patio" room, kind of out there mainly for crowded evenings. Big screens all around for your sport viewing pleasure. 
The classic dish you MUST  try, we were informed by the waiter , is one of the various Hot Iron Skillet dishes.
Dinner started off nicely with the crusty soft bread and shot of warm clam juice which is for dipping the bread into. The Hot Iron Skillet Roasted Shrimp with Mussels (Medium - $16.95) arrived on a sizzling platter and was doused in a buttery seasoning. The dozen  shrimp and dozen mussels were cooked just right, nice and tender. We had garlic noodles with dungie crab- it could have used a bit more crab meat , but the dish was good. The wine list complimented the seafood and any joint that has Trumer Pils on tap is alright in my book. Service was spot on too. A nice 'n tasty conversation piece of SF history, definitely off the beaten track, even if the neighborhood can be a bit sketch.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Get the clam chowder! It's very delicious!

I'm not sure if it was the rain that made my visit very enjoyable or the clam chowder here is just very delicious!

It was pouring rain and we weren't going to drive all the way to Fisherman's Wharf to grab some clam chowder, so a friend told us that there was one just right down the street from the house. Which was great news to us! 

They brought out bread and CLAM JUICE while we waited for our food. I've never had this before so when I drank a sip of it, I wanted to spit it out almost immediately. It just wasn't something I wanted to swallow down! 

We didn't order anything else because our mission was to get some clam chowder (for me), so we ordered two bowl. I thought that it was going to be served in a bread bowl, it wasn't! The clam chowder alone was amazing though! There was so much clams and the portion served was a lot! To be honest, a bowl would've been enough for the two of us to share. It's alright, I have some left overs that I'll enjoy later on tonight!.

Parking is terrible so you better hope that there's parking in front when you get there! :)
author: Elena K.

description: In a nutshell, people are missing out on this joint if they ignore it for not being a 4/5 star joint.  Came in for a late lunch with some family, not as crowded being that it was 130pm on a friday afternoon.  Server dude was laid back and helpful when we needed him.  Foodwise, the combo skillet was delicious, cioppino was okay (less soupy, more dense, good for dipping).  chowder was also good.  the skillet bread stands out.  i mean, amazeballs.  at  less than a buck a loaf it was the perfect dipping and tearing bread.  they also give you a shot of hot clam juice too for each diner, which was delicious to sip on, even better to dip your bread into.  Oh yeah, the combo skillet came with 2 different melted butter dips, which is freakin heaven in a tin cup.  i think one was a crab butter, the other i dunno, lol but both dips with the fresh bread was amazing.  I could totally subsist on fresh skillet bread and butter.  Make the trip here, with the history behind it, great bread and butter, its worthy of a trip!
author: Chon T.

description:
Love the decor, warm setting - looks like a fun place for tourists and locals.
Parking is limited.  Area it is located can be a concern.  Bread is very good.  Ordered was place quickly but the time to wait for our food Service is extremely slow.  Waitress never informed us how long for the wait.  Almost 40 mins later  our food a cup of soup, and a sandwich finally arrived.  How long does that take to prepare!?

If you are in a time crunch I would seriously reconsider. Price is $$
Menu choice is limited
Waitress is nice -she checks on us periodically. Not planning to come back anytime soon.
author: Darlene H.

description: Good food. Good atmosphere.  Locals place for great seafood in SF.  I like this place.
author: Javier R.

description: This place is a must eat at when in San Francisco. We had thanksgiving dinner here this year. It was a mob scene but the staff had us seated within ten minutes of our original reservation. We went both traditional (full turkey dinner for $39.95) and zuppa de pesce ($29.95). Presentation was impressive but more importantly, everything was delicious. The service was great. Wasn't overly thrilled about the 4.5% cost of overhead surcharge, but the prices were quite reasonable when compared to many of the other turkey day options.  Makes sense why they have been in business so long.
author: Kathleen C.

description:
Loved the old school decor and history.
$35 for very small overly breaded and overly deep fried crab cakes(2), a bowl of avg chowder and beer at lunch!. On top of that the owner collects an additional 4% for gov mandates on all checks. Huh?
Poor value. Avoid!

Thanks for your response Dennis.
Just to further elaborate. I actually had a cup of soup, not a bowl.

My impression of the rather small crab cakes is that they were machine made with a rather heavy outer breading and a heavy garlic olio. The sauce was so powerful, no one would have a clue if they were eating Dungeness.

I did see that you posted the note about the 4% additional add on being in part due to government mandates. Sorry, to me your product is way overpriced as is.
author: Michael W.

description: Battled traffic and drove all the way into the city to have dinner with a visiting relative. It's either the oldest restaurant in SF or in the US (unsure of which). But it's been around since the 19th century, over a hundred years old. The restaurant isn't that big but wasn't that busy though. We easily found parking in the back and they also have street parking in front. Came in and ordered the family size cioppino. Our waiter said it was huge and did warn us that it usually feeds 5-6 people. But the medium size cioppino only feeds like 2 and there were four of us. Anyways food took a little bit to come out. They gave us a giant round loaf of bread and we ordered a carafe of their house beer to tide us over. I didn't east my bread till the cioppino came anyways since I needed the carbs to break up the liquid and protein/seafood that was all the cioppino is. Finally they brought like this cast iron baby bathtub sized rectangular pot to our table. It was so huge - very daunting. We dug in and it did not disappoint. Rich, tasty flavor and filled with so much seafood.  Fish, shrimp, mussels, clams, crab legs, and squid. There was also some small pieces corn and potatoes inside too. It's definitely a once in awhile meal but I would not mind swimming in this family size cioppino tub every so often. I ended up taking all the leftovers home and it feed me about 4-5 more meals. They gave it to me in one of those aluminum catering/serving trays - that's how much we had left. Haha. Service was great and our waiter was friendly. I would totally come back - maybe with way more people next time.
author: Alison W.

description: I am coming back again! Delicious seafood! I love the restaurant's atmosphere. The seafood chipino  and the clam juice with the bread was a great appetizer. This was a great spot! Good customer service as well.
author: Jacqueline J.

description:
This is my first time here although born and raise in SF.  I really enjoy their kettle bread (crispy on the outside and soft on the inside). We also ordered their spicy chorizo bread, crab Alfredo, calamari, and seafood linguini (the sauce for this dish was very good).  My husband and daughter shared a burger,  which like their sandwiches,  are a foot long and their fries are nice and crispy.  They give you a glass of clam juice when you sit down .

The decor reminds me a bit Similar to Tadich Grill (back in the days decor with beautiful rustic look).  The booths have curtains for privacy and checkered table clothes.  I would come again.
author: FG L.

description:
We came for a quick lunch and it was excellent. A very old timey look but very clean and it seems that they have replaced many of the antique fixtures but kept the ambiance. Great bar, great service,  great food.

Ordered the baked clam escargo $11, a crab cake$8, individual cioppino (big enough to share) $25, kept ordering their breads with clam juice (free), and bluemoon pints (but they seemed bigger) $7 each.  

Service was great and attentive, never made faces when we asked for more bread, server was patient and explained some of the dishes for us, food came out quick and hot.

Left full and happy. Only wish I had gotten the breadbowl clamchowder, but ive never had these other items so I'm very content.
author: Leo M.

description:
The key word here is "old." If the seniors aren't at Westlake Joe's they're here.

I'm looking for the senior retirement van outside but I don't see it, yet.

I think (insert her name here, for privacy reasons I'll keep this a mystery) and I are the only ones under 60 here, but she says this is a traditional place, and I should try it, so I shut my mouth. And now I'm here.

Long wait. Crowded small tables. Hard sourdough bread.

I just had the oysters and the clam chowder. She had their well know crab something. Oh, and we got crab cakes too.

Nothing super special. Would I rather have gone to the Anchor Oyster Bar? Yes. Will I make the best of it here. Yes.

But, I achieved a minor win when she said their crab wasn't as good as she remembered.
author: Jack R.

description:
A San Francisco original! This claims to be the oldest restaurant in San Francisco. i loved the creamy, New England clam
Chowder, which was bursting with flavor and overflowing with clam!  it was exquisite service and they serve a plentiful portion of warm sourdough served with butter, as well as a shot of clam juice. I passed on the clam juice!
author: William H.

description:
