Bland food and Bad service. Only good thing is the decore. 

Had to call the busboy over to get the waitress. Guess she was so busy with having only a couple of tables. Seemed not as friendly and didn't offer a to-go box?

Ordered the Crab Alfredo and it was really bland and had way too much sauce. So overbearing I couldn't finish it and had to take it back. I went there before and ordered the crab enchilada and it wasn't good. 

Boyfriend ordered a crab sandwich. Mediocre at best.

Overall, I will not be coming back since I wasn't happy with the food and the service was just icing on the cake.  Prices are way too high and the quality is very low. Money well spent somewhere else where I can at least get my money's worth and have better service. 

Meh. I'll pass.
author: Vanessa M.

description: Great clam chowder and crab cakes - BUT, service not great and the dish they are most "famous" for (Clam Bake Cioppino) was just so/so and overpriced at $29. So stick to the chowder and cakes!
author: J D.

description:
Like most, I would never have expected great seafood from Bayshore. Sure, maybe if someone said there'd be fantastic creole or BBQ, I'd have nodded in agreement. But certainly not seafood! 

The Bayshore is far from the water and is industrious; it's out of the way and sadly unloved. Why would there be seafood there? And why would you forego the convenience of fisherman's wharf!?

The Old Clam House, period. End of discussion. This place is still a hidden gem in the sea of culinary greatness that is San Francisco. I'm almost tempted not to write a review becasue more would flock to this awesome seafood joint. 

There aren't many tourists so prices are reasonable for high quality grub. The atmosphere is what I would call "sophisticated picnic". There's the classic blue checkerd oil cloth but the beatifully wooded panels all along the walls take you to a northeastern loge for ladies and gentlemen.

The Old Clam House starts things off the right way, with free clam juice shots to whet your seafood appetitie. Next, we had their clam choweder which is chock full of tasty oysters. Each bite was creamy and meaty interspersed at times with a good chunk of ptotao, a chowder lovers dream. For entrees, we ordered the seafood lunguini which is basically the chiopino but with pasta, and the sand dabs. Both were absolutely delicious and great serving sizes. There were only two of us but we could have fed three easily! They dont skimp out of seafood and everything is so fresh. 

This is a must visit!
author: Marissa S.

description:
1st time here and im sure it wont be the last. Seafood was fresh and everything we ordered tasted really good. Will definitely be back and will recommend for special occasions. 
We ordered escargot, my favorite tasty calamari, crabwich with fries, crab alfredo and cioppino. 
Escargot was baked with garlic and butter. It was very fresh.

The place was nicely decorated as old school house and it gives an ambiance of being home and just enjoy the food feeling ;) 
I love this place.
author: Enah N.

description:
12/14/13  Dinner

Strong 3.5*   Established in 1861 and have been under many ownerships, Old Clam House is one of the oldest restaurants in town. Today, the bar area consists of the original structure making it San Francisco's oldest restaurant in the same location since 1861. It's also a bit out of the way, on Bayshore in Bay View/Hunters Point. The previous owner, Chua family, had run this place to the ground and that was why I have avoided it for a long time. Now the new owner has added a patio and revised the menu.

We showed up for the 7pm reservation. The place was already slammed, bustling with holiday festivities. Christmas parties and birthday dinners were in sessions. Hostess guided us to the dining room facing the bar. Yvette was friendly and made suggestions. The meal began on a good note with bread and clam broth on the house. I would love crab but the BF is not keen on it, so I won't venture the 3 lb platter. 

*Crab Encilada ($18.95): I ordered the plate with two enchiladas (single for $12.95). Two sumptuous enchiladas with generous crab meat filling, diced onions and green onions, shredded lettuce with melted cheddar on top, served on a skillet with red tomato sauce. They do not skimp out on the crab. Every bite has crab meat---I licked the skillet clean.

*Chicken Breast Milanese ($16.95): tender breast served with capers and very crunchy French fries. It's right up my BF's alley. 

All wines by the glasses $7.95 to $9.95 and you can turn any entree to a set by adding a clam chowder or salad for $4.95. I washed down my enchiladas with two glasses of Honig sauvignon blanc. It was a pleasant evening despite the hustle-and-bustle. Love the old-school Italian feel.
author: Matt Y.

description: very disappointed, always got bread and sm glassnof clam juice for dipping, guess no more. Iron skillet mussels don't seem to be the
author: Wm B.

description: Everything we ate here was delicious. I never tried it before but I am glad I did it. 150 years old restaurant. I will definitely come back.
author: Jonh S.

description:
Very  disappointing  lunch  date  with  my wife . We're  guests  since  the  1970s.

The  prices  have increased  and the portions  have greatly  reduced to a small  size . 

But I   was  shocked  when  I  asked  for  the bread. The waiter  replied there's  a charge  for  bread now.

I   will  not  recommend  this  joint  anymore .
author: Clifford J.

description:
Complimentary warm clam juice!  Salty and briny. (Vodka optional!)  You can drink it straight or dip the complimentary cold, hard bread in it.  Both ways were quite delicious.  We sat at the bar and enjoyed a couple drinks before the JT concert at Candlestick.  When I asked what the happy hour specials were, the bartender said they don't do happy hour (WTF?!!!) but then I looked at the prices and saw that most cocktails were $7.  For a bar in SF, I was ok with those prices.  I found this place from the suggestion of local SF Yelpers as a pre-show dinner/drinks spot close to the stadium.  They were right.  It was conveniently located a few minutes down the road.  Luckily we found a tight parking spot in the back parking lot.  The place was not busy which surprised me.  It was mostly an older, after work crowd and a couple other concert go-ers.  Maybe the location isn't the greatest.  Hunter's Point and lots of homeless in the area.  At least we were out of there before it got dark.

We ordered the calamari ($10), and I got the $15 pre fixe dinner, which included a generous cup of clam chowder (pretty good) and your choice of 4 entrees.  I got the crab enchilada.  Thought it was kind of bland but they were generous with the crab meat, and I loved the quinoa salad served with it.  Light and refreshing with a few veggies mixed in.  The calamari was lightly breaded in panko.  Nothing special but at least I got a lot of tentacles.  I also ordered the spicy Mary, basically a bloody mary garnished with a big red chili and rimmed with salt.

I guess this place was bought by the same ownership group as the Stinkin' Rose, the Crab House, the Dead Fish, and Calzone's, so I did expect it to be good.  Food was average, but it was a good place to go before the concert, where a damn 8oz cup of beer is $10!
author: Carol P.

description: Used to be one of my favorite places, but was Disappointed on my most recent visit.  It appears the prices have risen considerably, The cioppino for two has a new recipe to include large chunks of carrot, and corn cobs which appears to stretch the stew but doesn't hide the shortage of seafood.  I was a bit surprised at the $8 clam chowder, but absolutely shocked at the $12 clam chowder... Really $12/ serving clam chowder??  No Thanks!
author: Tony P.

description: Classic, Old School Restaurant!  Great food and drinks!  Love the clam broth!
author: Larry F.

description:
Changed over the years, of course.  Use to come here with parents in the early 80's.  A week ago brought my kid... Clam chowder super salty and ordered $50 platter of Mussel/Crab that was really dry and not tasty at all. Mussels looked like it was cooked to long. Tried one that looked really tiny in the shell and was rubbery.  That's when I knew the entire platter was over cooked. Took awhile for bread to come out. Bread came in a cast iron pan to look like it was baked in it but you can tell the bread was just warmed up and placed in it to look like it.  It wasn't a sourdough or at least didn't taste like it was?  Tab was almost $200 for the 5 of us.  We order 2 pasta plates that were okay.  I apologized to kids who are native SFers and waiting a long time to eat  crab. They know what it should taste like. (I made it up to them and cooked 7 Dungeness crabs for them the next night. )(There was a halt with the crab season in the Bay Area because of issues). 

A little disappointed.  Loved the nostalgia and warm memories the place I had  eating here with parents.  Wanted my kids to have the same but the food was not so good.   

Will try again because maybe it was a bad night and this can be such a great place because of locale and I know many Native San Franciscans would come back if they knew the food was good.
author: Leilani I.

description:
Julie is a great bartender. This place is in my hood, and I like a place that is clean, safe, lots of parking, with amazing FOOD! I'm down with the vibe and the great old-timey service.

Come by and get the cioppino.
author: Mark B.

description:
Arguably the best breakfast/brunch I've EVER had. DELIGHTFUL SERVICE TOO
Omelet with crab, avocado, green onions, raw milk cheddar.... YUM!
I am SO glad I came in here. Ana at the bar welcomed me and found and help me charge my phone/lap top and just couldn't have been nicer. (I was in the area getting my car fixed after it was broken into so I entered in a rather grumpy mood... However, the combo of Ana and "don't miss" fries had me skipping out the door. 
Thank you!
author: Kit M.

description: For a place advertising crabs, I ordered a half Dungeness.  Instead of a 'half crab', I got a couple claws and legs.  I sent it back to the kitchen and had the fish and chips instead.  Still the whole crab thing soured my experience.
author: Paul S.

description:
This place has been around for 100+ years and it's definitely had it's list of different owners.  They actually have a list showing the names of owners and the years they took over.
 
So, to make a long story short, new owners are running the place since a couple years ago..  Good thing or bad thing??

GREAT THING!

The inside's been renovated so it looks cleaner and more tables and booths.  The servers are super friendly.  We loved our female Asian server, but totally forgot her name..  Sorry!

But best of all, the food was awesome.

Steamed clams?  Probably the best pot of clams you can get anywhere.  I souped up all the broth...  Generous portion

Caesar Salad?  Husband says its top 5 on his list...  somewhere compared to Houstons.  tip:  ask for anchovies on the side

Beet salad?  I asked for extra beet and they didn't disappoint.  I loved the vinegarette and could seriously eat this everyday.

Patty melt?  Who eats this at clam house?  Apparently husband does and he found it to be bready.  His choice to disappoint.

This place is an institution and I know it will be around for a looooooooong time.  
Love it!
author: Seung Eun C.

description:
I went to The Old Clam House as part of SF Restaurant Week. I thought that it would be great to try a restaurant that rival Tadich Grill in terms of years in business. I was not disappointed on the food side. I ordered the clam chowder, braised short rib, and tiramisu prix fixe option. Everything was fantastic! The braised short ribs were delectable. I'll definitely be back for that again however the location and service were drawbacks.

It's a little out of the way but the food makes the trek worth it. Unfortunately, the service was just not up to par. I'm not sure if that was because we had a bad waiter or if the restaurant just needed more waitstaff.
author: Makela C.

description:
Awesome food,  reasonably priced.
The Cioppino is a stand out dish.  
Polite and attentive wait staff.
author: Justin N.

description:
We thoroughly enjoyed our dinner tonight.  The decor looks amazing. Our waiter was awesome. The portions are very generous and the drinks great too. Order the bread--warm in a skillet and dip into your clam juice (broth).  So tasty!
Both the fish and chips & Ciopino entrees could serve 2!
Will be back!
author: Mike D.

description: Love this place near my home , it's truly a hidden gem in this area. Great service , wonderful people and great for the little ones ..
author: Jimmy D.

description: You should order the calamari steak dore. My favorite. It can't go wrong with blue moon draft beer on a sunny Sunday !!!
author: Daniel L.

description: Bomb.com always fish and chips hella good clams juice great Andrew is super nice and cute thank you! !!!!!
author: Valeriana L.

description:
**Before I go any further please make sure you use Google Maps for the directions, not the Yelp directions listed. The directions listed will take you to the corner of Market and Van Ness. (Try it if you don't be me!)

First time visiting this restaurant as we were a group of 9 and 1/2 of our party was shoved in a corner, but our server was good and attentive and the atmosphere was definitely interesting. This restaurant is a once and a while type of place not a Friday night kind of place. The food was expensive considering it's not in the heart of SF. Wasn't good, wasn't bad.
author: J T.

description:
total waste of money. Way too expensive for food that's only passible.
pretty underwhelming. Service wasn't very good at lunch but thats expected bc it was empty.
author: Katie R.

description:
I think it's been 15 years since we first went to the Old Clam House. I don't know why we haven't been back sooner. It is so good. We went there for my birthday. We ordered calamari and crab cake appetizers. Yummy! Grossburger - wow! Louis salad, crab enchilada, fish and chips, goat cheese omelet. Every dish was excellent. Our server was warm and wonderful. We are definitely
coming back and we won't wait another 15 years. Bravo, Clam House!
author: Cynthia L.

description:
I have always loved the Old Clam House for a variety of reasons:  The great seafood, friendly staff and great service all compliment the history of this wonderful establishment.  Living in the Mission for the last 20 years has given me the opportunity to conveniently sample a great amount of diverse local cuisine, but it has gotten more and more difficult to eat out in my neighborhood.  Tech bros, brogrammers, beardos, lumberjack dandy boys and hipsters have pretty much taken over all of my "go-to" spots for a good meal.  This is one of the many reasons that I am more than happy to hop in my car and drive to TOCH for some peace and righteous grindz.

I noticed upon my last two visits that there is no longer a brunch menu.  I didn't ask, but I assume that they stopped serving those items and restricted the selections back to their core menu.  I'm happy to eat from the core menu at brunch, but I do miss those skillet omelettes.
author: Drew P.

description: The Old clam house was good for group and the service was fantastic. We ordered six old clam chowder bowls and it was delicious but it was a little to the salty side. I order a beer salad and it was good. We also order the clam soup family style and it was delicious but it was salty too. I love the bread though. We also had the seafood soup style and that was delicious. I would of given this place a five stars if the food was less salt but it was good and the service was good. I thought that the clam chowder was there speciality but it was too salty for me too eat. I will go here again and ask if they can lower the sodium in the clam chowder soup and the family clam soup.
author: Elaine H.

description: I first ate here in 1982 and every now and then since. I am glad it is still here, but the last couple of times I stopped in, I was surprised by the limited menu and the high prices on both the food and the beer. Beer prices were what you might expect in a downtown fancy hotel. Come-on this is Bayshore, give me a $3 bud light and some fish and chips. I'm a sucker for a fried seafood combo plate, but last time I was there for lunch I didn't see it on the menu.
author: John H.

description: I enjoy everything about this place.  It is a total throwback in a good way.  The food is good, not out of this world but good.   The chorizo bread is delicious. The service is always great.   Most importantly there is always a table.  No hassle. No pretense just a good place to eat.
author: Courtney C.

description: December 26 around 6pm i was having dinner with my cousin at The Old Clam House in San Francisco. After we had finish eating i went to the bathroom to wash my hands before we left. As i was returning back from the bathroom the Host was jumping all around and acting completely unprofessional. I spoke up to let the Host know that i was walking up behind him so he would be aware of me approaching. He continued to play and jump around like a little child. When the Host finally jumped and turned around he hit me extremely hard in my left eye with his forehead. The Host knew what had just happened and did not even attempt to apologize to me for striking me in the eye. No one from The Old Clam House came to ask if i was ok, no one seemed to care if i was hurt or needed any type of medical attention. Another customer was more concerned about my well being than The Old Clam House employees. After about 15 to 20 mins our waiter finally came to ask if i was ok. We waited for a very long time for a manager to show up. After waiting for what seemed to be a life time, was told that they do not have any managers available to come and speak with me. I find this completely and totally unexpectable. The employees are childish and should not be allowed to work in an environment where they can potentially hurt a customer. Management is non existence and can care less of their customers and for their employers. When the regional manager finally responed he asked if i needed a paramedic I declined at the time because there was no swelling. I did receive a discount for our meal not because of management, our server  took it upon themselves to give us a discount for what we have been through. Management was a very huge disappointment and i can only hope that the owners of the restaurant will be able to see this complaint and be able to rectify the problem. I have been in many situations before, this one is absolutely the worst. No leadership, no discipline and zero fucks given.
author: Peruanita B.

description: Their ciopinno was super delicios. They also have full service coffee and tiramisu for desert.
author: Roman G.

description:
lunch yesterday...chowder and a small salad...great service..not too crowded..

love the little glass of clam juice..
author: Brent P.

description:
It takes very little to make fresh seafood great. I usually come to the Clam House a couple times a year and always enjoy it. I love the ambiance with the neon beers signs at the bar with the pictures of the great 49er players from the past on the walls. Great tasting Cioppino. Truly a classic feel, a true San Francisco feel to this place. Its a place you can hang out with friends or family and enjoy great seafood without a heavy price tag. A classic restaurant in my opinion. 

Whether or not the restaurant stays a classic remains to be seen. I have heard it has recently been sold and I see remodeling taking place. The reason for coming here is because its the "old" Clam House, anything different would destroy what makes this place great. To lose the classic style of the before mentioned bar area with the photos of the great players from yester-year,  to lose those things is like making me watch the 49ers of today. I'm going to lose my appetite really quickly.
author: Michael L.

description: Went to this place with friends.  The cioppino was good, the ambiance ok.  The menu seemed limited, and the service was a bit lacking in promptness.  The worst was that my rental car was right in front of the restaurant and was broken into.  Enjoy this restaurant, but leave nothing in your car of value.
author: Aaron G.

description: Came here to celebrate Valentine's Day with my family. The clam juice is always a hit with my picky kids. Our waitress Kathleen was genuinely nice and very sweet with the kids. The crab never disappoints and the portions are large and filling. I frankly forgot what everyone else ordered because I was drooling over my sizzling crab plate. The hostess forgot to bring me my crab cracker (bringing me actual crackers instead) but Kathleen was nice enough to get me some yummy Tiramisu to make up for it. The great service and attentiveness Kathleen provided is rare. The food never disappoints. We will definitely be back!
author: Tiffany I.

description: As a former history teacher (after 30 years in the Army), I felt compelled to eat at The Old Clam House because of its unique history. Our extended family ate dinner here in the early evening.  Parking was not a problem probably because there were so few patrons at this time of day.  We were greeted with the standard complementary glass of tasty clam juice.  We ordered a variety of items from the comprehensive menu. Because I had eaten such a large lunch, I decided to order the Louie salad with crab. Before our meal arrived, we enjoyed the house-made crispy baked kettle bread plus an order of the skillet roasted chorizo cheese bread. My wife ordered the clam bake cioppino which was so large that she shared it with our daughter-in-law.  My son ordered "the fish fry" while the kids had fish and chips.  Portions were extremely generous.  For dessert, we all shared one piece of the salted caramel vanilla crunch cake. I now know what I want for my next birthday cake.
author: Russ O.

description:
Pricey and so-so food.

I'm giving them three stars however because I enjoyed the following:

Oysters were really great, even in off season
Clam broth, served in small cup on arrival
Fresh bread
Excellent Bloody Mary
author: Casey D.

description:
Three stars for the ambiance alone. I love this style of old-school place! The fresh oysters were nice and the bread and butter with clam juice to dip it in was great. 

But, the food itself was remarkably "eh" and chain-feeling. We came for lunch. The chowder was potato-y and flour-y and sadly tasted kind of like it came from a can. I like a thick creamy clammy chowder that had more flavor from clams, cream and maybe bacon than flour and potatoes. 

The sand dabs with couscous were OK but very, very buttery-- my date didn't like them, I thought it was OK. 

Nothing seemed very fresh or home-made, though. Despite the great ambiance, for this price I expected more.
author: Dina G.

description: Had dinner here again last night.  Cioppino as good as always.  Friends had the basa fish and the calamari steak-  both also fabulous.  The highlight of the night, however, the best part was our server Johnathan.  He was fun and on it.   Reminded me of the old days when Jorge used to serve us.  Excellent time!
author: Kristen S.

description:
From the outside not all that appealing, but walk into a very comfortable and retro lounge and dining room. The service was excellent. Prices were reasonable by SF standards and the food was good. This is not a haute cuisine sort of place, but if u want fresh seafood, reasonable portions, and tasty food, this is it. 
The clam chowder was chock full of clams, the spinach salad with crab meat was excellent. And great fresh hot bread. I ordered the lime torte for dessert - a bit on the heavy side but tasty. Only complaint was that the coffee I ordered wasn't hot; but when I told the waitress, she quickly rectified that.
author: Ashland A.

description: The 2 hostesses were rude from the get go. one was much more interested in her cell phone than dealing with customers.  I tried to order take out and one hostess told me no, another lady asked after me and apparently they told her yes. As I was walking back to my car the woman was nice enough to tell me they told her yes so I went back in to order.  They were nice to her, but still rude to me.  I ordered my food and wanted to and the hostess got huffy and stormed off to add the drink and didn't come back for 20 minutes and my food was cold by then. And I thought it a bit unprofessional that she was wearing an open backed shirt working around food. Didn't even say thank you when I paid or anything.I wish they would have been a bit nicer considering it's Christmas! The cold service and cold food left a bad taste in my mouth and I don't think I will be back ever. I just threw my food away and wasted $17 on a bowl of soup.
author: Lola L.

description: I think they have new owners because their menu, food, decor and service has changed. I was a regular before and haven't been back for a few years. I recently came back  with my family and the service was D-. Our main waitress said that it was some of the guys first day on the job.  They served our clam broth/soup 30 mins into dinner. They used to give it first before any appetizers. Bread is $.90. Overall, it's not like the old Clam house. #SAD
author: Dion R.

description: Was in town for the weekend and was brought here by a relative. Absolutely loved it! We were greeted with clam juice (which I had never had) but it was delicious! I loved the old quirky decor, the service was great, and the food was delicious! Looking forward to my next San Francisco trip so that I can go back!
author: Sylvia P.

description: This place is so cute! Well worth the money we spent. We had kettle bread that was soo good! Very friendly server. I will definitely return.
author: Debra H.

description: We ordered cioppino, which was really delicious. The place reminds the old San Francisco Bayshore. It appeared kind of expensive to us (for this area of the city).
author: Jeffery K.

description:
The moment I realized that I AM OLD.

Sitting there while everyone compared bling bling engagement rings, talked about princess versus mermaid dresses and exchanging pictures of their kids, I sat there wishing I could undo time. If things had been different than maybe I can be in their shoes too.

But here I am, 21 for the 10th year with a "23 year-old boy toy" (as he likes to tells everyone) and a 8-pound bark-a-fluff named Teddy, my closest thing to a child except he doubles as a cockblocker. 

Naturally, during my delayed quarter life crisis, I turned to Mr. NSS for comfort. Like any good bf, he tried to cheer me up by telling me he was my 400th Yelp fan. He said, he kept tabs on my page and when he noticed I was at 399 (while he was driving), he pulled over the side of the road just to google how to fan someone on Yelp. Awwwww...he truly knows the way to a Yelp addict's heart. He then asked, "Where are you dragging me next so you can write a review and take 6969 pics for Yelp?"

Old Clam House was my choice, San Francisco's oldest restaurant. A very fitting choice given the way I was feeling. 

I've never visited Old Clam House, an SF institution which existed since Lincoln was president. I heard things have changed since The Stinking Rose (http://bit.ly/ROSgfN)/Bobo's (http://bit.ly/UQKeY1) had taken over last year; namely, the menu changes, higher prices and smaller portions. However, being a fan of both places, the Old Clam House seemed promising. Too bad it was a disappointment just like their other sister restaurant, Crab House at Pier 39 minus the attitude (http://bit.ly/U9HRvx).

Dinner started off nicely with the complimentary crusty soft bread and shot of warm clam juice which is for dipping the bread into http://bit.ly/UQI7DH. The Hot Iron Skillet Roasted Shrimp (Medium - $14.95) arrived on a sizzling platter and was robust in buttery seasoning http://bit.ly/10gijQH. The nearly two dozen of shrimp were a bit overcooked though. The Lotsa Crab ($49.95) was a complete waste of money http://bit.ly/WgFHd3. The BLAND crab legs managed to be oily (from butter it was cooked in) and dry at the same time. The crab was extremely overcooked, making the crab meat stringy and super dry. Even worse, there was barely any seasoning so I actually used hot sauce on the table for flavoring. You're better off going to PPQ in Outer Richmond for a complete 5 course crab meal for two for the same price as this platter. What a shame considering its crab season and I couldn't tell if the crab was fresh because it was SO overcooked. For a seafood restaurant, the Bone-in Filet ($29.95) was surprisingly solid http://bit.ly/UD4nLb. It was perfectly cooked to a medium rare with a delicious tenderness. The creamed spinach was an unappetizing greenish brown color but the divinely soft smushed potatoes made up for it.

Service was friendly enough but slow. Considering it was pretty dead on a Wednesday night, I can't imagine it being all that stellar or timely when it's busier on the weekends. 

Getting a little taste of San Francisco history wasn't cheap. There are way too many options in the city with far superior food to be spending $140 for an overall mediocre dinner for two. Anchor Oyster Bar (http://bit.ly/U9FvMY) and Sotto Mare (http://bit.ly/XWgXMn) are my top two choices for seafood in SF.  Plus the ambiance at the Old Clam House was still a bit dreary despite the remodel which didn't help my cause. 

Hmmm, I guess it's a good thing that I use my Ben Wa Balls (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Wa_balls) to keep me from being an Old Clam. All you "Fifty Shades of Grey" lovers, you know what's up!

OTHER NOTES: 
*FREE corkage so pop 'em bottles!
*Located in the industrial part of Bayview/HP with a lot of incoming traffic so it's safe.
*Three dining areas: more "formal" dining area with booths, bar area with plasma TVS for watching the game, and an enclosed patio.
*Parking lot in back.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Such a cool spot with amazing history, and a great bartender, Judy, who shines like a bright light, and has tons of character. My party of four arrived at Happy Hour, and enjoyed the old bar for a bit before being seated.

Once seated in one of the cute, cozy booths with curtains, we ordered some appetizers: oysters on the half shell, popcorn shrimp (the smallest I've ever seen anywhere), and some clam chowder.  We also had cioppino (pretty good), home made bread served in a skillet (but not warm?), and a crab enchilada that my friend raved about.  Oh, and some clams- yum!

The place got super-packed, and our server seemed flustered, but was incredibly sweet, and did his best.  The atmosphere of the place is so relaxed, so fun that we enjoyed the heck out of ourselves.
author: Dolly S.

description:
Still giving 4 stars though last night was pretty bad. Due to a private party that consumed the entire patio, the whole restaurant and kitchen were in a tizzy. The restaurant was totally full--first time I've seen that. The hostess ignored us (she was overwhelmed); the manager ignored us too. We had reservations but still waited while they seated parties that put their name on a list. Not fair to us with a reservation, and no acknowledgement. 

We eventually got seated (only waited 15 minutes). Drink order was taken quickly, but we asked for water three times before getting it (during the meal, not before). We never got any clam juice, even though we asked for it and wanted our friends to try it.  Why? The private party used all the glassware! C'mon. We suggested getting some in a coffee cup--but none came--ever. We finally got some bread after asking a few times. The food was good, as usual. But we had to track our server down a few times. The skillet mussels are great--my fave--but they were so hot I burned and blistered my finger.

We felt bad this morning when we realized that we split the bill with friends but only tipped on half the bill. Our mistake. But the service was pretty bad. John, we forgive last night. We'll come again and give a better tip.
author: Michele H.

description:
My first thought of the restaurant was that I really liked all the history on the walls. There were so many pictures of the old days of San Francisco. 

At the start of the meal, it came with a little cup of clam juice that comes out with the bread and butter. I dipped my bread with juice and it was tasty. 

For my entree, I had the petite filet mignon. They cooked it correct to how I like it and it was awesome. It came with a side of spinach and mash potatoes that was very delicious. 

I definitely want to come back here again to try the seafood.
author: Jason L.

description:
We had lunch there yesterday and were very disappointed.    This place is very expensive for the food that they serve.     The crab sandwich was a bread sandwich,  portions were way 
overpriced.     We eat out in San Francisco all the time so we have a good gauge for food.
Salads were ordinary with dressing dumped in a small container.
Eat somewhere else.
author: allen h.

description:
Use to like old clam house but this visit made us not want to come back.  

Got our usual the cioppino and they were really skimpy on the seafood and instead had more veggies.  To make it worse, they did not even give us bread with it.  Very disappointing. 

Then we got the fried calamari and they gave us no sauce with it.  Would have complained but we bought this all to go.  Total came up to 46 bucks.  Definitely not worth the price for what we got.
author: Angela L.

description:
We took some friends from Southern Cal to this landmark location.  Everything ordered was delicious: 
The medium size cioppino for 2 people was more than enough to feed 5 of us and still had leftovers.
The grilled double mussels & double crab with garlic was amazing, however, next time we would not order the mussels because there was a lot in the cioppino already.  Too bad grilled clams is not an option.  
The kettle bread was oven hot - crispy on the outside and soft in the inside.  
The free hot clam juice is too salty.

Why such bad rating?   UNFORTUNATELY, the evening was ruined when we finished our dinner and got back to our car that was parked behind the restaurant in the back alley.   The car side window and back window were smashed!  Broken glass everywhere inside the car.  Nothing particularly valuable was stolen, but so much damage to the car.   That dinner ended up costing us over $1300 after including the cost of dinner and the loses to our car.  That was an expensive dinner!   DO NOT PARK IN THE BACK ALLEY!!!  It would be a definite plus if the Old Clam House provides valet parking or hires a security guard in the area.
author: A.F. N.

description:
The food was good and our waiter was great. I especially enjoyed the combo skillet; however, I deducted two stars because of the hostess's bad attitude. She is an Asian girl with bangs and shoulder-length, black, curly hair. 

We came on a Saturday night (tonight actually) and there were about 4, 5 empty tables. We didn't rsvp and the hostess "demanded" that we rsvp in the future. She then continued to comment, in a very arrogant tone, that we were lucky to even get seated right away because they are usually very busy.  Throughout the entire time we were there, the restaurant was never full.  Maybe we were, indeed, lucky tonight but the way she said it was rude. 
When we finished our dinner and walked out, she completely ignored us as we walked pass her and exited the restaurant. 

I am not sure if I want to go back. Although the food was good, the hostess ruined my night.
author: K L.

description: Highly disappointed been coming here since 1980 obviously it's had a few difrrent owners but the newest menu is worst one yet.  I use to get hot good sourdough bread for free the crab sandwich is horrible compared to the original one . I used to look forward to get a bucket clams which is not on the menu anymore. I just don't agree with theses new recipes I've had better food here in the past. This was my go to spot haven't been here in a long time smh.  Might I add the service is great .
author: Bernard R.

description: I know this place for around 30 years, excellent food,good service, one of the best sea food, should try it!
author: Jose M.

description: This is a place of old fashioned seafood dreams. Never wake me up, I'll just die happy here after a couple of beers and the cioppino. Service was excellent and parking easy as we got the space right in front. I want to come back for the hot pineapple rum French Toast.
author: Susangela M.

description: Better each time! Crowded today. The clam-chowder was perfect as always, and the Fish & Chips were best I have had in a long time. Didn't each all the fries, but coulda. Old Clam House does not disappoint. #fridaylunch
author: Vince C.

description: a new look for the old clam house, but thats about it. if you loved the food before, you may still like it. if you hated the food before, then that too might still be the case. the bread, which cost an extra 25 cents (i think) was hard and stale - skip it.
author: Long C.

description: The Old Clam House is a family favorite. I don't recall dining here as a young kid but now that i'm older and can appreciate it, i don't think we come here often enough! The food is so good. I haven't had the opportunity to try any of their pasta dishes like clam linguine or crab al fredo. What i can comment on is the seafood heavy dishes like the amazing cioppino, mussels, and clams. The cioppino broth is the best i've had. It's packed with flavor and heat. The fish and mix of shellfish is fresh and cooked perfectly. Any time you are handed a bib it means business. I'm happy to put on a bib at a restaurant.. it tells me i'm going to have a great meal.
author: Samantha L.

description: I really wanted to like this place. After driving past it many times I finally decided to give it a shot. Once seated, we were each served a shot of complimentary clam broth which was a nice touch. The wait staff was attentive but not overbearing. I only had the clam chowder but it was heavily salted to the point of not being edible. My dining companion had to dilute their chowder with water and still could not down it. I would say skip this place and head to Boudin Bakery for the better chowder at half the price. (Yes, I'm comparing this to a fast food joint at the mall.) Maybe the restaurant was having an off day but I doubt I will be back. This was a miss for me and after reading all the rave reviews I am puzzled by the high ratings. It's The Old Clam House so shouldn't the clam chowder be a signature dish to write home about?
author: W A.

description: Steamed clams and crab sandwich were really good!   Next time I'm SF again, I will make sure to go to this place.
author: Samantha P.

description: Best fish & chips ever!!! Noodles cream sauce & crab to die for!!!! Great service friendly and attentive staff ice tea is so good
author: Virginia S.

description:
I love this place. The funny thing is that most of the time I end up here intoxicated with my boyfriend. I usually order the cioppino which is okay - not the best, but far from the worst. I'm just not use to some of the items they put in the cioppino here. I love their seafood pasta with cioppino sauce and their creamed spinach (no longer served here anymore) was amazing. Bring the creamed spinach back!! 

My boyfriend and I always order mussels and shrimp as a starter. DELICIOUS! It's always perfectly seasoned! Their stews are also amazing which we order often. For the two of us, we always manage to spend over $100 here... The waiters have even questioned us "do you know how big our portions are?" lol and we always manage to have no leftovers. The food and service is great!
author: Kristen F.

description: It's been 5 years since my last visit . I'm an sf native so I've been here over the course of some years. Simply put. I had a good experience with the staff. Place expanded, prices went up (which is understandable) but menu got minimized a lot so a few favorite dishes are gone which doesn't make sense and will be sadly my last visit. Thanks for the memories.
author: Edward B.

description:
There were 3 reasons why we chose Old Clam House:
 
World Cup game on TV
New England Clam Chowder
Did not have to fight for parking in mid SF
 
2 out of 3 is usually not bad except it was the chowder that was not good. Come on, the name of the place is Old Clam House and it is in SF!! Should I expect so so chowder?
 
Their other dishes were not bad and the service ok - I just don't feel the love on this one.
 
Next time? I'll fight the traffic to get good chowder someplace else.
author: Eddie C.

description: After spotting it on the way home, I brought my family here (husband, son 14 and niece, 22) and we were all completely thrilled. From that warm clam juice appetizer (we were initially skeptical but one sip cured that), to the warm loaf of bread, the clam chowder, fish & chips and ciaopino, everything was amazing! The service was perfect, the decor eclectic. There are tvs around to view if you can't miss a sports event, but they are unobtrusive. The bar is fully stocked and the wine list has a good range. Unpretentious. Prices very reasonable. We'll be back!
author: Linda P.

description: My family and I are regulars at this one-of-a-kind SF joint.  Order the crab and shrimp, you will be very happy.  Just be prepared to get messy.  My husband and son love the fresh oysters.   I always order the crab or shrimp Louie.  I have never left this understated historic landmark dissatisfied.  Crunchy, chewy Sourdough with complimentary clam soup "juice" for dipping.  Garlic melted lemon butter will knock your socks off.  I do wish they had specials but otherwise, this place gets my 5 stars all day.  Even the oyster crackers are something special.  I am proud to call myself a regular here.  Don't leave SF without visiting The Old Clam House, at least once!
author: A H.

description: Came here for the very first time and ordered the Crabwich sandwich and clam chowder. The sandwich was very bland and the meat to bread and slaw ratio was not great. Definitely not enough meat in this sandwich. The clam chowder broth was great, however, I didn't get the seafood chunks I typically would get at any other restaurant. Service was subpar as well.
author: Jay L.

description: I ate here for the first time on Thanksgiving day. It was a very nice experience. The restaurant you can tell hasn't changed over the years and it was a great time going around looking at all the pictures and memorabilia. The staff was great and the food even better. Went with a group of friends and we had a very good time.
author: Joe L.

description:
I brought my family here many times over many years, partly because we've lived in the neighborhood for almost 30 years, and we thought the food was good and the atmosphere relaxing - we went for birthdays and other events.  But on a recent trip after a few years of absence - in the meantime, that giant shell and other Fisherman's Wharf props had been affixed to the roof -- which maybe should have been a red flag -- the food had changed.  The cioppino was some thick gluck of unseasoned tomato paste, very unappealing.  No garlic bread.  Impersonal service.  Not even in the same ballpark of what we used to come here for.  

Since the tab for two people including wine was about $100, I'm not sure when we'll take another crack at this.   I was sorry to have to X it off my list of places to go for the time being.
author: elizabeth o.

description: We stumbled upon this place while we were headed to smart and final. What a hidden gem. John was or server and amazing! The fish and chips was delicious and HUGE portioned. We also had Bloody shark chili Mary drinks with tequila...a must.  This place was established in 1861 and has a very nice feel to it. Definitely stop by if you're around the Bernal Hill neighborhood.
author: Ladan H.

description: bayshore dinner and evening street parking easy...complimentary bread, butter and clam juice...potent briny shot of broth...better used as dip to soften hard crusted bread...skip the dry $3.95 garlic bread...get the $9.95 clam escargot..squeeze of lemon and scoop out of the shell...very good...creamy white clam chowder $6.95 is rich and delicious...family size clam bake for $89.95 can easily feed 5 to 6 people...iron skillet pot cioppino filled with shrimp, fish, calamari,  clam, mussel,  crab, corn, olive, potato, etc...slight sweetness to the delicious red broth...some mess from cracking dungeness crab...food and drinks roughly $46 to $47 per person...
author: Hen A.

description: Was there last week for dinner. My husband was disappointed with the crab cioppino we ordered. It is his favorite dish to order when ever he eats seafood anywhere available. He will never order this dish again from here. Funny my husband has eaten this there a few times and is always disappointed in the amount of the seafood he gets but this time will be his last for ordering cioppino there because this was the final test. In his cioppino dish he received 2 small crab claws, 1 scallop and 2 baby clams and 2 shrimp, 2 mussles and a few rings of calamari and whole lot of filler which consisted of potatos, sauce ect. Thats it! For the price of this dish this was sad. On a good note I order the mussles skillet and it was good.
author: Debbie W.

description:
Awesome !!
Can't believe it exists here !!
Must see place - amazing seafood - great decor - great service !!
Love it !
author: Steve B.

description:
Yvette was a great server. Her food recommendations were on point. The crab enchiladas were excellent but the star dish was the clams escargot.
 If you've had a bad experience here give it another try. We came in 2010 and hated the food. They are now under new ownership and the quality of food has definitely improved.
Dessert: rum cake. Super moist.
author: Esmeralda R.

description:
I had the crab burger and fries recently at the Old Clam House. It was under seasoned and pretty tasteless despite looking really pretty. I have eaten at the OCH at least 2 other times over the years, but always felt that the food was forgettable and unremarkable. 

The french fries had enough salt in the seasoning, but they were lacking in deliciousness. All I can say is that they were just not great, maybe the seasoning tasted a little junk food like...

I loved the look of the dining room and would go again if I was going to drink, since the bar was quite nice.
author: Yvette K.

description:
Hmmm, I wonder why I never reviewed this spot even though the babe and I have been coming here for years? Maybe, it is like that old, comfy pair of slippers you have.  You tend to forget about it yet it is always dependable and there for you.

Totally love this place, because of the following reasons:

1) away from the hustle and bustle of the city (unless you want that).  Easy street parking.  I would definitely though park on Bayshore as opposed to the backside streets which are darker and with fewer pedestrians/traffic.

2)  cioppino is definitely the best imo and until i taste better it holds the title.  It simply is my favorite and pretty much the only dish I order when I come here, every time.  

3)  the excellent cup of complementary broth that they serve you to start your food journey off.  The babe swears by it and will unshamefully ask for more.  No worries, we usually tip well to compensate.

4)  the usually excellent and attentive service we have always received when coming here

5)  the simple ability to enjoy some good, fresh, seafood without having to break out the rolex and jimmy choos (not me, the babe :-)  ) .  Sure the food is not cheap but I wouldn't say it is overly expensive too.  Believe me, I have been to those restaurants where they serve you that itsy bitsy thing on the big white plate and charge you an arm and a leg for it and you should be on your knees begging for more.  This is a more casual place where you can just eat without the fuss.  Absolutely nothing wrong with that.


Man, need to go tonight....

Honey?
author: V C.

description:
Love this place! Its a bit out of the way and in a strange location but once you get inside you understand why. Its been there forever! The history is on the walls and you get a short summary on the menu and some old photos. 

The food is good if you like seafood and/or steak. Beyond that there is not much else to order. Its out of the way but worth a visit for the history.
author: Sunny Y.

description:
About 20 of us celebrated my Grandma's 90th birthday at the Old Clam House.  Where better to celebrate the oldest person we loved than the oldest restaurant in San Francisco?  Or so we thought . . .

Earlier in the week, I had called to ask whether we could take a family picture before dinner.  The person said she'd make a note in our reservation to give us enough space to take pictures and to not seat anyone in the patio area, so we could have the space to ourselves.  When we arrived, the tables were not set up to provide us with enough space to take pictures, and they had seated two other parties in the patio area with us.

Our waitress was excellent and worked well under the demanding pressure of our large party.  She was the only good thing about my Old Clam House experience.

The Hot Iron Skillet Mussels were tasty, as were the menagerie of appetizers we ordered to share.  But, all three orders of the fried calamari appetizer were disappointing because they were soggy and cold when they got to our table.

I got an order of Lotsa Crab (about 3 pounds) to share with my sister.  You could tell that the crab was not so fresh and had been frozen, which can be okay, but after I had 1-2 pieces that tasted bad, I just stopped eating because I didn't want to get sick.

Overall a disappointing and frustrating dining experience.
author: Christina L.

description: We have always enjoyed our dinners at the Old Clam House, so when we were out that way, we decided to stop by for some chowder for dinner. As another patron from last night indicated, the service was not good because of a new waiter and some other issues. We never received the clam juice that usually greets us, and there were lots of other service issues. While the food is generally good, I want to mention a confusing issue on the menu. The "golden clam chowder" costs $7.99, while the same chowder in a bread bowl costs $10.99. When we asked for two orders not in a bread bowl, she asked if we wanted bread. Since they always used to provide a few slices of great San Francisco french bread, I asked if it was complimentary, and she said yes. When she brought a round kettle loaf like the one another patron raved about, we were happy, even if the menu did say it costs $.99.  However, when we received the bill and were charged $10.99 each for the bread bowl chowder as well as the $.99 bread, I questioned her. She explained that the $7.99 order is called a "cup", even though the menu does not say that. We saw the size of the $7.99 order at the table next to us, and it is much more than a usual restaurant cup -- more like a medium dinnerware bowl. We would have been quite happy with that. Just thought other patrons might like to avoid this confusion.
author: Marietta B.

description:
Great place! I've always wanted to come here and boy am I glad I did. My dad and I stopped to grab some chowder and it was so good! Really hearty with a potatoy vibe and tons of clams! Bread and butter served with a bomb shot of hot clam juice for dipping. Pro move. For sure coming back with way more people in tow. 

Ps. The stuff on the wall is killer and the bar looks like a force to be reckoned with. Plus they show NFL highlights.
author: David B.

description:
This has been a long standing establishment with great food and customer service.

I do believe they have had a couple of different owners in the past.

A couple of things could need improving....  there is no parking. Its not the best area in SF but c'mon...by now you should do something about your Parking.

Also....you use to have Scalone on the menu. No longer. That was a to die-for dish!!
author: Janet T.

description: Staff were really nice. The food we ordered weren't that good. My son had the crab sandwich. It was big! But not tasty at all. I had some clam chowder since this was a clam house. Didn't like it. They do give you a shot of clam juice.
author: Eric S.

description: Five stars for the food and Marlon, our waiter at lunch on Saturday, November 12.  However, we were dining with a promotional comp, given to Concierges in the city,  and the seating hostess or on-duty-manager, an Asian lady,  had no idea what the promo card was, was very brusque and unapologetic of her ignorance and was quite arrogant in her 'stance'.  She ignored us the rest of the meal, and while checking in with other diners, always bypassed our table.  That said, we were served, although we did not receive what was called for on the comp card...(no mussels), and the food and service from Marlon was spectacular as always.  He really loves his job and is truly an asset to the Old Clam House.  Will definitely recommend to guest and continue to visit ourselves.
author: Vernon H.

description:
I pondered into this hidden gem on Friday afternoon with my father who is a huge food critic. We were greeted and waited on by a gorgeous young lady named Jessica. She was very sweet and highly educated on the current menu, so I allowed her to order one of the main dishes strictly off of instinct. 

We had the calamari, clams escargot and clam chowder for starters. ALL THREE WERE INCREDIBLE!! 

The fish pasta and short ribs on the other hand.. May have put other restaurants out of business! BEST SHORT RIBS IN THE BAY AREA HANDS DOWN. 

Lovely staff with incredible food. What a great find. Already looking forward to having lunch there next Friday.
author: Krikor K.

description:
I love the location! It keeps away anyone who considers this neighborhood scary/ghetto/sketchy. Not coincidentally, those are the same people who annoyingly call my hometown San Fran *shudders* 

I came to the *old* Old Clam House a decade ago but I can't remember anything of my clam chowder or what I had for an entree or even the former decor. 

BF & I visited the (apparently new) Old Clam House twice in about two months. They have Groupon to thank for that. 

Foods we tried: 
- fish & chips: gigantic piece of white fish atop crispy, yummy fries. Batter is top notch. I'm not a fish & chips kinda gal but this was 4.5 stars good! 
- crabwich: didn't care for the bread (not toasted enough & generally flavorless.) Generous with the lump crab. Probably would not get this again. 
- shrimp on a sizzling skillet: we always get this at any stinking rose/ crab house/bobo-type joint. Never fails to make our mouths happy. 
- whole crab: not garlicky like at the stinking rose, more natural-tasting. Very fresh. Yummy! 
- BF likes the broth that accompanies the sourdough bread. 

Try to sit in the Enclosed Patio. 

3.5 stars.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Cant wait to eat here again!!! Me and the honey shared the iron skillet mix with clam chowder and calamari. The chowder wasn't my favorite but calamari, skillet and the lemonade were bomb!!! I loved it! 
we came in at 3 pm on a weekend which is after the lunch crowd but before dinner it was perfect.
author: Mary Jane P.

description: AWFUL!!! I'm a S.F. native and very familiar with th e Old Clam House,but hadn't been there for a while....WHAT HAPPENED?????  I'm not a picky eater, but lunch was horrible. Ordered the fish fry..received three tiny strips of Basa fish maybe the length of my thumb. The shrimp were from a 36/40 count size which were extremely  overcooked, calamari was tiny and overcooked almost to the point of burnt. Horrible...how do the stay open?
author: Jacquie B.

description: This is defiantly a hole the wall, we ate the fish and chips and crab enchiladas. Fish batter was the bomb.com oh and not to mention the fries, THE BEST EVER!! Crab enchiladas with red and green sauce along with melted cheese baked in oven, LOVED IT. HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS PLACE!!
author: Michelle P.

description: It was fun to try the oldest restaurant in the city and the quality of the food was great too. We ordered fish and chips and grilled shrimps & mussels. We loved both. They greeted each customer with a small shot of clam juice as soon as everyone sat down. We appreciate the vintage atmosphere and the very friendly service. We will be back.
author: Paiyu G.

description:
It's very funny how they serve you the Ciopinno, but don't judge it because of that, is excellent!!! you will need more bread to finish the sauce.

I have tried in so many different places to find a nice carb cake, and here you can find the most delicious Dungeness Crab Cake, is awesome!!!
author: Michael L.

description:
What a great place! I've always just passed by here but never thought to go inside so it was my first time ever. I love the decor inside and the bar looked like some kind of old timey saloon setup for the bar (a place that looks like it would be fun to watch some games at since it was so spacious). 

The food kind of reminded me of some things I could probably get at the Stinking Rose (the sizzling platters, for example) but I still thought it was delicious. The cioppino was fantastic, although we did order a "couples" cioppino to split between four people and they accidentally brought us a single one - they later brought us another single one to make up for it. The first batch we had was kind of thick and I didn't like that, but the second one came out super piping hot and more soupy and cioppino-like (what I'm used to) and I enjoyed it a lot more. It was also a bit chilly outside so it warmed me up real nice!

I'm excited to come back here and try more things! Other things I dug was the clam juice starter, which we got two shots of because we think they didn't know we already had some (we didn't complain). I think the one thing that I didn't enjoy as much was the service. Our server was pleasant, but it seemed like she forgot about us and we waited a while for her to take our order. It was a Friday night so I figure she was running around super busy but it would have been nice to have her check in here and there. 

Other than that, had a really nice time and I also like the Milwaukee Steam Beer. Will come again!
author: Caroline L.

description:
It's almost empty at this place, but it's understandable for being at such an old location. In the middle of Bayshore Blvd, there isn't really anything around except a few fast food chains and warehouse manufacturers. The staff was friendly and they provide bread with clam broth for dipping. I ordered the crab salad and it was quite delicious, they use real crab meat so that's a plus. But do I really think $15-$18 is worth the salad, maybe not.

The pricing for this place is a little off for me, given that they do serve seafood, I still think I can pay the same price for something even more gourmet. I don't know, I'm a little bit conflicted with this restaurant, although it doesn't have enough it-factor for me to return anytime soon.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
If you can't say something nice ...

Here's the nice part: Love the way the place looks. Like its been here for over a hundred years. It has. Spacious, good looking bar, high ceilings.

OK, I said it.

My date and I wanted crab; it is crab season. Most people probably assume that a place that specializes in crab and is old-world authentic SF would have fresh, local crab, right? Wrong. I'm from NY so I assume nothing.

Me: Is the crab local? [stupid question, I know]
Her: No, it is from Alaska.
Me: Is it fresh?
Her: No, it has to come from Alaska
Me: How do you cook it ? [disappointed, but willing to give it a try]
Her: Very quickly.
Me: In what ?[now I am suspicious]
Her: With oil.
Me: Do you fry it?
Her: No, we cook it very quickly!
Me: Do you deep fry the crab?
Her: We cook it quicky! [a little desperation in her voice]
Me: So you submerge the crab in hot oil?
Her: Yes [giving up]
Me: Do you have any fresh fish?
...

We ended up with Sand Dabs, a crab cocktail [no,I did not ask how it was cooked], and a Caesar salad. Could not find the crab in the $16 crab 'tail and the salad was ho-hum. 

Here the service deserves special mention. A woman, not our server, brought a pan with a lid on it to the table, put it down, took the lid off, and said something like, "Here you go" or maybe "Sand Dabs," I am not sure. She left us with the hot pan, no way to serve it, no plates to serve it on. Who knows if they were fresh.

As I was paying the bill my date asked if I thought we should help bring the dishes back to the kitchen.

If you want crab, go to safeway/WF and get a cracked crab + a bottle of dry white wine + a nice bagette and eat at home.

WTF deep frying a frozen Alaskan crab in an authentic SF searfood restaurant? Skip it.
author: Mark S.

description:
WARNING:
Watch your bill if you eat at the bar.
I just found out I got charged 10 bucks for escargot snails that I didnt order.
Too bad I paid cash or I woulda sic'd my credit card company on them.
And to top it off I gave a great tip for mediocre food and flat draft beers!
The only good thing is the clam juice and bread, and the clam juice is watered down.
Be warned.
author: FLICK R.

description:
Its been more than a decade since my last visit here.  Not much has changed; the dining experience is the same as I remembered it.  I love the cup of clam juice (in lieu of butter) that they serve with bread. I would've been happy with just a loaf of warm crust french bread with the dip.  My friend and I started off with an order of friend calamari.  I guess I forgot how big the plate is; the appetizer was probably more suitable for 3 to 4 people.

I had the clam and linguini.  The portion of pasta was very generous and it was literately blanketed with about two dozen fresh claims.  I was happy that I got to have it again for lunch the next day.  Service was good overall.  It took a while for the check to come; that was OK since we were not in a rush.

This is a great place to hookup with old friends and enjoy good food.  The restaurant has been here for ever and I hope it'll be here for the next 100 years.  Parking can be a challenge depending on what time of the day and the day of the week.
author: Jean T.

description:
I was looking for a good place to eat dinner and didn't want to go to McDonald which was the same distance as this place.

It's pretty pricey for the portions they serve.

The lady who took my order was really helpful. The dish i ordered Clam Baked Cioppino was good, HOWEVER it didn't have a lot of seafood it had plenty of potatoes though which was just fillers. The sauce of the dish was good Just enough spice!
author: Katya D.

description: I really was pleasantly surprised by this restaurant. Overall everything was very good and priced reasonably. We started of with the garlic bread and clam chowder. Both were excellent and I am not even a real fan of clam chowder. For our entrees we ordered the filet mignon cheesesteak, crab enchiladas, linguine and clams, and the sea bass. For being a fish restaurant there cheesesteak was fantastic, the sauce for the enchiladas was full of flavor. Everyone really enjoyed there food and the entire experience. We purchased some gift cards from Costco which made everything even more affordable. We will definitely be back.
author: Paul D.

description:
I always have a good experience here. I've been coming here since way back, 15 years or so. Anyway, the iron skillet mussels are the SHIIIII* . My boyfriend and I can easily toss back 2 large orders to ourselves, plus the garlic bread. Cioppino is on point too, oysters, crab, I personally didn't care for the crab melt but that's just me. 

Always friendly wait staff, except this one girl who I guess is a hostess. She looks at me sideways, never smiles, and is quite a dry personality. But it could just be with my boyfriend and I. I'm sure she's a doll. 

Shoutout to my last server Christopher. You made our day with those delicious desserts!!
author: Eryn V.

description: Wow love this place - what a special find on bayshore. Yummy food and good vibes.  We had the skillet shrimp, spinach salad, clams and linguini, cioppino.  All was super tasty.
author: Kelly B.

description:
Tasty Food, Great History, Service & Kitchen in the Weeds, Sketchy Neighborhood.

Always loved the Old Clam House on Bayshore for the history and the robust food so we took some long time friends who had never been.  Made a reservation for 6:30 on Sunday just in case there was a crows (there wasn't). Due to traffic we were about 10 minutes late and even though our friends were already there, the greeter told us our reservation had been cancelled. 

Good thing the house was mostly empty so seating was no problem. Plenty of sea food for four to start and great kettle bread to go with it.
 
Three of us had the Cioppino which is made with chunks of corn, potatoes and canned black olives at the Old Clam House, actually tastes great and makes an interesting variation on the more traditional styles.  Beloved had a large salad with grilled shrimp. 

The service was as sketchy as the neighborhood.  For three people eating the Cioppino, we only got one spoon and one bib despite repeated requests. The server never bothered to check back for drink refills and the food came out in raggedy order with the double order of Cioppino they had taking more than 10 minutes more than my single order.  Considering that the house was less than ¼ full, there is no excuse for this. 

The Clam House is in the same building that it has been in since the 1800's on Bayshore in Bernal "Depths" which is a pretty sketchy neighborhood. As we parked in the alley behind we saw at least three instances of shattered window glass. We parked the old mini van with a note that the doors were open and there was NOTHING to take. As we left, a family parked near where we were sadly looked at the shattered hatch of their car and told us that all their luggage was gone. 

It is that kind of a neighborhood. 

Park on the street if you can.

Overall we would give this visit a low B. Great food, sketchy service and a kitchen in the weeds for no reason.
author: Jim D.

description: Amazing service. Yvette our server was awesome. The last time I was here was 2010 and the food was horrible. My wife and I decided to give it another try, so glad we did. Excellent food and service. Will definitely come back. You have to try the crab enchiladas. AWESOME!
author: Victor M.

description: Loved the old clam house.Under New management, over priced and lost its charm. Crab cakes are still good!
author: Lana S.

description: Ordered a crab sandwich, hardly no crab, just bread. New owners, not the same clam house that I remember. Very disappointed!
author: Patricia C.

description: EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTED! I have been dining at the Old Clam House since the early 80's and it was my ultimate favorite seafood restaurant. Since I was in the City today, my husband and I decided to stop by for dinner around 7pm. The first indication of significant change was that the clam broth came out without their iconic sourdough bread and butter. I searched the menu for Shrimp Scampi and it no longer exists. I asked the waiter about a regular bowl of clam chowder and was told that it's the same price as the bread bowl of chowder. Ok, no problem. So, I decide to order a regular bowl of Clam Chowder and a Crab Louie, only to find out that they no longer serve San Francisco Sourdough bread! WHATTTTT?!!! I understand new ownership, but if your going to keep the same name, the restaurant should serve most of the same items. The Old Clam House use to be a San Francisco staple, now it no longer exists! If you are a long time fan of the Old Clam House of the past, you will be disappointed. I believe that the food they currently dish out is good, but IT DOES NOT COMPARE TO THE "OLD CLAM HOUSE" OF THE PAST!
author: PATRICIA D.

description: This restaurant is unsafe. After being assured by our server that where we parked was safe, we returned to the car parked behind the restaurant to find the back window smashed and belongings stolen. I will not go back.
author: David G.

description:
Came here on Christmas Day with family. The service was awesome..the food is outstanding. The Cioppino and the crab was amazing. Huge portions but fresh, delicious food. The bowl of clam chowder was more like a pot of clam chowder. 

A great place for any family gathering!
author: Mimi T.

description:
I love the clam amouse bouche drink they give you.  I always ask for extra.  This time I got the cioppino and it was delicious.  I also loved the clams escargot....I really always wish they would do duet type offers where you can pick 2 items or 3 items depending on how many are sharing.  This way I could get the clam linguine, cioppino and something else delicious, BUT I guess that's just me being a pigger. :) 
Go and enjoy.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Great spot!! Location not so great but when I'm inside I forget about the location. The menu is simple and to the point! Definitely a
Classic like they say an oldie but goodie! The wait offers good service and the food is delicious.
author: Patricia G.

description: I'd give a zero if possible.  For a Fishwich sandwich, a salad (overdressed), and two glasses of wine -- $56 -- no where near worth it.  Everything is an add on.  This used to be a cool place where workers in the area hung out.  No more.  For some reason Clam House went high price without the quality and value.  I won't be a customer.
author: Lora L.

description: A good place to sit down and spend time with friends
author: joey c.

description:
Loved the Cioppino.   I brought my family here for the first time for dinner.   My brother wasn't into peeling his own shrimp, so they provided shrimp already peeled just for him.   He was happy. 

Its one of the few unique restaurants that I return to in SF. 

The food and cocktails are consistently great.
author: Erin W.

description: This place use to be good. ... under newer ownership and the worse cioppino ever! !! First of all it came with only two small crab legs, not claws. Worst of all the sauce tasted like nothing but plain old tomato sauce with no spices at all. Total and utter disappointment. Also, the clam chowder was the worse I've ever had. Water based. ..no flavor or spices at all. This place is too pricy to have crappy food! Don't waste your time or money.
author: Richelle S.

description:
We went to The Old Clam House for lunch. Parking was scarce. We discovered a tiny lot behind the restaurant and parked in front of their trash bins. The smell was awful and right behind our car was a dead, decaying rat. Obese flies (and probably blind) smacked into our faces left and right.

We expected the restaurant to be busier since we were told to make a reservation. We came in around 3:30pm (on a Thursday) and the restaurant had only 3 tables and a few patrons at the bar. We seated ourselves and a kitchen staff/bus-staff brought out two shot glasses of overly salty seafood broth, cold bread, and piss-yellow, dry, hard butter.

We ordered and presented our Groupons: $17 for a whole 2lb crab or regular cut prime rib. We got both and a side of their "Mashed Yukon Potato and Zucchini," Italian Wild Strawberry Cheesecake, and a Coke. The other stuff amounted to about $18. With tips and everything, we spent over $60 and I really wish that $60 was spent elsewhere.

Service was ok; not great, not bad. The people were friendly. I would've really appreciated it if our server had told me that the prime rib came with a side of their "potato" already so we wouldn't have ordered another side of their "potato" which we never touched. 

My boyfriend ordered the crab and as he said, "it's not very good." My boyfriend is not that picky with his crab. Freshly steamed crab is his favorite. No seasoning required. So for him to say the crab was no good, I'm guessing it wasn't very fresh. It did come out really fast, like less than 10 minutes. We've steamed crabs at home and it takes longer than 10 minutes.

The prime rib came with 6 pieces of their "Smushed Dutch Creamer Potato." The steak was huge. It was at least 20oz. BUT there was more fat than meat. I lopped off all the fat and the portion of steak compared to fat was pathetic (like less than half). It tasted fine, I guess. The potatoes looked like they got stepped on. I kid you not. I've never had "Dutch" potatoes and I am not making fun of the Dutch. Maybe that's just The Old Clam House's interpretation of that dish. Seriously, what did those poor petite potatoes do to you? They were served with some sour cream on the side. Flavorless and very greasy.

The "Mashed Yukon Potato and Zucchini" came out to be exactly like the "Smushed Dutch Creamer Potato." Six pieces for $5.95. A buck for a tiny stepped-on potato!? And I don't know why I got more stepped-on potatoes. I thought I was getting mashed potato. They gave us two menus and one menu had "Mashed..." and the other had "Smushed..." I don't know.

The cheesecake could have been better. A sliver of a four-layer cake with alternating yellow cake and cream cheese topped with a strawberry/raspberry compote jelly. The cream cheese was light and airy but still creamy. I liked the cake instead of the usual graham cracker crust but the cake was really wet. Not worth $7.95.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Great food!! A good place to go for a late lunch on a Sunday. Not crowded, really mellow.
author: Celeste D.

description:
The cioppino and the sampler plate were fantastic. Both together make a good meal for two. The drinks alcoholic drinks were very good. The good and the bad is the location. It is out of the way over in the warehouse district but this can prove to be a plus since the location seems to keep the crowds down. 

Unfortunately the service was a little lacking, I'm not sure if it was due to one waiter or not. It was a Sunday night and we had to ask for bread at least four times while others around us got their bread first. 

Over all I would definitely go back.
author: Steve S.

description: We love this place and don't understand some of the mediocre reviews.  Food is always solid here and service is good.  We love the cioppino and the couple portion is probably enough for 3 people.  Reasonable prices and always a good meal.
author: Matt B.

description: Service great, cioppino yummy. Kid had chicken and chips that were cooked to perfection. Garlic bread also wonderful. Been here since the Civil War: there's a reason they've stayed in business. If you're looking for an old-fashioned seafood restaurant in the Bay Area, this is the place to go.
author: Faceless E.

description: Had a lovely lunch, both of our selections were excellent! I had the organic beet salad and my friend had the crab sandwich. Don't miss the homemade bread! Not a terrific area, but lovely once you get inside. An impulse that became a great experience.
author: Kathryn C.

description: Many friends have suggested coming here for fresh and delicious seafood. Not to mention this is one of the oldest historic SF restaurants. We were glad we made a visit as the food lived up to its reputation. Service was great. The restaurant definitely had the feel of stepping back into time. It's nice. All the dishes were dialed in, flavorful and fresh. Also, the dishes are very affordable. We learned that this place is owned by the aw person that owns Dead Fish in Vacaville, which is another one of our favorite places to enjoy seafood and a beautiful view on a warm day.
author: Tam S.

description:
Was super excited to visit upon returning to SF, and went there soon after arrival. Is this place under new management? The menu changed and portions were much smaller.

The bartender was lovely. Service was great...

But have been suffering from food poisoning for the past 3 days!

I came in for my birthday weekend to visit friends and family and instead of having a nice weekend, have been in bed most of my visit here.

Old Clam Bar, thanks for the memories, but your heyday has passed.  

Move on hungry eater...
author: Amy I.

description: Good seafood. Great for clams, oysters, and mussels. Convenient location right off the freeways with decent parking. This place has been here for a bit, and they still hang in there. Always a fun crowd too.
author: Peter K.

description: Wanted to love this place...but was impossible.  Clam juice was surprisingly very good.  Ordered bread, received no bread...got a weird excuse for no bread...meanwhile tables all around us received bread.  Was offered free cheesecake in place of bread, alas there was no cheesecake.  Crab was ok, not worth $70
author: Justin A.

description:
I can't compared it to the Old Old Clam House. I never went until 2011. 
Yes I understand that they've changed owners and the inside is different. 

Anyway.

I love their cioppino. Generous heaping portion of seafood and they do not skimp. I mean, how can anyone skimp on seafood in a cioppino!? Believe me, I've had skimped seafood cioppino before =( 
They always give you 2 crab legs (not the puny ones either), tons of fresh clams, mussels, squid, and shrimp. Only got a few chunks of fish but that was very fresh as well. I think the fish may have been grilled prior to tossing it because the skin was crispy. 

oh, and since I am a Old Clam House noob, I had no idea that was a shot of  hot clam juice that they give you when you first sit down. I admit that I asked the waiter what it was. It's too salty drinking it on its own, but tastes delicious when you've dipped some bread + butter into it!

Skip the clams casino, clams escargot are better. Not saying it's bad, but the flavor is just a whole lot better on the clams escargot. I know I know, escargot? Aren't those supposed to be snails? Just let it go..
author: Susy C.

description: I'd come back for the chowder alone!  So far that's all I've had... waiting for the rest of my meal but that would bring me back.
author: Andrew R.

description: I thought the food was pretty good but the coolest part is that the restaurant was founded when Abraham Lincoln was still president.  If you like clams, definitely on the "to-do" list.
author: eli o.

description:
This place is Old School.  From its location in a working neighborhood, the decor inside, to the food, this place does not hide from its dive persona, it embraces it with darn good food.  The staff was very friendly when we first came in and the service remained prompt and friendly the entire time.  You sit down and the first thing you are handed is a clam juice.  A nice, hot salty broth with a clam essence and a hit of scallions, just a great way to start.  We had the cheese chirizo bread and calamari for appetizers,  The chirizo cheese bread was just nice, gooey and warm with a hit of spice.  The calamari was fairly good but the breading did not stay as crisp as I usually like.  I had the Cioopino and the broth had a great lightly spicy flavor with lots of seafood including a good amount of crab.  It was a bit different for me as it had potatoes and corn, almost like a clam bake but it was a good addition as both soaked up the flavor of the broth.
