My wife had the fish and chips and she did like them very much too.  The fish was fried nicely had did have very good flavor in the batter.

We were a large group but we all just ordered the two items.  I know that when I do go back, I do want to explore this menu more.  But if the items were any indication, they do seafood well and it will be worth going back!
author: Scott P.

description: Crab cakes were excellent, crab alfresco was excellent. The coolest decorations in the city, and 150+ years of history, plus they give you this free hot clam juice shooter for free which was delicious don't listen to the haters do yourself a favor and come here
author: Deango R.

description:
Rustic atmosphere, old school type place that's rare in SF.   My go to dish here is the cioppino, lots of fresh seafood.    Decided to try the clam pasta dish instead.   Very tasty pasta , portion is modest if you're a big eater.   

For appetizers, ordered crab cocktail and calamari.   Fried calamari was okay, probably wouldn't order again.   But the crab cocktail is sweet and fresh, wish I ordered two.     The cup of clam chowder was delicious and rich

This is a non pretentious place with a local feel.  Service staff are nice down to earth people.    Oh, the seafood linguini is the best linguine I had in this city.   You gotta try this place at least once.
author: John L.

description:
Not what it used to be ( but then again, what is what it used to be ? ). The Old Clam House used to be a place to time your visit to when the 49er's (that would be the football team) would  hang out and dine after a game. Used to be a bit dingy. Used to be a bit divey (ooops is that a word?). Now "cleaned up", food is still good but more pricey (but what isn't more pricey). History (one of the oldest continuing restaurants in SF). Still like the vibe / character , it is now a bit more modernized. Gotta have clams at The Old Clam House,  the Calamari, the Mussels, the fish ... Seafood Seafood Seafood ! (although they do have some beef dishes on the menu.... but who would go to The Old Clam House and order a hamburger ????)

The good news is that the new owners seemingly have a sense of tradition (maybe why they bought the joint) and thankfully did not wreck the culinary orientation.
author: Matsuo U.

description: A great seafood meal at a reasonable price.  Not the best neighborhood, very industrial, and certainly no seaside views.  Parking is spotty.  But once you get inside, lots of history, a great bar with cold tap beers and excellent cocktails.  They do pack too many tables into the space, so it gets cramped, especially on the patio.  The food makes it all worthwhile.  Great seafood and great breakfasts.  Fantastic ciopinno.  Very good service.  A great alternative to the high priced options in the city center.
author: Ken P.

description:
I have wanted to try this place for years.... It is out of place and looks like something you would find in NJ.... In some small beach town....or under the 101 in a sketchy area....  

My wife and I shared the clam chowder, my wife had the cioppino and I had the fish and chips.  I have to say the fish and chips were the best I ever had!  Well the fish was.... The chips were just ok. If they kicked them up a notch with had cut fries I think I would be a regular here.  

The chowder and cioppino were also good.   The pace is a bit pricy, but the staff was friendly and the food was good.
author: John F.

description: This place keeps changing owners and has not improved with any of them in the 7 years of me checking in for improvement.  After all I reside in the area and would love to have it back as my go to place in the neighborhood.  At this point all I will get from here is a Crab Louie.  Last nite I got one with extra crab & it still had about a 1/4 cup, if not less, of crab on the salad. What a rip off!  With all the changes thru gentrification happening in San Francisco this is one place I wouldn't object getting gentrified.
author: Deana W.

description: It seems like I visit the The Old Clam House probably twice a year and it's not necessarily because the food is all that great, but rather, I think it's because of the nostalgia. This place reeks of old-school San Francisco, pre-$4.00 cup coffee and pre-hipster onslaught. This place has been around forever... As a matter of fact I think it's the oldest existing restaurant in San Francisco, but I may be wrong. The food is decent and the servers are pleasant enough... It's a good place to relax and enjoy the game while having a few beers as well. The clam chowder is probably your best bet!
author: Louise I.

description: The Old Clamhouse has a charming 'old world' feel. We tried many dishes. The Fishwich, garlic bread, seafood salad, the clam and shrimp hot place. Everything was delicious! The Fishwich was a tad bit greasy.
author: Cyn T.

description:
Good food in a very historic atmosphere!

I was here twice in the past few weeks.  Once for a private party in the enclosed patio room, where the guests were offered choices from a special menu; the second time was to try the regular menu.  I came back the second time since my experience the first time was so good!

The building has been a restaurant continuously and in the same location since 1861.  This makes it the oldest restaurant in California. The interior decor reflects that and is great and perfectly appropriate, including tin ceilings, and lots of historic photographs on the walls.  When this restaurant first opened, it was on the water front (on a river that snaked to the bay); now the waterfront is over a mile away due to land fill over the last 150 years.   The bar is the original 1861 part of the building.  It has a somewhat crooked unevenly slopped floor; the restaurant staff said that they are required by the city to not fix it since the floor is historic.  Patrons may dine in one of three rooms: the bar room, the main dining room, and the enclosed patio room (originally outside of the original building, but not completely enclosed). In the main dining room, there are several curtained booths for private dining. 

The historic decor is a great setting to the delicious food served by this restaurant.  

Cocktails are about $8 each and are competently made and generous. 

To start, everyone is served with bread and a shot of hot clam juice.  I have never experienced hot clam juice before.  I found it to be very good and an appropriate start to the meal. 

On my first visit, I had the cioppino, which was delicious (and a bit messy). The sauce was thick, slightly spicy, and very delicious.  There were many pieces of various fish and shellfish including large crab hunks.  

On my second visit, I had the Calamari Steak Doré ($16.95). This was perfectly cooked (it is very easy to over cook calamari, but the chef here knows how to do it perfectly, so that it was tender, juicy, and delicious). It is served with a very tasty tiny pasta (acini di pepe) with sun dried tomatoes and snow peas. 

On our second visit, it was right after the Dickens Fair (a few miles away in the Cow Palace), so were were attired in Victorian clothing (I was wearing a top hat, frock coat, ascot, waistcoat, etc), but it fit in perfectly since the restaurant decor is of the right era.  [Other people don't wear Victorian clothing here, but as long as we were wearing it, I felt that this restaurant was the most appropriate place for us to dine after a day in 1863 London!]. 

I recommend this restaurant.
author: Mike M.

description:
We had planned to pick up a bunch of crabs from Half Moon Bay for Christmas, but my sister suggested lunch here instead, so no one would have to clean up.  Good idea.  There were 7 of us around noon, and the service was quick and generally good.

We ordered calamari, fries, garlic bread, a couple of salads and a couple of large platters of cooked mussels, shrimp and crab.  The crab was overcooked, but everything was tasty.  I don't like a lot of salt in my food, so it was good for me.  The portion sizes seemed right, since we managed to finish everything and no one was still hungry.
author: Seong P.

description:
Three stars for the food and one star alone for the wonderful server we had today. She was a doll. We had fresh oysters, clams escargots, caesar salad and cioppino. The caesar was ok, not the best I've ever had but everything else was really up to par, good size portion and plenty of flavor.

The pints of Anchor Steam were the best beers on tap I've ever had in SF, and I drink a lot of beer. It was the perfect pint. This is a diamond in the rough. I love the curtains on the booth spaces, made me feel like I could be movie mafia! Small but decent kids menu too. I'll go back for the beer alone.
author: Susan C.

description:
Like many of the reviewers I have been going to the Old Clam House for years. But unlike most reviewers I don't think the place has been ruined by the new owners. At least not the clam chowder. It's the only thing I order and is still the best I've ever had. 

Every restaurant I go to (and always those that specialize in seafood) I order the chowder. From my unscientific survey, I must say from Half Moon Bay to the Wharf and everywhere in between, the Old Clam House's is the best around. 

We parked behind the restaurant (in a small alley) and walked by the open kitchen door as we made our way to the front entrance. I sneaked a peek inside the kitchen. A cook was stirring the chowder in a large steaming industrial pot, whistling a tune with a smile on his face. Happy restaurant staff is always a good sign of a decent restaurant. The kitchen floors were spic and span clean. No flies, no rats, no spills, no garbage.

With the change of ownership, the decor has changed a bit too, as in cleaned up. Literally. Sure, the license plates, old photos and other items of nostalgia has been heavily edited from the walls, but seriously, when was that stuff last cleaned? So some character is gone, but no doubt so is inches of dirt and grime. I do miss the car above the bar and the clam shell bar stools, but other than that, I appreciate the facelift, the new clean red checked tablecloths and modern menus.

If you're a fan of thick, creamy, dense chowder with more potatoes than clams, OCH's chowder is NOT for you. Their chowder is brothy, light on the potatoes and brimming with clams. Oh so delicious accompanied by hot, fresh Sourdough french bread that's so good it doesn't even need butter (but if you want it, it's provided, nicely chilled). 

I LOVE the shot of clam sauce that's served with the bread before your entrée arrives. It's like a little preview of what's to come; tempting your taste buds. I'm not aware of any other place that does this. It's unique and delicious.

I ordered a pilsner to go with my chowder. I'm a lightweight so I appreciate the half pint option. The smaller size actually encouraged my husband and I to order additional beers they had on tap to "taste" which made the meal a lot of fun.

Parking is VERY limited, but as long as you're aware of this, it's not a big deal. The chowder is worth it!! Don't take multiple cars if you're going with a group. Pile into one car. It will make things easier. Try the narrow lot behind the restaurant (which is more like an alley). There might be "a" space. Or park along the side street. Be sure not to leave any valuables in the car and lock it up tight. OCH has been on this spot since 1861. The neighborhood around it has changed over the years - a bit rundown and industrial, but don't be intimidated. OCH is on a busy street corner and there's no scary streets to navigate. The entrance is just steps away.

Enjoy the chowder!!
author: Jenn H.

description:
I love dining here  and have been a regular for a couple years.  There are great servers who know our orders and take good care of us.  The mussels can't be beat.  Crab Louie is a fave!  The menu changes occasionally (now they charge for bread with dinner?), and the new long-boat dinner dishes are awkward. 

But ... the real reason for the low review is the safety in the area.  My friend's car was broken into recently while parked here.  Tonight we didn't heed her warning and parked in the dark alley behind the restaurant and our car also had its window smashed, all for the thieves to take some things they no doubt can't use.  Sorry - until security is better, we won't be back and I will miss those mussels ...
author: Erika M.

description:
Have not been here in a long time, but I will come back often now, if even only for the Hot Buttered Rum pancakes. Yep, they are that good. Imagine what it might taste like, and then go have some, and you will agree. So good. 

The seafood is still on par with anything else, perfectly prepared, comes out steaming, so yummy. 

And the warm clam shot to start the meal is always a nice treat. 

+1000 for the receptive staff being so cool with my party who changed tables twice during our meal because it was too hot near the window. 

I love the patio, but not so much on sunny days, gets too hot. 

And the chili bloody mary is really good, too. nice and spicy with a rim of chili salt. 

Place has lots of history, and the bar is  super old school SF Charm. 

This place should be on your short list of SF Must Try.
author: Adrian M.

description:
Came for a nice family dinner, celebrating my Dad's birthday. 

I had always passed by this place before, but since the outside looked kinda weird and dirty looking, I thought the inside would be the same. Fortunately, it wasn't.

The bread tasted very fresh, it was delicious. Service was also good. We got there around 5ish, so the place was half empty when we got there but it got a bit busier around 6ish. 

I ate the shrimp linguini, and it was alright. It wasn't flavorless, but I think it could've been better. The serving sizes were a bit disappointing, I think my plate was a little more than $10 but the serving was pretty small, but put on a fancy plate to create the optical illusion of a lot of food.

I wouldn't mind coming back. But I wouldn't voluntarily go there with friends.
author: Sophia G.

description:
Update - We decided to try the Old Clam House again. Saw some photos on line that looked like they spent a good amount of effort in cleaning the place up.  

Well, the only nice thing I can really say about the place is that the remodel they did was nice.  WITH THE EXCEPTIONS of a) they took off 90% of the fun stuff on the walls in the bar and b) they removed the tractor seat bar stools.

They do not have the large cherrystone clams anymore. We ordered the steamed clams and although it was a more traditional broth, the clams were over cooked. My husband did like his basa with lemon butter caper sauce. I ordered the cioppino but got the pasta with cioppino sauce. 

Upside: the prices are lower than they were before. They now have a kids menu at super reasonable prices. They also upgraded the dinnerware. 

Honestly, we probably won't go back.  No clam house linguini, no cherrystone clams - those were the 2 reasons we braved the not-so-elegant neighborhood from the peninsula for dinner. 

I've down-graded my rating to 2 stars.  Sorry - I liked the old Old Clam house better. 

Original Review February 2011
I've been going to this place for over 20 years.   I LOVE this place but I'm afraid the winds of change are blowing.  They are under new management (owners of Calzone's in SF) and they are screwin the pooch by making changes to standard, good old favorites on the menu.

We had dinner there last night.  We always order the steamed clams. The waitress warned us it's different... said "there's parsley in it now".  Hmm there was parsley in it before.  UGH it was the same giant clams but the broth - WAY too salty and it is PESTO that's in the broth.  

Our hearts sank but we kept our hopes up for the rest of the dinner. Only to be kicked in the gut.  I crave the Clam House linguini... that's the reason we braved the storm on a Thursday night to have dinner.  I could see that the red sauce was different.  And it tasted different. I get the half white/red sauce... the white sauce was watery.   Since we had just eaten a ton of crab over the weekend, my husband decided to try the broiled salmon. BLAND. Lovely looking veggies and mashed potatoes that went with.. BLAND.

What an utter disappointment.   We gave the waitress an earful. We asked if there were new owner - she said yes.  We asked if there were new cooks in the kitchen.. she said YES! We gave her all our feedback.  She siad the new owners were going to focus on "higher quality food".  Holy crap - that's double-talk for "we're in the biz and know this place could be better" 

To make matters worse, we couldn't help but notice the original dining room is completely under renovation.  They left the classic tiled roof but I dread the thought of change in a good ol place like this. We usually eat in the bar.  When I asked the waitress if they were going to remodel the bar... she stuttered and said she wasn't sure. I'll HATE it if the remodel the bar.

New owners of OCH - PLEASE do not try to make the Old Clam House  some swankerffic north beach restaurant.  People don't drive to the bayview/hunter's point for ambiance.  The only thing going for OCH is the food and historical interior.  AND YOU'VE DECIDED TO CHANGE BOTH!!

There's an old saying - If it ain't broke, don't fix it. You're about to ruin a very good thing.

p.s. thanks for power-washing behind the building. That was a highlight of the trip.

Giving 3 stars today hoping that on our next visit we aren't entirely disappointed.
author: Hitomi B.

description:
Came over the weekend and glad to see their cioppino is still excellent. I especially appreciate they include a good amount of quality fish in there and not just shell fish.  The crab meat is fresh and firm. The the broth is very addictive.  

They are offering lunch specials on weekends too. A very good deal with a nice bowl of their signature clam chowder and an entree of choice with a side of quinoa for $12.95.
author: Manny K.

description: We have come here many times over thw past 30 years.  The place has gone through several owners and many menu changes also.  The latest change seems to be the worst.  The plates have gotten larger ans the food portions smaller.  Looks good for a presentation, but if your hungry go somewhere else.  By the way the prices have gone up, larger than the size of the plates.  They also use frozen crab in San Francisco...????  What is up with that????
author: Peter S.

description:
Ambiance is cool.  The mid 50's manager that seated us seemed alarmed that we would not spend enough money when we asked to be able to use laptops in the bar.  He didnt need to worry, the prices were high.

I am sure it takes money to maintain a place like this.  However, the beers are like ball park prices with their $6 small a joke in a restaurant.

Here is how it breaks down, this is a place to try once so you have been there.  But, the food doesnt even live up to Pier 39 Bubba Gump quality and this is shameful at the price.

If the steamed clams or chowder had just amazing flavors then you could justify an $85 pre-tip bill for three appetizers and three beers.  But the flavor of the food is what you would expect from a TGI Fridays.  

If you have to go for the experience, get a cocktail and cup of chowder, say you did it, and then have your meal elsewhere.  In the end, it felt like having a cup of chowder at Disneyworld.  You didnt get anything special, you paid high, but the environment was well decorated.

Service was prompt but tepid.
author: Scott F.

description:
Starting with the calm broth and bread and going onto the main course and dessert, the restaurant is great. Having been here quite a few times - the food is always consistently delicious. Mixed seafood entree is a favorite. Drinks are also creative and tasty - love the cucumber martini. AND they have the best breakfast. Who would have thought that a clam omelette could be this delicious! 
Both male bartenders are extremely professional and attentive. Had a girl bartender once - she was a bit sloppy, had her hair down, didn't follow the "standard" house procedures of providing proper utensils and setup for dinner or coffee. Hope she has been trained properly since, but even that was not enough to lessen my experience at the Old Clam House.
author: Poppy C.

description:
I would give them ZERO stars if possible. This is my first Yelp review that I have ever done, that is how bad the service was that I could no longer just sit back and allow restaurants to give crappy service along with mediocre food. 

First off, I came here 2 weeks ago and the atmosphere was chill and the food was just alright until the bill came. The waitress had overcharged mines and my boyfriend's cards by at LEAST $300 when our bill was only $40. 

So we both got overdrafted and had to pay the overdraft fees on top of being out of those couple hundred dollars for a week and half.

Spoke to the manager and he said there was nothing he could do but that he could give up complimentary meals. 

2 weeks later- We return thinking that we would both get our meals on the house. NOPE. The same waitress (that messed up last time) returns to our table to give us our bill, so I was surprised and told her that the manager said that our meals were on the house. She then told us that we would only be able to get one meal for free after arguing with me about the date that I came into the restaurant last time. I tried to tell her that it took more than week to get my money back into my account, and she confronted me to insist that I only came in the week before- which is definitely wrong.

ON TOP of while all this is occurring, another customer was also complaining about the service to the manager. I overheard that this customer was unsatisfied with the manager and how he was handling their complimentary coffee and dessert. The customer was trying to explain how unprofessional it is to say you are going to do something, and then not follow through with it. Thus, the manager was not being a man of his word. 

As we were leaving, the customer looked clearly bothered and attempted to reach out to the manager again and the manager just reacted with little to no concern. From what I experienced, the manager seemed to have some prejudice towards certain customers, giving a different quality of service to certain customers.

Therefore, if you want to OVERPAY for mediocre food, with TERRIBLE managerial service, then the Old Clam House is the place to go. Otherwise, don't bother.

Trust me when I say, I'm not too demanding to customer service, I understand how it feels to be working for a restaurant and how frustrating and stressful the job can be, but this experience was just over the top bad management that I had to write a yelp review.
author: Cat M.

description: Authentic decor and fast friendly service. Excellent clam chowder in a bowl and beer. Ordered a liter of The Old Clam House Milwaukee Steam beer  and was a happy camper! Kind of in a weird neighborhood but worth the trip!
author: Samuel L.

description:
Tried the steamed clams.  If a place called "The Old Clam House" can't knock steamed clams out of the park, then, well, maybe they should change the name.   

The dish was served in a saucepan and while the broth was excellent, there weren't many clams and they were tiny!  After shelling all of them I had maybe 5 bites.  (See the attached photo).  Now I'm from the east coast and even the crummiest place on Cape Cod would blow this away.  

For a $17 lunch it was very disappointing.
author: David P.

description:
Finally visited this place after their renovation. When I walked in, it seemed to be the same Old Clam House that I remembered. I brought my girlfriend here after she mentioned she was craving seafood.

Her sand dab was prepared well, but she did not enjoy the sauce. I had the seafood cioppino. It tasted great and I had my fill of seafood. The sauce was so good that my girlfriend used the leftover sauce to flavor her fish.

Overall, it was a nice time at a nice restaurant. No complaints or issues here.
author: Jesson d.

description:
I've been here a handful of times over the last 15 years and I keep coming back because of the atmosphere. It's a casual family friendly restaurant with some alright  seafood. I like the clam chowder and the salads are good. The crab enchilada was a bit salty the night I had it but the concept was good. I like that they serve an Israeli couscous instead of rice as the starch on the plate. 

I went on a Monday night and the bartender was not the kind of person I'd expect behind this bar. I was expecting someone seasoned and maybe a bit salty with a personality. But this guy- god bless his lil' heart- was kinda bland. Service was acceptable so I'm not going to fault him. Not everyone like me wants a charismatic bartender.

Parking seems to be a challenge especially if you're a single woman arriving on your own at night. So be on the lookout for shady people. You're walking along Old Bayshore after all.
author: Allison J.

description: The BEST cioppino you can get in bay area ! Hearty, fresh seafood, just a "comfort" food and the price is so reasonable. The family size one can easily feed 4 with leftover. I also tried the crab on skillet but found it to be a bit overcooked, hoping it was just that day. Definitely solid place for seafood
author: Mimi L.

description: Clam bake, steamed clams, clam broth with bread...YUM!  Desserts were very good also.  Definitely one of my favorite restaurants.
author: Marvella W.

description: I am a sucker for historic restaurants, and this one has been there for almost a hundred years. Loved their clam "juice" as they call it (a glass of clam broth, delicious!) and the chowder. Great history but the current neighborhood isn't my favorite (kind of industrial), but what the hell.. It was a fun lunch! Definitely recommend it!!
author: Marina V.

description: Born & raised in SF, used to come here all the time as a kid - many memories of good food & family. In town for vacation & I was a bit nervous seeing how much the city has changed - would The Old Clamhouse be as good as I remember? YES! Amazing dinner - did the Hot Skillet Double Shrimp & Crab & I killed the whole thing. Just go. Now.
author: Secret S.

description:
Crab season is on!  

The menu here gives a choice of 1, 2, or a lot of crabs, and a recommendation of how many people should eat each size order.  If you've eaten crab before, you know you'll eat all you get.  

My Lady was looking forward to steamed crab, and we did not ask whether that was available.  It is, but if you want it be sure to ask for it.  We didn't and we were surprised.  

We were seated at mother-in-law's request on the patio, and ordered 2 whole crabs, steamed vegetables, a Caesar salad, french fries (mother-in-law's favorite), and a bottle (3 glasses? Take the bottle.) of Trefethen chardonnay.  OK, the table was packed.  Packed!  And sitting right on the edge was a tempting loaf of good old sourdough bread with butter.  I must have thought about picking up a slice of that sourdough about 20 times.  

The Caesar salad was good and the steamed vegetables were all right, but the dungeness crab was what it was all about.  2 whole cooked crabs, served on a sizzling platter, drenched in butter, so hot you could feel the heat radiating into your skin.   There it was.  Secret sauce and all.  After the waiter brought out the bibs and nutcrackers, all conversation ended.  We had to break free every morsel of fresh crab meat.  Game on!  

After the crab feeding frenzy, the house showed us a game of its own:  a little dessert-only menu popped up out of the waiter's pocket!  My resolve to stick to my diet was decimated.  A lemon torta della nonna (I don't know.  Lemon chiffon pie, with extra yumminess.), Italian wild strawberry cheesecake (Hey!  Real strawberries!  With 2 extra layers of crust snuck into the middle, FYI.).  A black tea, a green tea, a coffee with milk.  

Oh yeah!  

The whole extravaganza was $168 + tip for 3, and I must express appreciation to our waiter who made sure we were happy all the way through.  Also to the hostess who checked out the patio table for us before we started the trek from the front door.  

I could go on, but let's just summarize that my impression of the Old Clam House as a first-class seafood restaurant has been restored.
author: David D.

description:
This place is a wonderful and historical hideaway. With great food and great staff!
Great for a group and weekend seafood fix. 
Keep this to yourself.... Ok?
author: C J.

description: One star for the ambiance another star for the hardworking bus boys. Food was average. Disappointing service. You can barely spot the waitresses. I ordered crab cakes, clam escargots, clam chowder and salad, shrimps&mussels skillet, and seafood linguini. Food was fast ... way too fast. I got everything I ordered all together in 5 minutes. I don't know if it's the restaurant style or they thought I'm Asian!  Last but not least they charged for the bread! Most of the restaurants with the similar menus serve better bread with the meal at no charge.
author: Prinya W.

description:
This is an experience every San Franciscan should have in my opinion. I think most costal cities have a legendary old school fish restaurant. We have a few in SF but most of them are super fancy. Though this is not cheap, it is also not a white linen experience. It is a great place to go with family and spend hours having delicious crab and things. Keep in mind that the area around this place is a bit sketchy so don't leave anything visible in your car. We were broken into but we are aware leaving a laptop bag in view was pretty stupid. Don't make that mistake and don't let that stop you from coming here. It is totally worth it.

Come here and have crab and an Anchor Steam while you remember why you love this city.
author: Eric G.

description: Nothing bad to say! The last time I've been here was about 15 yrs ago for my sisters 18th bday! Everything has changed but for the better! Food was awesome. I can't believe I only live bout 5-8 minutes aways and I never thought of eating here again, until my cousins and my sister got together and we decided to eat here. Everything was delicious and the Peachy Martini is the BEST!!
author: Mona Lisa L.

description:
Very disappointed. We have wanted to come here for  years because it is one of the oldest restaurants in SF. The new owners must have remodeled it, and to me, it looks like new things that are made in the old style. The outside looks original, but not the inside doesn't. I wanted to feel old time San Francisco, and I didn't. 
We ordered crab and were very disappointed. It wasn't moist and juicy and delicious, although the garlic butter was great. 
The service was wonderful.
author: Patricia B.

description:
Can I get some seasoning people?!

The "clam chowder" was really more like clam and potato soup, not a true chowder. If that's the color of chowder, something is very very wrong.

I ordered the shrimp scampi and there was no seasoning on anything. A little salt helped a lot, but even then I wasn't really impressed. In a town that prides itself on amazing seafood this place doesn't come close to meeting the bar. 

The chocolate mousse cake was really just chocolate mouse with Hershey's syrup drizzled over the top. 

With this place's long history I really hope they get their act together.
author: Vanessa J.

description:
Have been driving by this place for some time and finally had dinner here this evening.  
Definitely an old time feel and great 50s/60s music playing in the background.  My husband and I started with two perfectly prepared and chilled martinis.  Love how they are served in individual shakers.  They also start you off with small glasses of warm clam juice.  Delicious.  My husband had the cioppino and I had the steamed clams.  Both were generous servings and very tasty.  The bread is nice and crusty and excellent for dipping in the broth.  Attentive, but not intrusive service.  We will be back.
author: Deonna T.

description: Not thrilled with the oysters I got here. Kusshi are normally delicious and sweet and these had a bad aftertaste and smell. Should have returned them but stupidly just paid and left. The garlic bread I ordered was the only redemption, crunchy on the outside, sliced thin into perfectly manageable slices. And not too much butter or garlic, just right.
author: Kat M.

description: Absolutely wonderful experience, from the little clam juice cocktail, to the crab-for-two.  Great cocktails and cheesy garlic bread also.   Every dish that passed our table looked and smelled incredibly delicious.   It was very difficult to finally decide on our entree.   Wide variety on the menu!    Our server was such a delight, made us feel so welcome.  The ambiance is cozy and historic, and delightful.    I will definitely be back with friends.
author: Audrey F.

description: the service was good..once again sf did it again..stuff changes daily..and in this case not and i mean not for the better .shrimp louis !! rip off !! they gave a native of sf... bay flippin shrimp and dressed it up with the foofoo baby beets !!! and fancy greens !!! no asparagus !! no hard cooked eggs !! it was a fraud in all aspects !! I'm gonna say it again..rip off.if you at all a chef ..that Louis wouldn't have come out of your kitchen..I would've been ashamed. HOW DO YOU NOT KNOW ???
author: Linda R.

description: The food was off the chain. So freaking good!!!! Service sucked. Our waiter asked 1 time was everything ok and that was before we even ordered. ..He walked past our table to 3 other tables making sure everything was good. I had to wait 10 minutes for a new fork. Poor service but great food
author: Jessica H.

description:
Highlights:
-Easy to make a Friday night reservation.
-Cool atmosphere - definitely casual but did not feel out of place going trendy for date night
-Servings were large enough for next-day leftovers
-Funky cocktail list

The food was pretty good, but a touch bland for the number of ingredients. The tomato mac and cheese with clams was great, but maybe it was just too much food and too much of the same taste. I'd recommend getting two dishes and sharing!
author: Lia S.

description:
3.5/4 STARS 

I used to come here with my family as a kid. I still come here occasionally...although I do remember the food being so much more flavorful back then. I'm not sure if its due to a change in management and cooks over the years, but there definitely is a difference.

So recently I've been here on a couple of occasions. I went here a ladies brunch, dinner using a groupon and had dinner after my graduation with the family. The food for the ladies brunch was ok. I ordered the crab alfredo. It was very creamy but definitely was in need of some seasoning....or salt...something.... It was creamy but really really bland.  

 The time I used the groupon was great. I ordered the prime rib and it was cooked just right. It was a great sized portion and I really enjoyed it.

As for the graduation dinner. I ordered the lamb shank which was overall really good. I enjoyed the flavor as did others that were nibbling off my plate, but others that were joining me for dinner did not enjoy their selections as much. I guess their orders were bland and small in portions. 

This place is kind of a landmark, but can be a hit or miss. Things that I love to order which are consistently good are the clams in a pot, clam chowder and crab cakes. 

Things that are okay but definitely need a dash of salt are the white cream pastas.
author: Krystal T.

description: cioppino soup. Old school. Get their steam beer too.
author: Ryan K.

description: This place is close to my house and i pass it all the time on my way to the freeway. It looked like a good restaurant so I came here for lunch and I must say I was not impressed. I got the clam linguine and it only had a few clams and the pasta had no flavor. I had to keep adding salt and pepper. My boyfriend ordered fish and chips and it was okay but not memorable. It seemed like very mediocre food but with a large price tag. I thought it was an off day for them but my brother also tried them out and he waited 45mins between appetizer and entree. He was not impressed either. I won't be coming back here.
author: Lisa M.

description: I've gone back to the Old Clam House twice this year since my last review in 2012 and WOW what a difference. The food is very good. The cioppino is delicious (although slightly expensive) and the crab louie salad was very well put together. The house clam juice was a great starter and the house made bread is great for dipping. The drinks we're not perfect, but we're not here to rate this place on cocktails. Overall, I had a great time here. Good job for turning things around!
author: Phil C.

description: We had a fantastic time here the other night! I can't believe I had never been To the Old Clam House before. Their cioppino is so delicious, it might be my favorite in the entire city. The staff was friendly and the service was efficient. I loved the bread and clam broth that they served at the beginning. The price was right, and I left feeling full and happy. The only meh part of the meal was the fried clams, but they were still good. Really great old San Francisco ambiance; I am definitely going to take visitors here from now on.
author: Regina L.

description:
This place has been on my bucket list for a while now. As a native San Franciscan, I've driven by this place for decades but never stopped by.  After seeing a review on SFGate, I decided tonight would be the night.  I'm not sure whom I'm more disappointed in, Mr. Bauer for recommending this place or TOCH for the experience.

I made my reservations via Open Table for 8 pm. En route, I get a call saying I missed my 730 reservation. However, by the end of the message, she had realized her error and said she sees it's for 8. Made me a little anxious that the place would be packed and we would have to wait for our table.  We arrive and not only is the place half empty, but the hostess stand is unmanned.  We stand around for easily 5 mins trying to get someone's attention until a waitress finally spots us and after giving her my name says to go sit over there at the table set up already.  Doesn't even have the courtesy to lead us to our table. We sit there and it turns out she is now our waitress, but doesn't come by to take our order for 10 mins.

Now for me, dining out is the food, service, and atmosphere.  If one is off then the others better be on point to make up for the missing link.  We had the clam chowder (decent, but a little salty), the beet salad and the seafood cioppino.  The portion was generous but the flavor was lacking. The kids had the pasta with tomato cream sauce and it came out a gloppy clumpy mess.  The chicken and fries were ok.  Throughout the meal we had to flag someone down for more bread, more water, the check.  Leaving the impression, that if we didn't, the servers would have just left us to ourselves.  

Having heard the pedigree of the owners, I had high expectations, so much so that I made reservations at another of their restaurants, Osso Steakhouse this weekend simultaneously when I made the one for TOCH. However, given this experience, I'm having serious second thoughts and might just cancel.
author: Dave T.

description: First time to the Clam House this weekend.  Getting water and a cocktail took forever for as slow as it was.  Some older gentleman standing around I assume the manager or owner could've pitched in a little more with that.  I got the crab enchilada which is NOT an enchilada.  It's a wet burrito with cheese and crab inside that wasn't even as good as my super seafood burrito from a taqueria.   Why are you calling this an enchilada?!  It is offensive to my Mexican food sense being half Mexican. The tiny martini glass was also a let down.  Can't recommend this place I'm afraid.   Next time we are going to  Scoma's.
author: Lisa J.

description: Split a small cioppino with my lady yesterday. Crab leg tasted funny, then bit into a BAD mussel which tasted of feces. Had to shoot the rest of the clam juice to cleanse my palate. Appetite gone after that. Stomach problems later that night. Not fresh. Plain and simple.
author: Anthony R.

description: We are regulars and the pan roasted mussels, fish and chips, and freshly baked loaf of hot bread never disappoint. We enjoy the complimentary glass of clam broth as well. Yesterday at lunch, the customers at the table next to us ordered the clams prepared escargot style and the wonderful garlic aroma wafted over us like a heavenly fog. We love everything about this place including the kind greeters, servers, and bussers. It is past season (July) for local crab so enjoy the excellent fresh fish and mussels instead.
author: Donald K.

description:
Good:
Comfortable atmosphere
Tasty seafood (We had the steamed clams and fish and chips)
Several TV's for sports fans looking to watch the game
Plenty of parking

Bad:
A bit on the pricier side
Service was quite slow and needed reminders
A little hard to get to if you make a wrong turn on the way there

Random tidbit:
In the guys bathroom, they have what appears to be a footwash...  like the kind you would see if you went to the beach and need to wash some sand off

Pretty solid place.  It's a bit on the pricey side and the service is a bit slow.  My girlfriend was jonesin' for some steamed clams and this place seemed just right.  They serve you clam juice with some bread and, while tasty, didn't give us any bread.  The fish and chips was fairly large and tasty.  The steamed clams were tasty as well, but the clams were small and the portion a bit small for the price.  Overall, worth a try but I am not sure if I'd go there on the regular.  Just special occasions I suppose.
author: Vincent-Arthur B.

description: Reading the reviews, I got my hopes up. It was really nothing special. The fries were good, but why make a big deal about French fries? Anyway, I'm not impressed and the service was minimal. I will not go out of my way to come here again.
author: Michelle R.

description:
I can't believe I've been  missing the oldest restaurant in San Francisco  for a decade .. Built in 1861, before Abraham Lincon
became president. Mission Bay was a real bay, until the duchies took over Potrero Hill and the bay... I was invited to a private party of the 50 people.. 
I had the rib with veggies and a small salad..
the dressing tossed in the salad was just too perfect..
I don't think I had ever eaten such a lean beef like that..
Our waiter was pure good, since we were all 
Tipsy.. But I think their hostess could do a better job.... Not because of me ,but it Is the warms hostess that gets their customer happier at first sight.
I do recommend to my client who wants to be stronger "get bigger"to add 6-8oz beef depend on their healthy status ..
Thank you for the fabulous beef..
author: Pedro D.

description: My boyfriend and I came in for lunch. There was nobody there so we figured it would not take to long to be served. ..wrong! And to add insult to injury she was being super loud in the back speaking Spanish (I'm not against the language but one language please! Or at least keep it down back there!) where she shouldn't be! Stop talking about your personal business out loud in front of customers in either language!  For someone who understands Spanish-language I know what she's talking about!  I'm in the restaurant business and this is totally unprofessional and disappointing! I'm still in the restaurant right now  (11/29/2014 @12:17pm)and the host is STILL being loud in the back! Management needs to step it up!!!!!!!
author: Phenion T.

description: I fell in love with this place. The food was fragrant & so very delicious. The selections are incredible. It's a must try.
author: Liz D.

description:
We just had brunch here for the second weekend in a row... and we'll likely go back next weekend to bring some pals who also live nearby. The ambiance is inviting and full of old school charm and character. The service is great and friendly too. 

The first time we went, we weren't sure what to think of the hot clam broth they start you off with, but it is delicious and great for dipping your bread. We also enjoy the crab benedicts, smashed potatoes, hot buttered rum pancakes, blood orange mimosas, and bloody marys-- which are all rather tasty and worth going back for. We haven't been for lunch or dinner yet, but are looking forward to trying the Old Clam House for other meals.

Note that they do open at 10am on Saturdays and Sundays for brunch, even though their web site says 11am.
author: Lori H.

description: The food and service here was exceptional.  We came here for a work lunch.  The meal begins with a "shot" of a warm clam soup I guess it is.   I had the crab alfredo for my entree.  It was sooooooo full of crabmeat.  I finished the entree and wanted more.  The serving was huge but I hopefully burned some of the calories off at the gym..lol  Highly reccommend this place for lunch or dinner.
author: Keith E.

description: I Love this place after they got a few upgrades.  The food is great and the service is excellent.  The tables are small so if you have a big group it's gonna be tight.  I had to ask for a few things that we didn't get on the table but other than that it's one of my favorites for seafood.
author: Rose R.

description: I've been here twice for work parties. Seafood (cippioni?) was pretty good. I like their bread. Great staff.
author: Ange G.

description:
WARNING........WARNING.......WARNING

THIS PLACE HAD HORRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

First we had to come into this location to make a take out order. (wow) 
After waiting 30  minutes for our Lazy Man Cioppino to be prepared, which we paid $30 for.
We went home and opened the bag and there was NO BREAD!!!!! Who eats a Cioppino without bread.  I guess my fault for not looking. 
So my husband called to ask about the bread, he was told that is an extra charge. I about fell out of my chair. You mean to tell me, bread is extra after sending $30 for the Cioppino. 
 "WHO DOES THAT!!!!!!"
A man on the phone said it would be an extra $1.20 for each piece of bread. I was not happy as we just spend $30 for this meal and now they wanted $2.40 for bread. You know we each needed our own slice. So for those folks who are familiar with the Cioppino know the importance of the bread. So my husband when back to get the bread.  I do know one thing I will not patron the Old Clam House again. 
I have already started my search for restaurants who will give bread (without extra charges) with their Lazy man Cioppino's. Guess what Old Claim House every place I have called, YES they give bread at no charge. "Found several places "WHO DO THAT!!!!!!!"
GOODBYE OLDD CLAIM HOUSE, you have lost a very loyal customer you had for 20+ years over $2.40.
Be assured I will tell everyone I know of this horrible customer services you have provided. 
Don't ask me about the Old Claim House.  I have nothing nice to say.

HOPE IT WAS WORHT IT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Felicia K.

description: This place is amazing the atmosphere the food is just wonderful the service is just terrific I can totally see why this place has been here for 150 years oldest restaurant in sf definitely try it out trust me try the ciopinno
author: Nicholas Y.

description: I used to love this place when I was a kid and came all the time all the way through high school with my family, but some time when I was in college, the place changed ownership, and it hasn't been the same since.  Went back recently, and the cioppino was tiny (as was everything else), and the food just wasn't the comforting, old school SF food I remember it being.  I mean, I'm not even sure what's happening on the menu anymore.  Enchiladas???  Food is decent but got pricier and doesn't shine a light on what it used to be :(
author: Tracey L.

description: This place use to be so great I had to give it five stars.  In the last year things have really started to go downhill.  The food menu has been considerably cut on two different occasions to save money now. The staff is turning more quickly.  All of this is the sign of the end of an era when it comes to The Clam House....
author: Kevin R.

description:
Have driven past here a thousand times and always meant to stop in. It's old San Francisco, it's seafood -- what's not to like? Well as it turned out, quite a lot.

As others have mentioned, once you are seated, they give you a glass of clam broth. My oh my, this is one tasty little drink. But it went downhill from there. 

First of all, it wasn't that busy, around mid-afternoon. But even though there weren't that many people there, they must have been very understaffed, because we sat and sat, and waited and waited. Finally someone came and took our drink order. I could see it sitting on the bar all by its lonesome and considered getting it myself, but finally someone brought it to our table. We ordered our lunch and waited again. I think it's pretty reasonable to assume that if two people order one dish each that they will arrive at the same time. But if you assumed that at the Old Clam House, at least on this occasion, you would be wrong. My husband's dish was delivered to the table separately -- no explanation about where mine was, just slapped it down and left. I sat there and looked longingly at the kitchen entrance, hoping mine would materialize. Nowhere in sight. My husband was nearly done when my entree finally appeared. Really bush league service. And the kicker was, it wasn't even that good. I had ordered steamed clams, one of my favorite meals. When it arrived, it looked like a lot of clams. But as I began to take them out of their shells, it became apparent that half of the shells were empty! I'm from Boston and the Cape and grew up digging and eating steamers, I know that sometimes there are empty shells. But there were so many that I swear the kitchen had to have known. Who knows? Maybe they did it intentionally to make it look more impressive. But I was not impressed.
author: E. G.

description:
First time eating here, dinner. Sand dabs were pretty good, crab cakes and beet salad were excellent. House beer was surprisingly delicious, and my wife's martini got two thumbs up. 

Service was friendly, professional and ridiculously fast. 

Will be coming back.
author: Korbett C.

description:
Gotta Love the history of this place..after the 1906 Earthquake and it's "Still Standing" serving great seafood to the masses after all these years....I was introduced to The Old Clamhouse by a Co-worker in the Late 70's and have been going ever since ! A recent visit to theIr Website shows some pretty neat Inprovements as of late so I better gas up the Horseless Carridge and head for the City...Be prepared to rub elbows with all walks of life here as its always been a Local hang out from Suits to Bikers all of them with the 
Common Like of Great Seafood.... Over the years I've tried just about everything on the Menu- but I'm still partial to the basic Clam Juice and Sourdough accompanied with a 
Ice Cold Draft that they serve as a starter....
author: Dave A.

description: I sorta forgot about this place (since the big change) But I gave it a shot and it was delicious.  It seems like they got it together finally!
author: Ken M.

description: I love this place. When the fresh bread and clam juice arrived I knew the food was going to be GREAT! and I was right.
author: Jacek P.

description: Talk about old school...and in a good way.  Good food, good service, a little out of the way, but a good spot when you want some seafood classics.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Ambience - 3 stars
Food - 3 stars
Service - 4 stars
Drinks - 4 stars

I would give this place a 3.5 stars if I could. My cucumber gimlet came in a cocktail glass and also accompanied by a half full small shaker. I like that.

Clam chowder and the fish & chips (HUGE) were good and hearty, but I didn't do my "MMMMM!!!!" thing, so it's a 3 stars. I'll most likely go back though.
author: Aya C.

description:
Really like this place. 

We had chowder and fish&chips. Both were excellent.

Server was amazing -- fast, fun, friendly. What else could you ask for?

I'll be back...
author: Craig I.

description: Just awful. Lots of historic kitsch on the walls if that's your thing. Service was just OK and the food was terrible. I had a shrimp sandwich loaded with mayo and served on a white bread hamburger bun that tasted like it came off the bargain table at Safeway. Pasta dishes looked equally unappetizing. Unless you are a history buff [Clam House is the oldest existing SF restaurant] stay away. -lars
author: Lars J.

description: A mom and pop place. Really awesome cioppino. If you get the one for 2, it is plenty of food for 3 adults. We even had leftovers! Service was great and had an overall fantastic experience. From the street you may think it isn't great, but once inside and eating the yummy seafood - you'll be glad you came in!
author: Jessica D.

description: Who would have thought this little restaurant so far from The Wharf would be so darn good!? This is apparently one of San Fran's oldest restaurants dating back to 1862, I believe. The cioppino was so delicious and a single portion was quite generous and enough for 2 people IMO. It's a must try. Also had some delicious crab legs. For the price, it's definitely great seafood with good portion size.The place is cute and charming and off the beaten path and the wait staff were very nice and attentive. I'd definitely go back!
author: Melody Z.

description: This has been on my must go list forEVER and this trip was totally random. Had started out late afternoon headed to Just For You. Of course, there was a crowd waiting to be seated and it was already 3:00. Next stop, Flora Grubb, which turned out to be just a little more coffee and less food than we anticipated. My friend said, "How about the Clam House?" Turned out to be the perfect solution - not only was it near by, but I could check it off my list. Have to admit, the menu looked a bit pricey but everything we ordered was excellent! I had a crab omelet that came in a skillet (and was gigantic) that came with some really crispy potatoes (just the way I like 'em). Love the atmosphere - strangers were chatting between tables - and the staff was great. Don't know what took me so long, but I will definitely be back soon.
author: Robert M.

description:
I am in food love.

My boyfriend and I came here on a whim after driving by it literally hundreds of times on our way home from work. He kept telling me that it was a really nice restaurant, but I just couldn't imagine anything close to "nice" being on that stretch (or any stretch) of Bayshore.Luckily I was feeling totally bored with my own cooking this weekend and all of the restaurants in the Mission, so I decided to give the Old Clam House a try.

This was probably one of the best seafood restaurants I have been to in the city. I would say, from what we had, that they stand up to Hayes Street Grill and totally out-do The Fish Market, and are a bit less expensive as well. Here is what we had:

Starters:
-Delicious complimentary bread and clam juice as we waited for our food
-Bowls of clam chowder that were incredibly thick and creamy. I, who do not even like clams or any clam chowder at all, was practically licking the bowl. 

Sides:
-We ordered a side of Dutch Creamer Potatoes and a side of Swiss Chard. They are large enough sides for two people to share and have some left over.  The potatoes were covered in this delicate crispy skin that tasted like they were pan fried in butter, and the swiss chard was just about the best I've ever had. It was sauteed with bacon, onions and lemon juice and was just perfect. Not a hint of the bitterness that I usually get when I order this in restaurants. 

Entrees:
-The Seafood Cioppino Stew was my boyfriend's pick and he ordered a "bowl" size instead of the larger "terrine". He was worried it wouldn't be enough food, but couldn't even finish it. His words--the words of a man who is not impressed by much-- "The best cioppino I have ever had." All of the seafood inside was fresh and flavorful.
-I ordered the pasta with a red pepper and onion sauce with shrimp added. I would give it a 3.5 out of 5. It wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be and could have used more sauce over the noodles. The shrimp and noodles were cooked perfectly though, and tasted fresh. 

I was really craving a little Moscato or Limoncello after dinner, but they did not have it on the menu, so that was a bummer. I skipped desert, but the waitress did mention it is all made in-house. Our consensus after the meal was that we would definitely come back to try out more of the menu. Excellent experience for an early Sunday afternoon dinner!

Dinner for two with two glasses of wine $75
author: Sylvia H.

description:
We just go back from an informal early Sunday evening dinner with a group of seven friends.  We were seated in a cozy corner away from the ball games on TV and had no problem with multiple conversations.  The attentive, friendly and knowledgable service started with delicious bread and shots of clam juice.  After asking a fair number of questions of our server who was very forthcoming with answers, we all decided on the three course prix fixe menu.

There is a choice of delicious, meaty clam chowder done with a creamy potato base or a nice salad with very fresh romaine, grape tomatoes, red onions and house vinaigrette for a first course.  Choices for the entree for our party included tangy cioppino, a generous portion of sizzling dungeness crab legs and crab enchiladas.  There were seven other choices available.  Service was timely, but not rushed.  The entrees were delicious and generous enough to be filling but not enough to be gluttonous!

One in our party decided to skip the desert course and had both the chowder and the salad.  She missed out on delicate tiramisu, tart lemon cake, rich rum cake and fresh strawberry cheesecake.  The desserts are not made in-house, but the waiter told us they are from Bindi, a Milanese bakery that provides wholesale, high-quality Italian desserts to restaurants and clubs around the world.

Groups of six or more are charged an 18% service fee, but the service was worth it.  The prix fixe is definitely the way to go for a complete meal because it's a savings of 30% from a la carte prices with the same size portions.

The restaurant has been in the same location since 1861 and the decor of historical photos reflects some of that history.  The atmosphere is clean, simple and inviting.  There is plenty of parking and access from US 101 is extremely convenient.
author: Ahmet A.

description: FIrst time here. It was really nice place. I don't remember what I had at the moment but my fiance had the Cioppino which he said was good but why better before the new owners. I'll stopped by again when we visit SF.
author: Erica S.

description: We had recently discovered The Old Clam House and their amazing pan of Sand Dabs which were so delicious. I say were,  because a change has been made that has ruined the Sand Dabs for me. They used to be served with delicious Acini pasta, which absorbed the butter lemon sauce beautifully and enhanced the flavor of the Sand Dabs. Today the dish was served with Gemelli pasta and we were told this would be permanent. So sad! The Gemelli are heavy and flavorless. I won't order the Sand Dabs again. There must be something extra special about a place for us to battle the lack of parking space and traffic. Now I'm not so sure The Old Clam House is worth the hassle.
author: Susan A.

description:
Amazing history.
Great food. 
Wonderful bartenders with great attitude and skills.
Easy to find parking spot.
Fast service at the tables. 
The area is a little industrial but it's pretty safe.
author: Eric S.

description: The worst service I have had in years plus $7.95 for  a side of fries get a clue...Clam Chowder OK, AND $28.00 for Shrimp they were tasty but for that price take the freaking shells off.... NEVER EVER AGAIN....
author: Matthew R.

description: My hubby and I stumbled upon this lovely restaurant while on a business trip! Has so much history and was so amazed how old the place is. ..the food was delicious , service was great and the drinks loved it! My hubby ordered the filet mignon which was presented so pretty with yummy potatoes,pearl onions,i think sweet potatoes and corn and I ordered the crabwich sandwich...so delish! I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Chebet S.

description:
Went in for lunch today out of tradition for an institution that has been around for many many years in San Francisco. Over the years I conducted much business here for the Union at lunch time.

So my better half chose to go here for lunch and the first thing that goes wrong is that we get something other than what she had ordered from the bar. We have to go up to the bar because now we can't find the waitress. His response is well thats what you ordered and I can only think how do you know that you were not at the table when we ordered drinks. Customer service? I think not! They were not able to produce the first thing we asked because they said they did not have it although as we looked at the fully stocked bar we noticed some excellent substitutes none of which were suggested by the server.

The menu is not that good anymore so I would think that the customer service would have to be kicked up a few notches. We were unable to eat what we ordered, and so we packed it up to go.

I would say to the management that folks will have to be taken in the back and reminded that customer service it essential expecially at a time where the place is practically empty.

I hope they survive but it looks bad. Oh did I mention the prices have gone up dramatically. I don't mine spending the bucks but give me something in return.

Speaking of returning....I don't think I ever will! Big loss for this establishment as I like to eat and entertain out a lot and always take care of the servers. The check gave me the breakdown on tips and I normally leave a minimum of 30% so I left 15% which means the server was hurt by this suggestion oh well thats business.
author: Jim S.

description:
First of all, clam juice is weird, and I loved it. When we were seated (out on the closed-in patio, away from all the TVs inside (we were there on Super Bowl Sunday) where the music was GREAT), the waiter brought us hot clam juice in glasses. I had to ask what to do with it -- was I supposed to sip the hot juice of clam? Because I would! I just needed to know. Yeah, he said, or dunk your bread. I did both, both ways were fantastic and as salty as the ocean. 

The crab was spectacular -- quite literally all the crab I could eat, and I can eat a LOT of crab. My wife says no one has lived until they've seen me covered in butter, eating crab. Usually I am fastidiously neat while eating. I don't like to get my hands dirty. In fact, when I was a kid, I would only eat half a chocolate bar, and then ask to wash my hands so I could eat the other half. 

Not crab. Crab, I attack like the Tasmanian Devil attacking a zookeeper (it happens, people: check Youtube). And this was some crab. Delicious. 

Lala said the steak was good, too. I believed her. The oysters were perfect. The martini was a little weak, but they give you a good amount, so that doesn't hurt. 

We went on a Groupon, but we'll be back just on our own. 'Cuz mama don't go too long without her crabby little delicious friends.
author: Rachael H.

description:
Without question the most amazing clam chowder on the planet...! My girlfriend and I flew from Vegas and were headed to BevMo to stock up for the weekend. by sheer chance of the luck of the gods we stumbled upon this beautiful old place. The first thing we both noticed where the floors were as crooked and windy as Highway one along the coast. We sat at the bar where the waiter set out with a strange, warm cocktail in shot glasses and hot bread. After one sip of the premium elixir we both knew this was going to be an exceptional experience. Our drink was a mixture of clam juice and potato soup prepared just right. We ordered clam chowder and cioppino (mixed seafood).  And that, as they say, is when the fun began...

Served from the table of Zeus himself, the chowder cannot be adequately represented with human words. Even my Spanish girlfriend having eaten seafood and clams her entire life is still talking about it two days later. The chowder was not in the least over salted, it had just the right amount of each key ingredient to harmonize their wonderful favors. And the seafood soup was the freshest ever...
author: Yelp V.

description:
I frequented the Old Clam House in the mid-2000s (under the previous ownership).  I've heard people lament how the place had become sterile when the new ownership took over.  Truthfully, from my recent May visit, I was not able to perceive a difference between the new and the "old" and "new" Clam Houses... maybe just some superficial cosmetic changes and the elimination of the televisions from the bar area.  All in al, I thought the food, drinks and service were just as middling as they were under the previous ownership.

I will say... as a self-proclaimed cioppino connoisseur, I found the cioppino quite disappointing.  It had a decent amount of seafood, but the tomato broth lacked body and the depth of flavor I expect from cioppino.
author: Michael H.

description:
Go for the clams!  They're  So good. sure, one would expect the clams to be good here,  given the restaurant 's name. But it  does measures up. 
Eventhough the clams were on the small side, We still will be back for more
author: Linda D.

description:
I love this place.  I have gone here off and on over the years.  The food is always good and the service is always top notch.  I noted that someone wrote in their review that the prices are high but for San Francisco they are what you expect for a decent restaurant.  [If you want to pay just a little less go to McDonalds just down the street and eat that slop.]  My go to dish here is the clam chowder which I love.  But the cioppino is also delicious and the fish and chips are great.  I have never had a bad meal here.

My last visit here I took my nephew along for the ride and he is notorious for being picky about food, especially seafood.  He inhaled his meal and was poaching on my chowder.
author: John P.

description:
5 stars for the whole Dungeness Crab... it is the truth. It is the deep fried Dungeness Crab truth. Amen. 

P.S.: My wife wants me to add that the bread should be toasty warm when it's brought out.

Background: I've been going to this restaurant for the last 4-5 years with my wife maybe once a year even though its right around the corner. Last week we celebrated her birthday with the 3lbs of "lotsa crab" and it was incredible (not sure what happened for the other reviewer), a week later we were back (remarkably) and I had the whole crab and it was my best shellfish experience of all times (including my multiple visits to Maine to visit my brother).
author: Adam G.

description: Old school charm, big feast of a seafood boil, and delicious bread.  Lots of regulars who seem to be treated extra well by the servers.  Good for families, special occasions, or just plain guzzling of warm clam juice.  This is our new date night spot.  Prepare to get stuffed!
author: Desmo K.

description: Very old school feel and vibe. I recommend coming here. Had the crab, and it did not disappoint.
author: Steven V.

description:
A terrible Valentine's Day experience. We waited a long time for our waitress to take our order--and then much, much longer for our food to arrive. It finally came an hour and a half after we got there--and my dish wasn't what I ordered. (I'd asked for seafood pasta and got cioppino.) My wife also found her seafood  "enchiladas" to be more like burritos. 

Eventually, someone came out and offered a half-hearted apology and an offer of free dessert.; we were so ticked off, and it was so late, that we declined. We were billed for the full cost of the meal, including my seafood pasta which I never actually got.

Never again.
author: Harry M.

description: Great place to eat. Food was great. service was wonderful and the ambiance of the place is so nice. Definietly try if in the area!
author: muftia k.

description: Martinis! Well, that's just the start... We picked the Old Clam House from a hotel magazine (in room) and decided this was historic and probably good. I used to work in the area and remembered seeing the Old Clam House, but never went (shame on me). What a class act this place is! Generous with the clam juice with bread and butter. We like fish, shellfish, garlic, spicy sauce and were satisfied with the offerings. My friend chose Seafood Cioppino, I had the Seafood Linguini. The seafood was plentiful, everything there, clams, mussels, scallops, shrimp, calamari and octopi. the spicy sauce was perfect - what more could you want? Oh yes, martinis of chilled cucumber vodka so refreshing. The food was a great value for the price. I'll be back.
author: Cheryl S.

description:
Not to be missed-- had a great time and felt so nourished by the delicious food.  I hope it stays open another million years~ and that I get to return someday to try other dishes.

We enjoyed the shot of clam juice--it was akin to miso soup.
Fresh sourdough bread & butter--a treat. And better for the belly than plain white bread bcz sourdough is fermented.
Delicious marinara-type seafood platter a friend ordered-the abundance of sauce left after the calamari and fish bits were picked out made amazing bread-dipping, and I poured some on my somewhat simple arugula salad. (the salad was a light simple balance to all the other rich food. But I still doused it in sauce--yum!)

My amazing friend Polly Superstar and all her/my amazing friends celebrated her American citizenship by partying here, and what fun we had!  Thank you Old Clam House, for being an SF institution with class yet down-to-earth service.
author: Ms Ayden B.

description:
This place sucks now.. Been going to the old clam house for years and the new owners have completely ruined it.  

I feel sorry for anyone who has given this place a good rating since the change in ownership because they really have never experienced this place when it was good.
author: Derek L.

description: This has got to be my favorite restaurant. I take my friends my family and my employees here. Food is always great service is good, unless your a snob. Best clam chowder I've ever tasted. Soft drink portions are very generous. Everything  on the menu comes very generous. You never have to ask for a drink refill because the give you a small pitcher of your drink on the table. Great place to eat. If you notice most of complaints about this restaurant are from the younger generation who wouldn't know the difference between good seafood or not, because they have only had seafood a few times, in their short life. They have nothing to compare it too. This restaurant is for people who have respect and some sort of class about them. This restaurant has been around before their grandparents were conceived. This place is more than a great place to eat its a landmark. How can anyone have anything bad to say? Shame on anyone to say anything wrong about this place. You should all be sent to etiquette school.
author: Victor M.

description: We discovered The Old Clam House earlier last year and loved it!  The location is a bit odd underneath the freeway overpass, but so convenient when on your way up to the City.  Everything we've had here (I think we've come back at least three times) has been delicious.  Not only are the crabs and seafood dishes excellent, but the prime rib is one of the best ever anywhere!  The cioppino ranges from good to fantastic depending on the kitchen staff or night of the week, I guess.  Clam chowder is great, and the steamed clams are awesome.  If you need your seafood fix without the hassle and wait of finer restaurants in San Francisco, The Old Clam House will do in a heartbeat!
author: Sherri C.

description:
I enjoyed learning about the history of The Old Clam House and ended up having a pleasant experience.
We arrived around 7:00pm and were greeted warmly by the waitress. The menu was not huge, but there was a good selection of dishes. In the end, we decided on oysters for appetizer, the prime rib and a whole (dungeness) crab. The waiter also served us bread and clam juice, and explained that it was a tradition of that place.
We did not have to wait too long for the food to come out. The oysters were fresh and the perfect size, being a oyster lover myself, it was a good start. The prime rib was also perfectly cooked, and came with a side of roasted potatoes that were delicious. The highlight had to be the crab. It came out smoking hot on an iron skillet. Although it didn't look too big, the crab had A LOT of meat, with the special garlic sauce fully infused into the meat. In short, the crab was delicious. 
Despite finishing all the dishes (and cleaning the sauce on our plates), we still found room for dessert and ordered a tiramisu. And although I had no high expectations, it was delicious as well; rich and creamy, the perfect ending to a wonderful meal. 
All in all, really loved the food. The place started to get crowded around the bar as the evening went by. I could tell that those who were there are regulars, and now I know why. Now I have a good substitute to the overpriced tourist traps of Fisherman's Warf,  Will definitely be back for more of that delicious crab.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Well, I came here at about 9:30pm on a Friday night! The first thing I saw was an old lady throwing up in front of the restaurant with her friend holding her hair up. Although I did not see her throw up, she might of been faking it? I mean people to do stupid crap like that to try to get free or discounted food right?

The service was good as there were not too many people there. I was given bread and clam juice (which I never had in a shot glass) and since they ran out of house bread I got garlic bread .... Score! This was pretty good!

I ordered Clam Chowder for an appetizer and for a place called The Old Clam House I was expecting a fresh and amazing tasting chowder, sadly I was disappointed with it. It was luke warm!

I had the prime rib dinner and that was only so so ..... it had a disappointing fat to meat ratio, so mostly fat and very little meat. The meat had decent flavors and the effort was there and maybe I just came to late and didn't get the better and fresher soup and meats.

Would I return? Probably not.
author: Kris D.

description: I've been here several times with my girlfriend. We love it. The steam clams are amazing, as are the oysters on the half shell. We've also had the fried fish, the crab, and the fishwich as well. Everything was well prepared. The interior design is very old school and warm. The staff is attentive, warm, and down-to-earth. Parking may be tricky. There is a lot around the back of the restaurant in an alley. It seems a little murky but we haven't had a problem so far. Also, the give you a complementary shot of clam juice before taking your order.
author: Rudy S.

description:
Was looking for seafood close to where I live and this came up on Open Table, so booked it after reading the Yelp reviews...It reminds me of one of those local establishments you would expect to find in most coastal towns, but right on the water - this place is a little more inland (although we aren't far from water any direction you go in San Francisco) - a lot of charm and character to the place.  Lucky we had a reservation as we were walked right past a dozen or so people who didn't have reservations and they all gave us the stink eye - so long suckers - make a reservation next time you want to eat on a Saturday night at 7:30PM...
I tried one of their local draft beers to drink - nice and light flavor - we ordered the clam chowder and they make it a little different than I have had any where else - seems like the potatoes were almost pureed into the broth - made for an interesting consistency and a really stand out clam chowder like nothing I've every had before.  Order the bowl - it was worth every bite.   I had the Crab Louis salad for dinner - this was just enough of a meal for me and the crab was very fresh and tasty mixed in with a lot of extras to make it a decent meal.
Wait staff is really fun and other than the table next to us that had one too many drinks that they had to sing along with all the songs that came over the sound system - probably time for them to go home before the one sitting across from me falls out of his seat - we left before that happened, but was only a short amount of time before he passed out - other than that....I will make this a regular stop now...looks like I can go to the bar and just eat there if I want to swing by on the way home from work some night.  Great spot.
author: Steve A.

description: The Clam House has been a tradition in my family for generations and this is why it is so hard to write this review. I will start by saying the food is great, the atmosphere is nostalgic and I believe the new owners have done a great job with this place, especially with the private booths (you can close the curtains) in the main room. However the service is why I am giving my beloved Old Clam House a 1 star. In the past it has always been friendly, fast, and enjoyable but we got the wrong server last friday. Jonathan was rude, sarcastic and in a way came off plain snobbish. Nothing was wrong with the food and it all came out in a good amount of time but his attitude left a bad taste in all our mouths. He made the meal itself less enjoyable and turned a pleasant evening out into a bad mood. I have a hard time picturing myself going back, which is sad because like I said my family has been going there for generations and we have fond memories, let alone family pictures, at The Old Clam House. This last experience has tainted those memories and it will be a while before I go back, if I ever even do. If you do go to The Old Clam House do yourself a HUGE favor and ask for a different waiter.
author: Carrie P.

description: My parents and I came here during Pride weekend and it was pretty dead. That was awesome! I had broiled salmon with pasta. The bread was delicious. They have TVs and the staff is really mellow and kind. I don't know why I don't come here all the time!!!
author: Julia D.

description: Fish and chips... yummy. Bread dipped in clam juice shooter (I dont drink it) beverages served in glass milk bottles. Watch a game, eat a meal... works for me! =)
author: Ms C.

description:
I'm giving it a 2 star rating only because I don't think "A-OK" quite describes this place.  The Old Clam House used to have the best clam chowder.  It's where I would take people who came in from out of town and the food was always delicious.  Yes, it was a little divey and what not, but who cares.  It's what I liked about this place.
