The new owners are the same owners of "The Stinking Rose", "The Franciscan" and a few other of the tourist trap restaraunts down on the wharf and in north beach.  So maybe they're trying to turn it into one of those with it's fake antiqued paint job and old feel.

On to the food, my most beautiful wife and I ordered the clam chowder and "Lotsa Crab" (for two).  The clam chowder reminded me of a watered down split pea soup with clam thrown in it.  Gone was the delicious creamy and oh so amazing clam chowder of old.  The crab came next and it was only subpar.  There are much better places in the city to get crab and for less.  It almost tasted old.  I can't put my finger on it, but there just wasn't something right.  Needless to say, I probably won't go back again.

RIP The Old Clam House
author: Joe K.

description:
Best food, bets drinks, best service! We had a big family gathering - more than 40 of us - and had a complete blast. Bartender Judy was the best and . Server Yvette was totally top notch and kept us in line and made us welcome. She had as much fun as we did - and she got every damned order right!

The food was awesome - Dungeness Crab Enchiladas, old school Crab Cioppino - real San Francisco Cioppino - Sand Dabs... Just awesome local food. 

Highly recommend.
author: Tim D.

description: Great food .... If u love sea food , this is the place you want to go . Have been here only once though but defiantly going back when in SFO .
author: Vinod K.

description: So it was our first time here and it was pretty quiet on a Sunday evening. We settled in quickly with our table and got our menu. The menu was simple and was easy to order from. Since it was a seafood restaurant, we decided to go with the Cioppino (couple size) and a mussel/shrimp platter (medium size). It was a very good portion for the two of us. It also came with warm clam juice and bread to dip into the delicious Cioppino. The shrimp/mussel platter with butter sauce was juicy and delicious. The Cioppino soup was filled with variety of goodies, including clams, mussels, shrimps, potatoes, olives, crabs, carrots and many more. This is one of the closer places we can go for seafood from now on.
author: Elaine C.

description: We just went there a couple of days ago and surely i really enjoyed my seafood festival meal.. their choppino for 2 is a really a good worth the prize dish, it has alittle bit of spice on it, full of good fresh seafood in it.. So i will definetly gonna go back their and try some of their platter dish, next probably will be their Calamari..
author: Marnie P.

description:
Speaking as a "Bernal Heights yuppie"... They've sanitized most of the character, and raised the prices. I'm not against change, but the reason I bothered to go here was *because* it was a local joint with character that did seafood well. I can get starched tablecloths and pricey wine at any number of places in the city, but where can I go now and see a car above the bar?? Where?? Now there's only a token strip of license plates above the kitchen... I'll probably go back, but it won't be the first choice. 

Annoying drunken hipsters last night probably didn't help either.
author: Chris K.

description: If you haven't been here yet, you must go! Great ambience and tasty seafood. In a weird part of town that's not very nice but worth the trip.
author: Maria B.

description: We stumbled on this amazing restaurant.  The best cioppino I have ever eaten. The salmon was delicious as well.  Although the salmon portion was small.  The clam broth served with the bread is amazing.  I can't wait to go back.
author: L S.

description:
How should I start this?? I'll put it like this... Before all the renovations took place, I would've rated The Old Clam House with 5 stars but now that it's under new ownership/ management and everything has changed, I am rating it with 3 stars. You would think that with all the up-grades it would get 5 stars but NO, that is not the case. However, I must say that their interior decor has gone up a notch but their food has gone downhill,and that my friends does not work out well with me.

They took a lot of their signature plates off from their new menus!! The food now comes in smaller plates and for some reason, it does not taste as good as it did before. They probably got new cooks. They used to have lots of San Francisco themed memoribillia, which is now gone.  I think they are trying to make the O.C.H. a more up-scale place, which, is not what the Calm House was known for. The one thing that put me in a "Wow, this sucks now" mood was that their prices doubled! Someone has to pay for that new look though, right? Smh...
author: Cesar N.

description:
Looks like The Old Clam House has changed ownership and revamped the place and menu. Gone is the old Giants and 49ers memorabilia on the walls.  The place did to get revamped a bit because it was a bit dingy. But it gave it character. They added a indoor patio on the side where it used to be storage. They might want to frost the windows a bit. Don't see the need for everything to be open because there's not much of a view in an industrial area.  We were seated in the patio area even though there were plenty of tables in the bar area. The floor must not be on a even slope because I felt like I was eating down a hill or something. 

Menu - It was our first time dining in there since they changed ownership and revamped the menu. The menu looks more pricey than what regular patrons would be used to. We tried the calamari appetizer, Fish and Chips and the Seafood Pasta in spicy ciopinno sauce. The sauce wasn't spicy at all. It had regular and green pasta w crab, clams, mussels, and calamari. The pasta was a bit over cooked and the sauce was a bit bland.  The fish and chips was a very generous in size. It was decent . Not too greasy or overcooked. The calamari was ok.  Nothing too exciting or bad about it. It was garnished with some peppers. Crispy and not to battered. 

Service: I don't recognize any of the staff and it looks like they revamped that too. Our waitress was good and very attentive. I have no qualms about her or her service. 

Overall the food was just ok. I have to somewhat save my opinion till I go here a few more times to find my one favorite item. New menu means new experimentation. The place seems too pricey for the area. Maybe it's because it's near yuppy Bernal Heights.  Hopefully the place can change my opinion when I try it a few times more.
author: keith s.

description: Dropped in here for lunch on a saturday and was seated right away, We took advantage of Costco's gift cards and brought our 2 boys with us. They greeted us with a couple of clam juice that were really delicious. We ordered the cioppino for 2 and the serving was huge, and very good. We also ordered the crispy crabcakes and clam chowder, and they were also really good. My boys loved the fish and chips. We also had bloody mimosas with it and we were impressed. We loved all the old pictures of San Francisco displayed inside. The bathrooms were clean. What kept us from giving this place 5 stars was that there was only one server and one assistant that time. Our food was brought to us quickly when there were only 3 tables being served. A few more people arrived, and it took the server a while to get back to us for water refills and our bill. Overall, though it was a great food experience and we will come back again. Parking is on the street.
author: Neil L.

description:
The Old Clam House recently changed ownership.  While that brought a cleaner decor, the food however, went downhill.  It saddened me to learn that they no longer offer the signature cherry stone clams.  No more Clam Bake, my favorite dish of the original Old Clam house.  The new Old Clam House only carries regular small clams that you can get from a gazillion other places.  Why do I have to come here?  

My other must-have from the old Old Clam House, the Lazy Man Cioppino is now replaced by the Seafood Cioppino, which is smaller in portion and thicker in the sauce.  While the flavor is good, it's smaller and just...different.  Just not what it used to be.  

The prime rib was blah at best.  My husband described it as Reno prime rib. I know, we shouldn't expect too much of the prime rib from a seafood joint.  But if they taut it on their wall and their menu, please make it halfway decent.

The only thing I can praise about the new rendition of this restaurant is the service.  It is definitely better than before.  Too bad... we can't get a satisfied tummy from good service alone.

Goodbye old Old Clam House, who I could count on to have the giant cherry stone clams 365 days a year.  And goodbye new Old Clam House for I will not be returning ever gain.
author: Irene T.

description:
It's my second time here. The first time we had mussels that were out of this world. This time we each had a dungenous crab, which is in season. It was fresh and cooked to perfection with a hint of butter and garlic (not drowning in butter as most places do it.) 

The biggest downside is the location. It's on Bayshore Blvd, an industrial area with absolutely no charm. But if you have a car and are willing to go out of the beaten path, you won't be disappointed.
author: O Z.

description:
I drive/bus by here all the time but haven't had the occasion to dine in. Finally made a reservation for last night and it was packed by the time we got our seats, so make sure you rsvp. We felt a little cramped since we had 4 people and we had our purses and nowhere to put them. They are doing the SF restaurant week so we ordered 4 sets and another dish as well. Sadly our kettle bread and butter was cold, would have enjoyed it much better if either the bread was warm or the butter was softer. I really enjoyed their caesar salad!! (my fav dish of all the dishes on our table) The clam chowder was barely warm and would have been tastier if it were warmer. We were all pretty full from just the starters already so 1 set would have been way enough per person. (we ended up taking out most of the entree) The boneless ribs were very tender, fish fillet was just right but the crab legs were a little disappointing; We imagined it bigger. Desserts were great, only wish the chocolate moose have a thin layer of cake because the portion was really big.
I also like how the business manager actually reads and reply to most of their reviews whether it's good or bad :D
author: Amy Z.

description:
1861...the Civil War started, Bayshore Boulevard was actually on the waterfront, and the building where the Old Clam House was built.  Step inside the building, and you'll actually feel like you've stepped back in time.  Never had I experienced this in San Francisco...Boston, yes, but not here.

I was lucky enough to read the reviews first and ordered the house specialty, the cioppino.  It came to me in a big bowl, topped with two slices of garlic bread standing on its end.  I was sold on the broth - very light, but had the right spices and was not overbearing.  It came fully loaded with crab, scallops, a couple pieces of fish, and one large prawn.  Down this with the house ale and this lunch had enough food to hold me over till the next day.

We also had the clambake, which was good but not great.  It was loaded with mussels, prawns, clams, but I thought the broth was uneventful.  The fried dishes on the other tables looked pretty good, so if you're into that, I'm sure you can't go wrong.  Make sure you get the au jus dipping sauce with your sourdough bread, which is the broth from the steamed clams.  It's a healthier alternative to butter, and more flavorful. 

Be careful where you park.  There is no on site parking, but if you're lucky enough, you might find a spot in Rape Alley, aka Mugger's Lane, which is right behind the restaurant.

If I read this book by its cover, I'd have nothing to write, because I would never have ventured into this place.  The TV show  "Check Please, Bay Area" and Yelp really hit it big with my latest discovery, and yes, I'll be back.
author: Ron L.

description: Really excellent change oysters fantastic mussels to die for and the big surprise clam broth. This place is now a destination for seafood lovers. Jason the brand new bartender did a great job. Bloody mary perfect great wide menu just like the east coast. I am coming baaackkkk! I also love the booth atmosphere very nice and reminds me of the Tadich and Jack and Jeanty's too bad they went out of business.
author: Peter A.

description:
This establishment has been in my parents neighborhood for years **before they got new owners and redid it** and my parents have yet to visit, **My parents are super old fashion, well truthfully they don't like spending mula unless it's at an Asian restaurant, typical Asian folks I say**. Trying to be different from my parents, my friends and I decided to stop by for dinner. 

Street parking available if you're lucky bc it tends to get packed very quickly. Upon entering, you're greeted than escorted to your table, menus are handed out and complimentary bread and butter. *Fully loaded bar!!!*

I usually end up ordering one of their pasta dishes bc I LOVE pasta!! Somehow I can never seem to go wrong with any of their pasta dishes. Delicious and saucy :) 
*And with their fully loaded bar it's an alcoholic's dream and nightmare!!* 

Great food and service and always with great company.
author: Anonymous P.

description:
This place is magical. Oldest restaurant in San Francisco (since 1861), always plenty of parking, open every day of the year AND no corkage (plus it's next door to BEVMO)!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Did you hear me mention NO CORKAGE?

If you love garlic, you'll love The Old Clam House, in fact, it is the same owners as The Stinking Rose (as well as Calzone and Salida's in Sausalito). From the hot clam shots served with bread to the escargot clams, clam linguini in white wine sauce, and finally tiramisu, everything was a flavorful sensation. We were thrilled that they had Cloudy Bay on the wine list too.

I want to go back and try the private booths with curtains that you can close. This place will take you back to the 19th century, only with better tasting food.

Couldn't have had a nicer evening, and the place is yet to be rediscovered, so it is not crowded.
author: Jon R.

description: There's a reason why this old school seafood restaurant is still going strong. The food was really good! As soon as we sat down we were brought complimentary clam broth which was delicious. We both got a cup of clam chowder, shared the crab sandwich, kettle bread, and steamed clams. All were really tasty and not too salty which can tend to happen with clam broth. The clams had chunks of potatoes and carrots stewed in the broth which made it super hearty. Make sure you order some bread to soak up that yummy broth.  The crab sandwich tasted fresh and somewhat healthy with avocado & not drenched with mayonnaise.  We went for a weekday lunch and it wasn't cheap, but it was cheaper & less greasy than a place like The New England Lobster Co.  The location is pretty industrial and parking is off the street.  Oh also, they have this hot sauce on the table and I love super spicy, but this was to the extreme. Even with just a few drops I was sweating under my eyes!  I'll definitely be back!
author: Linda C.

description:
simply put, could be better.
1. location.  interesting place, not easy to get to and parking is not available.
2. ambiance.  nice feel to the place.  like the old pictures and the history reflected on the walls.
3. food.  portions are smaller then the price would expect.  My wife had the omelet and it was nice but not great, bacon had to be sent back.  something looking like potatoes came with the omelet.  I had the crab enchilada double.  it was smaller then i have seen for a single.  taste was okay but nothing spectacular.  FF were reasonable.
4.  services.  adequate but cold.  the bus person was the nicer of the people plus the older man at the door.  waiter could have cared less if we were there.
5.  Price.  WAY TOO HIGH!  75 dollars for an average place is out of control.

Cannot recommend this place based on the price against the return.
author: Tim F.

description:
Double crab and mussels so stupendous I'm giving it 5 stars!

The dish with the cole slaw/bacon .... was meh - skip it
author: Ira S.

description:
Ok the place has changed alot,the old menu is gone and most of the old staff is too. It's not a bad place to eat. The new menu is a little boring and the price went up a bit. They change hands about two month ago.So
if you want ok sea food this place is ok. If you want great seafood this isnt the place to go anymore.
author: LON B.

description:
They start you off with a warm shot glass of clam juice and it's delish.  The complimentary bread's a little hard as it scratched up the roof of my mouth but the fishwich or fish sandwich is the best I've had.  I thought it was perfectly battered, moist and layered with a good coleslaw that's not overly mayo'd.  The fries were similar to J in the Box and Burger King.

I was here for a late lunch at 2.30pm so there's no reason for the service not to be on point.  I've already raved about their sandwich to my friends so we'll be heading out here when we're on this side of the bay.  We'll probably roll 4 deep to drop off our next buddy who flies out of SFO.
author: Jona C.

description:
I bought the deal on Groupon for one crab or one prime rib for The Old Clam House because I figured it was worth trying and the boyfriend and I are both down to work for our food, and could use the cracking practice for our upcoming trip to Maine.

We went on a Wednesday night and there were only a few other tables filled, but we decided to sit out on the closed-in patio.  We gave the waiter our Groupon and ordered two crabs and some drinks.  The boyfriend got a blood orange margarita and I got a peach/oj/whiskey cocktail, both of which were good, although mine was definitely worth the money for the amount of alcohol that was in it. They gave us some bread and a shooter of clam juice to dip it in, which I honestly was a little hesitant to get behind, but it wasn't bad. They gave us our drinks in a little dairy farm jar, which was cute and helped in the refilling area.  The crabs came out and they were amazing. Sizzling and covered in garlic herb butter, it was an epic crab experience. The waiter and the guy helping him were both very attentive and friendly, making sure we had everything we needed.

I definitely recommend this place to anyone even though we only had the crab, as it looked like it may not be very popular in the Bayshore area, and it would be a shame to see this place go under in this bad economy.  Next time I'd probably opt to share a crab and get some sides instead of having a whole one to myself, as it is a lot of work and I was stuffed to the brim by the end.
author: Heather B.

description:
The crab was AMAZING!  The best I've had - good size chunks of crab, juicy & perfectly cooked w/ butter & garlic.  The broth shooter w/ bread was tasty.  We also ordered the kids menu - chicken strips & fries.  Flavorfully seasoned chicken- very good.  
It is in a sketchy part of town but the restaurant is very nice.  There is only street parking.  
Definitely going there again for crab.
author: Z Z.

description:
What happened!!!  We live in the Los Angeles area, so only get here a couple a year (my husband was 25 years in the 
Bay Area... this is nostalgic for him).   Anyway, what a complete turn around!  Can they even call "Old Clam House"?  Where is all of the 49er stuff?  Where are those fabulous big steamed clams?  Thank God some of the servers (and our usual busboy) were there, because, at least the service was excellent.
    I'm totally disappointed and don't think We'll be back (the food wasn't bad, it just wasn't "right").  Could someone please let us know if things ever get back to normal... or where I can buy all of that great old 49er's memorabilia?
author: Erin L.

description:
We had a great time.  The service was excellent, the food was great and I loved the ginger martini thing!  We had prime rib and the crab and shared.  The crab was excellent, almost to hot to touch and it was moist and flavorful.  Prime rib cooked as ordered with mini potatoes.  I loved the salad, butter lettuce pumpkin seeds with a blue cheese dressing.  

The San Francisco history, including a tin plated ceiling oozes from this place.  I loved it.  My favorite, old school bar and restaurant with parking and close to the house.  Not cheap, but well worth it!!!
author: Stephanie N.

description: Loved the clam juice. Loved my basa. Share the dinner plate - it's huge. And it was tasty. Old fashioned - but much more affordable than cousin restaurants like Sam's and Tadich Grill.
author: Andrew K.

description: Great clams and linguine.  Good Blood Orange margaritas.  Clam broth shots are delicious.
author: Nutty B.

description:
So sad.  :'(  They changed the cioppino!  I used to DREAM about the cioppino and count the days until we had the opportunity to splurge and go back to The Old Clam House to feast.

While the place looks nice, and the service is more buttoned up now, I really didn't mind the super casual atmosphere it used to have.  It used to be AMAZING food and a lot of regulars.

Went back last night and the clientele is a bit different, the menu has completely changed, and while the food is fine and pricey (like you'd find at Fisherman's Wharf), it was not awe-inspiring.  My husband refused to finish his meal -- something he never does -- because he was so disappointed at the "new version" of our favorite cioppino.

Unfortunately, no longer worth the trip... we'll have to find a new place for REAL cioppino.
author: Eleanor P.

description: I love this place! if you like crab and shrimp this is the spot for you. seafood cioppino is great and the bread with warm clam juice was something I never had but delicious appetizer. portions are generous. Mine and my wife's favorite is the double shrimp and crab - a feast for at least 2 people. service is always excellent. definitely a place to check out.
author: Main M.

description:
Wow, Sad to see a great restaurant go to HELL!!! When uve been going to the same place for about 30 yrs you dont read the reviews on Yelp. You just KNOW.
 The ownership change was not for the good. The makeover of The Old Clam House is startling! From looks to menu to food, all have suffered.
I will not be going back to a bay area institution due to the fact it no longer is :(
author: Thomas E.

description: The food was good for lunch. The oyster shot of soup they serve with bread was too salty but good flavor. We had the clam chowder and split popcorn shrimp. The chowder was very potato flavor heavy. It could use a bit more clam flavor. The popcorn shrimp was good. We would go back and try the place for dinner. The inside was nicely decorated and very clean. Good service too.
author: Marianne L.

description: We grabbed some beers after volunteering in the area, the place has an old charm and an interesting selection of spirits. We chatted with the bartender who was real cool.
author: Ameer N.

description:
I had heard of this restaurant as well as driven past it all my life but just recently made it in... My boyfriend took me here to cheer me up on a rough week, and wow, it sure did!  We splurged and it seemed like we ordered just about everything on the menu, (from oysters and clams to pasta)...and I am happy we did because next time I know EXACTLY WHAT TO ORDER!!! - Red wine of course, Garlic bread, the clam chowder was amazing, 
Baby Iceberg bluecheesedressing&baconbits = super yummy presented nicely in a unique large white bowl, and to top it off, the Spicy Shrimp pasta dish was beyond fabulous for my taste buds, i even made myself stop so i could take some home for the next day!!!  I can't wait to go back!!!
author: Jessica C.

description: Dropped in about 30mins before closing with my honey. She'd been at least twice before, but it was my first time. We were promptly seated & given a shot glass of some yummy, warm oyster broth. We looked over the menu trying to decide and a waiter approached us to ask if we were ready. His demeanor seemed off and he awkwardly said, "OK!" and turned to walk away after we stated we needed more time. Eventually, we were ready to order and the seemingly disgruntled waiter took our orders. I ordered the seafood pasta, she ordered dbl shrimp/dbl crab. When her food arrived on a sizzling platter it looked delicious, but the shrimps seemed to be a tad over cooked. My dish arrived shortly after. I assumed a seafood pasta would be made with some sort of white sauce, but this dish had a tomato based sauce. No biggie...except the tomato taste was VERY overpowering and took away from the assorted seafood in the dish. On the bright side, there was way more yummy seafood (clams, mussels, shrimp, squid rings & legs, crab) than pasta noodles...and my sprite was good! Anywho...it wasn't a complete fail and I'm willing to give them another chance.
author: Ursula R.

description:
The Old Clam House was so much better. The new owners have "yuppified" the place. The old ambiance is gone, such as the car over the bar. The Giants were playing the A's that night and they had soccer on the big screen! Isn't this place still in San Francisco?
 The service was horribly slow and it wasn't busy at all 7 p.m. Friday night. Drinks expensive no place for a working man. The food: I ordered Fish & Chips, it was to big of a piece for the hot fryer so it was to crispy on outside and underdone on inside + very greasy! Girlfriend had a crab sand which was very small and unsatisfying for the price. Not a pleasant meal we wont go back. They should have kept the old menu like the Gumbo.
author: Chris W.

description:
Overall, the food was ok and the atmosphere was good however the service from the waitress could have been much better. We went on 8/22 to celebrate an anniversary and received a call about 30 min prior to our reservation for confirmation. I thought that was weird since most places will call a day or two before to remind you of your reservation. Anyway, parking was plentiful and we were greeted by the hostess who sat us down immediately in the "original" section of the restaurant. The restaurant has 3 areas..the original with fabulous tables that has "curtains", the bar area with tvs and the newly added "patio" surrounded by windows. 

We sat down and got the clam juice shooters and bread. I want to add that I've seen the restaurant on "Check Please Bay Area" in fact, I have it on my playlist and have noted that the restaurant has had some upgraded renovations. Since the show, the food presentation has declined. The clam juice were literally served in a shot glass whereas in the show, they were served in larger soup cups. I did not catch our waitresses name but she was the only waitress in our section which could explain why the service was subpar but should not be an excuse. She came, and took our orders; Calamari, Mussels, Ciopinno, Grossburger, salads, a couple of kids meals, 1 soda and water for 6.  The soda came and they forgot our waters so we had to ask.  The food was good; the only suggestion is that Cioponni could have used some spice and the complaints was that the mussels were good but were literally the size of jellybeans!! The kids meals did not include a veggi side or drink, just the entree.

Our waitress had a cold attitude and NEVER stopped by our tables to ask how things were going or to refill our waters/soda/spoon for the soup. We had to literally keep and eye on her to try to catch her for our requests...she kept on whizzing by so fast!

Overall, it was OK. For the price of the food and the experience, there are better restaurants.
author: Jerome H.

description: This place is a hidden gem, just off the freeway and in a strange location.  But inside it's cozy and charming with an old school vibe.  They serve you a little shot of clam broth to start.  The seafood is all excellent.  I've tried the cioppino (packed with seafood and delicious), the chowder, and the lobster roll.  All were great.  The service is friendly.
author: cherie y.

description: This place was really good, ordered the combo. The only problem is the tiny tiny tiny, I mean TINY shrimps....Crab + Mussels were great! Love the bread + dipping sauces.
author: Tiff W.

description: My family and I have been going to The Old Clam House for many years, but in the last few years the food quality and quantity has really declined. The latest inside remodeling is nice so I thought the food last night would be like it was  many years ago. Unfortunately NOT, the crab enchilada was a BIG DISAPPOINTMENT, there was hardly any crab in it, and of what there was it was tasteless, and nothing else was served with it. $15 for one enchilada, what a rip off! There was a charge for french bread too! I don't believe I will be going back there.
author: Martha M.

description:
Just. Don't. Eat. Here.

Good busboy, dreadful food. Really unspeakably awful. The bar may be fun, but I came to eat and was miserably disappointed.

What a nightmare.
author: Nicole K.

description:
This was a very interesting and random find for my friends and I. We came here on a quite new years eve, and I can definitely say we enjoyed both the food and the service here. They were a pretty typical seafood/chowder house, but apparently this place is special because they have been around for quite some time. 

We all started out with the interesting bread/clam soup combination which turned out to be really good for opening up our appetite. My friend ordered the cioppino and I just had a bowl of the chowder. All of the food had really fresh, and delicious seafood. The chowder was extremely hearty and left me so satisfied. Unfortunately this place is in an extremely inconvenient location from where I live, so I don't see myself coming back again. But if you're around the area it's worth a try! 3.5 stars.
author: Daniel L.

description: Been going here for many years and I was very disappointed tonite with both the food and the service..1. They no longer have sourdough bread! This is San Francisco folks  Please bring me some Acme with my seafood 2.They don't serve bread anymore!  You have to buy the bread they bake  3. Clam chowder is served in a bread bowl and the bread isn't that good 4. Ordered crab and had to ask for something to crack it 5.Waitress never came over ta ask if everything was OK .... Spoke to the manager about my concerns and he  was very unsympathetic..  he said "things change"...but not always for the better...Don't think I'll be going there again!!
author: Steven N.

description:
I bought a couple of coupons when it was on sale. They actually allowed me to use to coupon for me and my companion. She had the steak while I had the crab. Both of our meals was delicious. The caesar salad was also good and was enough for two people. They served this clear soup that made the bread taste even better.

The service was excellent. It was fast and very friendly. I would definitely return.
author: arleen r.

description: Been wanting to try this place for years. Came with expectations of a classic seafood house and all were fulfilled. Solid menu, friendly service from our waiter John, and an easy experience with our two girls. We had the clams escargot and louie salad with crab. Kids had fried fish and popcorn shrimp. All excellent.
author: Gary O.

description:
Was here in 2004, and first time back tonight since then.

GOOD Service, (Smaller Portions on the Prime Rib/Crab), YUMMMY Clam Chowder and the Blue Pointe Oysters were a bit on the Warm Side.

Otherwise, GOOD STUFF! Will be back!!!

Cheers!
author: Emily L.

description:
To be honest, I was expecting the food to be as drab as the outside of the building... but, it was a fantastic surprise.

Am I just a naive crab-eater? I assumed we'd get some typically boiled or steamed crab. Instead, the roasted crab was fabulous. It's my new favorite way to eat crab -- the brittle shell is way easier to break away than boiled, steamed, or breaded and deep-fried.

Even the sides we ordered as "filler" -- fingerling potatoes, french fries, and cole slaw -- were exceedingly tasty. I was not expecting this.

We'll be returning...
author: Derrick L.

description: I've been wanting to come here for the longest! Good thing I finally checked it out today. The place is so clean and nice. I can tell they put effort into their displaces. I ordered lemon tea, clam chowder and medium hot skillet shrimp and everything was so good. They have great customer service here! I will come back forsure to try their crab.
author: Aida L.

description:
Andrea, apparently among the the guilty parties, alleged "We're going to keep this landmark alive"

Too late, Andrea. You killed it. It's already dead. I hope your bankruptcy is filed without further delay and you get and stay out of town.

Go to hell!
author: Swing C.

description:
This place has been around since 1861, and I've never even heard of it! But I have heard good things so I was excited to go for a Christmas dinner with friends.

I decided to order one of their specialties to get a good feel for the restaurant, so I decided to go for the cioppino because they claimed it was "the best in SF." And that's exactly what it was. The cioppino was a big bowl of deliciousness - that's all I have to say. TONS of seafood - crab legs, shrimp, fish, calamari (with the tentacles), clams, and mussels - and two pieces of garlic bread to enjoy with your stew. The bf ordered the Prawns Flamingo which was like alfredo with several large pieces of shrimp/prawns and baby shrimp. Not too rich like some alfredos can be. He was very happy with his dish. Almost everyone in our 10-person group took a baggy bag home because they give you so much food. That's a big plus with the bf.

It is a wee bit pricey, but the quality is definitely there. It's not in the greatest neighborhood, but the food is definitely worth the risk. The wait staff is friendly and very attentive. The inside of the restaurant had a neighborhood feel to it, with license plates and 49ers memorabilia all over the walls. I can't wait to come here again.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Great food and servings are huge! Their fried calamari is delicious and I love their calamari steak. Lots of good looking things on the menu. Home made bread is good too!
author: Calvin M.

description:
Had the cioppino. It was so delicious. One of the clams was unopened... hmm.... upon opening, think slimy black sand came pouring out.... Other than that, it was still worth it.

Still the old cioppino men, with all the different soup options and a little clam on fire in the middle of the bowl
author: Henry C.

description: I came for my birthday the crab cakes we're great this time around last time crab cakes weren't good the seasonal wild berry Italian cheesecake was delicious probably a favorite for me
author: Jana O.

description: I was in the area viewing the Academy of Art University spring art show around the corner and stumbled across this place.  Charming historic building inside and out.  Old school professional service from our young waiter (efficiently and graciously takes our orders and even recommended the small instead of large calamari appetizer since we already ordered a lot of food) could have upsold us but he turned out to be right - we had a lot left over.  All we ordered was very good. Warm clam juice sounds nasty but was very good and our group had all age ranges and we all liked it.  Everyone enjoyed their meal and we sampled each others as well - all nicely done includes chowder in a bread bowl, clams and linguine, fish and chips, fish fry, sand dabs, crab noodles,  I parked behind the place since it was easy parking with no issues but regarding the ENTIRE San Francisco area I would never park my car ANYWHERE in the city with any luggage or anything of perceived value in sight.  The city is still charming but I feel crime has increased dramatically and the stench of human waste in the streets (none at Clam house or within smelling distance at least)  is increasing. People are leaving more behind than their heart in San Francisco!
author: Ray L.

description:
So for the past few years, my family and I have been coming here to celebrate my dad's birthday. We have loved their specials as well as their cioppino. We decided to continue the tradition, and came here this past Saturday for lunch.

The place always starts you off with complimentary clam soup. The soup was delicious, with the clam stock being very fresh and nicely flavored. The waiter got us an extra order because we like it so much.

The sourdough bread is one of the most sour and crusty in the city. They get it from a local bakery. Unfortunately, it was a bit on the cold side. I do prefer it warm. That being said, I still enjoyed the bread because I am a sucker for sourdough.

Crab Sandwich - The brother in-law ordered this. One of the best crab sandwiches. They use the leg meat, which has a nice texture and was very flavorful. The cheese sauce was delicious, and the hollandaise was also very creamy and rich. The fries that came with the order were great. This was the only good order of our outing, unfortunately.

Rib eye - mine and my sister's order: I ordered rare, and my steak was slightly over cooked. Both of our steaks were a bit underseasoned (needed a bit more salt). Our grilled veggies were also only half cooked, and had a still raw taste too them. The potatoes were fluffy and buttery, but because they were buttery, they really stole the flavor from the actual steak. The portion of steak was a decenet size and I was able to make 3 meals out of it.

Seafood Linguine Red/White - these are what my parents ordered. Lots of seafood on these, but the sauce was so bland. My parents heavily seasoned their dishes with pepper and parmesean cheese, and it still tasted bland. They were both very disappointed at how this turned out.

My dad said he probably won't come back because he felt that it was overpriced for the quality that was served to us. I agree, it will be hard to come back. It feels like this place has changed a lot in a year, though it could just be an inconsistent cook. Who knows. I just know that I probably won't come back either unless I am invited for a party, or if my dad decides to give it one more shot.
author: Marc T.

description:
I've been coming to The Old Clam House for 35 years and have always loved it. NOT ANYMORE!   I only had the cioppino and called it quits.  Lack of depth, poor quality clams and shrimp, tomato pasty generic sauce.  At least the mussels and crab in the cioppino were alright.  Didn't finish it.

 The ambiance has changed from old, local and unique that gave you a feeling of sharing another era. Changes have been made in the past, but never to this extent.  I wish them luck with their new clientele that must like pricey chain restaurants with mediocre food.
author: Eric G.

description: This place is expensive and touristy and in a weird part of town but the food is good. They serve you a warm shot of clam juice after you're seated and I want to go back just for this. Iron skilled roasted ship was good. Have taken visiting parents here and it went well. Good for kids.
author: Leigh C.

description: Excellent food . clam bake was great , the single serving is more than enough for two!! Clam escargot was really great !!
author: Anis A.

description:
Great old history to it - you'll find pictures of the original architecture of it and that area around the restaurant.  I went here last week for lunch and apparently it has been newly renovated.  

3 things that I thought about:  *SF tradition;  *business lunch with character; and *that scene from My Best Friend's wedding when they sing "I Say a Little Prayer for you".  

Bread & butter:  Hello freshly baked Acme bread and real butter.  With a side shooter of a clam/seafood broth.  FANTASTIC! 
Appetizer: Steamed clams in the most remarkable white wine butter sauce w/ crisp crostini which I then dipped more Acme bread in.  
Calamari- standard deliciousness
Lunch:  Crabwich with avocado and red onion.  Let me know tell you that that was one of the best crab-sandwiches I've had.  The crab had to have been cracked right before they served it to me.  Tasty!  My friend had the fish and chips which was the largest fried fish I've seen before.  If you're hungry get that!!! 

I want to come back and try more.
author: Deanna A.

description:
I have been coming to the Old Clam House for over 30 years and seen it change with different owners. I was hoping the latest one would be back to the old clam house I remember. 
I like it, but here is my wish list
1: smaller cherry stone clams instead of the big tough ones.
2: chalkboard with the fresh catch of the day. Or at least daily fresh fish choices 
3: charcoal grill
These would earn another star!

Thanks for keeping the clam juice!!
author: Ken B.

description:
Nice little place kinda in the middle of nowhere.

They start you off with bread/butter and a shot of some clam broth - very yummy.

We had the cheesy bread, which came on a hot skillet surrounded by a cheese/tomato/chorizo sauce. The clams were excellent - garlicky good. The crab enchillada had chopped lettuce/watercress along with crab inside, so it didnt feel overly heavy/cheesy as some other places.

Oh yeah, and ambiance is very casual, relaxing and homely.

All in all, pretty good place to get your fix of seafood. Next time, I really want to try to clam chowder.
author: Priya K.

description:
I went for an early dinner last night with my friend. She had the cioppino, which she said was delicious. I had shrimp scampi which I have to say was the best I ever had. Wait staff were polite and competent. Wine pour was generous on the by-the glass- wine. After reading the below reviews I am looking forward to trying the clam chowder and fish and chips when I return.
I don't usually pay much attention to back ground music in restaurants(unless its too loud) but my only complaint and it isn't a big one is the 60's and 70's music that was being played. "We all live in a Yellow Submarine" etc just wasn't my taste. Possibly something a bit more jazzy?
author: Kathleen K.

description: My clam linguini was not very tasty, and the pasta was not cooked very well.  However, the steamed clams were tasty, and my family really liked the cioppino.  The kids' clam chowders were a bit too salty.  Service was very good, though.
author: B. Y.

description: I grew up here in the SF bay area, but you know for some reason, had a hard time finding this place. I had been to the San Mateo location a number of times (now closed), but never to the one here in Bayview/Hunters Point. My problem, not their's.Came with my wife and cousin, both of whom use walkers to get around.  There was no convenient handicapped parking, so I let them out and them set out to find at least somewhat convenient parking. Finally found parking in the alleyway that they share with a number of auto repair and body shops.  Anyway, once we were all seated, we placed our cocktail orders (excellent Bloody Mary, and my cousin proclaimed her Old Fashioned the best she ever had.), and then placed our dinner orders. Wife ordered the crab enchilada, cousin had the fish and chips, and I ordered the sand dabs. We also had the Clams Escargot as an appetizer - absolutely outstanding. Service was very attentive, but not overbearing. I would not hesitate to return here.
author: Louis D.

description:
Cute hostess.
Good bread.
Good clam broth juice to start.
Good Cioppino.
author: Henry H.

description:
I came here for dinner once.  Food was good and prices are reasonable.  Service was good but what can you expect when we were one of two tables there that night. 

It could be that the neighborhood sucks so maybe you don't get a lot of families coming here...

If you want to go, go during the daytime.  Neighborhood isn't the greatest.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Food = good, hearty portions

Atmosphere = home-y

Noise = loud

Service = good.  Typical 'american'-fare service...yeah, sassy.

Parking is around, just have to be careful...
author: Fannie S.

description:
Let me just start with: Do not come here expecting to get what you had when you were here a few years ago. I agree with previous reviews that this place is not the same as it used to be since they changed owners. Place looked nice, but thats about it in my opinion. I looked at the menu the night before to get an idea of what I might order and that menu said that they had prime rib. SURPRISE! No prime rib. Turns out that the day I went was also the first day they changed their menu. They replaced their prime rib with filet mignon, but what's funny was that they didn't even have any yet. You'd think that if you're going to change the menu, you'd at least have what is on the menu. Anyway... On to the food.

We started with the fried calamari. It was actually pretty good considering it was gone in about two seconds. It also came with some fried lemons? A question mark because I'm not sure what they were, but they weren't bad. We also ordered a bowl of clam chowder. Only complaint was that this came out to our table about 30 seconds after we put in the order. Okay, not 30 seconds but it came out quicker than it took us to decide on ordering it. Our waitress hadn't even walked back to the kitchen before it was brought out to us. Makes me wonder how long its been sitting. For our last started, we ordered the garlic bread with melted cheese. They brought out plain garlic bread, but brought it back to add the cheese that they forgot. It came back out looking like a fistful of cheese was thrown on top and stuck into the over. If I had known that all they were going to do was that, I would've kept the regular garlic bread. Now to dinner. My boyfriend ordered the seafood cioppino and my stepdad ordered the mixed seafood pasta with spicy cioppino sauce. They both had no complaints. As for my mom and I... Well, we ordered the same thing. We ordered the clam linguini with white sauce. Again, all the food came out fairly quick. Quicker than I would've liked. When it was served, the noodles were not linguini, they were fetuccini. The excuse for that was, "It depends on what kind of package of noodles we get. If we get fetuccini, then that's what we have." No comment on that response otherwise this review will be longer than it already is. On top of the wrong noodles, they weren't cooked properly. They were over-cooked and stuck together. Gross. I like my pasta al dente, thank you very much. Oh and it wasn't even hot. Got it sent back immediately, and just as they should have, they took it off the bill.

I probably won't EVER come back here, but maybe they'll get their act together and actually serve what they have on the menu.
author: Katie P.

description:
The servers are excellent too bad the food is not up to par. We have been customers for a very long time. We decided after giving it a break since new owners and try it one more last time this would be the third. Didn't impress us. Must be new chef. Pricey for very little. I ordered the crab legs and there is more meat on a tarantula than what was on my plate. Go to Red Lobster in San Bruno and not only will it taste better but is cheaper. Even the clam juice is watered down. Definitely will not go back. What shame they forgot the are located on Bayshore and believe it or
 not  did have regular patrons. This is not Dead Fish in or Boibi;s or the Franciscan.
Terrible food, how can you screw up pasta.
author: Darlene P.

description: We actually visited the OCH twice during our trip to SF.  Friday is fishday in our world - and the Old Crab House was just what we were looking for.  We loved the ambiance - oldest restaurant in San Francisco (since 1861), with lots of "memories" on the walls.  Friendly service, seating accessibility, good food and no corkage fee - what a combo!  The oysters, crab, halibut  -- all were delish.  We will return.
author: David S.

description:
1861, same location. Historic photos & clippings. Hot clam juice in a shot glass before you finish sitting down. Great desserts (only $1.95 if you've had the prix fixe meal such as the calamari [yum]). Free parking on the street. Friendly, cooperative servers. Quiet in dining room.

We will be back to this eatery, if only because it is unique. Sure, there might be better white clam chowder in S.F. and sure, there are better views for eating seafood. However, this restaurant is an experience, and many groups celebrate here. 

Cannot believe I lived in the Bay Area for almost 40 years before visiting this place!
author: joyce h.

description:
Casual restaurant with a full bar. I've been here several times, recently changed ownership, food presentation and pricing is different, but the uniqueness is still there. 

Every time I go to the Old Clam House, it reminds of an old town with cow boys. I like the decoration and the setting. Generous amount of crab on the crab alfredo, creamy sauce, famous for their fresh seafood. Yum but still over priced.

A restaurant only locals would go to and definitely not one of those Wharf touristy seafood restaurants. Worth a try.
author: Pauline H.

description: Been here twice, and it was da-LISH on both occasions. Big ol' beers, good bread, and that short rib? Zang...friggin incredible.
author: Booky C.

description: The place was charming and the food was pretty good. Went there on a Saturday night at 8:30 and the place was pretty slow so don't think it's a hit with the locals. Place is quiet and not much of a vibe going on there. I had the crab enchilada which was more of a burrito than enchilada. The crab was cold in the middle which I didn't care for. We also had the dungeness crab which was good. We stayed near the airport so this place was closer than going into the city/fisherman's wharf so that was convenient.
author: Owen I.

description:
Ambiance is nice.  Service was slow and there weren't that many people there.  We had the clam bucket for the appetizer... sauce was good (garlic-y clam juice... hmmm), but the clams were overcooked and I had to spit mines out cause I couldn't chew it enough to digest.  Just like rubber.  I ordered the Cioppino which was decent.  The seafood was cooked perfectly but the assortment of small scallops and small shrimp didn't appeal to me.  I'm used to big shrimp, nice sized scallops, big chunks of meat, etc.  They must be cutting back on costs.  I prefer a more tomato based sauce with this particular dish.  There's was more soupy.  Also, the garlic bread that came with the dish was stale.

I may come back and try another dish or just to have a drink at the bar cause I like the vibe at this place.
author: Angelique B.

description: We went there last night with our 3 1/2 year old grandson. Everything was great including the clam chowder. The waiters were very professional and attentive and were especially nice to our grandson. The atmosphere can't be beat!
author: Julie J.

description:
This place recently got a make-over, and I'd been wanting to try it out.  It looks like your classic old-timey seafood joint where you won't find any bells and whistles, but the fish and steak will be solid.  To my surprise, the food slightly exceeded my expectations.  True, no bells and whistles, but what they do, they do well.  I had the linguine clam pasta.  The pasta tasted fresh and was cooked perfectly al dente with a rich, but not heavy, butter garlic parsley sauce.  The clams were tiny delicate morsels, clearly fresh, and as a plus, I found no mini grains of sand in my clams!  The sides - creamed spinach and french fries - were excellent.  Nothing crazy.  Just great preparations of solid food.  I was little concerned when the creamed spinach arrived and was still green.  I'm accustomed to my creamed spinach looking light green at most as it's usually doused in cream and butter.  This creamed spinach, by contrast, looked spry.  I tentatively took a first bite and happily got a burst of tender, savory spinach flavor.  The fries are double-fried, so extra crunchy and delicious.

I was really impressed with the service.  I had ordered the crab sandwich for my grandma, but we were served the clam sandwich.  I honestly couldn't remember what I had ordered, I figured I said crab, but it's entirely possible I didn't.  My grandma was dismayed though, so we told the waiter.  He immediately whisked away the clam sandwich, apologized, and brought us a crab sandwich.  I suspect he also couldn't remember what I had ordered, but he was totally professional, not at all annoyed at the change, and remained awesome the whole night.  

This is a great spot for good food and relaxed vibe.
author: Pearl L.

description: Good food and good prices! I'll definitely be back for more sand dabs! Service was friendly and efficient. Total win!
author: Scott H.

description: I like the history and the people that I have run into when I have come here. The food has been hit and miss. Three visits in the last two months, sometimes great, other times not so much. You can't go wrong with the steamers,mussels/shrimp combo or cioppino. All worth the money. Anything else has been a gamble with lesser degrees of satisfaction.
author: Steve S.

description: Fine time dining here. Seafood. Drinks. Character. Kid friendly.
author: Kev M.

description: It's difficult not to like an establishment that has been around since before the 1906 earthquake.  Local history is oozing from the walls of this place.  Try to score one of the curtained booths along the left wall if available.  The service is friendly, they make you feel at home.  Plus, the food is pretty darn good to boot.  My wife and I frequent this establishment a couple of times a year and have never been disappointed.  We like to bring out of town guests and friends as we're concerned the patronage may be declining due to the razing of our beloved Candlestick Park and we want this place to continue to survive.  We used to see lots of 49er fans here after our home games but you know the rest of that story.  On our most recent visit we ordered the fish and chips and linguini and clams.  Shot glasses of clam broth precede the meal, a nice touch.  Warm sour dough bread, you have to pay a little for it but it's well worth the paltry sum, is served with soft butter.  Loved both of our entrees but thought the broth with the clams was just a pinch too salty.  The portions are large so be prepared to take home the leftovers, including the bread.  Bottom line, if you haven't been here you're doing yourself a disservice.  Parking can be a challenge, there are a few spaces on the street in front and a small alley at the back.  Niners fans, get your butts back in here, there's nothing comparable in Santa Clara so drown your sorrows and down a good meal back home.
author: Randall P.

description: I have been a fan of this restaurant since I moved to S.F. some 50 years.  I have sent friends and family there regularly.  However when I was there this week and learned that they are limiting their pasta choice to "gemelli", a tasteless and heavy version of the many wonderful pastas available.  It totally ruined my lunch.  If i go back, I will check in advance to see if they have done away with this misguided decision to have only one kind of pasta.  I have enjoyed the linguini and clams and sand dabs with acini in particular.  I will miss them and The Old Clam House. I hope the new owners reconsiders his decision.
author: Lillian J.

description: Thank you for your response we were at the restaurant  around 5 pm to watch the niner/bronco game Sunday 10/19. Like I said I grew up coming to The Old Clam House. Is like go my kids to have the same memories too.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
We have been meaning to try this place out for a while and finally made it for dinner. 
The hot clam broth they give you is tasty but their bread is blah. It still amazes us that in a city with such wonderful bread that some restaurants serve this sub par stuff.
The skillet shrimp are delicious and very flavorful. A little work is needed to get them completely out of the shells but it's worth the effort. The crab enchiladas are packed with crab and tasty. Ours could have been hotter (temperature).
Skip the Caesar...the dressing is too much mayo and not enough flavor (you need the zing of anchovies in a true Caesar dressing). 
Service was okay. Our bottle of water arrived with a very dirty cap; it looked like molasses dripped on it. Your staff needs to wipe that down before serving it; we don't want to see that we certainly don't want to touch it. Cocktails are inexpensive but weak.
Overall it was a satisfactory meal but not necessarily one that I would go out of my way for.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: I just can't believe we decided to do Mother's Day here! It was such a waste of money! I ordered the clam chowder and salad and the chowder was super salty, the salad was bitter and old. The worst part was that when we complained about the salad (which was almost completely untouched) the waitress did nothing. Service sucked, the waitress did not spend any time checking on us. Everyone around us got bread and clam juice before our food, we only got bread after her manager reminded her; this was delivered with our food. Strawberry lemonade sucked as well! I mean who messes that up? I had to ask for extra lemons to add to my juice. Only plus side was that despite the nasty tasting fish sandwich the fish was battered great and crispy! Overly seasoned with spice though. Even the oysters we ordered were shucked poorly. 50+ dollars down the drain! We ended up going to jack in the box down the street! So much more satisfying!!
author: Shirlene M.

description: Went here on a recommendation from a friend. In business since the 1860's. Great crab cakes, great fish & chips. Service was perfect. They have private booths with curtains for those who want real privacy.
author: James N.

description: I had my 75th birthday party at the Clam House with 17 friends and relatives. The service was a 15 on the scale of 1 to 10. Our wait person gave us more than adequate attention. We had the patio room to ourselves and the food was fantastic. She even uncorked the wine I brought and the cake we brought was cut and served to us. I really highly recommend the Old Clam house for its food, service and hospitality. Oh, the bartender doesn't use a mix when making the margarita. She uses fresh lime and agave syrup for the cocktail. Excellent preparation of the drink!
author: Marian G.

description:
5 stars for Clam Bucket: $17 
This place has the BIGGEST clams I've ever eaten. It's called cherry stone clams. It was so gratifying delicious! The clam itself couldn't fit into my mouth, I had to use a fork to pick it up. I enjoyed every chew of the clam meat. It came with their garlic bread. The clam broth (garlic + butter + scallion) was mouthwatering. I wanted to togo it even after I finished all the clams. It was that good.

2 stars for Clam Chowder: $4/cup
Splash Cafe in Pismo Beach still holds the best clam chowder. Old Clam House's Clam Chowder was a bit salty (might have been sitting in the pot the whole day), but their clams bits in the chowder was the biggest I've ever seen. 

4 stars for their raw oyster: $11 for 6 oysters + cocktail sauce
I wish they served the whole oyster. I believe they sliced half of the oyster out for visual purposes? It was served on top of ice with cocktail sauce + horseradish paste and lemon. I love how fresh it tasted!

3 stars for Clam Linguini: $~20 (forgot the price)
Huge portion linguini. I was overwhelmed by how much seafood there was in the linguini. They gave you a generous portion. I felt it lacked in flavor. The red sauce was not as great or buttery as I'd hope, but still decent.

5 stars for their Shirley Temple with Soda Water rather than Sprite
One of the best shirley temple i've had, even though you can't go too wrong with it. 

The service was great. Prices for seafood was very decent. It costs us $58 dollars w/o tips for the both of us. I'd highly recommend the clam bucket, definitely worth it. The environment/decor need a little brush up. It felt cold and old (kind of like Texas Roadhouse). I'd definitely come back because Holly Sh*t, this place is 1 min drive from my house and is seafood heaven, not denting too much of your wallet. The area this place is in is a bit sketchy, so just be careful. There are parking in front and back.
author: MT D.

description:
Very disappointing...we new when we ordered our meal...the first question I asked is if their under new management and she said yes.  When you notice that as soon as your served that pretty bad.   Forget the Clam Chowder...more potatoes less clam.  Portions are more expensive less food.   

DONE!!!!  It's to bad!!!
author: Carol D.

description: This place is amazing. Two musts: the mussels and the calamari steak.
author: Genevieve W.

description:
This place is kinda weird - points for nostalgia factor - and alot of locals eat here as well as scads of tourists.  It's, natch, known for seafood and it's good here.  We had steamers and they were sooooo delicious.

OK - I had originally put 3 stars (it's really ramshackle inside) but reconsidered and gave them 3.

Like another yelper below has said - this is a place you don't neccessarily HAVE to visit - but if you've lived in SF or the Bay area for ANY significant period of time, you've been here.

P.S.  We came here for dinner only - I can't comment on service at lunch.
We had very good service the night we came - but it wasn;t too crowded that night.
author: Karen F.

description: Love this place. The atmosphere, staff, and needless to say, the food is always top notch. Ask the dear bartenders, Anna and Judy, for an extra large clam juice. Enjoy your meal.
author: WhatDoIKnow S.

description: This was a great spot that has been at this same location for a long time.  The food was delish!.  I had the Louie Salad with crab for two and it was so good that  I went back to eat the same thing a week later.  The drinks are worth the price.  My favorite thus far.... The Cucumber Martini. A must try!  The staff have been nice and the ambiance, adequate.
author: Ivonne G.

description:
This is a very old school San Francisco place serving the traditional favorites in a casual, down home setting. 

The seafood dishes are fresh, simply prepared, and reasonably priced.  My personal favorites are: the bucket of steamed cherry stone clams and the lazy man's cioppino, which comes with garlic bread.   This and the basket of sourdough bread on the table should feed two just fine, family style.  If there are more in your party, the Chef's special saute, a platter loaded with sauteed shellfish and red snapper over pasta with a side of fresh steamed veggies, provides a good counterpoint.

I also like the hot cup of clam juice they bring you when you first sit down.  The calamari is pretty good, and the clam chowder is just OK, but overall, this is a great place - fresh tasty seafood, unpretentious service, and fair prices.
author: Elaine L.

description:
You can't beat the portions here for fresh seafood.  The atmosphere is a bit blue-collar-ish and casual -- sports bar feel if you go to the dining room on the right.  More family-oriented if you go to the dining room on the left.  It is located in the middle of a very industrial part of town.  You go to this area only to dine here.  There is nothing else around - plus probably not a good idea to roam around.  

The clam broth and sourdough are free and good together.  We ordered the lazy man cioppino, the clam chowder and the clam bake.  They are all excellent.  They don't skim on the seafood they give you -- scallops, prawns, crab legs, mussels, clams, etc.  You name it, it'll probably be there in that giant big bowl.   Service is friendly.  We always bring out of town friends here if they want to get seafood.  We rather skip out on the tourist traps of Fisherman's Wharf!
author: Jannie Q.

description:
The end of an era. I've been going to Old Clam House forever. It was one of my most favorite restaurants. Not anymore. The menu completely changed, which is fine. The apps were ok and the soup and salads were good. I had the clam linguine and added crab. There was absolutely no flavor in the white sauce. My cousin had the one with the red sauce. It was a little better. Someone else got the crab Alfredo. That was ok, not great. Our dinner was not worth the money we spent. I've NEVER said this about Old Clam House. 
Overall the food was really disappointing. I'm so heartbroken. If the past owners/chefs work anywhere else, can someone please let me know? 
I'm giving them 2 stars because the service was amazing and our orders came out in a very timely matter.
author: Leslie C.

description: Went here 10-15 years ago, but didn't remember much.  On fathers day my dad chose this spot, he has been coming to this place often for the past few months, in fact the a new waitress tried to sit us at a different spot and another waitress took us away and placed us at my parents favorite indoor location.  lol.  Great start with the oyster broth shot!!!! loved it for dipping my bread.  Then I had some jumbo prawns, fish n chips and a wonderful clam linguini.   The pasta was just done prefectyl. Great service, wonderful sized portions and wonderful food.  My wife and i will be back.  O yeah dont forget to get the layered rasburry cheescake. loved it!!!
author: Richard G.

description: nice cozy place when u enter u kinda feel like your at home. the staff is friendly  and very helpful with the menu. theres a decent amount of tables but thwy are alittle close to eachother but its cool I dont mind it. theres no dress code but you can often see people dressed real nice and people dressed casual. anyway leta get to the food hahaha..... I ordered the braised short rib with no bone. It tasted like a beef birria (which is goat soup in Mexico) it came with a side of veggies nice and roasted. I recommend getting this if u dont want thier pasta. The cioppino is my favorite it runs for about 25 bucks.you cant go wrong the taste is satisfying and everything is fresh... they will hook you once u taste the comp. Bread and oyster juice two thumbs up. This is a san fran best.
author: Rigoberto C.

description: I stumbled upon this place quite randomly while out on a weekend walk, and boy, am I glad I did.  Delicious lunch and fantastic service!  i'll definitely be back.  Just wish it were in a more "pedestrian friendly" location for this girl without a car.
author: Sally A.

description: A San Francisco jewel. Been around since 1800s. We love this restaurant. Order the large mussels for a treat ( they come out on the biggest sizzling platter you have ever seen. ). Especially if you live I. The southern part of the city this is a great restaurant to support. Similar quality restaurants in other parts of the city are swamped. At the Old Clam House you can walk in and get a table !!!
author: Anne M.

description:
Craving clam chowder on a brisk SF day and realized we'd not been the the OCH since it was taken over by those of Stinking Rose/Calzone's fame.
Have to say we liked the clean & shiny face lift!  Looks essentially the same with a good scrubbing done by someone who knew how to treat all of the beautiful wood in the bar.  No more "saddle" bar stools, but we saw one on hand, I guess for posterity sake (or perhaps posterior!).  They added "booths" to the dining room, but really they are just partitions separating tables/chairs, I was hoping for comfy, cushioned banquettes. 
Now for the food...
They still offer up the Clam Broth when you sit but it seemed starchy  - potato starchy with the little bits clinging to the side of the clear glass tumbler.  It was almost as if they strained the chowder base before adding more thickener. And it was more oniony/garlicy than clammy.
Clam chowder - meh.  Uber thick but not creamy.  Tinged yellow rather than the luscious, creamy white we are used to on this coast.
Hubby order the Calamari Steak Dore Lunch Special for $12.95  A fine value!  Came with above mentioned cup o' chowder (note to self, order salad next time) a large, tender, lightly battered, properly cooked piece of calamari but the side, oily ancini pasta with sun-dried tomatoes & snap peas seemed to be a bit of a throw-away.  The on-line menu says it is in a spicy cioppino sauce, it's not. 
I had the Fishwich - HUGE fish sandwich!  A whole fillet of white fish, again properly battered and beautifully fried, served on what seemed like a 1/2 loaf of ciabatta with olive oil slaw.  Served with tartar sauce & lemon on the side.  I must say, one of the better fish sandwiches I've had.  Ate 1st half with bread, 2nd without and I could really see how the olive oil & vinegar slaw complimented the fish.  And, at $9.95 another fine value.
Cocktails...
Chili Mary - their version of Blood Mary. It was ok, a bit much on the Worcestershire sauce but it packed a punch.  
Blood Orange Margarita -  a bit sweet, not the tart loveliness I expected but again, nice pour on the tequila.
Be fairly warned though, they're served in a 12 oz tumbler, not a pint glass.  For $9 we expected the latter.
OH - we started with 1/2 dozen lovely, briny, sweet oysters. YUM!
Will go back, but probably for oysters & beer or to check out the $9.95 Saturday-Sunday Brunch!
author: Us And J.

description: This review is for their brunch only. This is easily the best brunch spot I've been to in recent months. The crab benedict here is the best I've had in this city. Good service. Good coffee. Good clam juice. Go.
author: Jay N.

description: The steamed clams and clam chowder were tasty! I'd pass on the fried clam strips.
author: Clayton K.

description:
Ok, so after reading the reviews here on Yelp, my roomies and I decided to dine here at the Old Clam House. The food was great, though the fried oysters were not fresh but those breaded ovals that so many places pass off as oysters. But I loved the shrimp salad and my hubby got the clam strips which were delish! All in all it was good, though a bit pricey.

On a side note, Rape Alley did not live up to its name. In spite of it's promise, it was a huge disappointment!

Stick to the seafood. Forget Rape Alley.
author: Nick B.

description:
I hadn't been here in decades so when some friends wanted to get together for an event in the neighborhood, it seemed like the perfect place to grab a bite.  Dinner started well with a plateful of fresh sourdough and clam juice. 

I ordered the Golden Gate Clam Chowder and the Crab Enchilada while my wife and friends ordered the Steamed Clams, Cioppino and Grilled Salmon.  I was eager to dig in but with the first bite I knew I hit a mother load of salt.   And while I'm pretty tolerant of salty food this was way too much.  The Cioppino looked OK and the  Grilled Salmon was nothing special. The Steamed Clams were great according to my friend but it seemed a small amount for the price.

The bill we divided came to $36.00 a head including beer for me and one cocktail per person.  I didn't think it was worth it.
author: Holger A.

description:
Let's break it down, what do you go to a place like this for? Food and atmosphere. The food can be contemporary (and should be) in a place that was founded in the 1800's. So what keeps them open besides the legacy? The food and the place.

We ordered (as a party) several apps and main courses. Every one was not only what you would typically expect, but they have found a way to enhance every dish. The sauces were savory, the shellfish/crustaceans/ mollusks, etc.  (as the case may be) were perfectly prepared. Not too tough or salty, really well executed.

Afterwards there was a Cumbia band from Venezuela playing in the lounge and although we are VERY Anglo, and the crowd there was not, we were made to feel welcome and invited to dance along. It was Fantastic. 

I would return there anytime. 

Food: traditional and inventive also. Savory broths amazing, not too salty and well balanced.
Service (bar and restaurant): attentive yet not too invasive
Ambiance: not too sure if the band was not going, but a landmark for sure

Return potential: 4 sure!
author: J L.

description:
We started at the bar while waiting for the rest of our party to arrive. The bartender was great. Friendly and attentive. We were expecting a great experience. But there were a few missteps. Our server was Ryan B. who got lost after taking our drink orders as soon as we were seated. We had to ask a second time for water, and iced teas.  And bread. We came in at 1:30 and it didn't seem  very busy, judging by several empty tables. Perhaps they had someone call in sick or had a large group we didn't hear or see. At any rate, after waiting for about 10-15 minutes and feeling abandoned, one of us left the table to hunt down where our server went. Then another search for where our drinks and bread were hiding, after our first request got lost.  Ryan came finally with our drinks and the bread. He apologized. That was fine, but just remember customers will wait a good amount of time as long as they have their drinks and bread to munch on. When the food was served, it was very disruptive. Ryan was again apologetic, saying he was busy with other customers which we would have no quarrel with, but we are his customers too, right? The food we were served was in general good, with a few complaints. Our crab cakes were over cooked and the pickled cucumber(?) served with the cakes tasted dried out in spots which was probably due to being under a heat lamp too long. The cioppino was tasty; however one thing that spoiled the enjoyment was the crab legs were not cracked at all. It was a messy chore to dig through the sauce to get to the crab and then find out it had not the initial cracking. So here you have a slippery leg that hasn't been cracked for easier eating. I also would have wished for a chunkier crab sandwich. I got a finely shredded crab meat mixture with a lot of mayo. I think small crab chunks would have tasted better, and would have justified the price. 
At the end when he presented the check, Ryan found time to be friendly, and very chatty. I found this especially annoying. I expect service to be gracious and friendly and attentive from the beginning: not at the end when I will be rewarding service given with a tip. Ryan was given a decent tip, only because I was not the one to pay the check. I would have been less forgiving, but we had come with friends and were celebrating Christmas a week early. So no drama. I think The Old Clam House has a fine reputation in terms of food and service. I just hope that they are not resting on past laurels. The staff and kitchen need to never forget what constitutes excellent service and excellent food. Hopefully we just happened to hit on a bad day. We may come back.

Update: This is a late posting. I did not see the reply from The Old Clam House until now. I like to post when the business takes the time to write back, and The Clam House did that shortly after my review was posted. Jim sent a very nice message expressing concern with the service issues I had brought up. For that I will add a star, and will definitely come back for another try.
author: Diane M.

description:
TERRIBLE TERRIBLE TERRIBLE!!!

I used to love this place! Whenever I visited home from college, I would always hit up The Old Clam House for their seafood linguini. After the owner change, the food is horrible.

Clam Linguini: First off, this is NOT LINGUINI! It's a sad version of cheap egg noodles I would find at Pacific Super or Ranch 99 for $.60 a pack.  Secondly, the dish was sad and small compared to my old favorite, which the waiter said was the same. Thirdly, the clams were terrible. They tasted bitter and gritty. I returned this dish back to the kitchen. I'm so disappointed.

Seafood in Spicy Cioppino Sauce: Again with the cheap Asian egg noodles?!? The dish was again a small portion the size of half a pack of ramen noodles and tasted terrible. The sauce tasted a bit sourer than what a cioppino is supposed to. The seafood was lacking.

All in All: Don't let their 150 years of tradition bit fool you. They don't have the charm of the Old Clam House nor the delicious food of the past. SKIP THIS PLACE!
author: Jessica M.

description:
You really have to give it to Tb...it's one of those days again that we havent had a full lunch and were hungry by 4pm...we kept suggesting different types of food and names of restaurant...until Voila!...I said "i want to eat crabs"...and then he goes "let's go to the Clam House"...and again do I ever say No?

So we went...for a minute I thougt we were going to Jack in the Box...he always wants to tease...I never thought that we were already parked in front of the Clam House.

We ordered the Steamed and the Grilled Seafood Plates and like always we finished everything...It was good....It was delicious!.

Service is great, a little bit pricey but will definitely come back.
author: Malou C.

description:
SO DISAPPOINTING!!!  We each hadn't been here since we were younger but our memories of the place from then we're fabulous, so when craving clam chowder I thought of this place out of nostalgia.

The clam chowder tasted like it started as a cup of salt and they just added a touch of the chowder to give it some taste.  The crackers (I had to ask for) were stale.  The menu didn't state that my crab and cheese sandwich came with mayo so I had to send it back to be remade without it.  I wish I would have just cancelled the order all together because even without the mayo, it was HORRIBLE!!!  I took one bite and couldn't eat any more of it.

The service however was even WORSE!  Our waiter seemed so annoyed when we asked him something.  Even to give him our food order, then we had to call him over to give him our drink order.  When I sent my sandwich back, he didn't believe that the menu didn't state that it had mayo so he actually looked it up before taking it back!  And please...talking on your cell phone in front of your customers is just tacky.

When the $50 bill showed up on his bill recently it almost had an anti-yelper creating an account to protest the restaurant.  Now that's serious and I don't blame him!  Definitely not coming back!! No, no, absolutely not!
author: Ninja H.

description:
Came here tonight with a couple of friends for dinner. It's a thing we do every month, taking turns paying each month. The one that was paying this time decided on this place. No complaints from us so here we are.

From the outside, it looks like any old building. But when you are in the inside, it looks funky. Sorta like a TGIFridays but without the annoying servers that wear their vests adorned with flair. God, I hate that...

Anyways, we all sit down and ordered drinks and apps. after the server left, this other guy comes over with bread and water and little Chinese tea cups you see in dim sum restaurants. But instead of tea, these things were filled with clam broth. Now, if you enjoy seafood, don't drink this straight because it is SALTY! Use the bread and dunk it in then eat it. Cuts down on the saltiness by a lot.

So we ordered the Oysters Rockefeller and fried calamari. Both were good. Not overly stupendous but still good.
