The oysters lacked the abundance of bacon that is usually used to make them and they had some sort of weird cream sauce on it. I remember they were just the oysters on a half shell, bacon, spinach, cheese and breadcrumbs. But maybe each place makes them differently. The calamari was good. Tender and lightly breaded. Cooked really well and not chewy at all.

I ordered the Cioppino. I liked the presentation but the bowl lacked heat. Like it needed a little red pepper flake added to it because the soup or broth or whatever you guys want to call it, it lacked depth. I believe if it had that little kick it would have been better. And adding some hot sauce to it would not have been the same because the hot sauce would did not have the opportunity to cook into the seafood. It's just an add-on flavor. But, nonetheless, it was a huge bowl of seafood. One huge prawn with a copious amount of bay shrimps,scallops, mussels, squid, some dungeness crab and one large clam. It was good but not great.

In short, it's not all that bad. I would love to give it that extra half star but 3 is the best at the moment. I just can't justify giving this place a 4. Maybe next time. I know I will be back later this year.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Be warned, check your bank statements because The Clam House double charged my card. They charged me once on the date of my visit and again 3 days later for the identical amount, over $100. I've heard of them doing the same to others.

They told me multiple times they were going to refund me but they never did. After 3 weeks of this, I eventually just went ahead and filed a claim against them with my credit card company.

They are also not a neighborhood restaurant at all anymore. They are owned by the same group that owns The Stinking Rose, The San Francisan and other tourist spots. Our new name for them is "The Old Scam House"!
author: teddy w.

description:
This is a cool 30+ bar that blends Mission/Bay View clientele pretty well.

Everyone seems to know everyone like an urban version of "Cheers".

Bar staff are cool.

They hv 3 TVs for sports.

The food is plentiful, but calorie-laden, and very rich.

This is my new fav place to toss a few back and people watch while yelling at Sandoval for hitting into another double-play.
author: Miguel O.

description: Great Holiday menu and service.  I am sad they no longer have the Happy Hour all day every day. ON the regular menu, not happy with the quality of the noodles in the linguini and clam.  Feels like the restaurant is trying to get by with lower quality food.
author: Emilia G.

description: Nice place and change from the old establishment.  It has some uplift and brightness.  Very friendly staff.  they come with some warm clam broth to dip your bread.  The oysters on a half shelf were delicious and fresh.  the clam chowder was okay.  Our fish and chips were light and crisp.  the others in our party who had different seafood dishes, salads, etc...were happy.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
The food here is awesome. The cioppino comes in a huge bowl with tons of shrimp, clams and crab. The pasta alfredo is good and so is the shrimp sandwich. 

At the beginning of the meal you'll get a small teacup of greenish clear liquid. It's not tea, it's claim juice so just beware of that.
author: liz s.

description: Our friend had wanted to come here for a while. It's sort of an odd spot, on a not particularly appealing street, but The Old Clam House pleasantly surprised. I loved the clam juice starters and the seafood was tasty. It's not super cheap, but the platters were good for sharing. Mmmm crab.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I've been going to The Old Clam House since I was in my mother's womb, literally and have always loved every bite I've ever taken... except when the changed owners this past year.  
Walked in with my family for my nephews confirmation dinner and asked if their menu was very similar or somewhat different from the previous owners and was assured they didn't change a thing.  So we go on and order our usual appetizer, calamari.  The plate was literally 2/3rds fried jalapenos and 1/3rd calamari, and the old recipe didn't even include jalapenos.  I then ordered a cup of clam chowder, something they are known to make fantastic.  Took my first bite and had to down the big swig of beer just to get the awful taste our of my mouth.  Tasted like they put some creme, old clams (they were chewey) and celery into a chicken broth and told us it was clam chowder, it was disgusting.  Not wanting to stay any longer if their main courses were also different, we asked if their fettuccine alfredo was still creamy.  The waitress informed us that as long as we paid for extra sauce it should be somewhat creamy and they don't use fettuccine at all, but smaller noodles.  I am not lying, her exact words... Why call it fettuccine alfredo then??  We paid for the appetizers and drinks and left.
Extremely sad they choose to lie to their patrons and say the menu was the same when they've made so many changes and made it from old and delicious to hippy and disgusting.  Will NEVER go back again, breaks my heart...

PS: No more old Giants, 49ers or license plates on the walls, made it more "sophisticated" but I loved the old walls, gave it character.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
If your too scared to go to Bayview, stay scared.... cuz i dont want too many peoples bumrushing my favorite clam shack. 
When you walk inside this place its like a time warp back to the 30's or something. They recently remodeled and its really gorgeous inside with a huge old fashioned bar and big heavy booths.
I can see fancy ladies with cigarrette holders drinking cocktails, or mob bosses meeting their partners here for a hot plate of crab.
There is parking in back and a patio if you wish to dine outside.
For a date, or with family, or just for fun, this place has great food and an awesome vibe. The service is very professional and attentive.
They have wonderful old fashioned cocktails and every table gets a cup of clam juice and fresh sourdough when you sit. You might think ewww- clam juice- but its so delicious. I wanted to drink the whole buttery cup and steal the neighbors!
We shared a few appetizers- the clam chowder which is excellent obviously, and the salmon carpaccio salad which was delightful. 
The real treat was the mussel and shrimp skillet. They serve you a huge hot plate of sizzling seafood with a butter dip in the center and you just go to town until your belly bursts. This was plenty of food for two hungry ladies. 
I loved all of the food and I especially enjoyed the feeling of stepping back in time to when people really treated their customers well and took sincere pride in what they do. 
I hope this classic joint never leaves San Francisco.
author: M K.

description: we haven't been there in a long time when we went it was good . I had fish & chips we had clam chowder that could have been better with some milk or cream in it. my husband had mussels & I think clams .it was good.
author: Nellie J.

description: SF Chowder doesn't ring home very well with me, a good amount of clams and potatoes but was lacking a flavor boost. (Bacon?) As for the fried shrimp, you get nine, about the size of a quarter, for $11.95 with chips (fries). Dinner salad starts at $7.95. Tried the baby back ribs, six ribs very tender and tasty, with 6 little red potatoes, $14.95. If you want a side of steamed veggies it will cost $4.95 extra as with other side options. Not a very good deal and I would have to call the pricing $$$ over all. This meal cost me $39.00 with no drinks. They did a very nice job with the interior. I think the owners need to remember they are in Bernal/Potrero/Bay View and not North Beach/Marina/Pacific Heights!
author: Art R.

description: fun, spacious, relaxed, good variety of seafood, and lots of parking.  we ordered crab cakes, steamed clams, grilled mussels, and the "Golden Gate Clam Chowder."  The crab cakes were alright, as was the chowder.  Clams and mussels were delicious.  I'd definitely come back again.  This place would be great for a big party.  I gave them 3 stars rather than 4, however, because the prices are somewhat steep.  I would have liked trying out more things, even if they made the servings smaller.
author: Ash T.

description:
1) like the decor upgrade

2) $5 corkage is a great deal and wine list improved 

3) bring back the old bar stools

4) bring back the old menu
author: Justin H.

description: Great old building, parking not the best. There on a Saturday night and it seemed as they were understaffed. Appetizers are good, Beet salad is awesome. Ciopinno was fair at best, very bland and was surprised there was no fish filet in it at all. Tirramisou is THE BOMB. I would have rated 2 1/2 if allowed by yelp but with the slow service and bland ciopinno I just couldn't give it a 3.
author: Lou K.

description: A clam chowder restaurant that's located in an industrial district. But this is a place worth finding. The clam chowder is full of flavor with tons of clam meat. Priced the same as Fisherman's Wharf without the crowds and parking hassles.  I would give them five stars if they had a half-portion lunch menu.
author: Alvin W.

description: Brunch is something to enjoy and when its bad its awful, this place was GREAT! the service was fierce and the drinks are strong. The food is delicious and the only thing that could have been better was the pasta which I am not a fan of.
author: Rod M.

description:
A hidden gem! The neighborhood will deceive you. 

I was raised in sf, so the old clam house has been a family favorite for years. The ambiance is calm and classic. It goes through stages. Some times are better than others. I'm not sure of they've changed management. 

The five stars are for never being too crowded, good food, and the full bar. The clam juice may be scary for some, but it's very delicious. The sourdough always tastes fresh, which is a must for a native San Franciscan. 

I took my boyfriend here for our last night as sf residents, and he loved it! That says a lot since he's a picky eater. The cioppino is to die for!
author: L. D.

description: What happened?!  This place totally changed for the worse. The prices are outrageous for what you get and it's either bland or too salty, not a good mix in my book. The menu is very limited from what it used to be and I didn't see any of my old favs.
author: Matt M.

description: This place used to be so good! I think they must be going out of business because their menu has been drastically reduced and the quality of the food reminded me of childhood dinners at The Sizzler. Although I'm pretty sure Sizzler's Manhattans never came out in a wine glass...
author: Al K.

description:
Walking into the Old Clam House is like walking into the past.  It's a charming old building with the original wainscoting and memorabilia from the past 150 years.  The wait staff was attentive, friendly and helpful from the moment we arrived, and even before meeting our waitress we were treated to small glasses of ... clam juice!  Sounds gross, but absolutely delicious.  The bread was fresh and the butter spreadable.

Everything about the experience was great until the food arrived.  At around $20 each, our entrees (the clam linguine and the clam paella) were not cheap, and both were bland and without distinction -- the only discernible flavor was salt.  Portions were generous and so both of us brought home our leftovers, but it turns out neither of us plans to eat our leftovers, so we threw them out.  

The folks next door in the bar seemed to be having a great time so... come for ambiance and a bit of San Francisco history, come for the friendly service, come for the clam juice, come for the drinks (and perhaps, according to these reviews, the appetizers), but skip the entrees.
author: John M.

description: The food was good but the service was poor. The waitress forgot three things that I asked for. Which I think was a big nono. She also forgot to bring out our desert order for about 15 min. I had to leave my table walk up to the bar where she was standing talking with the bartender and asked her if she forgot about our desert order. She totally forgot to put our order in, but acted like someone else messed up our order. So the food was good but the service was poor. Im not sure I will ever go back there again.
author: Brian J.

description: The restaurant  was lovely, the food was delicious. I will DEFINETLY  return. However, I will make sure I have a different server. He was a nice young man. That's all I can say. I am not going to do a server bash here, as it isn't helpful. I am hoping that this young man decides to take his craft a little more serious. just wish we had the female brunette server at the table across from us.
author: Dawn S.

description: just got a order of clam chowder.  It used to be soooo good, but what I just got was TERRIBLE.  didnt even finish a small cup.  saw that they changed owners and the menu.  will not go back
author: seth r.

description:
Generous servings! Clam Bake is served with actual flame. Cool presentation.
Chiopinno has plenty variety of clam, shrimp, crab, squid, fish, etc. Recommended to all!
author: Lynn T.

description: Just discovered this place from a friend who is a bonafide seafood expert.  I can't believe I've lived in San Francisco most of my life and have never been here.  They start you off with a shot of clam juice, it sounds weird but it's really good.  We had the double crab and double mussels, crab & shrimp louie salad and sand dab - everything was all super fresh and roasted perfectly.  YUM!  Aside from the food, the coolest part is that this restaurant has been around since Lincoln was president. The photos and memorabilia from over the centuries is fascinating and adds to the charm of this old place.
author: Connie W.

description: Can't recommend this place enough.  You're served bread and a small glass of clam broth when you're seated.  The menu has something for everyone.  I went with the a cup of clam chowder for my starter and fish and chips, minus the chips as I substituted the sauteed Swiss Chard for my meal.  There is an extensive bar and wine selection.  I enjoyed a pint of Trumer Pils with my meal.  The wait staff is outgoing and knowledgable. Our food arrived quickly, which is a plus when you travel for a living.  They even brought me a second glass of clam broth with my meal.  The decor is inviting and the copper ceiling transports you back to another time when it was a working man's restaurant.
author: Ethan R.

description:
I have been to the Old Clam House in each of the last 5 decades.  My father brought me there as a child and as a native San Franciscan I continued my visits through last week.

I was very disappointed.

We stopped in for lunch on a weekday, about 2pm.  The place was almost empty--which in fact is a good thing as it gives one an opportunity to see all the memorabilia and photos hanging on the walls.  The menu offerings are expensive considering the casual atmosphere and rather lazy presentations.  Anyway, I went for the Crab Louis, my partner went with the Calamari and a cup of clam chowder.  All were below standard.  The Crab Louis (at $17.50) featured slightly wilted lettuce (complete with brown spots as if it wasn't even reviewed in the kitchen) and 1/2 of a hard boiled egg (guess they needed to reign-in costs) and, most disappointingly, an underwhelmingly small portion of crab.  Making matters worse, the limited crab contained not a single claw piece (that rich, meatly matter).  For that kind of $$, the customer deserves much, much better.

Things were no better for my partner.  Her calamari was heavy and overcooked and the batter had no taste at all.  The same can be said for the clam chowder soup which tasted artificial and lacked any detectable seasoning.

All in all, the atmosphere is great, but the place is coasting on its unique image and serving way too expensive and underwhelming food.
author: Remy M.

description: What a disappointment.I have been to The Old Clam House quite a few times. Went today to find out they have new owners,remodeled and have a new menu which is very expensive. By remodeling,they took away the nostalgia and the ambiance.My husband and I ordered the hot dungeness crab sandwich.That was all you got. No cole slaw, no fries nothing. The price was $17.95. Seriously? For a sandwich? So, we ordered a cup of clam chowder which was $3.95 extra and it was just ok. I have had better. Sandwich was good but they should serve something with it. Needless to say, we won't  be going back. Very disappointed:-((
author: Amber N.

description: Can't say I'm s big fan of the changes to the menu. How can you call yourself the clam house when there are only a hand full of clam dishes remaining on the menu and all are a shadow of their former selves
author: Spanky M.

description: Found this place on groupon, got the whole crab ususally 34.95 for $17 (great price right?) servers and bus boys very attentive and overall pleasant.   Had fried calamari as an appetizer , excellent. Everything was good but I've had better for cheaper and would come back if they offered another deal on groupon but not for full price, wasn't $35 good for the crab.
author: Mimi W.

description:
I like this place.  The decor (espically the Jag above the bar) and bread basket will keep you occupied as you wait for your food...

I felt for the server because she seemed to be working by herself during a busy lunch rush, but there were no delays in service. She was kinda sexy, too...

The food is good.  I ordered the crab sandwich, and they didn't skimp on the meat.  I wish the menu had mentioned the mushrooms, though.  I could've done without having to pick those out...
author: Nathan W.

description: Very sorry to see and taste the changes at The Old Clam House. Other reviewers are correct. This place did not need to be "improved" and it cannot be turned into a tourist restaurant. It was a restaurant for locals and it's sad to see it go.
author: Cliff R.

description:
I've been down to Bayshore before to recycle old electronics or to have a late night drink and doughnut at the 24 hour bar/doughnut shop while hanging with friends of friends who have a warehouse music practice space on Barneveld but I had never really noticed this place before I had to take my boss's truck to Ford for service (you get the tenor of the neighborhood...).

The Old Clam House is not only OLD San Francisco (which I love) but you can actually notice that the building leans out toward the sidewalk.  Classic!  The interior did not disappoint - pretty much exactly as expected.

We went for a late lunch on a weekday so the place was pretty empty.  The service was ok - not great, not bad.  Loved the little clam broth bowl they bring you as a starter, although they don't give you spoons which makes getting the clams out of the bottom a little tricky.

I ordered Oysters Rockefeller and a Shrimp Louis Salad and my coworker got the Crab Sandwich.  I also ordered the house pale ale.  The beer was a little on the weak side for pale ale but for $3 (guess there is happy hour pricing?) I can't complain.

The Oysters Rockefeller were incredibly tasty and exactly what I wanted.  The Shrimp Louis was decent, better sized than I imagined it would be and had a ton of bay shrimp.  The dressing seemed like bottled thousand island but did the job.  My coworker really enjoyed her sandwich which was warm with melted cheese covering it.

This place is a tad pricey but was well worth it.  It's the type of place I'd take out of town guests to get a taste of real San Francisco seafood without having to deal with the lines or crowds at a place like Swan.  I will definitely return!
author: Jon B.

description: Probably the main attraction of The Old Clam House is the interior design and decor, which reflect the fact that this restaurant has been in operation continually since the late nineteenth century. The surrounding neighborhood ain't the best, but somehow this place keeps on going. Ownership is now in the hands of the company that also operates such Bay Area eateries as The Stinking Rose, Salito's, and The Dead Fish, all of which share certain menu specialties, notably an excellent garlic-roasted Dungeness crab. I ordered what was billed as The Old Clam House's original crab cioppino, and I found it disappointing. The broth was fairly bland, and there were too many extraneous ingredients (corn on the cob, carrots, potatoes).  My wife ordered a basic breakfast item (eggs, bacon, and "crispy potatoes"), and she enjoyed her meal a lot. The dining room was half-empty and reasonably quiet, but it is a small room with hard walls and low ceiling that likely gets very noisy when full. The adjoining bar also occupies a small room; it WAS full (at mid-day!), and it WAS noisy indeed. Parking exists in a narrow, industrial cul-de-sac behind the building, but given the neighborhood, I'd leave all valuables stashed at home. (At least one other review here on Yelp! mentions smashed car windows.)  Service was mostly fine, although we never received or were offered bread, whether for an extra charge or otherwise.
author: George L.

description:
great food & great decor. we loved all the old pictures hanging everywhere. we got the crab feed, cioppino and chowder (we're hungry folks!) and everything was sooooo good. 

we plan to come back for sure. 

the only thing that bothered me was the slow service.
author: ashley d.

description:
Wow, We have been coming to the "Old Clam House" for many, many years a few times a month. 
The new owners should have just changed the name while they were at it with all the changes to the menu, recipes, drinks, remodeling and needless to say their original staff. We tried to be optimistic to the changes until last night we went for cocktails and dinner. They only carry one domestic beer and both cocktails/beer have gone up in $$$.

The Menu...Don't look for the Old Clam House favorites, Cioppino, Vongole Linguini with Clams, Prawns Flamingo, Calamari it's all new menu. No calamari in a  seafood restaurant ? What's up with that??
We ordered the "Sand Dabs a la Calamari" fried small strips of fish, the is dish was ok the serving was small and not worth the $9.95. The Clam Linguini was a concoction of bland pasta in a broth no taste at all, we actually returned this and settled for a crab sandwich, .Crab on a baguette with four slices of avocado, red onion ask for mayonnaise, as you need something to complete it. The Crab in their "secret garlic sauce" is okay, the sauce was graining couldn't tell if it was garlic powder or what, as there were no signs of fresh garlic. Keep in mind it is not the cooks,, they are the same cooks. It's the new recipes that they are being forced to use.

It is no longer the place you can hang out seeing familiar faces, the new management have succeeded in catering to a new clientele, not of this neighborhood with their new menu to suit a different palate. Unfortunate for the people that have been going there for many, many years and expecting good quality seafood in a casual atmosphere. You can keep your "toy box tomatoes" and tasteless food. The menu is pretentious just like the management that they are bringing in from their other venues to oversee the old staff. The menu is the same for all their seafood restaurants, The Old Clam house is now part of a chain. Better off going to Red Lobster if you want to eat chain food restaurant type food. 

We will miss our waiters and waitresses, bartenders and the Manager they were a great team.
author: Kathy A.

description: Yummy Cioppino and the bread with warm clam juice was simply delightful!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
It was better and cleaner than I was anticipating, which is actually saying quite a bit in its favor! 

I thought the food was excellent value for the money and it was BEAUTIFULLY presented. I thought this was especially true for the big shellfish bowls. However, the pasta was undercooked,  the sauce was lumpy and I thought that across the board everything lacked flavor. 

The service was attentive and unobtrusive, which is again saying a lot. However, it lacked initiative. I had to ask for drinks to be refilled at least three times. Also, we were finishing our meal around the time the restaurant closed and the server didn't even offer us the option of desert. I assume this was because they wanted us out of there, which I understand, but was disappointed by. 

Bottom line: Clean, respectable and low-priced. But nothing more.
author: shannan R.

description:
I review sparingly, so here goes:

The "new" Old Clam House is a gem.  You won't find seafood and shellfish - not to mention delicious cocktails and wines/beers - at this price point anywhere else in the City.  They present their drinks in their own cocktail shakers that you pour yourself -- a nice touch that is rarity in SF dining.  The Clam House Pale Ale on draft is a superb complement.

But mostly, it's about the clams, clams, clams.  They are delicious and served in myriad ways - steamed, escargot style, with linguine, etc.  If you're not into clams (maybe not the spot for you), the crab preparations are similarly divine.  Crab cocktail, broiled dungeness with the works, you name it.

Heck, if you're a salad person, the arugala and ceasar salads are fantastic.  The latter comes perfectly dressed with small crispy croutons, big shavings of parmesan, and fresh cracked pepper - just the way I like it.

I love the old-school decor and the history of the place.  That is just icing on the cake.  Love hearing Frankie in the background, too.

A must try if you live or are visiting in the area.
author: Christopher M.

description: "This  place is a treasure of history dating back to 1861 with good food and attentive service.(really liked our waitress) Enjoyed the entire experience. Get there when it's not crowded is a good idea. So few places stay open all day so it's perfect to visit early or late and don't be in a rush. Start with tasty clam juice.and bread.  Loved the Acme Garlic bread. They also have many organic items like Strauss butter. The Caesar salad was excellent a perfect to share. The butterflied San Dabs with  no bones were perfect and so were the sides of veggies. My husband enjoyed veggie pasta. We were not able to eat dessert,  but there were many good choices. Good selection of wine, beer and a great cozy atmosphere makes this a perfect SF tradition. They offer Sunday Brunch too.
author: Stevanne A.

description:
Went to the Old Clam House yesterday, April 19, 2011.  Was greated by a very nice waiter who told us to sit anywhere.  He then explained that the Old Clam House was sold to new owners which is why all the stuff was removed from the walls and the dinning room and bar were redone.  The new owners are planning more changes for the bar room, new tables and table clothsm etc.
It is sad when an old standard makes these changes expecially in an industrial area where I cannot imagine this type of decor would go over.  But hey, it's not my place so about the food.
Except for the Clam Juice shooter I think it has lost alot.  Maybe they are putting the "flavor" into the decor.
My husband had the Crab Alfredo, my Aunt had the Clam Acini pasta dish and I had the grilled Basa with the Acini pasta side.
The Crab Alfredo was bland.  I think they forgot to put the Alfredo in it.  The Clam Acini pasta had a very bland tomato base.  There were plenty of clams and some delicious sausage but there really was no "oomph".
I had the grilled Basa (a nice white fish) with lemon, butter and caper sauce.  That was done well but the Acini with sundried tomatoes and pea pods was bland.  
We all expected more out of our meal and were disappointed.
The dessert on the otherhand was good.  We shared a Chocolate Mousse cake and that was yummy.
Sometimes it is best not to make too many changes to a good menu until you can be assured the clientel won't desert you.
If they keep up the menu such as we had I can't see the place being around for a hundred more years!
author: June I.

description: the food is always good here but  the service can be better.  It always feels like they are under staffed  for dinner service,  you guys really need more waiters because it is ruining  the experience.   lunch service it's much better because it is not as crowded.
author: HR W.

description:
The Clam House was recently taken over by new owners and it has been significantly remodeled for the better.  The car hanging over the bar is gone.  I liked it but it would no longer fit w/the upgraded appearance of the bar/restaurant.  Most of the old photos and memorabilia are still there, but they have been cleaned up and some of it has been culled out to make the walls look neater and less "kitschy" which is not necessarily a bad thing. 

However, all of the tables now sport white table clothes and the dining room on the left (as you enter) which was previously very dark and dingy is now bright and inviting.  They also added a side patio  on the right pat the bar dining area along the side street with very attractive etched/frosted windows but they did the work w/o a permit and it is currently closed.   They hope to get the permit issue worked out soon.

The menu has also changed significantly and prices have also seemed to have risen.  My GF and I decided to order a combo of plates to share: Seafood Cioppinno (similar but not the same as before), Steamed Clams, and Roasted Shrimp.  They still serve great sourdough bread w/warm clam broth, which is still very tasty.  The cioppinno comes in an Italian tomato sauce broth w/2 crab legs w/a part of the heart attached, mussels, manilla clams, calamari, shrimp and a couple pieces of thin sliced garlic bread.  I think some fish is supposed to be in it too but I didn't notice any.  The cioppino seems a little smaller than before and the crab was a bit overcooked but the rest of the dish was fine.  The steamed clams were actually cherrystones; there were a lot of them and they were very fat and meaty.   The clams also came w/a couple of thin slices of toasted garlic bread and the broth was delicious!  The roasted shrimp are new and we got the medium order w/24 of them served on a hot metal platter covered butter and garlic.  If it wasn't buttery enough, there was an additional metal container filled w/melted butter to dip the shrimp, clams and other seafood in.  The shrimp were well cooked -- not too much or too little.  There was some shell to deal w/but it wasn't a problem.  All in all this was a  delicious meal -- much better than I experienced at the Clam House previously.

Service was provided by Andrew who had to work the entire room by himself for awhile.  He was very polite and as attentive as he could be considering all of the tables he had to serve.  Add a $6 glass of Anchor Steam and the tab was "only" $61 (before tip)  for a very filling meal which seemed reasonable considering all of the food we received.  We were both stuffed.  

So, my opinion of the Clam House has changed.  Can't say that I'm a fan of the newly remodeled restaurant yet, but it is definitely better than before and is now IMHO "A-Ok."   If you haven't ever been there or haven't been there in awhile, check it out.
author: Martin C.

description:
CONTRARY TO WHAT THE NAME IMPLIES, this is not an aged lady whore house!  i mean, come on.  wouldn't this be the best name EVER for a senior citizen brothel???  the ad in the back of, "grandma pussy" or whatever sick fuck porn mags you disgusting men read would be all, "the hottest octogenarians in town are at The Old Clam House!"  or some shit?  right?

THAT BEING SAID.  i totally forgot this place existed.  i was forced to eat here when my aunt from out of town read about it in some fucking magazine or newspaper article.  It's a totally old school charming restaurant...the kind where you could see a ghost eating cioppino in the corner and be all, yeah, a ghost would totally eat here.  The vegetarian and vegan options were how do i say?  limited.  The waiter seemed a little depressed when he had to deliver a baked potato with tomato sauce on it to me.  it seem to pain him more to deliver the bland, dry thing than it pained me to eat it.  actually, it pained me more because i'm sure he got to indulge in some delicious clams in the back.  of the vagina variety.  

i'm not even talking in english anymore, am i?
author: Laura B.

description: We came here after a tour at Candlestick Park. The tour guide Ken recommended this place.  The service was great from the moment we walked in the door. The waitress was very nice,  knew the menu and recommended a few things. I had the clam chowder and fish & chips. No complaints there. My date had chioppiano. He really likes the flavor and lots of different  in it.  Only down fall is the parking.
author: angela c.

description: Love the new interior.  Food was sufficient, but somewhat pricey.  Clams escargot were the tastiest dish of the meal along with their traditional clam broth.  Our server tipped over my glass of water and spilled it all over.  He was apologetic and gave us two comp desserts.  This adds the third star to my review.  I think they need to get rid of the pads under the table cloths.  They make the glasses tippy.
author: Lee U.

description: If your expecting the same Old Clam House, don't bother!! The food and service are a hustle, they definitely are cutting corners. I realized after we were done eating that there are new owners. Good luck to them, this place will never make it.
author: Joe B.

description: Been here once before like 5 years ago. I had lunch there is afternoon with my boss. I had the chicken caeser salad which was good (but I like the caeser salad at costco's for $3.99) and he had the shrimp and crab louie salad. The bill was like $42 + tip. Came out to be like $50. For salad?Good thing I wasn't paying. I wanted to eat the shrimp louie salad. It looked so good, but I wasn't in the mood to break out in hives and start scratching while I'm at work. I guess I could eat here again.
author: Gessa C.

description:
Underneath the shiny veneer of San Francisco's downtown skyline, neighborhood boutiques, and tech millionaire's manses, you suspect there's an authentic, crusty, personality-rich culture somewhere. This side of San Francisco makes appearances only on rare occasions though. So when it did last night at Old Clam House, I was grateful for it and felt sheepish that I'd driven past all these years. I used to live walking distance pretty much, and it's right by the Alemany market. It's crazy to think the restaurant is at the edge of what used to be the Bay, but is now warehouse-infested landfill. 

The cioppino, as many Yelpers already commented, is very good. It's a work of art really the way they present the huge amount of seafood and top it with bread, etc. Plus, they bring a bib! A rare thing for this town... aren't there dinner companions you'd take here just for the pleasure of witnessing them sport one? 

Is the seafood the best in the City? Far from. But the experience, if you're in the mood to see the other side of San Francisco, is worth it. We both said we'd go back. Next time I plan on trying the linguini and sitting at the friendly old school bar.
author: Shoshana D.

description: Fun atmosphere, good service and something for everyone on the menu.  Oldest restro in same location in the city!  A great stop for out-of-town guests.
author: Vicki L.

description:
I ended up here last minute and not really hungry. I was very impressed with the service from the time we walked in the door until the time we left. 
Great food and great service what more can you ask for. The cioppino  was unbelievable and the clam bake was amazing. I'm a total fan of this place and will definitely be back.
author: Jesse M.

description:
Driving down bayshore I would always pass this place and kind of wondered if it was any good. Kind of unsure of what to eat for dinner, we decided to come and give this place a shot. 

There is a tiny parking lot in the back probably only good enough for about 6-7 cars. Otherwise you would need to park on the street which isnt that bad either. Inside the place is decorated with memorabilia from the past with pictures of celebs hung up. They also have half of a car nailed above the bar. Lights everywhere with old license plates and tthey had some sort of up beat jazz music playing. Also next to our table we had an framed 100 dollar bond from maybe the 1940s or so. I cant really recall. 

So when we sat, they brought us some bread with these two teacups taht had a soup of some sort. Kind of salty but would taste much better with the bread. 
We then started off with the Calamari appetizer and ordered the Prawns flamingo? and this other dish which basically consisted of mussles, clams, crab legs,prawns, and shrimp in a tomato sauce with angel hair pasta.
The Calamari was quite good, there was very minimal batter and I think they probably just used some flour and tossed it into the fryer. Crunchy and quite flavorful.
The Prawns Flamingo, was almost kind of like an alfredo, loaded with 6 huge prawns and lots of shrimp. It was creamy but not too rich and I was able to taste the seafood.
The other dish, that mixed seafood with angel hair in tomato sauce was really good too. Tomato sauce had a nice light flavor and the angel hair worked quite well with it.

Overall the food and service was very good~ I will be coming back again for sure!
author: phillip w.

description:
Don't bother!  

Wanted to take my Mother to a local seafood restaurant without going to the embarcadero ... well, first of all, the vegetables came out blanched and cold,,,, secondly, the scallops were rotten, and the shrimp was close to being spoiled as well.

Got cramps in my tum tum now.
author: Maya L.

description: We went here based on reviews we saw online on the restaurant's website. We were really looking forward to it. We were however sadly disappointed. We were seated in a booth, and brought shot glasses of clam juice. What we were supposed to do with these we were clueless. The waitress finally came over and we asked her were we supposed to drink this and she looked at me funny and said it is clam juice like we were supposed to know what were looking at. Later we saw that people were served bread and they dipped their bread in it. We were not served bread however. My boyfriend ordered the crab sandwich and there was very little crab in it and the hamburger bun it was served on was dry and falling apart. I got the fish and chips and the chips were good and I was pleasantly surprised that the fish was not battered and fried, which was a nice, light alternative. The waitress never came back to the table to see if we were okay or if our food was okay. We left very little tip sad to say. Lastly, were charged $1.44 for a government fee of some sort. That was the first I have ever seen that. We were not impressed and will not go back.
author: Carroll L.

description: decided to return here as it was a san francisco institution and was really disappointed.. first started wtih calamari and they were doused wtih peppers and chilis and totally inedible.. bowl was filled with sliced lemons , fried, which were jsut to make fewer calamari... then had fish and chips with salad substituted to the chips.. the fish was greasy, as it if had not been dried or drained and the salad was quite watery... definitely not worth the price and not worth returning to in the future... look elsewhere for fish and chips
author: ira l.

description: went there for lunch today with 2 others. Place was nice, Liked how they serve their sodas and water in individual carafes and also the clam juice was a nice unique touch. I wished the bread was served warm but it was still nice and soft. I got the crab enchiladas and it was good, sauce was nice and thick. My girlfriend got the fish and chips and another friend got the crab sandwich. We all enjoyed our food but the clam chowder could have been better. I will come back again to try their prime rib some time.
author: Tommy C.

description: we made life easy for our server that night - four orders of cioppino please. left happy, full, and satisfied. broth was flavorful, ton of seafood, and nicely toasted buttery bread to dip. i was the only one who failed and didn't finish mine, so i had to take it to go. would definitely come back again.
author: Sherilyn T.

description:
reading all the old reviews,  i am sad that i never made it to the original...i can not imagine anything better than an authentic 49ers dive bar with great seafood...how could anyone think that ripping our years of charm is a good idea...especially in this neighborhood

the place now is pretty bad... there is NO character.  the beer is skunked.  the food not appealing

sad sad sad

no reason to come here
author: nick g.

description: I have never gone to this establishment until recently, but I had a groupon and my mom was visiting.  Since she loves seafood, I thought we would try a new place.  We got to the restaurant around 7.  I was told that tables of 2 do not need a reservation.  By 7, we had a table of three but there was no problem since the restaurant was pretty empty. I always get concerned when restaurants are that empty at 7 pm because they are empty for a reason.  I've been to the Franciscan, also a restaurant I took my mother to when were doing some sight seeing at the Wharf.  The Old Clam House's whole dungeoness crabs were the same flavor and preparation as the Franciscan.  The potatoes were good but the greens were bland.  Overall, Old Clam House was okay but not worth the full price without a groupon.
author: Soo C.

description:
I hate this scummy part of town. I hate driving here. I hate having junkies and bums panhandling me. I hate the insufferable noise of friggin 101 blaring in my ears all night. but I cannot say no to these orgasmic steamed clams. brave the neighborhood elements and slurp up some clam juice w/ real sourdough bread -- it is worth the unpleasant trek through this shitpit.

ps -- this was great fun after a Saturday afternoon Giants game
author: Prima D.

description:
Love it, love it, love it! The seafood is divine; fresh and cooked the right way, plenty of garlic and butter. We started off with the famous buckets of clams...or should I say, buckets of HUGE clams. So good. 

My entree was a called Lazy Man something. It's a combo of fish, shrimp, scallop, crab, calamri, in a tomato sauce. It was huge portion too. 2 people can definitely split. 

Overall, very yummy seafood. So yummy that I felt like the ocean was right outside. Atmosphere is not fancy but it's very cozy. But hey, if you have good food, everything else just fade away....
author: My V.

description: DISAPPOINTED!!!! Hadnt been here in over 15 years but decided to check it out since it use to be so good and its in my neighborhood. Everything has changed. I do like the outdoor dining area but the food and the service was a complete disappointment and too pricey! Never again!
author: Jenn S.

description:
Chiopino and Garlic Crab Salad = heaven. I love seafood, not really into land animals that much unless its something out of the ordinary. Came here for dinner since it was a hop off near the free way. My friend was driving me home, so he suggested this place. I was thinking whatever..HP..I'm good. Turns out some of the best restaurants are found in this area. 

Hunter Point is considered a taboo for most Asian American communities but it turns out its not like that. Well seasoned and prepared seafood = you'll get alot of customers. Period. Though I only ordered 2 dishes, it was pretty filling. I even ordered the Lazy Man dish to go and take home. Showed it off to my stereotypical Asian friends who only salivated when I started munching in the morning. 

I forgot to mention, this place has been here since the Gold Rush days, 1860's. Back then, HP used to be the place you would find most citizens known as Vigilantes would be living. Now, its riddled with violence; give or take.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Big portions. Good fish. A little dark. A bit noisy. A bit pricey, but probably not by other people's standards. 

I felt like I was eating in a historical place (except for all the sports posters). It felt like eating at the Lobster Boat in New Hampshire--it gave me the same kind of feeling, but I only went to the Lobster Boat 3 times about 10 years ago.  I just had a good feeling about the realness of the Clam House food and the staff.

This would be a great place for my 49-er friends to hang out.  A lot of people come here for the bar and watching sports.  I don't drink beer, but I felt compelled to have a few with my dinner since everyone else was.
author: Priscilla L.

description: My husband and I went to eat here about 3 days ago.  This place use to be my favorite place to eat with my husband.  However, they changed their decor and made it look better but I rather have the old clam house back because the food was amazing.  The food is not that great and the prices doubled.  They don't make my favorite Fried Calamari with french fries and veggies instead now you have to buy everything separately.  We are not going back there anymore.  It was not a good experience.  Change is never always the best.
author: Jorge-Rosie G.

description:
It may not look so new, it may not have the best parking, but the food here is pretty decent. Everything is pretty chill here, you come in, seat yourself, and it seems as though for lunch when I came there was only one waiter, but service was great. When seated, I get a cup filled with yellowish liquid (looks like a chinese tea cup at dim sum/Chinese restaurants). At first, I thought it was tea, then I reminded myself this is not a Chinese restaurant and it has to be butter for your fish or something. It was actually seafood broth that is great for dipping their hard sourdough bread into. The prawn cocktail comes with 5 prawns along with some veggie garnish. The broiled salmon comes on top of mash and a side of steamed squash, string beans, carrots, and broccoli. 
P.S. Top it off the broiled salmon with teriyaki sauce instead of hollandaise and it's good.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Do you want to hear the saddest thing in life? I am allergic to clams. Yes, you heard me. Clams. Not oysters (thank god).  Not mussels, not crab, not seafood. CLAMS. 
I LOVE CLAM CHOWDER. I LOVE THE CLAM BROTH they serve you before your meal. When my dad wanted to go out for his birthday, we would go here. He would always get the cioppino, and I would always try and steal his broth. No luck. 
So i now have to settle for fried stuff, pastas, and everything else without clams. 
Besides the fact this place is in the ghetto, its wonderful. The bar area is decorated beautifully. the drinks are great, and the smell of the clams is enought to make me WANT to risk going in to anaphlayctic shock.
author: Janet R.

description: I went here with my family a few times.. years ago.  I love this place!  I would definitely recommend the clam chowder.  I read that its undergone new management so not really sure how things are going now.  I hope they do it justice!
author: Jacqueline D.

description:
I don't live too far from here, but the neighborhood is creepy nevertheless whether at night or in the day.  I think if the Old Clam House were situated in a better location I'd dine here much more often.

The prices are a bit on the steep side, but the seafood is usually well prepared and the service is very family friendly.  The servings are big so it's a good idea to bring friends along to share, and when you're done with dinner your friends can give you the security of safety in this neighborhood.

The Clambake Special was awesome with tasty clams, oysters, mussels, crab, shrimp and corn on the cob too.  The Lazy Man's Cioppino is a must try with an assortment of fresh shell fishes, scallops and calamari.  Tear off some of the chewy french bread and soak up the delicious broth.  The other dish was big, but the cioppino is gigantic.  I don't understand why their broiled salmon is served with sauce.  Ask your server for sauce on the side like I did, and you'll find that the fresh, flaky salmon is best without a sauce.  There are also beef and chicken selections on the menu, but why oh why would you pass up the fabulous seafood?
author: Sara A.

description:
I've been to The Old Clam house on several occasions. The first couple of times I've been here the food was amazing. I LOVED the chicken wings an d the clam chowder. I went in a few weeks ago, my server Veronica, explained to me that the  menu has changed when I was asking for some of the classics on the menu. A little disapointed in the change and it doesn't seem liek the change is offering any benefits, especially after readyu some of the recent reviews.
*  Veronica offered AMAZING costumer service and recomended some alternatives. PLEASE BRING BACK THE CHICKEN WINGS!!!!
author: Ashley B.

description: Always good. Never had a subpar food or service here.The only downside is parking but so is half of SF. Highly recommended.
author: Jorydude r.

description:
HOT CRAB SANDWICH !!!!!!!
Crab w/ garlic, shrooms cheese and holandaise sauce how bad can that be ya know
I gotta let you know that 1. it is a little pricey but you get alot and what DONT cost anymore? 2. DO NOT PARK IN THE MICKEY D PARKING LOT or you can tack on an extra $375 and that will really make the trip expensive (the tow company is two blocks down the street and they must have someone sitting in the lot waiting... those dirty bastards) I still hate myself for being lazy that night 3. I only get the crab san, ciopino or scalone (it looks kinda wierd but tastes hella good kinda like fishcake but not really) oh yeah and the steamers (clams for those of you that dont know), if you get any of these your gonna be happy.

So the place has been here since before Columbus "discovered" the new world and hasnt changed in my lifetime and maybe for a couple of past ones too. If you sit on the bar side its loud as hell but you can walk up to the bar and get drinks fast if your server is busy or slow. On the diner side theres more of a family feel but its still kinda loud. The service is either great or super slow (I cant figure out why its always one or the other maybe its got something to do with the tides or leap year or... I digress)

Gettin back to the food. Ive had the "on fire" dish it was pretty good, the fish and chips aint all that and ive tasted some of the pastas which some people like but i wasnt too impressed. Remember its called THE CLAM HOUSE so i would suggest maybe not expecting a whole lot from the pasta or burgers. Order whats in season or fresh that day its listed on a chalk board in the back oh yeah they got bomb ass oysters sometimes too. Just ask your server what the staff is eating that day and its usually the best bet OR just get the Crab sandwich.

Should get 5 Stars but i gotr towed once and I still have major resentment over that. Damn im still mad think Ill find a towing twelve step meeting
author: Scotty B.

description:
New ownership=bummer. This place used to be great. Went in last month to satisfy my fried seafood platter craving and it wasn't even on the menu. WTF!
I should have gotten a clue when I saw that we were almost the only people there.
author: scott c.

description:
I went about a year or so ago and it wasn't very good. The food was greasy and tasted refrigerated. 

I just went back today (reluctantly) to try it again because I heard it was under new ownership. The decor looks like it got a revamp and the food was excellent. Looking forward to trying it again.
author: Robert K.

description: This place has great history and the service is impeccable. Unfortunately, the food is hit-or-miss and always overpriced, though drinks aren't quite as expensive as the food. Worth checking out for the history, but the atmosphere isn't such that I'd hang out there regularly.
author: Joe P.

description:
Old Clam House is a SF institution.  It sticks in my head from childhood that there were claims of being the oldest SF restraint.  Now who was making those claims and if they are true is anyone's guess, but I tell you this because it's believable.  The place is old school and it's San Francisco, except that it's Bayshore old school San Francisco, which means that it's cute in a grimey kind of way and the food isn't foodie good, it's fresh seafood at a greasy spoon good.  It's off the nostalgia meter for me.

As a kid we always used to come here after the niners games to warm up on Cioppino.  I suggest you do the same. 

As far as price, I suppose it's a bit expensive depending on what  exactly your idea of pricey is.  I mean it's a lot cheaper than most of the seafood restraints around town and the portions are far heftier.  There's always the McDonald's across the street; if you think $25 for some seafood is too much you can get the $4 McFish sandwich, but it won't be fresh...

http://www.cleanscores.com/2268/Old+Clam+House%2C+The
author: Ann W.

description: Used to come here all the time in the 80's and 90's-the clamhouse linguine and steamed clams bordelaise were excellent and a favorite on the menu (these items no longer exist on the current menu). Tonight we went for my husbands b-day and it was a huge disappointment.  My combo shimp & crab louie salad had about 6 shrimp. a small clump of crab, slices of unripe avocado and olives that were rotten. The steamed broccoli had age spots-it was not at all fresh... we had to ask for water, bread, butter, parmesan for my husband's bland pasta and we had to keep asking the waiter to take away the dishes to clear up room on the WAY too small table.  I won't be back and I don't recommend that anyone else go there either.  This restaurant was at it's prime back in the 80's, but now it's horrible.  Don't waste your money-try Catch! ;)
author: Wendy S.

description:
My favorite seafood restaurant in San Francisco.  Though Old Clam House is not in a convenient location, there is always parking and it's a great place to stop by after a Giant's game.  

I have a sentimental attachment to this place from going as a kid...  This place has that warm-hearth type feel and a sense of history (it's been around for 100+ years in SF), making it perfect for family dinners and for dates.

As for the food, the clam broth they give you to dip your bread in when you sit down is savory and delicious. All the seafood is fresh and they are totally liberal with portions.  I recommend the steamed clams and the cioppino.  

Thanks for reminding me that I need to go back soon, Yelpers.
author: Sid D.

description:
OCH has a couple things going for it. First, parking. Right in front or just around the corner. Being in the middle of an industrial/commercial neighborhood has its benefits. 

The food was pretty good and large portions. You're served a basket of sourdough and some clam+chicken soup. If it were a cold day, that would hit the spot. The chowder was pretty good. Not steaming hot though. The clams were not chewy, so already that puts it above 95% of other places. Could've used some oyster crackers though. The dishes are pretty large, we shared two plates amongst the three of us. The seafood ravioli was the best. The prawns flamingo was ok. Both were pretty rich also. 

The history of the place is pretty cool. It's been around for so long and there's a list of all the owners since opening day/year. Since it's getting to be warmer, what could be better than a bowl of chowda?
author: The Sock S.

description: Last night I went to The Old Clam House for dinner because I enjoyed my lunch there in August.  This was a major disappointment.  I ordered linguini and  clams and they served fettucini instead, when I told the waitress she said they made their own pasta and serve this type with all their pasta dishes.  i asked her why they called it linguini and clams instead of pasta and clams, and she said she'd call it to the owners attention.  One of the women sitting with me said this happened to her in September. Also, they served a very small amount of clams and several of them were tightly closed and not edible.  I stayed away from this place for years and was looking forward to going back on a regular basis but I wouldn't go back now.
author: Connie O.

description: Very old fashioned kind of food.  Simple yet fresh and enjoyable.  We had the clam chowder, crab salad and french fries.  The salad was enjoyable: crispy lettuce and fresh avocado.   The service was great and the young bartender was really nice.
author: T H.

description:
Great place, feels real old school.

The food is delicious and not very costly.  The neighborhood kinda sucks though, but the parking is pretty damn good.

The service was a bit lackluster in that they all seemed kinda down, but hey, they could be having a bad day or just tired or something.

The Fettecini (sp?) was good, as is the Calamari.

I'll come back one day.

Enjoy my first review in months.
author: Mike V.

description:
Disclaimer:  I'm a vegetarian, so I can't vouch for the quality of the seafood here, but I can tell you there's a bunch of it on the menu and the place smells fishy enough.

It's a casual, family-feeling restaurant.  Seems like a lot of "regulars" go there.  I had the fettucini Alfredo, which was OK.  Service was polite enough.  And now I can say I've been there, old clams and all.
author: Andi T.

description:
I come here to treat myself w family every now an then before jumping on the freeway to go home after a looong Sunday of visiting grandma. the old clam house is so yumm an laid back that's the best way to describe it. coming from pleasant hill, i don't understand why every seafood restaurants need to be fancy... but this place is so delicious, i usually get the fried calamari that comes piled high with french fries on the side and veggies or the fettuccine Alfredo with all different kinds of seafood inside its so amazingly good those are The two things i recommend.  but if your not a seafood fan, the veal with red wine mushroom sauce and mashed potatoes was to die for! the service is good and pretty fast. nice water guy that alWaYs checks up and friendly bartender. 
 
    i know its in a crappy part of town but get over it, go for an early dinner or lunch when its still light . your gonna end up stuffing your face with the huge portions anyways, you won't feel like shit when its time to go to bed..haa
author: Isabella T.

description:
I had a great experience at the Old Clam House. 

I personally loved the setting, as it's in a very old building with lots of interesting old (literally old, like from the 1800's) plaques and certificates and SF stuff on the walls and beautiful old pressed tin ceilings with a nice wooden bar. I came during happy hour, which is a bargain at only $3 for any beer or well drink. I ordered a bloody mary ($6)  not a well but always kind of a risk as plenty of places don't know how to make a good one, but it was delicious. The waiter was very nice and accomodating and even gave my mom her lemon drop for the well price. It was very good as well and made with fresh lemon juice, definitely a high-quality drink.

I ordered striped sea bass in red pepper sauce with vegetables, and it was HUGE and very, very fresh. A large vegetable side, surrounded by little shrimp, and the red sauce was delicious and light.

Overall, this isn't a date type place, but quite well-priced for what you get, with good service and a nice atmosphere. Plus, it's been in the same building since the civil war and is a real piece of San Francisco history. And it may be far away to some of you, but not everyone lives in "north" SF- it's actually pretty close if you're from the outer Mission, Excelsior, or Bernal Heights.

Edited to add: The clam chowder isn't really very good, it's true.
author: aunt t.

description:
Went here last night to eat with some friends and the food was okay. The cherry stone clams were really good with the white garlic sauce. The garlic bread was also good. We dipped the garlic bread into the white garlic sauce .They ran out of oysters so we didnt get to try any. 

We had a few pasta dishes and it was okay. It didn't have much flavor or sauce. They have a full bar and the cocktail drinks are really good.  

The service was great and the waiter was very friendly. Overall the food was okay.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Unfortunately I haven't been back since I was 13, but I still rave about the clam chowder. Can't wait to return to see if it meets my expectations, but I'm sure it will. Service & quality of food never faltered when I visited. I was still in my "chicken finger & fries" phase when I frequented The Old Clam House, but like I said...the Clam Chowder has me dying to return...especially now that I'm willing to venture out & see what they really have to offer. : )
author: Jennifer B.

description:
This is a charming restaurant.  I love the atmosphere of the license plates hanging on the wall, the side of a red car at the bar, and the randomness of objects collected over the years.  

They provide bread before the meal and a clam broth in a tea cup. Clam broth is good but it can be something to grow accustomed to for some.  I eat the Clam House Linguini in White Sauce.  It hits the spot and the seafood is plenty.  The crab sandwich is also something to salivate after.  Food coma is soon to follow.

A little frustration in finding parking though.
author: Diana C.

description:
I am truly disappointed, The old clam house is not like the old clam house. I  just had dinner with my family for my mothers birthday and was very disappointed with the food and service.
My favorite thing to order at the old clam house was the Lazyman's Cioppino since i was 10 years old, when the waiter asked me for my order I asked for the Lazyman's Cioppino, well to my surprise the dish did not look or even smell like the original dish, i should have figured it out when I did not see it on the menu.... Anyway the place is another regular tourist trap, the ambiance and wonderful food is gone... I AM VERY DISAPPOINTED...........
author: M B.

description:
I have been eating here for years. Today I had the Shrimp and Scallop
Saute. The plate arrived with a small pile of noodles under 4 shrimp on 
steroids and 4 scallops that had been consuming growth hormones. 
Tender, sweet and succulent ( they used to say that about me ). Along
with that were some sauteed green beans, carrots, broccoli and 1 spear
of asparagus. The service is never lacking and the servers and bartender are the nicest people.  As another reviewer said the neighborhood is a bit sketchy but be bold, go forth and enjoy the old
clam house. If you don't enjoy the company of your dining companion, you can always enjoy all the old car license plates affixed to the walls. Fun stuff to look at while waiting for your food.
author: Cindy J.

description: I just discovered this place recently and I was quite happy with the service and the quality of the food. The clam house is not fancy but it has a nice bar and good food. I recommend for locals or a fun place to bring your tourist friends who want to experience some local flavor. I am under 40 and like to stay away from those trendy over-priced joints. The breakfast was excellent and I am not a breakfast person.
author: Christina R.

description: We had a Crab Louie and a bowl of steamer clams. The food was good although the clam juice was bit salty. Good service too except why won't they take your money? Had to wait too long for the server to pick up our card. Since they have the fancy wireless order system maybe they should consider adding cad swipe at the table. That'd be awesome.
author: Greg J.

description: I've been coming here for years and this place rocks. Given the fact it's been at the same location for over 100 years should be enough reason to check out this historical restaurant. they serve parisian bread , clam chowder is the bomb and if you're craving seafood they have a great cheeseburger. I'll visit the clam house sooner rather than later.
author: Richard G.

description:
Wow! I haven't been here in years and what a difference!  we had some business in the area and decided to stop in because we noticed it looked different from the outside.  I used to come here in the old days but had stopped going because the place had seemed to be let go over the years.

We were in for a shock but in a good way!  It was a very pleasant experience.  The restaurant is much cleaner but still has a nostalgic ambiance.  The seafood was all very fresh along with the salads.  Even the bartender from years ago still works there.  I'm coming back for the prime rib and to sit on the patio!  The history this place has to offer is a bonus!
author: Rose P.

description: Absolutely loooooooooooooooooooove the steamed clams!
author: Anita L.

description: Ive been to the Old Clam House a couple of times. I liked the old decor but the new patio is very nice as well. The food was great (both times). Most recently I got the prime rib which was awesome, better than my last experience at the House of Prime Rib even. It was so tender and flavorful. My boyfriend had the Salmon which was good but was suffering from major food envy because he was wishing he had ordered the prime rib.  This is an out of the way place Id definitely recommend to a friend.
author: Lindsey T.

description:
Way better than your regular trendy overpriced seafood restaurants in city.

We ordered some anchor beers, the cioppino, and the clam bake special. The place is kinda like a biker bar-comfortable. The portions were large, the food was excellent-the waiter even lit a clam on fire when he served my wife's clam bake.  Later some locals walked in from a nearby auto shop and ordered 6 pitchers of beer. This is my kinda place. I'll be back when I want a friendly place to drink pitchers with large portions of good seafood. This place is well worth the drive out of the city away from the yuppies.
author: Rod C.

description:
Sorry if this place doesn't meet the high standards of some people they all probably like things like Olive Garden and the Cheesecake Factory.  What I love about this place and others like it, is that it is one-of-a-kind.   And beyond that the food is fantastic and not too pricey.  The staff has been there for fifteen plus years and there is no b.s., thank you Clam House - and to our waiter Julio for years of fantastic service.

Oh...If the food is "soooooo delicious" and it is good service why would you ever give them 3 stars in first place?  get off your high horse.
author: Kasi S.

description:
Zero stars!  After this meal I lost a little bit of faith in yelp.  Really guys this place has a average rating of 3.5 stars, do you guys not have taste buds or had really good seafood ever before?  First of all this place was really busy, we sat down and ordered, the calamari came out super fast and it was fairly decent, so we were off to a good start (well except for the fact that one of the bus boys that brought our oysters flung the plate around so fast that all of the water/juice landed on my bros lap and he didn't even say sorry).  Then the shit hit the fan, we waited maybe 45+ minutes for our entree.  My mom order the rib eye medium rare and it came pretty well done and the mash that accompanied it was clearly from a box mix.  My cioppino was full of nasty and old seafood.  The crab tasted like licking the freezer.  My bro had the clam bake which was full of sand and unopened dead clams.  I wish I could say something about the waiter but we didn't see him the whole night, he never asked us if we were ok or got refill on drinks.  This meal took us close to two hours to complete and it was about $114 (totally not worth it).  This place is garbage and I have no idea why it was packed!  Please help me understand.  I'm going to barf my nasty food out now!  

Pros: calamari wasn't chewy.

Cons: everything was terrible; service and food TOTAL GARBAGE!
author: Amy C.

description: Dive-y location but not interior.  Knew about this place always drove by it but this was the first time I dined here.  Absolutly LOVED it!  The Crab Enchilada is to seriously DIE for!!!!
author: Donatella Y.

description:
This place always seems super crowded in the evenings.

I ordered shrimp fettecuine alfredo and I ate as much as I could but it looked like I had barely touched it.

My boyfriend tried to eat the rest, but again, it looked like no one had eaten anything.

Needless to say, the portions are large.  And the meals are good.

Not the best, but quite delicious.  Not the cheapest, but well worth the money.

A fun place to go on an occasional date (:
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
I get out to the BVHP community often and do stop in here for lunch, what can I say but its the better option in a part of town that needs more options.

Its true they do serve large portions here but its more like a double dip in the batter than more seafood.

If you like overly fried fish this is the place to go.  It has an old world charm, the drinks can be a bit watered down so stick with the beer (at least you get what you paid for).

The seafood salad and fried calamari are good options, the Cesar salad has way too much mayo and that dried processed Parmesan cheese (so called cheese).
author: G R.

description:
The Old Clam House feels like a working-class answer to the upscale period-piece's Sam's and Tadich's downtown.  

There are enough blue-collar regulars to counterbalance those visiting from offices, and it's obvious that this is a comfortable local for all types in the area.

The large open dining room with the bar is decorated with license plates on the walls and signs like the one instructing complainers to "take a number" by pulling the pin on a plaque-mounted hand grenade.  Although the house can be loud and crowded, the staff is extremely friendly and efficient at taking care of the diners.

Our food was okay, but too inoffensive to rate beyond fair.

The shrimp on the Caesar were medium sized and tasty, yet the dressing was bland and a bit oily.  (And what made it that yellow color -- we didn't taste any spices.)

The New England chowder suffered from it's corn-starchy sauce.  No spices here, either.

A seafood stew was billed as spicy -- we were even warned  by the waitress.  But, only  a mid-Westerner who never even has eaten pepper would associate the dish with spices.

For years I have wanted to go to this landmark.  Now I have.
author: Galen W.

description:
Can barely recommend. The cioppino was okay but the clambake special was barely edible. Service was sketchy, had to practically beg for serveral items which should have been mandatory (lik wet naps to wash our hands after eating shellfish). 
It looked like it should have been more fun, but wasn't...
author: Carla B.

description: 4 stars for the crab salad.  I came here today with some coworkers for lunch and it was yummy!  My boss ordered the steamed clams appetizer..I wasn't huge on those because of the chewiness factor, but the flavor of the broth was yummy. garlic and wine maybe?  The crab was fresh, not the canned stuff.  I like the old school decor and Frankie playing in the background.  It was a bit on the pricey side, but you should try atleast once.
author: anne m.

description:
We had a craving for calamari (with the tentacles).   Since we were in the San Bruno Avenue area, we racked our heads trying to figure out where we could get some around that neighborhood instead of traveling all the way to North Beach Italian restaurants. 

Then it occurred to me that there was this restaurant that I ate at about 10 years ago that was a seafood restaurant.  Old Clam House! I gave them a call and and asked if they served fried calamari (not the clam strips kind) and they do.  Right on!! 

The place was just as I remembered it.  Quaint little restaurant with the sea harbor decor.   We couldn't wait to get our hands on the calamari and it was nice and crispy.  Lots of tentacles how we like it.  For the main entrees, we ordered the chicken parmigiana and we were shocked at how huge the portion was.  We shared that plate.  My friend even had to take some home.  I ordered the cioppino and the seafood was as fresh as can be.  We also ordered the pesto clam liguini and the clams were huge, not puny like how other restaurants serve it.  May have been cherrystone clams.   Everything we ordered was very good. Definitely some really good comfort food.  We were stuffed in the end!

Service is good and waiters are very attentive.  I will be visiting again when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Lucky M.

description: Heard about this place for years. Dad had an appointment in the city so we thought about the Old Clam House for lunch. The outside has great "old" San Francisco written all over it and the inside has great character! We were greeted and sat right away and our waitress who also had two other parties of 6 each was attentive and really nice. The beer was cold (hard to go wrong there) and the food was decent. Dad had the chowder (menu said Boston but they only had New England) so slight disappointment. I had the crab sandwich, it was soaked in a very rich, cheesy buttery sauce that over powered the crab a bit but still okay? Best part of it all is listening to my Dad talk about the first time he was there on a cold rainy night when he was 18 and their warm clam juice was heaven on earth. I think it's a great place to check out and I will be back for sure.
author: Tracy T.

description: Had the seafood skillet..yummy....plenty to feed 4 with an appetizer...great flavor as well!
author: David S.

description: Not much to say that others haven't. Very, very good food, but the portions are a bit small for the price. My buddy and I had the Crab Alfredo and Crab enchiladas, with some oysters to start. All of it really good. If you're seated in the bar area, sit by the wall away from the bar, not in the middle row close to the bar. Staff was awsome. I will definitely go back.
author: Byrne B.

description: My husband and I have a late Saturday afternoon date here after a day of appointments in the city. We try to make it to TOCH at least 1x month and we order the same thing every single time-the hot skillet crab and share a Louie salad.   The crab is well-seasoned and isn't salty and the shells are crispy making it so much easier to crack and eat.  We take our time and enjoy ourselves!
author: Brenda C.

description:
This a 3 star place no more no less.
Some of the stuff linguini w./ clam sauce is not bad in fact fairly good, but some of the other stuff you could get at Long John Silver.
Pick wisely an you should be ok.
The bar is a cross between a biker bar and a biker wanna be bar,some of the patrons look like they have never had a drink anywhere else ,which may be a good sign ?

I find the crowd a little to troll like for my liking,but if your looking for trolls at least you don't have to go under the bridge,they are hanging out at the bar in the Old Clam House.........!
author: Guiseppe B.

description:
Hidden Gem!




***************If your a girl and you sit at the bar, watch the bar stool. It will bite your Nanie!
author: Douggers M.

description: The old clam house has been around forever. I come here sometimes Friday or Saturday night after work for some drinks and food. I have always had a good time here and the bartenders are cool too.
author: Dennis K.

description:
I grabbed lunch with a co-worker here the other day. I had been wanting to try this place FOREVER, and was super excited. Maybe I shouldn't have been so excited... We arrived during the lunch rush hour and there was only one waiter and one bus boy working the tables. Patience is definitely a virtue. 

I ordered a cup of the chowder and the crab sandwich. The chowder was just o.k. It was thick, but there weren't much clams or potatoes. Actually, I don't even recall having a single clam... The crab sandwich was mediocre as well. There were large chunks of crab meat but I wasn't a fan of the melted "cheese" (which I still don't believe was actually cheese) or the hollandaise sauce they smother on top of the sandwich. The fries were EXCELLENT. 

Oh! I forgot to mention the sourdough bread and clam broth they give you while you wait for your meal. I gave the joint an extra star just for that alone. I LOVE free bread. DON'T BE FOOLED BY THE ASIAN TEA CUP, IT'S NOT TEA!
author: christina t.

description:
It's obvious little care is taken in the selection and preparation of at least some of the food there.

What a crying shame that such a landmark restaurant (almost 150 years old) has gone down the tubes like it has.
author: Ann B.

description: Could you possibly be a native and never eaten here? I don't think so. Absolutely the best Rockefeller Oysters I have ever had in my life! A good stiff drink and some seafood and I am a happy camper!
author: Christina B.

description:
The Old Clam House is a great spot in the Bayview , "Gateway to Hunters Point" neighborhood right off the 101. Parking can be difficult, try for something close so the Car Stereo "De-installation team "doesn't ruin your visit here.  If you like like Garlic & fresh clam laden Clam Chowder, OCH rules! Nice real Sourdough French Bread served up with clam broth for dippin purposes, good Oysters on the half shell, MMMM!! And while you're at it support the local favorite and get an Anchor Steam on tap. The entrees can be a bit on the pricey side but the quality is good. 
Check it out!
author: Matt E.

description: EEK indeed. If I could give this place NO stars I would. The only reason for the 1 star is they were open and the bartender was great. I live close and this has been one of my "go to" spots for a quick bite or to take someone from out of town to show them a true "San Francisco" restaurant for 20 years. Never will go there again!! New owners, Ok we can deal with that, but the food was a serious disapointment. This is my second visit since the new owners. The first was just as bad, but I chalked that up to just buying the place and needed to get their feet wet, my bad, it was worse this time. If you want to be a great restaurant, you need to have a great (or at least good) chef, not here.
author: kathy S.

description:
I usually love going to some Old San Francisco spots just to feel a sense of nostalgia.  So went here a while back and was expecting a Great Meal.  I mean, this place has been here forever so it should have great food, right?  

Well, I guess, when you order the wrong thing, you may not get that great food that ALL those other diners got over the years.  Can't really remember what we ordered but the food definitely was subpar.  

At least I can say I tried it though.  Otherwise, I would keep wondering....
author: Mark W.

description: What can you say about this place?  Its kind of an old divey sports bar, but they definitely have the best cioppono I've ever had.  I wouldn't order anything else.  Huge portions.  I'll be back for more.
author: Jeff H.

description: Came back after years of being away. I raised my daughter with monthly trips to the Old Clamhouse but we stopped coming when the food and ambience got blander and blander.
