What a revival! The food and cocktails were fabulous, the service was terrific and the renovation of the space makes for 3 separate dining areas, each beautifully redecorated. And very kid friendly. We had a big family dinner (9 people total including 3 kids) in the heated porch area. Our waitress was wonderful. And we even got the 2 year old grand baby to try oysters and roasted mussels! We rediscovered an old family favorite and will be back, for sure!
author: Diane J.

description: Cool place...but...sat at the bar and the bartender was a complete idiot. Forgot bread, food cold, too busy doing side work. Will try again because past experiences a big plus. Oredr seafood, steak was lame.
author: Robert P.

description: Among other things, the cioppino here rocks hard!!!! Location is not in the best neighborhood but I've seen worst. Sports bar typish restaurant.  Good and friendly service. Prices are reasonable for what you get.
author: Fe C.

description:
I've been going there for years, and the food had always been great, however now it is not!

The prices have skyrocketed while the food quality has taken a nose dive. It now tastes like all of the bland food you get at all tourist places in the wharf or North Beach.

This restaurant had been around forever supported by locals, but now the new owners have applied a tourist trap quality food and I do not see this restaurant being here in the future.

I will not be returning as this place has been ruined.

Go to the filtered section of to see the NUMEROUS recent negative posts.
author: J M.

description: The old clam house is GONE.  New Owners.  Higher prices and the amount of the food is way smaller.  I was  disappointed. I have been a customer for over 20 years, I don't think i will return.
author: A. P.

description: Nice place to eat some good affordable seafood.  I had fried oysters, prawns, oysters rockefeller, and crab stuffed mushrooms.  It was very good and I'd go here again in the future.
author: Vernon M.

description:
Just had another business lunch there with 10 people. 

Service: Actually pretty good for 10 but we got there before the rush. 
Value: Food is Average vs. Cost is Above Average 15-25 per plate.
Style: Very Americanized with pasta's and Italian influence.
Quality: Mostly Frozen but check with waiter for daily special, etc...
General Comments: For the location, it's probably the best seafood joint within a couple miles. Has a bunch of stuff (half a car, etc) hanging on the walls.

Food Broker Score (1-100) = 67 points (C+ on F to A scale)
author: Food Broker W.

description:
well, we were really just looking for a bar with a tv to watch the 49ers on sunday afternoon. they fit that bill but were intriguing enough that we took a table instead and had lunch. 

a shot of hot salty clam juice for every customer - what an interesting "welcome."

the specialty is clams paella acini which the menu describes as "with cioppino sauce, sausage, olives & cheddar." so you know how you read ingredients on boxes and the thing that there's most of comes first? not this time. the dish is basically acini (tiny pasta bb's) and cheddar cheese with some tomato, sausage and oysters. not that there's anything wrong with that - if it's what you're expecting. so there's your forewarning.

also, on the pricey side. but what old-style seafood place worth it's salt (pun intended) isn't?
author: Will R.

description: Devastated, we came here for my fathers 70th birthday  in anticipation of this authentic restaurants cioppino and what we arrived to was a completely revamped updated restaurant.  We learned new owners had taken over the restaurant and the modifications they made stripped this restaurant of it's history.  All the oddities, random license plates and pictures that used to line the walls are now gone and the walls are now empty and bare.  We decided to stay and to try the cioppino since we came this far and what we received was a small dish which receives 4 out of 5 stars for presentation but 1 out of 5 stars for flavor.  The soup base tasted like tomato sauce instead of the authentic soupy cioppino broth we were used to, not one scallop was to be found and the mussels were over cooked.  I guess when the new management took over they revamped not only the restaurant but the menu and the recipes as well.  The new menu has more meats than seafood and you actually have to look for clams in their dishes (a little ironic since the name of the restaurant is "the old clam house").  OH yes the the biggest offender, their "calamari" isn't calamari but strips of fish.  They no longer have authentic calamari on their menu.  The waitress told us that hopefully they will bring it back in the future.   I learn most of the old staff quit when the new management took over.  The new management Calzone owns Stinking Rose, Franciscan Crab Restaurant, boboquivari's, the dead fish, salito's, Crab House and several other restaurants all over SF.  You can actually find a few items from their other restaurant on the menu.  Too bad... I'm going to miss coming to this restaurant.
author: M W.

description: ehhh.. havn't been here since the new management took over, but finally got the chance to go and I think people really suck at giving reviews. This place is really pricey and the food is mediocre.  Their serving size is somewhat decent, but not like the previous owners. The Drinks/Cocktails are waayyyy pricier and wayyyy smaller. Bartender looks like a prick. Serious attitude serving people that are seated, but serving people at the bar where he'd get a tip? no problem! hmmm.. Service is a little slow, but again its a decent place. Definitely not the same though =( (SAD FACE)
author: Priscilla B.

description: Went for dinner the other night with relatives and wow was The Clam House worth it!  Had the crab cakes which were full of crab (some are over breaded)!  Then had the shrimp and crab platter!  Fabulous, came with garlic butter which was also very tasty!  The bill was high (5people) but well worth it!!
author: Ashlie V.

description: I love this place!  Granted, I've only eaten lunch here due to its location near the corner of Urban Blight and Crime Spree; dinner I'm sure is just as delightful, if you wanna take that risk.  This is the only place I've found that really has the variety of east coast seafood I grew up eating.  The cioppino is a must order!  Very flavorful broth and generous amounts of seafood.  The only other place in the city with comparable cioppino is Anchor Oyster Bar on Castro Street (I rank Anchor #1 and Old Clam House #2).  The cherry stone steamers were amazing.  Plump and fresh, I couldn't get enough of them!  The service is great and the atmosphere is very homey and friendly.  Although a tad pricey, based solely on food quality, I give this place 5 stars!
author: P.J. D.

description:
i came here feeling and acting pregnant.

so i had this very, very bad craving for a HOT MELTED CRAB SANDWICH which they serve at LUNCH TIME ONLY! and i was sitting on my comfy chair situated next to the bar, hoping that i will be served this plate of excellent fresh crab, topped with gooey, melted cheese and hollandaise sauce on a crunchy bread at DINNER TIME!

i flagged the gentle mannered manager/host and asked if i could have that dish i was lusting after. he agreed to my special request and told me just to have our waiter know. 

how could he not say NO to a fertile, knocked up looking face? 

the waiter took my "primo demand" with my additional comment of, "the manager said i could order that." 
remember, i'm supposed to be pregnant here.

the other dish that was ordered was the broiled salmon with teriyaki sauce, steamed vegetables and mashed potatoes. i didn't like it, but he did.

we ate in silence and once in awhile i look around to observe. the dining room is more sedate, simply decorated and quaint compare to the bar with a long slab anchoring the room and old license plates nailed all over the walls.

like the decor, the food on the menu speaks to another time. ordering with caution can bring a lovely meal of simple seafood & sourdough bread, but otherwise there are pitfalls like the broiled salmon.

the salmon didn't taste that fresh, though it looked super fresh and the potatoes was not that great either, though it has a nice consistency, texture and served generously.
i know my sandwich was BETTER than his fish.

moreover, i kind of liked the digital jukebox. great selections of r&b, funk, soul & pop. i also noticed that the bartender was a charming and friendly woman that everyone on the bar loves having a conversation with her.

that night, the place smells of pure decency and with pleasant aroma.

albeit the fact i WAS NOT preggers, however, water retention to your face can mistook you for looking an expectant mommy.... it was nice to have that MOOD, hankering for something that you know you might won't get, then you gave your best shot and you GOT IT. it was awesome!

their customer service was exceptional and indeed, a superb place to have your craving on during that time of the month.
author: Nelle A.

description:
the old clam house claims to be the oldest restaurant in the city. i dont really give a shit. 

the foods good. that all that matters. i love getting the cioppino here. its a pretty awesome sight. youd think they dredged the bay to get enough seafood for this dish. this aint no small plate dish. just wish it had some more kick to it, but meh i tend to eat things more salty and spicier than most. 

3.5 rounded up.

tip, if youre coming for dinner, try to park on bayshore, not the surronding streets, think 550 barneveld.
author: Euge L.

description: This place is well-named, considering the clams looked, smelled, and tasted old enough for us to send them back, despite the waiter and manager's assurance - then insistence - that they were fresh . . . although tellingly both declined our invitation to try them.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I've been going to OCH since I was a kid. I've always found their food to be consistently good. At my recent visit, I was shocked to find out that my favorite appetizer (stuffed mushrooms with crab) now costs $15!!! That's as much as an entree and its a small serving. I ordered the cioppino for dinner and muscles and crab legs were not fresh. They had a "fishy" taste and were over cooked...So disappointing.
author: Marleen C.

description: Have you ever been at a restaurant and started giggling nervously out of embarrassment because the plate of food in front of you could feed five adults? That's what happens when your food is presented to you here. The irony of the situation is that minutes prior we were complaining about paying 21 dollars for a bowl of cioppino. The aforementioned soup comes in the largest (non-punch) bowl I have ever seen and has a bread and seafood mound on it in the shape of a small volcano. The Clam House is quite possibly the most un-pretentious restaurant I have eaten at in the city limits of San Francisco and we will definitely be making our way back here in the future.
author: Bucky K.

description: Clam House FAIL! New owners, new menu...I want my Clam House back.
author: Leslie C.

description: ok went there and got seated in the covered patio area.  Kind of nerve wrecking as you are watching the traffic wiz by thinking someone could loose control and crash right into you.   Nevertheless, great seating and service.  Now the food.  We are seafood buffs and this restaurant did not cut the mustard for quality and flavor.  We both felt the crab was frozen not fresh.  I determined that it was overcooked too as it was very dry.  The salmon was a very small quantity for the price and it too felt like it was frozen and not so fresh.  For a seafood restaurant in SF, they can afford fresh seafood -not frozen.  We experienced much better tasting food at the dead fish restaurant across the bay  We don't think we will be visiting them again.
author: Brian P.

description: The Old Clam House used to be one of my favorite spots in SF for dinner. The clam juice and parisian bread that you are given upon arrival is a nice start. The clam chowder is a must here. I always order the cup, because the bowl is too big for me! I think this establishment must have changed hands during the past few years because the last time I ate there, the food was not as great as I remembered. They took the popcorn shrimp off of the menu, which was a huge downer for me. The shrimps were always fresh, juicy, lightly battered and they melted in your mouth! Why would they take them off the menu?
author: Yvonne C.

description: The food is actually pretty good, the place is pretty interesting, and the prices are OK. The service, on the other hand, is hit or miss. I've had great service and I've had servers with nasty attitudes. Nasty enough to stop me from going back. The last straw was, for a period of time, they were closed for remodeling. I wanted to go eat there and since it's out of the way I decided to give them a call to make sure they were open. So when they answered, I asked them politely if they were opened and the person who answered had a really nasty attitude and answered yeah. Judging by the tone of voice, this person thought I was a complete idiot and that it was the dumbest question. Needless to say, I ended up not going that night and have not stepped foot in there since.
author: Diane M.

description: Love the new menu!  Ive been going there for years as I work in the area. About time. The old clam house had many things going for it, but this change is a welcomed one. Lets start with decor. It seems as though they are going to try to bring its essence back as this is a historical place. A lot of the pictures, sports memorabilia, and the potpourri decor have been eliminated. It is now just he beautiful original building being polished up. I ordered the steamed clams and the broth was tastier. The added cheesy garlic bread was prime for the dipping!  I llke the way you can order the fish prepared with their various toppings.  Congratulations, my friends and family are there.. at least twice a month if not more! The prices are reasonable.
author: jorge d.

description: Returned here after thirty years and still find it to be warm, funky spot with real SF tradition.  Interesting, creative seafood dishes, daring and tasty.  Just took off one star for the drinks.  not bad, not great.  Hostess was warm and informative.
author: Roy G.

description:
I went there with high expectation and was really disappointed.
Clam chowder was salty and texture was too solid. Fish dish of the day had an interesting combination of sole, shrimp and mashed potato but it didn't taste right. Despite the relaxed, neighborhood joint atmosphere, dishes aren't particularly cheap either.
Service was sketchy as other reviewer wrote, and the noise was unbearable; I had to shout to talk to my friend facing me over the table.
I might go there for a beer but wouldn't return for food.
author: Kamome K.

description: I use to come here when I was a kid with my dad.  It isn't fancy, very casual.  It's an old restaurant, been around a long time...and looks it.  It's cozy though.  I love it, the seafood is fresh, steamed clams are the best!!  They even give you clam juice to dip your bread in.  I remember the first time I got it, they gave it to us in what looks like tea cups, and I took a sip of it. I thought it was tea.... It's good to sip...but meant for the bread.
author: Charla M.

description: I have to say i was not sure about this place, because i never heard of it and of the location. As soon as we got there, we had to check it out, being there since 1861 , i have to say i was expecting something nostalgic , and  it was. This was a late lunch so no crowd what so ever, so as soon as we sat down, we were given hot clam juice in a little cup with some sourdough bread. The prices looked a little expensive and we weren't sure if it would be worth it, so we just ordered the calamari. and after seeing some dishes come out, our eyes were popping out. The cioppino was really good and the crab sandwich was also a good choice. i have to say we all were very happy to find this place.
author: john k.

description: I just discovered this place by accident on my way to do a "Lowes Hardware Run".  I love seafood, and I loved everything I had here.  I sat at the bar, and really enjoyed chatting with a couple of the people who work here.  Especially the bartender, Adele; she was polite, friendly, efficient, and helpful in every way.  They had quite a few options of draft beer, and I tried two, but unfortunately they were not too cold.  I think they need to work on getting the thermostat turned up where the kegs are kept.  Other than that, absolutely everything else was just great.  The sour dough bread (which they give you to dip in their home made clam stock) was delicious.  I ordered a Prawn Cocktail that was so fresh, it was prepared after I ordered it.  I've never had tastier, plumper, more perfectly cooked shrimp!  It was so good, I got "on a roll" with wanting to try other things on the menu.  It soon became a "seafood feast".  I had oysters on the half shell which were big, tasty and "perfect".  This was complimented by their cocktail sauce which had a healthy dose of horseradish.  I ended with the most delicious Crab Louie Salad.  This salad was "off the hook".  I use this phrase when things can't get any better for me.   The salad had tons of delicious ingredients like tomatoes, boiled egg, cucumber, carrots, etc., but mainly an incredible amount of fresh crab meat.  It was so good, that all I had to do was squeeze a couple of lemons over it.....none of that Louie dressing!   I did taste it though, and it was your basic thousand island, good and fattening.  All in all, this was a great spot, and I'm glad I found it.  The fact that it's been around since 1861, they've had a chance to get things right.  HA.  I'll be back.  Let's see; what else do I need at Lowes?
author: Vance P.

description: Only been here once with dad and Ate, but it's pretty cool.  There's a lotta kitschy stuff going on; fun, relaxed, blue-collar atmosphere.  I need to re-visit!  All I remember was that I ordered cioppino and that I  was happy.  :)
author: jen a.

description: Got this out of the way. Been curious for a long time. Not too good. I had fried calamari appetizer which was over-cooked and dark brown without much flavor ($10). I also had a bowl of the Boston clam chowder which was thick and pastey, way too salty, with very few ingredients ($7). My friend's dish was better: he had a pasta in cream sauce with giant prawns. It at least had some flavor of wine and garlic. It had no grated cheese on it and they did not offer any. I guess this is the new economy? This is located on Bayshore and has supposedly been around since 1861 so the appeal's got to be about nostalgia and not so much the food.
author: E. M.

description: Second visit since the change of ownership and I must say I will be back very soon. I had the roasted mussels ans shrimp-- deliciousness. Might be the best mussels i've ever had. Tender, flavorful and no fishy taste. Service was great and our server new the menu and preparation of food very well.
author: Larissa L.

description:
i love this san francisco landmark  great sea food  loud noisy resturant  the waiter is always friendly     go enjoy and treat yourself 

my favorite is oysters on the half shell
author: spiritsf a.

description: My partner and I have always wanted to try this place, and we made reservation for dinner on Valentines Day. But I was stuck on a business trip in Orange County and flight delayed over 5 hours, so we rescheduled dinner for last night, day after Valentines Day.  The food was great, if you love seafood, you have to come to this place. Parking was easy but what made it great was the restaurant staff and our server, I believe the server's name was Yvette. She made the whole experience wonderful, she knew about the menu and made great recommendation, she was attentive and was fun, we even kid about having her sitting down and eat with us. I had the seafood linguini, and my partner had the linguini with clams, we also had oyster, fried calamari, clams escargot, and the clam chowder, they were all so yummy!  We will be back real soon, I am going to have to try the seafood cioppino. Thanks for making our night with great food and wonderful service.
author: Howie C.

description: This was my first time since the change of ownership. Service was excellent. Food was ok. I had the cioppino. The flavor was unremarkable. Their escargot flavored clams was excellent as was the mussels and crab combo. They have dropped the old menu in favor of a menu apparently taken from their other restaurants. I don't know if I will be back as I was looking forward to the old menu.
author: David T.

description: This is one of the best San Francisco landmarks! It's been here forever ---- my family used to frequent this place before all the chain restaurants started popping all over the Bay Area. It's an old building and the tables and chairs can tell you that but the food is great, fresh and affordable. Try their cioppino or seafood alfredo or any of their seafood combinations deep-fried. You can never go wrong with their fresh seafood and the servings are huge and satisfying. They accomodate groups of all sizes and I love how they are so family friendly.  The ambiance is what you can expect of it but the service has always been great!
author: La C.

description: After hearng about the new owners for The old Clam House, we decided to go back after about 10yrs-sorry we did. I had the clam chowder, brown in color, too much strach from the breakdown of the potato's seemed old; went on to the Crab Cocktail- it was all shreded fibers-very dry,  NO flavor, no taste like you get with fresh juicy crab. sitting on breadcrumbs-must have been from a store- no one took the time to by or make fresh breadcrumbs. Well that leaves the wedge salad- salad dressing was from a bottle too. Apparently these people own 6 other resturants, well they have ruined this one.,
author: Timothy L.

description:
One of the best cioppinos anywhere.  The 'mescalenza" is a shish-kebob rack of gulf prawns and other great seafood.. served with a clamshell full of 151 rum that is ON FIRE   wowww...   several of their other dishes are served 'with fire" also.  Lots of food, you will not go away hungry.

Its a working class kinda joint, no yuppie stuff here - this place is the real deal and imho the best seafood anywhere in San Francisco.  (ok, sure, there are lots of 'ties' for best seafood in sf, but this one is my favorite!)
author: joe b.

description: My in laws used to come here all the time so we were excited to try it. they filled are request  and moved our table away from the draft doors. Our server was nice, friendly, they were super busy so we received less attention. However, everyone did not like their plate except one, which was a filet fish, its hard to mess that up. I ordered a alfredo pasta, maybe my expectations were too high bcuz out was so bland and undercooked,  I needed to add a ton of salt and pepper so far tgi fridays was far better and cheaper. My husband ordered the crab enchiladas, and he said it didn't taste fresh at all and being in san francisco theres no reason any seafood place shouldn't have great seafood. And our parents ordered some clam pasta which had bowl full of undercooked pasta that stuck together and bout 5 tiny clams. Now I know pasta is cooked al dente but both was just undercooked. The good pay is they care about service so they compt with a free dessert that my husband enjoyed but we won't be returning
author: Ashara M.

description: I grew up coming to this place. As a kid, it's a complete blast. There's a giant swordfish on the wall; they start you off with a little cup of broth to dip your bread in; the steamed mussles and clams are served in a silver bucket. But today I went back for the first time in years. Either it's gotten worse or I never noticed how mediocre it was. Although the seafood seemed fresh and good-quality, the food surrounding it did not fit the same description. The clam chowder I had was too thick (verging on pudding) and lacked flavor. I will say that I appreciate the fact that they used red potatoes in the chowder. The crab salad was a bit wilted and was short on accessories as I call them. Overall, this may be a fun place for families but the prices are too high for what you get.
author: Maya S.

description: Can anyone say overpriced? I used to come here with my parents way back when but I stopped in recently for dinner with some friends. We got parking out from on bayshore and that was probably the highlight of the night. So we all sat down and looked over the menu and all looked up at the same time because the prices were not what we expected. We decided to eat anyway, maybe the food might warrant the price. It didn't. My pesto was a bit of pasta underneath a half gallon of a bland creamy pesto sauce. My friends didn't enjoy their meal either. In fact one of my friends got sick immediately after we ate there. The service was ok and the bathrooms were clean but don't go here for the food. Extremely bland and over priced.
author: D J.

description: Best Chiopino in SF other than Moms! House super fresh crab salad and homemade garlic sourdough croutons is part of my life's simple pleasure! This place has been around since 1895 or something crazy like that. It's chill-ax spot too, very reasonable and low key.
author: sonia m.

description: This place is awesome. Fresh oysters. killer Ceasar, and the Cioppino is delicious. Sit a the bar, have a cocktail and order dinner.
author: tim a.

description: This place while out of the way of most places you would go is worth the drive. Everything I've had here is great. All the seafood is very fresh. The chipino comes in a large portion and is awesome. Prices for fresh seafood are very reasonable. I promise you won't be disappointed. Not a great neighborhood but not horrible either. Just keep your wits about you when you park. Not a romantic type setting but a fun spot for a group of friends or a occasional meal with your significant other :)
author: mitchell l.

description: We went on a Saturday for an early lunch.  Not many customers at that date/time but there were a few people at the bar already.  There's a chopped (lengthwise) Jaguar E type behind the bar.  Lots of stuff (license plates, pictures, photos) on the walls of the bar.  You don't see that everyday.  Cioppino was super good.  A huge portion that my wife could not finish.  A rrally good deal for $22.  I had the seafood ravioli which was really good too.  Really good sourdough bread and the service was great.  The only thing was that I had difficulty understanding the waiter.  He sounded like Henry Kissinger.  We're definitely going back.
author: D J.

description: passing by this place previously all i could think was, "how is that place still open?" until one day, my friends decided to go after a day at the dirt bag challange. me, i have NEVER out of the 6 years i have lived in SF (or in my 30 years of exsistance) tasted clam chowder. hey, im mexican! what else can i say? so i ordered the oysters. my friends ordered the clam chowder and the cioppino. i will just say that i LOVED the chowder so much i had to get a cup for myself (which i licked clean) and found myself reaching over to my friend's cioppino bowl and stealing clams, crab legs and shrimp! yummmm. o and i scarfed my oysters down too! yes, i am a fat ass. thanks!
author: claudia o.

description:
even though the place was out in an industrial area and felt like we were gonna get infected with some type of disease, the food was pretty good and the people were really nice. i'm not surprised though at the appearance, i mean it IS called the OLD CLAM HOUSE. the seafood "bowls" (rather than platters) looked delicious! the best part of the meal would have to be the clam juice they served when you first sat down and the bread to dip in it! fantabulous. i wanted a refill but the bus boy took it away. weird th ing though, i felt like the people there were trying to hurry us out the whole time. i don't know...

btw, not somewhere u would take for a fancy date
author: Judy L.

description: Had dinner here with my friend on Sunday night, we both were hungry for something warm after  both riding our motorcycles that day.  I suggested the Clam House for the Cioppino since it is the best in SF!  I was not disappointed everything was exactly how I remembered it. Massive bowls of deliciousness!  Good service on a weekend evening, parking is always easy and you get take home a bib if you don't use it ;-)
author: A M.

description: Great food and great bar!! Decided to come here after hearing so much about their seafood and cioppino and I definintely wasn't let down at all. I loved the decor! And the staff were so nice. So now onto the bar...granted the bar stools are a little tall (I'm short..lol) but it was such a chill place to have a few drinks after the meal or on any night actually. I'll definitely be going back there every now and again!
author: Isabel B.

description: I have been a loyal customer of The Old Clam House for years. They recently changed their menu and I am totally and completely disappointed. For years I've had the calamari steak for lunch, and not only did they not have it, the shrimp louie I had was stingy and not great.
author: Peter B.

description: I hate the new clam house they are RUDE and the menu sucks!! I been coming here over 15 years and is so sad to see this happen. Where did the old clam house go?
author: Tt I.

description: I ordered the barbecue Shrimp and scallops over rice (to go order), I got home and my meal had very little shrimp and scallops, and was drowning in a oily white sauce.  I have no Idea what it was, it was not listed on the menu as being covered in white sauce.  I called the manager about order, he said the only way he could help me was if I brought it back, his apology went something like, I am sorry you misunderstood the menu.  Living across town, I was not about to drive back.  I was not impressed with the meal or the way the manager handled the situation.  Be careful what you order, or stick to the clam chowder.
author: Donna L.

description: Best cioppino I have ever had. $20.00 a bowl is pricey, but.......yea, I need to go back and bring my sons as it was that good. Can't comment on anything else, but for cioppino, it's worth the drive (or take CalTrain)
author: Don B.

description: Food is not as good as it was. Clam house was always best in s.f.    Definately smaller potions.  Our waitress Veronica  was great. Seems like a chain restaurant now.  Its just okay,  it has always in the past been delicious.  There is no atmosphere so may as well go elsewhere.  Its a shame that a great place has seen its heyday!
author: Sandy B.

description: Big portions, tasty sauces/broth, friendly service, and seemingly fresh seafood.  Steaks, not really their strong suit.  Still good and plentiful after all these years.
author: Damian S.

description: My wife and I had an early lunch today at TOCH and... it was the best eat-out experience we've had in a long time. We started with the obligatory clams appetizer, and followed that with the Dungeoness crab sammich split between us. Everything, including the friendly service, was top-notch -- even the freshly-brewed iced tea was delicious. We'll be returning in a couple weeks for another lovely brunchy-lunch at TOCH.
author: Dave B.

description: mmm-mmm.  simply delicious.  a cool restaurant filled with years of history and yet designed for the modern era with charm.  very laid back and comfortable.  the service was excellent.  the food in abundance. the drinks, topnotch. definitely exceeded your typical seafood joint.  i ended up with the crab alfredo and it was like having crab with some pasta.  every bite was filled with crab.  gary ventured into the prix-fix meal and had one of the best chowders he has had in his dining experience; the sizzling cracked crab legs; and we shared his tiramisu.  he was satisfied.  we had a difficult time finishing our plates because (as noted above) there was so much of everything.  our dishes were very rich in flavor and very tasteful.  yes, we will definitely return.  if i could mention two downsides and these are so minor and has no reflection on the restaurant, but it would be nice if they lowered the lights just a tad and try to park in the front as the back is very dark and seedy.  but this will not stop us from coming back as the old clam house has us "clamming" out for more.
author: Benjamin B.

description: When I was a wee little mexican, my parents liked to come here and eat lunch, they would drag me along, and I would walk over to McDonald's and get a happy meal while my parents chowed down on food.. Well we came here today for mom's day...  and I wish I had walked over to McDonald's to pick up that happy meal. The calamari tasted like burnt oil, the cioppino sauce was lack luster, and the chicken parmesan was tasteless and covered in something that was supposed to be melted cheese... I never liked you Old Clam House, and I don't think I ever will.
author: danny e.

description: I love this place! The seafood is so fresh, and prepared to perfection. Loved the butter roasted shrimp and crab dishes. Even, the complmentary clam broth and bread was so delicious. If it wasn't so out of the way for me, I would be there at least once a week. Good food at a reasonable price. Can't wait until the remodeled seating area near the large windows is available.
author: L L.

description: The Old Clam House has changed.  I thought with all the money they put into it, it would be improved or at least be a bit better.  But when I saw it and ate there I thought what the F.  It  sucks!!!!!  All the money they put into it they bleed it into their cheap dried out tasting food.  Hey, maybe I'm wrong but I loved the old clam house with the old 1948 jag.  Where can we  find the New Clam House?
author: Isabelle K.

description: We came here for a family dinner recently and good times were had by all! I had the clams casino and the dungeness crab. The clams were AMAZING and the crab was delicious and the best I've had in a long time :) The wine was good and the prices were reasonable...I will definitely be back for more!
author: N C.

description: great food and service.  great for foodies and groups.  great prices and quality.
author: Emily G.

description: i may be spelling this wrong but the pasta com comarones is the best pasta in my opinion i always get it..... the sauce great  prawns great egg noodle great
author: DANNY B.

description: This place has tanked!  Hadn't been to this SF classic in a couple of years, but ate there last night.  The prices have gone skyward, the portion sizes have shrunk and the atmosphere (especially the funky license plate covered walls - now bare) was nil.  There were only a few tables occupied when in the past it was bustling, noisy and friendly.  The staff seemed miffed that when the new owners took over they didn't tell them anything.  Just stripped the place and made the above changes in the menu.  The food, I have to say, is still good, but $18 for clam linguini?  Come on!  I don't predict it will be around much longer.
author: jessica l.

description:
As a 3rd Generation San Francisco Native....I had been here with my family in the 80's.  As blue collar middle class America goes, the food is fine.    A great place to go at least once.....Just for the eclectic atmosphere.  Healthy portions to say the least.    

Refill charges for flat RC Cola they pass off as diet coke.....NOT COOL!
author: Mike O.

description: Hadn't eaten here for years. Found ti to be a great value and really delicious. Had the crab louie - LOTS of crab and very fresh ingredients. Good service and not overpriced. If it has been a while since you've been there, you'll be pleasantly surprised!
author: T F.

description: No star" would be the official rating.  This place is reminiscent of a bad 1970s steak/seafood house with tacky paneling, a loud television, and trailer trash at the bar.  We started with fried calamari which was probably unrefrigerated and just barely dipped in unclean grease.  I had the "San Francisco's Best" Cioppino and it came with decorated with a half lemon and 2 bundles of parsley. Inside it looked like entrails.  I took a few bites and stopped.  My date had salmon that was cooked beyond belief.  The wait staff was nice though. All of this for $80.  My suggestion, go to McDonalds and order a fish sandwich for $2.
author: Ed P.

description:
we had to walk out of here
we came in at dinner time  (about 8pm) on a week day - there was only one table of 4 eating (an Asian family) & one  man at the bar drinking
the juke box was so loud (and obnoxious music) we could not even talk to each other at our table - the bar maid was putting money in the machine & choosing songs
we told the waiter we could only stay if they could turn the music down, as it was too loud for us to even hear each other
he said "people paid to hear the music" (the barmaid ???) - so I said "you expect us to pay to eat here (they are not cheap) - and we can not enjoy a meal with such noise"
we never ordered and just left - I doubt any of the rude help are the owners - so if they are going broke, they should get better help
I would prefer to support local businesses - but we went on to have a really lovely meal at the "Olive Garden"
wake up people
P.S. we have eaten here before - never 'cuisine' - very bland sauces - but we were looking for cocktails & they do have a full bar - actually a little to high priced for what you get
Better food & prices at "Valencia Pizza" (only beer & wine)
author: Marcia D.

description: Decided to give it a try since it's in my neighborhood and they're celebrating 150 years in business. The food was a total disappointment. I ordered one of the 'Specials' -- clam paella, which I was hoping would showcase the clams (isn't this restaurant named The Old Clam House?). After the waitress told me that the 'paella' is actually a rice-shaped pasta that she doesn't prefer in this dish, I ordered it with linguine. Linguine and clams; a classic, right? Not here. The spinach linguine (didn't order spinach, that's just what they served), was undercooked. Not al dente, but seriously needed another minute or two. About 75% of the small clams were empty! Just shells. Seriously. Leads me to believe they're sitting in a pot for a long time and the clams are sitting at the bottom of that pot. Don't they notice when they plate the clams that they're mostly just shells? The sauce was heavy and overpowered the dish. The few clams that made it in were completely lost in the sauce. They threw a few canned black olives in which did nothing for the dish. I honestly haven't had a meal this lackluster in years, and certainly not in San Francisco. Super disappointing to go to a seafood restaurant and get such a bad seafood dish. My son went here last week and said his meal was bad, but since he ordered a Philly cheesesteak, I figured it was because he didn't order what they're good at. From my experience, The Old Clam House isn't good at seafood either. Spent $40 for basically a mediocre bowl of linguine and one glass of wine. Will definitely not be back.
author: Julie T.

description: I've eaten here longer than I can remember and it is always very, very good and a lot of fun.  Any seafood dish and the bread and the clam juice - heaven on earth.
author: Etienne E.

description: i used to love this place !  they had great linguine with clams  .i heard they changed ownership.  i ordered linguine with clams. it was bad !  what a letdown !  pasta came out like rubber !  dry !  bland !  small portions !   never again 1
author: John D.

description: great ole SF spot w/ fabulous bartenders. cool classic decor. Great service & crowd. lotsa hard-wkg blue-collar guys. good spot 4 ladies to meet hard-wkg men. loved the chowder, calamari & $3 happy hr Pale Ale.
author: peaches w.

description: This used to be a go-to place for good, reasonably priced seafood. Sadly, no more. We ate there recently after many years and were very disappointed. The clams were rubbery, the calamari was too deep fried and the clam chowder was not good. Go somewhere else for decent seafood in the city.
author: Frank Z.

description: I have been going to the Old Clam House for more than 20 years ago. It hasn't changed; great then, great now.
author: Malcolm D.

description: This restaurant has not kept up with the times so if you want food that is totally old in presentation and old in design this is the place.  I ate a shrimp salad that was like the ones in the 50s very raw in presentation.  The service was terrible and there were only three of us in the entire restaurant.  The waiters seem to ignore you if you are not a regular customer.  It is a place for yee old crowd.  Not again for me. Juanito
author: john h.

description: if you are not used to being in a bad neighborhood don't come here at night aight!! the artea can be intimidating. the food in this place is kinda a hit or miss. sometimes it is off the freakin hook and some times it'S like " what the f...."!! but you can't go wrong wit da clam bake and the  cioppino!!! you oder those and yooz good ta go!!!!!! like i said the area's kinda grimy but freak that, any thing for good cioppino baby!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: RICKY C.

description: despite the creepy parking situation and the location in the industrial part of SF, its worth the trip to bayshore ave. my friend and I love seafood, so the lazy's man cioppino was perfect and serves 2-3 people. lots of seafood, literally overflowing and the broth is amazing as well. it's also reasonable priced, especially for seafood goodness. not sure what else is good, but we had the calamari, which on the normal front and Buffalo wings, which I could have passed on. Nevertheless, I want to go back and try the clam chowder and oysters. Also something neat that my friend and i experiences was chicken broth in a tea cup, it was also served with bread, so we just assumed that it went together.  yummy all around.
author: Olivia W.

description: Need your daily seafood fix?  Need a cold beer?  This is your place.
author: Nancy F.
